description: The Certified Information Systems Auditor (CISA) designation is a globally recognized certification for IS audit control, assurance and security professionals. Being CISA-certified showcases your audit experience, skills and knowledge, and demonstrates you are capable to assess vulnerabilities, report on compliance and institute controls within the enterprise. One should have a minimum of 5 years of experience and be able to demonstrate proficiency and understanding across the 5 domains areas, which include auditing information systems, protection of information assets and others.

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Mike discuss best practices and tips for preparing for the CISA exam.
episodes.title: CISA Exam Preparation
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.205 --> 00:00:14.296
Hello.
Welcome to another exciting episode,

3
00:00:14.296 --> 00:00:15.231
here at ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.231 --> 00:00:17.250
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick, and

5
00:00:17.250 --> 00:00:20.930
today we're doing our certified
information systems auditor.

6
00:00:20.930 --> 00:00:24.130
And in this episode, we want to
take a little bit of time to kind

7
00:00:24.130 --> 00:00:28.630
of go over the certification, some of
the requirements, and some of the dos and

8
00:00:28.630 --> 00:00:31.890
don'ts, and some tips on
getting prepared for the exam,

9
00:00:31.890 --> 00:00:35.720
getting registered, who provides the exam,
and things like that.

10
00:00:35.720 --> 00:00:38.230
And with me today, is Mr. Brian O'Hara.

11
00:00:38.230 --> 00:00:42.460
One of the authors,
of the Cybex, CISA study guides.

12
00:00:42.460 --> 00:00:45.050
And who better to talk to
you about the exam, right?

13
00:00:45.050 --> 00:00:47.030
Than the author of the book.

14
00:00:47.030 --> 00:00:48.680
So, here is Mr. Brian.

15
00:00:48.680 --> 00:00:49.540
How's it going, Brian?

16
00:00:49.540 --> 00:00:50.310
>> Hi, Mike, thanks.

17
00:00:50.310 --> 00:00:51.810
Thanks for having me.

18
00:00:51.810 --> 00:00:57.180
This morning I'd like to kick off and
talk a little bit about the exam,

19
00:00:57.180 --> 00:01:01.556
the ISACA CISA exam, as well as exam prep.

20
00:01:01.556 --> 00:01:04.720
I'm not going to tell you a lot of
specifics about the exam in terms of

21
00:01:04.720 --> 00:01:05.410
questions.

22
00:01:05.410 --> 00:01:07.232
I know you'd love to have
the questions and the answers.

23
00:01:07.232 --> 00:01:08.607
>> [LAUGH] What's the answer
to question number four?

24
00:01:08.607 --> 00:01:09.113
>> Yeah.
>> [LAUGH]

25
00:01:09.113 --> 00:01:10.615
>> But I want to talk a little bit about

26
00:01:10.615 --> 00:01:14.595
some of the things you should
expect on the exam, how to prepare

27
00:01:14.595 --> 00:01:19.590
more effectively for the exam so
that you do the best you can.

28
00:01:19.590 --> 00:01:24.810
The first comment I would make is that In
all my 20 something years of taking exams,

29
00:01:24.810 --> 00:01:29.820
the CISA exam was by far one of
the toughest I've ever taken.

30
00:01:29.820 --> 00:01:31.510
Very tough exam.

31
00:01:31.510 --> 00:01:33.970
One of the reasons that the fail rate,

32
00:01:33.970 --> 00:01:37.710
which is about 40% on average,
is as high as it is,

33
00:01:37.710 --> 00:01:42.470
is that often times inexperienced
auditors take the exam before they have

34
00:01:42.470 --> 00:01:47.720
actually completed time in the trenches,
if you will, doing actual audit work.

35
00:01:47.720 --> 00:01:49.610
So that when they start
studying all this material,

36
00:01:49.610 --> 00:01:53.930
rather than it just being memorized,
it really should become assimilated.

37
00:01:53.930 --> 00:01:57.300
And it should become part
of your knowledge base, and

38
00:01:57.300 --> 00:01:59.770
that's hard to do if you haven't
had the real world experience.

39
00:01:59.770 --> 00:02:03.190
>> Yeah, you know you see a lot of these
vendors saying that they require so

40
00:02:03.190 --> 00:02:05.430
many years of experience before.

41
00:02:05.430 --> 00:02:07.960
And a lot of times it's kind of who ha,
right?

42
00:02:07.960 --> 00:02:11.050
I mean, you can get in there if you
know the material you can pass the exam,

43
00:02:11.050 --> 00:02:13.510
not the case with this
particular exam though.

44
00:02:13.510 --> 00:02:14.100
>> Correct.

45
00:02:14.100 --> 00:02:15.420
That's right.
You have to have a minimum

46
00:02:15.420 --> 00:02:17.500
of five years experience.

47
00:02:17.500 --> 00:02:22.930
And you have to demonstrate knowledge and
proficiency in a very wide

48
00:02:22.930 --> 00:02:27.220
range of topics, some of which I'm going
to talk about here in just a minute.

49
00:02:27.220 --> 00:02:32.780
So there are five domains covered in
the ISACA CIS exam as it stands today.

50
00:02:32.780 --> 00:02:36.078
The first being the process of
auditing information systems.

51
00:02:36.078 --> 00:02:40.080
That covers 21% of the questions.

52
00:02:40.080 --> 00:02:42.720
I don't know the exact number
that that equates out to, but

53
00:02:42.720 --> 00:02:47.440
the total exam is 150 questions, so
you can do the math if you want.

54
00:02:47.440 --> 00:02:51.990
Domain two, which is governing and
management of IT, is 16% of the exam.

55
00:02:51.990 --> 00:02:57.462
That's the smallest category, although I
think it's one of the more important ones.

56
00:02:57.462 --> 00:03:01.480
>> Information systems,
>> Acquisition development implementation

57
00:03:01.480 --> 00:03:08.380
is domain three that represents
18% of the questions on the exam.

58
00:03:08.380 --> 00:03:12.770
Domain four which is information systems,
operations maintenance and

59
00:03:12.770 --> 00:03:17.240
service management, is 20% and
then domain number five is

60
00:03:17.240 --> 00:03:20.180
the protection of information assets
>> Which is 25%,

61
00:03:20.180 --> 00:03:23.760
and in my opinion,
probably the most important.

62
00:03:23.760 --> 00:03:29.060
Because, the whole purpose of this field
of endeavor, is to ensure that we're

63
00:03:29.060 --> 00:03:33.280
conducting good risk management practices
in order to protect their information

64
00:03:33.280 --> 00:03:38.070
assets to the level that our
organizations have deemed necessary.

65
00:03:39.400 --> 00:03:42.090
>> So, that gives you a little bit
of outline over the five domains,

66
00:03:42.090 --> 00:03:44.660
and the amount of information
of each of those.

67
00:03:45.940 --> 00:03:48.210
We often times get the question, you know?

68
00:03:48.210 --> 00:03:52.890
Do I have to pass every one of
the domains in order to pass the exam?

69
00:03:52.890 --> 00:03:56.720
Well, my response to that is, you have to
be able to demonstrate proficiency and

70
00:03:56.720 --> 00:03:58.710
understanding across all five domains.

71
00:03:58.710 --> 00:03:59.600
>> Age.

72
00:03:59.600 --> 00:04:00.570
I can't tell you whether or

73
00:04:00.570 --> 00:04:03.596
not you missed 12 questions in
protecting information assets.

74
00:04:03.596 --> 00:04:04.960
Whether you're going to pass the exam or

75
00:04:04.960 --> 00:04:07.280
not because it has to do
with the total score.

76
00:04:08.420 --> 00:04:12.060
The exam, as I said earlier,
is 150 questions.

77
00:04:12.060 --> 00:04:14.210
They're all multiple choice.

78
00:04:14.210 --> 00:04:17.680
You will have four hours
to complete the exam

79
00:04:17.680 --> 00:04:22.950
with a half an hour before the four
hours for oral instruction.

80
00:04:22.950 --> 00:04:27.270
So, the exams typically will run from
9 o'clock in the morning to 1 PM.

81
00:04:27.270 --> 00:04:32.396
Typically the oral
instructions take place from

82
00:04:32.396 --> 00:04:37.520
8:30 to 9:00 and registration
is generally from 7:30 to 8:30.

83
00:04:37.520 --> 00:04:43.930
Couple of tips, be early,
make sure you have picture ID's with you,

84
00:04:43.930 --> 00:04:48.150
make sure you've registered for the exam,
make sure you have all your paperwork.

85
00:04:48.150 --> 00:04:52.170
This is an audit association, and they
don't take kindly to people showing up

86
00:04:52.170 --> 00:04:56.050
without their paper work in proper order,
if you get my drift.

87
00:04:58.610 --> 00:05:04.660
So, If you have to travel a fair distance
as I did when I took my CIS exam,

88
00:05:04.660 --> 00:05:09.600
IS exam, I would encourage you to get a
hotel a night before if you can afford it

89
00:05:09.600 --> 00:05:11.218
or if your employer will help, et cetera.

90
00:05:11.218 --> 00:05:15.260
To make sure that you
get an adequate rest,

91
00:05:15.260 --> 00:05:18.830
drink plenty of fluids,
you know don't stuff at breakfast,

92
00:05:18.830 --> 00:05:22.380
get a little bit of exercise,
make sure you sleep well the night before.

93
00:05:22.380 --> 00:05:25.920
If you've done your preparation, and
I've taught college classes for years,

94
00:05:25.920 --> 00:05:29.600
if you've done adequate preparation,
you're going to do fine.

95
00:05:29.600 --> 00:05:32.980
Don't let yourself get all psyched
up when it comes test day.

96
00:05:32.980 --> 00:05:36.600
If you haven't done your prep and
you find yourself sweating,

97
00:05:36.600 --> 00:05:39.020
there's a good chance you're
not going to pass the exam.

98
00:05:39.020 --> 00:05:42.830
This is a tough exam, and very few people
get through it by the skin of their teeth.

99
00:05:42.830 --> 00:05:44.830
You either know it, or you don't.

100
00:05:44.830 --> 00:05:48.890
So, please make sure that you get a copy
of the book, that you read through it,

101
00:05:48.890 --> 00:05:53.840
that you use the practice questions
at the end of each chapter.

102
00:05:53.840 --> 00:05:54.820
When you purchase the book,

103
00:05:54.820 --> 00:05:59.940
it also entitles you to
a download of a practice exam.

104
00:05:59.940 --> 00:06:04.350
I don't exactly know the URL for that,
but I think we can get it later if we,

105
00:06:04.350 --> 00:06:06.314
[CROSSTALK] for posting up later.

106
00:06:06.314 --> 00:06:12.147
Practicing questions Is a great way to
test you or to prepare you for the test,

107
00:06:12.147 --> 00:06:19.350
I'm sorry, because you may see those same
exact questions just simply reworded.

108
00:06:19.350 --> 00:06:20.970
Years ago I played golf and

109
00:06:20.970 --> 00:06:24.330
I learned something from my old
golfer buddies back in the day.

110
00:06:24.330 --> 00:06:28.170
We used to hear people say I've
made that shot before, meaning that

111
00:06:28.170 --> 00:06:31.840
they've stood in that very spot because
their ball dropped in that very spot, and

112
00:06:31.840 --> 00:06:33.300
it was the same distance to the green.

113
00:06:33.300 --> 00:06:36.650
So they've actually made that shot two or
three times and they know how to do it.

114
00:06:36.650 --> 00:06:38.240
They're very comfortable with it.

115
00:06:38.240 --> 00:06:40.980
I think the same is true with prepping for
your questions.

116
00:06:40.980 --> 00:06:43.680
If you've read the material,
you've seen the question before.

117
00:06:43.680 --> 00:06:46.500
When you see it, even though
the words may be a little different,

118
00:06:46.500 --> 00:06:48.670
you're going to understand
what it's talking about.

119
00:06:48.670 --> 00:06:51.910
You cannot come to this exam unprepared.

120
00:06:51.910 --> 00:06:53.365
It will crucify you.

121
00:06:53.365 --> 00:06:55.540
[LAUGH] So do your homework.

122
00:06:55.540 --> 00:06:57.070
This is one that really pays off.

123
00:06:57.070 --> 00:06:58.130
I can't stress that enough.

124
00:06:58.130 --> 00:07:02.680
Okay?
So a couple of things about the exam

125
00:07:02.680 --> 00:07:07.710
again, make sure you
answer all the questions.

126
00:07:07.710 --> 00:07:13.100
Don't leave any blanks You won't get
any points for questions unanswered.

127
00:07:13.100 --> 00:07:14.600
Manage your time effectively.

128
00:07:14.600 --> 00:07:16.610
You'll have four hours
to complete the test.

129
00:07:17.610 --> 00:07:19.520
This is a pencil and paper exam.

130
00:07:19.520 --> 00:07:25.110
I would encourage you to write notes
in the margins of the paper exam.

131
00:07:25.110 --> 00:07:29.599
And asterisk your questions, answers,
etc., for you to review later.

132
00:07:31.370 --> 00:07:35.370
Even though you may question and

133
00:07:35.370 --> 00:07:40.040
answer, answer it anyway on your answer
sheet, and then go back to it later.

134
00:07:40.040 --> 00:07:42.940
Make sure you mark it appropriately,
go back to later to check.

135
00:07:42.940 --> 00:07:44.430
Because, again, if you run out of time and

136
00:07:44.430 --> 00:07:47.910
you didn't answer that question,
you're going to get zero points for it.

137
00:07:47.910 --> 00:07:51.499
And every point counts, [LAUGH] At this
point when you've only got 150 questions.

138
00:07:51.499 --> 00:07:56.755
There are no lab or
scenario based questions on the exam.

139
00:07:56.755 --> 00:07:59.878
It's all 150 multiple choice.

140
00:07:59.878 --> 00:08:05.463
Generally speaking, the best way to
prepare for those kinds of questions,

141
00:08:05.463 --> 00:08:09.330
is to eliminate at least
two answers that are wrong.

142
00:08:09.330 --> 00:08:13.130
There's almost always two answers
that are wrong, completely wrong.

143
00:08:13.130 --> 00:08:14.480
Choose the best answer.

144
00:08:14.480 --> 00:08:18.290
Not the answer you think is right,
but choose the best answer.

145
00:08:18.290 --> 00:08:20.030
Remember your study guides, and

146
00:08:20.030 --> 00:08:25.850
your test questions because they will
prep you for what the best answer is.

147
00:08:25.850 --> 00:08:28.530
There may be questions where
there are two good answers, but

148
00:08:28.530 --> 00:08:30.445
only one of those two is the best answer.

149
00:08:30.445 --> 00:08:31.020
Okay?

150
00:08:31.020 --> 00:08:32.030
So keep that in mind.

151
00:08:33.290 --> 00:08:36.280
And again,
I can't stress enough the practice exams.

152
00:08:36.280 --> 00:08:39.430
There are questions in the back of the
chapters are the best way in the world to

153
00:08:39.430 --> 00:08:40.730
prepare for this material.

154
00:08:42.380 --> 00:08:46.470
Bring several sharpened
number two pencils.

155
00:08:46.470 --> 00:08:48.050
They will have some pencils there.

156
00:08:48.050 --> 00:08:50.810
The test proctors will have pencils,
but they only have so many.

157
00:08:50.810 --> 00:08:51.996
And you're all grown up.

158
00:08:51.996 --> 00:08:53.355
>> [LAUGH]
>> So take care of yourself.

159
00:08:53.355 --> 00:08:54.880
>> [LAUGH]
>> Bring your own pencils.

160
00:08:54.880 --> 00:08:58.130
You may want to bring a sweater or
a jacket with you especially for

161
00:08:58.130 --> 00:08:59.560
the June exams.

162
00:08:59.560 --> 00:09:03.180
Because the rooms can be air conditioned
and often times quite chilly.

163
00:09:03.180 --> 00:09:07.880
Mine was, I remember I took my CSA exam in
June and it was quite cold in the room.

164
00:09:07.880 --> 00:09:11.490
>> Those are good points because
a lot of us are familiar to taking

165
00:09:11.490 --> 00:09:13.370
certification exams for Microsoft or

166
00:09:13.370 --> 00:09:18.630
CompTIA, and these are computer based
tests where we're typing on a screen.

167
00:09:18.630 --> 00:09:19.990
This is not that way.

168
00:09:19.990 --> 00:09:23.470
So you do this like the old high
school and college days,right?

169
00:09:23.470 --> 00:09:27.700
You have to come with pencils sharpened,
with erasers and all of that.

170
00:09:27.700 --> 00:09:32.390
>> Correct and in fact the exams are given
typically in a room that's set up

171
00:09:32.390 --> 00:09:37.340
in classroom style where you'll sit
next to each other and the proctors will

172
00:09:37.340 --> 00:09:41.770
specifically assign you seats so that
>> You not only will not be sitting next

173
00:09:41.770 --> 00:09:46.620
to anyone with the same CIS exam as you
because there are at least four of them.

174
00:09:46.620 --> 00:09:47.740
They mix those up.

175
00:09:47.740 --> 00:09:52.550
But you'll also be in the room taking
exams with folks who are taking

176
00:09:55.910 --> 00:09:57.740
their CRISC.

177
00:09:57.740 --> 00:10:00.440
They're CISM or they're CGIT.

178
00:10:00.440 --> 00:10:03.360
I don't believe there's
anyone else in the room yet.

179
00:10:03.360 --> 00:10:07.900
I think they're doing the new nexus exams,
the CSX exams online.

180
00:10:09.340 --> 00:10:10.510
So just be prepared for that.

181
00:10:10.510 --> 00:10:13.480
You will be in a room with other people.

182
00:10:13.480 --> 00:10:15.130
You're allowed to take breaks.

183
00:10:15.130 --> 00:10:18.630
You will not be allowed to bring food or
drink into the room.

184
00:10:18.630 --> 00:10:22.620
>> Unless you have some type of
medical condition that requires

185
00:10:22.620 --> 00:10:24.090
special accommodation.

186
00:10:24.090 --> 00:10:26.580
If that's the case,
please let the proctors know.

187
00:10:26.580 --> 00:10:28.870
Generally, you fill that
information out when you apply for

188
00:10:28.870 --> 00:10:30.840
your exam ahead of time so they know.

189
00:10:30.840 --> 00:10:35.620
But if nobody is prepared for
you, if you are wheelchair bound,

190
00:10:35.620 --> 00:10:38.180
or have special dietary needs,

191
00:10:38.180 --> 00:10:42.500
or you need to take prescription medicines
>> Or if you have a seizure disorder.

192
00:10:42.500 --> 00:10:46.270
Anything serious like that, please let the
test proctor know so they understand in

193
00:10:46.270 --> 00:10:50.080
the even that something were to happen
that they'd be able to respond properly.

194
00:10:50.080 --> 00:10:51.210
>> Very good.

195
00:10:52.570 --> 00:10:54.950
>> Let the proctor know when you
need to take a bathroom break,

196
00:10:54.950 --> 00:10:56.250
that's perfectly legitimate.

197
00:10:56.250 --> 00:10:59.240
They'll ask you to close your test
booklet, put your pencil down,

198
00:10:59.240 --> 00:11:02.870
leave all your stuff there and
you'll be checked out of the room and

199
00:11:02.870 --> 00:11:04.070
then you have to check back in.

200
00:11:04.070 --> 00:11:07.590
You can't just randomly walk back
in the room, they don't allow that.

201
00:11:07.590 --> 00:11:11.260
Again, these are very
persnickity auditors,

202
00:11:11.260 --> 00:11:14.830
they're very careful about the rules.

203
00:11:14.830 --> 00:11:18.880
Drink plenty of fluids in advance so
that you are not thirsty.

204
00:11:18.880 --> 00:11:24.340
I would stay away from caffeinated
beverages, Red Bull, excessive coffee etc.

205
00:11:24.340 --> 00:11:27.135
Maybe have a cup like me,
or two in the morning.

206
00:11:27.135 --> 00:11:28.570
>> [LAUGH]
>> When you get going but

207
00:11:28.570 --> 00:11:31.780
kind of take it easy with that because
it will only make you more jittery and

208
00:11:31.780 --> 00:11:33.500
make it harder for you to concentrate.

209
00:11:35.810 --> 00:11:39.000
I think I mentioned being on time.

210
00:11:39.000 --> 00:11:42.180
That's really important because they have
a lot of people they have to shuttle in.

211
00:11:42.180 --> 00:11:44.870
There's a check-in process that they
go through, it's very methodical.

212
00:11:44.870 --> 00:11:48.350
And they need plenty of time to get you
registered and get you in the room so

213
00:11:48.350 --> 00:11:51.280
that you're comfortable, you have
a little time to catch your breath, and

214
00:11:51.280 --> 00:11:56.459
that you have time to hear and understand
all of the proctors or instructions.

215
00:11:57.460 --> 00:12:01.020
Rules state that no one is allowed
in the room after the doors close so

216
00:12:01.020 --> 00:12:02.840
oral instructions have begun.

217
00:12:02.840 --> 00:12:06.050
So if you're late, I'm sorry but
you're going to have to retake the exam.

218
00:12:06.050 --> 00:12:07.970
They do not bend the rules on that.

219
00:12:09.650 --> 00:12:13.650
So you can beg and plead all you want
being late because your car broke or

220
00:12:13.650 --> 00:12:14.690
something and

221
00:12:14.690 --> 00:12:18.159

each of those to ensure that you

301
00:17:02.186 --> 00:17:05.378
are complete and
accurate in your audit activities.

302
00:17:05.378 --> 00:17:10.708
And then you also should be able to
conduct your audits in accordance

303
00:17:10.708 --> 00:17:15.620
with the IS audits standards
that ISACA has established.

304
00:17:15.620 --> 00:17:20.110
And again, you can download a copy
of those from the ISACA.org website.

305
00:17:20.110 --> 00:17:22.274
I would suggest that you review those.

306
00:17:22.274 --> 00:17:26.335
I don't know that there will be any
specific material on those on the exam,

307
00:17:26.335 --> 00:17:29.565
but they're still a good item for
you to know about, okay.

308
00:17:29.565 --> 00:17:32.860
>> Very good.

309
00:17:32.860 --> 00:17:37.830
>> You'll need to understand
the risk assessment concepts and

310
00:17:37.830 --> 00:17:42.000
again, tools and techniques which
are available on the ISACA website.

311
00:17:42.000 --> 00:17:47.523
If you go to their ISACA.org, you'll see
there's actually a section called tools,

312
00:17:47.523 --> 00:17:52.291
tips and techniques that you can download,
white papers, PowerPoints,

313
00:17:52.291 --> 00:17:54.805
PDFs, etc., for more information.

314
00:17:54.805 --> 00:17:58.430
You must have a knowledge of risk based
audit planning and project management.

315
00:17:58.430 --> 00:17:59.880
This is where for

316
00:17:59.880 --> 00:18:03.810
the very first time ISACA introduces
the idea of project management.

317
00:18:03.810 --> 00:18:07.099
They get a lot more into detail in
that in the CISM certification but

318
00:18:07.099 --> 00:18:10.810
in the CISA certification it's
introduced for the first time.

319
00:18:10.810 --> 00:18:13.910
That the audit is a project in itself and

320
00:18:13.910 --> 00:18:19.240
you have to become familiar with
basic project management concepts.

321
00:18:19.240 --> 00:18:22.170
It's not a real heavy
piece of the exam but

322
00:18:22.170 --> 00:18:26.830
you do need to understand that what you
are managing is an audit, is a project.

323
00:18:26.830 --> 00:18:31.475
And you'll even hear me talk later about
the IT project portfolio where you

324
00:18:31.475 --> 00:18:34.728
may have multiple audits
going on simultaneously.

325
00:18:34.728 --> 00:18:39.016
The portfolio is the higher level view
of all the different audits that might

326
00:18:39.016 --> 00:18:39.820
be going on.

327
00:18:39.820 --> 00:18:41.710
A good example is in banking.

328
00:18:43.010 --> 00:18:47.790
Banks typically undergo both IT and
financial audits on an ongoing and

329
00:18:47.790 --> 00:18:51.628
continuing basis round the calendar.

330
00:18:51.628 --> 00:18:54.690
>> [LAUGH]
>> A small bank might go through 12 or

331
00:18:54.690 --> 00:18:56.170
15 audits in a year.

332
00:18:56.170 --> 00:18:57.563
>> Wow!
>> You might not realize that.

333
00:18:57.563 --> 00:18:59.491
>> Uh-uh.
>> That there's almost constantly auditors

334
00:18:59.491 --> 00:19:02.060
in there, and
a larger bank it's almost continuous.

335
00:19:02.060 --> 00:19:05.180
There's almost never not
an audit team sitting on site.

336
00:19:05.180 --> 00:19:08.456
And those audit teams could be anywhere
from 1 or 2 people to 10 or 12,

337
00:19:08.456 --> 00:19:11.230
depending on the size of the organization.

338
00:19:11.230 --> 00:19:16.110
I went through an extensive FDIC
audit with a large national bank

339
00:19:16.110 --> 00:19:18.220
in the first part of last year.

340
00:19:18.220 --> 00:19:22.151
And there were actually nine FDIC and
FFIC and

341
00:19:22.151 --> 00:19:26.470
Federal Reserve auditors on site for
30 days.

342
00:19:26.470 --> 00:19:28.044
>> Wow.
>> [LAUGH]

343
00:19:28.044 --> 00:19:30.570
>> That was quite an experience,

344
00:19:30.570 --> 00:19:34.770
both learning and educationally wise.

345
00:19:34.770 --> 00:19:38.640
And then, the one of the last things,
not the last completely, but

346
00:19:38.640 --> 00:19:43.080
you should begin becoming
familiar with applicable laws,

347
00:19:43.080 --> 00:19:48.180
such as HIPAA,
FFIC guidelines for the banks.

348
00:19:48.180 --> 00:19:51.189
The Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act
is actually the law.

349
00:19:51.189 --> 00:19:54.952
FFIC is who promulgates
the regulations for banking.

350
00:19:54.952 --> 00:19:59.131
You just need to start becoming familiar
with those because when you go in and

351
00:19:59.131 --> 00:20:03.768
you start doing your audits, you are going
to be auditing against those standards or

352
00:20:03.768 --> 00:20:05.598
those policies and procedures,

353
00:20:05.598 --> 00:20:10.000
depending on the organization that
you're doing your audit activities with.

354
00:20:10.000 --> 00:20:15.220
Most auditing activities happen around,
probably the three largest are banking,

355
00:20:15.220 --> 00:20:18.510
healthcare, so FFIC and HIPAA and PCI.

356
00:20:19.760 --> 00:20:23.060
Very little manufacturing
unless it has to do with FDA or

357
00:20:23.060 --> 00:20:25.090
some kind of federal government stuff.

358
00:20:25.090 --> 00:20:27.973
Same thing with state government if they
are doing any business with the federal

359
00:20:27.973 --> 00:20:28.498
government.

360
00:20:28.498 --> 00:20:31.082
There may be FISMA or
FedRAMP regulations involved.

361
00:20:31.082 --> 00:20:34.621
But it's important that you begin to
become familiar with those terms.

362
00:20:34.621 --> 00:20:39.058
You won't necessarily need to be
able to define them in the exam or

363
00:20:39.058 --> 00:20:42.367
answer questions specifically about them,
but

364
00:20:42.367 --> 00:20:46.560
you may see a reference to
which of these is not a law.

365
00:20:46.560 --> 00:20:47.900
Answer, PCI.

366
00:20:47.900 --> 00:20:49.870
PCI is a contractual agreement.

367
00:20:49.870 --> 00:20:52.550
HIPAA actually is an act.

368
00:20:52.550 --> 00:20:56.150
That's what one of the A's in there
stands for is an act of Congress.

369
00:20:56.150 --> 00:20:58.098
So it is in fact law.

370
00:20:58.098 --> 00:21:02.308
So moving on.

371
00:21:02.308 --> 00:21:07.092
And then have some knowledge of
collection techniques which I

372
00:21:07.092 --> 00:21:10.410
want to bullet point for
you all right now.

373
00:21:11.520 --> 00:21:15.240
These become important because
you probably have done them or

374
00:21:15.240 --> 00:21:19.329
will do them, but you haven't
really identified or labeled them.

375
00:21:19.329 --> 00:21:20.900
And they go like this.

376
00:21:20.900 --> 00:21:24.168
Observation, and
I always call this a walk-through.

377
00:21:24.168 --> 00:21:27.420
A good old friend of mine
who is a CPA taught me this.

378
00:21:27.420 --> 00:21:28.830
A walk-through, an observation,

379
00:21:28.830 --> 00:21:32.870
is where you actually ask someone,
show me how you do that.

380
00:21:32.870 --> 00:21:36.680
Show me how you create an Active Directory
account, or show me the group policy that

381
00:21:36.680 --> 00:21:41.580
says your passwords have to be 12
characters, complex, etc., show me that.

382
00:21:41.580 --> 00:21:43.320
That's an observational one.

383
00:21:43.320 --> 00:21:48.912
An inquiry is when, this was [LAUGH] in
days gone by, in banking in particular,

384
00:21:48.912 --> 00:21:53.941
had a kind of a bad reputation for
being, that was 98% of the audit.

385
00:21:53.941 --> 00:21:56.410
You sat down in a room with somebody
with their spreadsheet, and

386
00:21:56.410 --> 00:21:58.410
they started asking you questions.

387
00:21:58.410 --> 00:22:02.025
And, in fact,
I have a little side story to tell about.

388
00:22:02.025 --> 00:22:06.210
A bank president at one time,
who had been a Department of

389
00:22:06.210 --> 00:22:10.380
Indiana Financial Institution examiner at
one point, told me a story about a young

390
00:22:10.380 --> 00:22:13.600
lady who was a new auditor who
didn't have any experience at all.

391
00:22:13.600 --> 00:22:16.530
The firm sent her out on her first job.

392
00:22:16.530 --> 00:22:19.570
And she would ask him a question, and
he would say, I'm sorry, young lady, but

393
00:22:19.570 --> 00:22:20.940
I don't understand you.

394
00:22:20.940 --> 00:22:24.819
>> And
she would simply ask the question louder.

395
00:22:24.819 --> 00:22:27.464
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So inquiry is one of those and

396
00:22:27.464 --> 00:22:30.730
I know we're starting to
run a little bit over here.

397
00:22:30.730 --> 00:22:32.050
>> You're fine.

398
00:22:32.050 --> 00:22:37.060
>> We have inspection, interview, and

399
00:22:37.060 --> 00:22:41.270
data analysis, and
forensic investigations.

400
00:22:41.270 --> 00:22:43.130
So data analysis may be,

401
00:22:43.130 --> 00:22:47.700
and we'll talk a little bit about
sampling techniques and methodologies.

402
00:22:47.700 --> 00:22:51.760
Data analysis may involve,
you have 100 employees.

403
00:22:51.760 --> 00:22:56.820
I wanna poll 20% randomly and I wanna see
when their passwords were changed last.

404
00:22:57.890 --> 00:23:01.710
Or you have a policy that all employees

405
00:23:01.710 --> 00:23:04.882
have a background check done
on them prior to hiring.

406
00:23:04.882 --> 00:23:08.840
I'm gonna pull a random
sample of your HR files for

407
00:23:08.840 --> 00:23:12.580
the last 12 months, or
haphazard sample, excuse me.

408
00:23:12.580 --> 00:23:16.780
And review those to see if they actually
did in fact occur before the hiring

409
00:23:16.780 --> 00:23:19.610
event occurred, things like that.

410
00:23:19.610 --> 00:23:22.530
Forensic investigation gets
a little more complex.

411
00:23:22.530 --> 00:23:28.390
That typically is not something that
auditors do without specialized training.

412
00:23:28.390 --> 00:23:31.470
It's not part of the CISA
responsibilities.

413
00:23:31.470 --> 00:23:36.060
Forensic investigations and
forensic audits are oftentimes handed off

414
00:23:36.060 --> 00:23:40.970
to specialists once a finding
is discovered that says,

415
00:23:40.970 --> 00:23:45.050
hey, we need to have somebody
specialized taking a look at this.

416
00:23:45.050 --> 00:23:48.100
And then lastly, I'll close up
this episode with talking about

417
00:23:48.100 --> 00:23:51.070
sampling methodologies and techniques.

418
00:23:51.070 --> 00:23:58.600
We talked a little bit about attribute and
variable testing, or excuse me, sampling.

419
00:23:58.600 --> 00:24:01.940
An example of attribute
sampling might be looking at

420
00:24:03.640 --> 00:24:09.550
all of a certain type of machine, a server
2003 or sever 2008 something like that,

421
00:24:09.550 --> 00:24:15.380
to see whether or not they have the same
baseline configuration done on them.

422
00:24:15.380 --> 00:24:17.851
And the other, the variable,

423
00:24:17.851 --> 00:24:23.753
would be simply picking randomly
across systems, something like that.

424
00:24:23.753 --> 00:24:25.029
>> Very good.

425
00:24:25.029 --> 00:24:25.974
>> So.

426
00:24:25.974 --> 00:24:30.010
>> All right, Brian, I tell ya, a lot of
information there as we get started with

427
00:24:30.010 --> 00:24:31.900
our dive into the world of the CISA.

428
00:24:31.900 --> 00:24:37.370
You really have to understand what
is meant by an audit and understand

429
00:24:37.370 --> 00:24:41.750
why we're doing it and the standards and
the methodologies that we've gotta have in

430
00:24:41.750 --> 00:24:45.610
place to ensure that we're doing a good
job and we're not missing anything.

431
00:24:45.610 --> 00:24:46.760
So we thank you for that.

432
00:24:46.760 --> 00:24:47.460
>> You're welcome.

433
00:24:47.460 --> 00:24:49.420
>> Hope everybody out
there enjoyed watching.

434
00:24:49.420 --> 00:24:52.290
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Mike Roderick.

435
00:24:52.290 --> 00:24:53.100
>> And I'm Brian O'Hara.

436
00:24:53.100 --> 00:24:56.129
>> And we'll see you next time.

437
00:24:56.129 --> 00:25:03.310
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Auditing Information Systems Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.843 --> 00:00:15.359
Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.359 --> 00:00:17.068
I'm your host Mike Roderick and

4
00:00:17.068 --> 00:00:20.960
today we're doing our certified
information systems auditor.

5
00:00:20.960 --> 00:00:24.480
And specifically in this episode we're
gonna be continuing on in domain one and

6
00:00:24.480 --> 00:00:27.950
we're gonna start branching
into audit reporting.

7
00:00:27.950 --> 00:00:33.635
And here to help me in today's episode
is the author of the CISA Study Guide,

8
00:00:33.635 --> 00:00:34.880
Mr. Brian O'Hara.

9
00:00:34.880 --> 00:00:36.090
How are you doing Brian?

10
00:00:36.090 --> 00:00:36.780
>> Hi Mike.

11
00:00:36.780 --> 00:00:37.880
Thanks for having me again.

12
00:00:37.880 --> 00:00:39.380
>> Absolutely.

13
00:00:39.380 --> 00:00:44.570
>> So today I'd like to do just a little
quick review over what we talked about in

14
00:00:44.570 --> 00:00:46.580
part one of this particular domain.

15
00:00:46.580 --> 00:00:49.160
We talked a little bit about audit risk,

16
00:00:49.160 --> 00:00:52.910
and audit evidence,
how to collect audit evidence, etc.

17
00:00:52.910 --> 00:00:53.650
And we started for

18
00:00:53.650 --> 00:00:57.080
the first time talking about what
the audit program actually looks like.

19
00:00:57.080 --> 00:01:00.290
In this episode, what I'd like to talk
a little bit about, which is really,

20
00:01:00.290 --> 00:01:03.548
really, a very important
component of this whole course,

21
00:01:03.548 --> 00:01:09.330
and the CISA knowledge base,
is art reporting.

22
00:01:09.330 --> 00:01:13.584
It's the single most important piece,
I think, of what an auditor does,

23
00:01:13.584 --> 00:01:17.176
because all the future actions
are based on the auto report..

24
00:01:17.176 --> 00:01:21.582
So it's important to understand
how your auto reports are built,

25
00:01:21.582 --> 00:01:26.080
the information contained in them,
how you go about getting them.

26
00:01:26.080 --> 00:01:28.920
That's where we're talking about
testing in the last episode.

27
00:01:28.920 --> 00:01:31.518
They're testing methodologies, etc.

28
00:01:31.518 --> 00:01:34.260
So I'm gonna give you
a little quick outline of

29
00:01:34.260 --> 00:01:36.810
the components of a good auto report.

30
00:01:36.810 --> 00:01:39.573
So for
students out there take notes on this.

31
00:01:39.573 --> 00:01:43.161
And then, we'll talk a little
bit about the audit charter and

32
00:01:43.161 --> 00:01:47.550
what that really means, and
then about generating findings.

33
00:01:47.550 --> 00:01:52.890
So to kick off with when you're
compiling your first audit report,

34
00:01:52.890 --> 00:01:57.040
there are a number of key headings that
should be included in any audit report.

35
00:01:57.040 --> 00:01:58.490
There should be an introduction.

36
00:01:58.490 --> 00:02:01.369
There should be an objectives section.

37
00:02:01.369 --> 00:02:05.084
There should be a limitations and
scope section.

38
00:02:05.084 --> 00:02:09.410
I'm gonna come back and talk a little
bit about some of these, some more.

39
00:02:09.410 --> 00:02:14.565
The period that the audit covered, so
for instance the start and stop date,

40
00:02:14.565 --> 00:02:17.830
those are very important so that people
know exactly when you were there.

41
00:02:17.830 --> 00:02:22.158
Because an audit for those who do know,
who have done these already in the past,

42
00:02:22.158 --> 00:02:24.820
is simply a snapshot of
the environment in time.

43
00:02:24.820 --> 00:02:29.890
It's not a reflection of
necessarily ongoing system status.

44
00:02:29.890 --> 00:02:32.170
But it is a snapshot picture.

45
00:02:32.170 --> 00:02:36.560
So having the limitation in scope
of the audit is very important.

46
00:02:36.560 --> 00:02:39.140
As well as the period
that the audit covered.

47
00:02:39.140 --> 00:02:44.229
Then, of course, the most important part
is the audit findings, what exactly you

48
00:02:44.229 --> 00:02:49.334
discovered, what your conclusions were
based on the findings that you obtained.

49
00:02:49.334 --> 00:02:54.237
And then, any reservations you
might have to the audit results, so

50
00:02:54.237 --> 00:02:59.312
for instance, one of the things I might
run into is I might say that some

51
00:02:59.312 --> 00:03:04.301
of my audit results were questionable
because I was unable to acquire

52
00:03:04.301 --> 00:03:09.319
adequate documentation on policies and
procedures from the staff.

53
00:03:09.319 --> 00:03:14.408
Either because of a time limitation or
perhaps even people were out sick, etc.,

54
00:03:14.408 --> 00:03:19.456
or in some cases we have staff who like to
kinda drag their feet and not cooperate.

55
00:03:19.456 --> 00:03:21.313
>> [LAUGH] say it isn't so.

56
00:03:21.313 --> 00:03:22.253
>> Yeah, as much as possible.

57
00:03:22.253 --> 00:03:25.829
>> [LAUGH]
>> So there's always a section there for

58
00:03:25.829 --> 00:03:27.608
auditor reservations.

59
00:03:27.608 --> 00:03:31.954
But I wanna go back and
talk a little bit about the objectives and

60
00:03:31.954 --> 00:03:33.929
the limitations and scope.

61
00:03:34.990 --> 00:03:39.580
So it's very important in
an audit report to talk about

62
00:03:39.580 --> 00:03:42.790
what kind of audit you're conducting, what

63
00:03:45.830 --> 00:03:50.610
the purpose is,

64
00:03:50.610 --> 00:03:55.280
who the stakeholders are that
you're writing the report for.

65
00:03:55.280 --> 00:04:01.460
So that basically when an executive picks
up the document they can read it and

66
00:04:01.460 --> 00:04:04.970
get a quick understanding of,
as well as a detailed understanding,

67
00:04:04.970 --> 00:04:07.550
of what exactly was found.

68
00:04:07.550 --> 00:04:12.490
And in mentioning that, while
the ISACA model doesn't include this,

69
00:04:12.490 --> 00:04:17.730
something that I've built into my reports
for years is an executive summary,

70
00:04:17.730 --> 00:04:22.060
and that's important because, often times
these reports will go off the food chain

71
00:04:22.060 --> 00:04:24.290
to higher management,
higher level management.

72
00:04:24.290 --> 00:04:28.970
And they don't always understand
the specific of IT systems or

73
00:04:28.970 --> 00:04:30.610
audit speak, if you will.

74
00:04:30.610 --> 00:04:34.519
And it's important to be able
to take your conclusions and

75
00:04:34.519 --> 00:04:38.823
put them in a high level,
sort of a high level summary in order for

76
00:04:38.823 --> 00:04:42.677
upper management to understand
what exactly happened.

77
00:04:42.677 --> 00:04:47.207
>> So like if you know your audience you
can really cater that report to their

78
00:04:47.207 --> 00:04:48.330
specific needs.

79
00:04:48.330 --> 00:04:51.878
>> Right and it's important because
we're continuing to stress more and

80
00:04:51.878 --> 00:04:54.666
more today in auditing,
we didn't so much in the past.

81
00:04:54.666 --> 00:04:56.847
But we're continuing to stress more and

82
00:04:56.847 --> 00:05:01.210
more executive management involvement
in audit results and tracking.

83
00:05:01.210 --> 00:05:04.050
Not so much the down in the weeds
of how did it get done,

84
00:05:04.050 --> 00:05:06.940
what was your sampling methodology,
they don't care about that.

85
00:05:06.940 --> 00:05:11.360
But the reality is because of the breaches
in the news you read about all the time,

86
00:05:11.360 --> 00:05:15.066
executives are getting more and
more pressure to have their fingers

87
00:05:15.066 --> 00:05:19.179
into the security world and know
what's happening in their environment.

88
00:05:19.179 --> 00:05:22.938
So it's really important that you're able
to communicate that effectively to upper

89
00:05:22.938 --> 00:05:25.310
management so that they know what to do.

90
00:05:25.310 --> 00:05:28.260
They know how to prioritize
their resources or

91
00:05:28.260 --> 00:05:33.370
we live in a world of limited resources
and we're constantly faced with challenges

92
00:05:33.370 --> 00:05:36.420
regarding where to put those
resources to best use.

93
00:05:36.420 --> 00:05:42.698
So in a risk based scenario for instance
you might have 12 different findings,

94
00:05:42.698 --> 00:05:46.593
all with different risk
ratings from high to low.

95
00:05:46.593 --> 00:05:50.914
You'll have to be able to decide where
you're gonna put your resources to address

96
00:05:50.914 --> 00:05:52.750
those in a reasonable timeframe.

97
00:05:52.750 --> 00:05:55.570
Based on the risk it poses
to the organization.

98
00:05:55.570 --> 00:05:56.120
>> Very good.
>> So

99
00:05:56.120 --> 00:05:58.959
that's why in the previous episode
we talked so much about risk.

100
00:06:00.500 --> 00:06:02.860
There's more information
on it in the book.

101
00:06:02.860 --> 00:06:06.066
There's also more
information at ISACA.org,

102
00:06:06.066 --> 00:06:09.820
if you wanna read further
in that particular manner.

103
00:06:09.820 --> 00:06:12.660
It's extremely important because
everything we talk about,

104
00:06:12.660 --> 00:06:16.920
the rest of the episodes,
will revolve around risk management.

105
00:06:16.920 --> 00:06:20.080
That's really what we're trying to do,
is to get our hands around.

106
00:06:20.080 --> 00:06:22.513
Not to necessarily minimize risk,

107
00:06:22.513 --> 00:06:26.566
which is what junior level
auditors try to accomplish, but

108
00:06:26.566 --> 00:06:31.933
to align our risk with the organization's
risk tolerance and risk strategy.

109
00:06:31.933 --> 00:06:33.337
>> Very good, very good.

110
00:06:33.337 --> 00:06:37.417
I know we had mentioned in a previous
episode, we talked about how auditing

111
00:06:37.417 --> 00:06:40.740
is similar, has some similarities
to project management.

112
00:06:40.740 --> 00:06:44.196
You had mentioned that we'll need to make
sure we know what the scope of our audit

113
00:06:44.196 --> 00:06:47.826
is, reminds me like in project management
we have something called scoped creep.

114
00:06:47.826 --> 00:06:51.825
And if we're not careful,
our project kinda gets out of scope,

115
00:06:51.825 --> 00:06:54.595
or same thing here in auditing?

116
00:06:54.595 --> 00:06:55.845
>> That's correct, Mike.

117
00:06:55.845 --> 00:07:00.937
It's very important to manage and
maintain scope, in audits.

118
00:07:00.937 --> 00:07:04.735
Because you'll start getting into areas,
you could have no expertise in, or

119
00:07:04.735 --> 00:07:06.986
the company didn't want you investigating.

120
00:07:06.986 --> 00:07:11.612
One of the things I've done in the past on
a couple of audits, were, where the scope

121
00:07:11.612 --> 00:07:17.020
wasn't clearly defined, but the company
wanted me to come in and do it anyway.

122
00:07:17.020 --> 00:07:20.390
Where I started poking around and was

123
00:07:20.390 --> 00:07:25.160
able to uncover other types of
risk around things like HIPAA and

124
00:07:25.160 --> 00:07:29.195
I was very quickly told, that's outside
the scope of what we wanted you here for.

125
00:07:29.195 --> 00:07:30.890
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I backed off.

126
00:07:30.890 --> 00:07:34.460
But the scope wasn't clearly defined,
so it wasn't clear.

127
00:07:34.460 --> 00:07:37.791
And initially they did want me to
poke around until I hit something and

128
00:07:37.791 --> 00:07:38.602
they said, no.

129
00:07:38.602 --> 00:07:39.459
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's far enough.

130
00:07:39.459 --> 00:07:41.280
Yeah, exactly.

131
00:07:41.280 --> 00:07:45.870
So all those pieces are really important
in developing your audit report.

132
00:07:48.270 --> 00:07:53.610
To help you with that, I forgot to
mention, reading the audit charter,

133
00:07:53.610 --> 00:07:54.390
for instance.

134
00:07:54.390 --> 00:07:59.070
In most companies if you're
actively involved in IT audit.

135
00:07:59.070 --> 00:08:01.200
You've already seen this if
you're a student studying, and

136
00:08:01.200 --> 00:08:03.410
you haven't had that much experience.

137
00:08:03.410 --> 00:08:06.130
You'll run across something
called the IT steering committee.

138
00:08:06.130 --> 00:08:09.660
The IT steering committee's
typically generate

139
00:08:09.660 --> 00:08:13.600
a audit charter which
says specifically what

140
00:08:15.210 --> 00:08:19.140
audit activities are going to take
place around their information systems.

141
00:08:19.140 --> 00:08:20.530
That could be in banking.

142
00:08:20.530 --> 00:08:23.900
It could be a FFIC audit, a FDIC audit.

143
00:08:23.900 --> 00:08:26.050
In healthcare, could be HIPAA audit.

144
00:08:26.050 --> 00:08:29.980
Healthcare could be a PCI audit because
most healthcare providers accept credit

145
00:08:29.980 --> 00:08:32.690
cards for payments, for
co-pays, things like that.

146
00:08:32.690 --> 00:08:37.640
So they're involved in PCI audits,
as well.

147
00:08:39.475 --> 00:08:44.168
So getting a copy of the auditor is
really important before you start

148
00:08:44.168 --> 00:08:48.779
your actual audit so
you understand the reporting, structures,

149
00:08:48.779 --> 00:08:52.093
the mechanisms, the organizational layout.

150
00:08:52.093 --> 00:08:58.110
But then coming back round to the other
end of having completed your report,

151
00:08:58.110 --> 00:09:03.846
what a common mistake I see in junior
auditors and in companies sometimes

152
00:09:03.846 --> 00:09:09.863
who don't have an ongoing audit program,
for instance in manufacturing,

153
00:09:09.863 --> 00:09:16.000
they may oftentimes ask you to come in
to perform an assessment, if you will.

154
00:09:16.000 --> 00:09:18.890
But it's basically an audit to find
out what kind of shape they're in

155
00:09:18.890 --> 00:09:22.000
with regards to,
are they handling credit cards properly?

156
00:09:22.000 --> 00:09:26.700
Are they handling bank account,
wire transfers properly?

157
00:09:26.700 --> 00:09:30.600
If they're self-insured are they handling
employee health records properly.

158
00:09:30.600 --> 00:09:31.730
Those kinds of things.

159
00:09:31.730 --> 00:09:35.394
Well, they're not really required
by law to be audited in any way.

160
00:09:35.394 --> 00:09:40.515
One of the things that happens
with junior auditors and

161
00:09:40.515 --> 00:09:46.500
with those kinds of facilities
is very poor follow up.

162
00:09:46.500 --> 00:09:51.300
So finding is that 20% of

163
00:09:53.050 --> 00:09:57.940
your staff are not completing their
security training on an annual basis.

164
00:09:57.940 --> 00:10:03.780
And that, that's one of your policies,
that all employees will participate in and

165
00:10:03.780 --> 00:10:08.660
pass a security training
program every 12 months.

166
00:10:08.660 --> 00:10:10.860
And I go in and do an audit.

167
00:10:10.860 --> 00:10:15.160
I do a haphazard pull of records,
and I find that 20% of your

168
00:10:15.160 --> 00:10:19.000
employees have not completed the training
and no one's done any follow-up.

169
00:10:19.000 --> 00:10:19.829
Well, that's a finding.

170
00:10:21.560 --> 00:10:24.850
That's something that's gonna be
written up in your audit findings and

171
00:10:24.850 --> 00:10:26.480
part of your conclusions.

172
00:10:26.480 --> 00:10:30.750
Part of your conclusions may in fact
relate back and say something like

173
00:10:30.750 --> 00:10:35.320
maybe there's a process that's not in
place to ensure that that happens.

174
00:10:35.320 --> 00:10:38.781
Maybe HR wrote a policy, but
there's no way of enforcing it.

175
00:10:38.781 --> 00:10:42.822
The're no who continually checks
to see whether that activity

176
00:10:42.822 --> 00:10:44.890
is actually occurring or not.

177
00:10:44.890 --> 00:10:49.590
So one of your recommendations may be that
you, not that you necessarily increase

178
00:10:49.590 --> 00:10:53.130
security training efforts,
but that you put a new policy

179
00:10:53.130 --> 00:10:57.490
in place with an enforcement mechanism so
that their managers are now responsible.

180
00:10:57.490 --> 00:11:00.660
If their managers don't report that
they've completed it that their managers

181
00:11:00.660 --> 00:11:01.570
get written up.

182
00:11:01.570 --> 00:11:03.670
>> Something like that.

183
00:11:03.670 --> 00:11:09.750
But what's even as important as that
is doing your programmatic follow-up.

184
00:11:09.750 --> 00:11:13.014
In most of the regulated industries,

185
00:11:13.014 --> 00:11:18.630
this happens because they are audited
on a routine basis any way.

186
00:11:18.630 --> 00:11:21.165
We were talking at the break earlier,

187
00:11:21.165 --> 00:11:26.580
that typical small community bank may
be $10 billion or less in assets.

188
00:11:26.580 --> 00:11:29.250
Undergoes 10 to 20 audits every year.

189
00:11:29.250 --> 00:11:31.900
>> Wow. [LAUGH] >> They don't even
have conference rooms anymore.

190
00:11:31.900 --> 00:11:33.195
They're just rooms for auditors.

191
00:11:33.195 --> 00:11:37.110
And you may go into,
I've been into small banks where

192
00:11:38.110 --> 00:11:41.880
there was one senior auditor,
and nine junior auditors.

193
00:11:41.880 --> 00:11:43.260
>> Wow.
>> Because they use those as training

194
00:11:43.260 --> 00:11:44.960
grounds for the new staff.

195
00:11:44.960 --> 00:11:47.550
And the bank only had 20 employees.

196
00:11:47.550 --> 00:11:48.170
>> Wow.
[LAUGH]

197
00:11:48.170 --> 00:11:49.455
>> What's the deal on that?

198
00:11:49.455 --> 00:11:53.390
Anyway, the point I'm trying to
make is they're used to an ongoing

199
00:11:53.390 --> 00:11:57.980
lifestyle of having audits, where
manufacturing companies, etc., are not.

200
00:11:57.980 --> 00:12:00.690
And so, in those regulated
environments it's much more common

201
00:12:00.690 --> 00:12:03.000
to do the follow up because

202
00:12:03.000 --> 00:12:06.380
they know that if somebody doesn't they're
just gonna get clipped at the next audit.

203
00:12:06.380 --> 00:12:06.950
>> Right.

204
00:12:06.950 --> 00:12:12.230
>> So on a finding like that,
an inexperienced

205
00:12:12.230 --> 00:12:17.690
auditor might write up and say,
you need to put this process in place.

206
00:12:17.690 --> 00:12:20.621
And then, not have any mechanism for
follow-up to see that it,

207
00:12:20.621 --> 00:12:22.170
in fact, is done.

208
00:12:22.170 --> 00:12:26.310
So one of my recommendations has nothing
to do with the exams or the requirements

209
00:12:26.310 --> 00:12:32.180
is that at the conclusion of your audit
that you schedule with your client

210
00:12:32.180 --> 00:12:36.970
both a 30, a 60, and a 90 day follow up to
find out, are they fixing those things.

211
00:12:36.970 --> 00:12:39.460
Now, again, in the banking world,
you're required to do that.

212
00:12:39.460 --> 00:12:42.270
The bank doesn't have a choice
because the next auditor

213
00:12:42.270 --> 00:12:43.490
is gonna come around and ask them.

214
00:12:43.490 --> 00:12:44.030
Where's your results?

215
00:12:44.030 --> 00:12:45.820
>> Gonna be the first thing
they're gonna ask, right?

216
00:12:45.820 --> 00:12:46.370
>> Exactly.

217
00:12:46.370 --> 00:12:49.360
Exactly, that is the first
thing I ask for.

218
00:12:49.360 --> 00:12:52.690
So it's important that you do your
follow-up work with your clients

219
00:12:52.690 --> 00:12:56.720
in order to ensure that they're
managing risk in the way that you and

220
00:12:56.720 --> 00:12:59.860
they both feel fits
their risk tolerance and

221
00:12:59.860 --> 00:13:03.000
their risk appetite and
matches their business strategy.

222
00:13:03.000 --> 00:13:04.379
So they can get to where they wanna go.

223
00:13:04.379 --> 00:13:06.450
>> Right.

224
00:13:06.450 --> 00:13:10.500
>> And so, one last thing I wanted
to say about the auto report and

225
00:13:10.500 --> 00:13:14.720
the auto report structure as well was that
there should also be a general statement

226
00:13:14.720 --> 00:13:16.950
on your IS audit methodology.

227
00:13:17.950 --> 00:13:19.120
That's important.

228
00:13:19.120 --> 00:13:23.450
It may seem like fluff,
that's a lot of people, but

229
00:13:23.450 --> 00:13:27.395
it's really important that you understand
and be able to explain what the testing

230
00:13:27.395 --> 00:13:32.307
and the sampling techniques

231
00:13:32.307 --> 00:13:37.590
that you used in your audit, especially if
you're doing any kind of special auditing.

232
00:13:37.590 --> 00:13:41.910
When I say special auditing, here,
we're primarily talking about what we,

233
00:13:41.910 --> 00:13:44.780
in the industry,
we call IT generals control audit.

234
00:13:44.780 --> 00:13:48.960
But I have done audits of specific
information systems, to see whether or

235
00:13:48.960 --> 00:13:52.600
not the transactions are complete and
accurate, and

236
00:13:52.600 --> 00:13:56.240
that there's no data slippage anywhere,
one way or the other.

237
00:13:56.240 --> 00:13:56.740
Things like that.

238
00:13:56.740 --> 00:13:59.342
And that's more in accounting
systems than anything else.

239
00:13:59.342 --> 00:14:02.601
But it's important to be
able to understand and

240
00:14:02.601 --> 00:14:06.513
discuss your audit methodology
in the report as well, so

241
00:14:06.513 --> 00:14:11.892
that everything is covered from intro
to objectives, limitations in scope,

242
00:14:11.892 --> 00:14:17.353
not necessarily in this order, your
general statement on audit methodology,

243
00:14:17.353 --> 00:14:21.080
the period of the audit,
that's really important.

244
00:14:21.080 --> 00:14:25.810
Your findings, any conclusions,
and reservations.

245
00:14:25.810 --> 00:14:31.100
One thing I will point out here is that
in financial audits you may have read or

246
00:14:31.100 --> 00:14:33.820
you may read opinions.

247
00:14:33.820 --> 00:14:35.430
We do not give opinions.

248
00:14:35.430 --> 00:14:36.865
CPA's give opinions.

249
00:14:36.865 --> 00:14:38.940
>> [LAUGH]
>> Those are legally binding.

250
00:14:38.940 --> 00:14:40.460
>> Okay.
>> And they have reverence to

251
00:14:40.460 --> 00:14:44.670
things that have to do with publicly
traded companies, etc., and

252
00:14:44.670 --> 00:14:46.920
they're specific things that
we typically do not do.

253
00:14:46.920 --> 00:14:49.810
We do not render opinions.

254
00:14:49.810 --> 00:14:50.610
That's another thing that,

255
00:14:50.610 --> 00:14:55.250
again, isn't covered in the book or
the ISACA requirements.

256
00:14:55.250 --> 00:14:59.790
And that is sort of standard,
excuse me not non disclosure,

257
00:14:59.790 --> 00:15:04.960
but standard
>> Standard practice,

258
00:15:04.960 --> 00:15:07.690
or-
>> Standard statements stating

259
00:15:07.690 --> 00:15:10.330
the fact that this is a snapshot in time.

260
00:15:10.330 --> 00:15:13.180
That we can't guarantee that
systems haven't changed.

261
00:15:13.180 --> 00:15:16.410
Stuff like that to prevent you for
being liable for

262
00:15:16.410 --> 00:15:20.860
anything that you might throw on a report,
cuz again, of any IT audit system,

263
00:15:20.860 --> 00:15:26.300
is only a snapshot picture and
time of that system, or systems.

264
00:15:26.300 --> 00:15:30.320
And should never be viewed
as anything more than that.

265
00:15:30.320 --> 00:15:34.160
So then, last couple points in this
session I wanted to talk about is,

266
00:15:34.160 --> 00:15:36.150
it's also really important,
and this is again,

267
00:15:36.150 --> 00:15:41.220
tough for inexperience auditors,
and it takes a mentoring.

268
00:15:41.220 --> 00:15:46.560
This is why the big firms typically
take inexperience auditors out

269
00:15:46.560 --> 00:15:51.810
and help train them in the field is that

270
00:15:51.810 --> 00:15:55.310
they'll let you sit through several
meetings, and get a feel for

271
00:15:55.310 --> 00:15:59.820
what it's like to communicate your
audit results to the key stake holders.

272
00:15:59.820 --> 00:16:04.258
And when I say key stakeholders,
that's often times the CEO,

273
00:16:04.258 --> 00:16:06.447
the CFO, the CTO, or the CIO.

274
00:16:06.447 --> 00:16:08.940
So you're talking to some
very high level folks.

275
00:16:08.940 --> 00:16:13.930
It could be just an audit committee which
is a layer between the C levels and

276
00:16:13.930 --> 00:16:15.500
the rest of the organization.

277
00:16:15.500 --> 00:16:16.840
It just kinda depends.

278
00:16:16.840 --> 00:16:20.910
But you have to understand your audience,
in order to communicate the audit results

279
00:16:20.910 --> 00:16:25.730
effectively, you have to understand that
you can't talk really technical stuff to

280
00:16:25.730 --> 00:16:29.260
C levels typically, but
you may to an audit committee.

281
00:16:29.260 --> 00:16:31.560
Just depends on who you're dealing with.

282
00:16:31.560 --> 00:16:34.420
So it's really important that you learn
to communicate effectively to those

283
00:16:34.420 --> 00:16:38.120
different audiences your audit results.

284
00:16:38.120 --> 00:16:41.410
And I think I already mentioned
the importance of doing follow ups to make

285
00:16:41.410 --> 00:16:44.310
sure the audit results
are in fact being addressed.

286
00:16:44.310 --> 00:16:46.843
Because if I do an audit and
I tell you all this stuffs wrong and

287
00:16:46.843 --> 00:16:49.741
then nobody does follow up and
nothing gets fixed what's the point.

288
00:16:49.741 --> 00:16:50.525
>> Right.

289
00:16:50.525 --> 00:16:52.700
[LAUGH]
>> It really accomplishes nothing.

290
00:16:52.700 --> 00:16:56.470
So-
>> Now,

291
00:16:56.470 --> 00:17:01.280
are you responsible for scheduling this
follow up as the auditor, or is it them

292
00:17:01.280 --> 00:17:04.790
that they're supposed to call you back,
or is it all part of the same scheduling?

293
00:17:04.790 --> 00:17:07.170
I'm gonna schedule the audit and the
follow up in six months at the same time.

294
00:17:07.170 --> 00:17:09.000
>> Yeah, good question, Mike.

295
00:17:09.000 --> 00:17:09.720
Good question, Mike.

296
00:17:09.720 --> 00:17:12.170
What do you think would happen
if you leave it up to them?

297
00:17:12.170 --> 00:17:13.070
>> There's gonna be no follow up.

298
00:17:13.070 --> 00:17:14.140
>> They probably won't do it.

299
00:17:14.140 --> 00:17:16.073
Yeah.
And its typically covered in the cost of

300
00:17:16.073 --> 00:17:16.666
the audits.

301
00:17:16.666 --> 00:17:18.392
>> Okay.
>> Generally speaking there's no

302
00:17:18.392 --> 00:17:19.730
additional cost but yeah.

303
00:17:19.730 --> 00:17:24.615
I typically made that part,
again typically, I'm talking generically.

304
00:17:24.615 --> 00:17:27.030
Cuz I've done this in a lot
of different industries.

305
00:17:27.030 --> 00:17:31.802
Typically we have what's called an exit
interview where we sit down the auditor or

306
00:17:31.802 --> 00:17:34.775
the audit team,
may sit down with the executives or

307
00:17:34.775 --> 00:17:39.288
whoever brought us in to conduct the audit
and we share the results with them.

308
00:17:39.288 --> 00:17:42.120
At that time that's when I
typically schedule those events.

309
00:17:42.120 --> 00:17:45.887
I just say I wanna come back in 30 days,
let's get it on the calendar, 60 and

310
00:17:45.887 --> 00:17:49.373
90 days, so that they know at the end
of that meeting that there's gonna

311
00:17:49.373 --> 00:17:53.390
be more follow-up and here's what's going
to be expected of us in that timeframe.

312
00:17:53.390 --> 00:17:55.823
>> Very good.

313
00:17:55.823 --> 00:17:57.698
>> And I think that covers it for
this session

314
00:17:57.698 --> 00:17:58.840
>> All right Brian,

315
00:17:58.840 --> 00:18:03.150
great information there as we continue to
look at our auditing information systems

316
00:18:03.150 --> 00:18:05.930
and talked a little bit about
the reporting side of things.

317
00:18:05.930 --> 00:18:08.990
And what we need to make sure
we include in those reports.

318
00:18:08.990 --> 00:18:12.780
And remember, if you guys want more in
depth coverage on any of these topics,

319
00:18:12.780 --> 00:18:16.760
just go pick up a copy of
the Sybex CISA Study Guide,

320
00:18:16.760 --> 00:18:18.670
of which Brian is one of the authors.

321
00:18:18.670 --> 00:18:20.860
So we're getting it right
from the horse's mouth.

322
00:18:20.860 --> 00:18:22.720
All right,
I hope everybody enjoyed this one.

323
00:18:22.720 --> 00:18:25.424
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Mike Roderick.

324
00:18:25.424 --> 00:18:26.957
>> And I'm Brian O'Hara.

325
00:18:26.957 --> 00:18:28.361
>> And we'll see you next time.

326
00:18:28.361 --> 00:18:37.479
[SOUND]

00:07:13.660 --> 00:07:18.400

00:07:19.770 --> 00:07:22.060

00:07:22.060 --> 00:07:24.170

00:07:24.170 --> 00:07:28.710

125
00:07:28.710 --> 00:07:31.440
There are administrative
control mechanisms.

126
00:07:31.440 --> 00:07:36.640
An example of an administrative control
mechanism might be a policy that's

127
00:07:36.640 --> 00:07:41.930

128
00:07:41.930 --> 00:07:46.540

requires that their passwords be complex,

129
00:07:46.540 --> 00:07:52.160
that they can only re-use after
the last 24, etc, etc, etc.

130
00:07:54.330 --> 00:07:55.830
So those are controls,

131
00:07:55.830 --> 00:07:58.990
you need to understand what

00:07:58.990 --> 00:08:03.450

00:08:03.450 --> 00:08:07.470

00:08:08.950 --> 00:08:12.290

to be implementing this kind of control

00:08:12.290 --> 00:08:14.190

00:08:14.190 --> 00:08:16.420
If not, then you've got findings.

138
00:08:16.420 --> 00:08:19.010
But you also need to take
a look at the controls

139
00:08:19.010 --> 00:08:21.300

140
00:08:21.300 --> 00:08:23.270

141
00:08:23.270 --> 00:08:26.200
Here's a great one I ran, [LAUGH] I
couldn't believe I ran across this,

142
00:08:26.200 --> 00:08:30.650

143
00:08:30.650 --> 00:08:34.570

144
00:08:34.570 --> 00:08:39.095

of their last 24 passwords.

145
00:08:39.095 --> 00:08:40.120
>> Mm-hm.

146
00:08:40.120 --> 00:08:45.950
>> However, there's no date specified on
the length of lifetime of the password.

147
00:08:45.950 --> 00:08:49.970
So the password can be less than
an hour old and be changed again.

148
00:08:49.970 --> 00:08:53.500
So one of the developers who was joking
around with me in a staff meeting one day

149
00:08:53.500 --> 00:08:59.020

that will change his password 23 times,

150
00:08:59.020 --> 00:09:01.410
so on the day that he
changes his password,

151
00:09:01.410 --> 00:09:05.820
he just runs a script, changes it another

152
00:09:05.820 --> 00:09:08.830
That completely bypasses
the intention of the control.

153
00:09:10.060 --> 00:09:12.260
>> Pretty much making
that control ineffective.

154
00:09:12.260 --> 00:09:12.870
>> Ineffective.

155
00:09:12.870 --> 00:09:15.920
So all you have to do, there's one little
check box in your group policy that you

156
00:09:15.920 --> 00:09:18.590
change, and
that control then becomes effective.

157
00:09:18.590 --> 00:09:21.430
So when you're looking at controls,
you're doing your audit work,

158
00:09:21.430 --> 00:09:26.970
you have to take a look at not only
the results of your control testing,

00:09:26.970 --> 00:09:28.440

160
00:09:28.440 --> 00:09:30.240
Are they actually doing,

161
00:09:30.240 --> 00:09:33.170

of the policy if you will.

162
00:09:33.170 --> 00:09:36.760
The spirit of the policy was to not
get users to reuse their passwords.

163
00:09:36.760 --> 00:09:40.210
If they can get around that,
then the control is not effective.

164
00:09:40.210 --> 00:09:42.332
It's basically a bypass, okay?

00:10:56.610 --> 00:10:58.090

doing what they're supposed to be doing.

00:11:15.070 --> 00:11:16.730

gotten much more important

00:11:18.830 --> 00:11:20.890
The way everything is interconnected, and

00:11:29.170 --> 00:11:32.060

now connected to your network?

00:11:32.060 --> 00:11:34.610

00:11:34.610 --> 00:11:35.960
>> That's absolutely correct, and

198

199
00:11:46.000 --> 00:11:50.660

200
00:11:50.660 --> 00:11:55.590

entity is bound to abide by.

201
00:11:55.590 --> 00:11:58.700
So, but,
you have to take it one step farther.

202
00:11:58.700 --> 00:12:00.890
Which is anyone can sign the agreement.

203
00:12:00.890 --> 00:12:02.290
>> Correct.
>> You still need to do your due

00:12:02.290 --> 00:12:04.840
diligence to audit them,

00:12:13.690 --> 00:12:16.690

211
00:12:31.180 --> 00:12:34.440

212
00:12:34.440 --> 00:12:37.250
Because even though it may not
have impacted me directly,

213
00:12:37.250 --> 00:12:41.730

00:12:41.730 --> 00:12:44.980
The other part of vendor

00:12:56.140 --> 00:13:00.990
What we're talking about is if I go
into a bank and I'm doing an audit, and

00:13:00.990 --> 00:13:05.690

that's part of the scope, and

220
00:13:05.690 --> 00:13:10.230
the objectives of the audit is I
will look at all the contracts for

221
00:13:10.230 --> 00:13:12.005

00:13:12.005 --> 00:13:13.100
Okay.

direct access to the bank after hours.

224
00:13:17.170 --> 00:13:17.910
>> Absolutely.

225
00:13:17.910 --> 00:13:21.476
>> I have stumbled upon them doing
lots of things they shouldn't be

226
00:13:21.476 --> 00:13:23.400
doing in my history of doing this.

00:13:24.680 --> 00:13:26.970
So, I look at those and I'll say, for

00:13:26.970 --> 00:13:30.960
