229
00:13:30.960 --> 00:13:33.780
Pull five records in the last
12 months and show me.

230
00:13:33.780 --> 00:13:36.400
Give me proof of that.

231
00:13:36.400 --> 00:13:39.270
Now, it gets a little more complicated
when you get into a really large

232
00:13:39.270 --> 00:13:42.720
organization, like a very large national
bank, or a very large hospital.

233
00:13:42.720 --> 00:13:45.290
They may have thousands of vendors.

234
00:13:45.290 --> 00:13:52.590
And you can't always provide that level
of scrutiny for that many vendors.

235
00:13:52.590 --> 00:13:57.440
So we go back, we fall back onto our
risk management model and we risk rank

236
00:13:57.440 --> 00:14:02.380
those vendors and we provide the most
scrutiny to the highest risk of vendors.

237
00:14:02.380 --> 00:14:08.040
So for instance, there may be
an office supply place that we

238
00:14:08.040 --> 00:14:12.289
buy all of our toner and paper from, they
can't get into the building after hours,

239
00:14:13.400 --> 00:14:17.510
we're never out of toner or paper for
very long, so what is the problem?

240
00:14:17.510 --> 00:14:19.020
They don't have access to anything.

241
00:14:19.020 --> 00:14:21.570
>> Right.
>> Very low risk vender.

242
00:14:21.570 --> 00:14:24.120
Again, cleaning staff,
very high risk of vendor.

243
00:14:24.120 --> 00:14:25.020
You may not think about it,

244
00:14:25.020 --> 00:14:28.700
but with physical access to the facilities
they can do a lot of damage.

245
00:14:28.700 --> 00:14:30.960
>> Yeah.
>> They can see things people forget and

246
00:14:30.960 --> 00:14:32.650
leave out on their desks.

247
00:14:32.650 --> 00:14:36.210
In bank audits one of the things that we
often times do is what's called a clean

248
00:14:36.210 --> 00:14:41.160
desk policy audit where we literally
walk around after the bank is closed

249
00:14:41.160 --> 00:14:42.710
while no one knows we're coming.

250
00:14:42.710 --> 00:14:46.290
We go in with a security officer and
we go around and we look on desks to see

251
00:14:46.290 --> 00:14:50.620
what kind of confidential information
may have been left out on a desktop.

252
00:14:50.620 --> 00:14:54.800
That could expose a customer or
expose a bank to some risk or liability.

253
00:14:54.800 --> 00:14:55.730
>> Interesting.

254
00:14:55.730 --> 00:14:59.030
>> So
evaluating those SLA's is very important.

255
00:14:59.030 --> 00:15:02.090
The last component of that is
also ensuring that the customers

256
00:15:02.090 --> 00:15:04.120
getting what they pay for.

257
00:15:04.120 --> 00:15:08.010
Another example is, this happens all
the time in very large organizations,

258
00:15:08.010 --> 00:15:12.320
I worked in a health core organization
a couple years ago where they were paying

259
00:15:12.320 --> 00:15:16.680
in the millions for connectivity
to all their regional hospitals.

260
00:15:16.680 --> 00:15:21.450
And they had a specialist come in and
do an audit, who does nothing but that.

261
00:15:21.450 --> 00:15:23.610
They work with telecommunications company.

262
00:15:23.610 --> 00:15:26.620
Save them a half billion
dollars in the first year.

263
00:15:26.620 --> 00:15:27.520
>> Really?
>> Because they had

264
00:15:27.520 --> 00:15:28.710
circuits they were paying for

265
00:15:28.710 --> 00:15:32.130
that had never been turned on because they
didn't have the staff to follow up on it.

266
00:15:32.130 --> 00:15:36.260
So they brought this young lady in,
she did an audit of all their circuits and

267
00:15:36.260 --> 00:15:37.940
saved them a half million
dollars the first year,

268
00:15:37.940 --> 00:15:41.020
right out the gate, just by identifying
circuits that they weren't even using.

269
00:15:41.020 --> 00:15:43.220
Didn't even know that they had them.

270
00:15:43.220 --> 00:15:47.940
So, evaluating those service level
agreements is really important in terms of

271
00:15:47.940 --> 00:15:52.800
driving value for your audit and
helping your customer also manage risk.

272
00:15:52.800 --> 00:15:56.850
Because having those circuits, for
example, was a risk to the organization

273
00:15:56.850 --> 00:15:59.510
cuz maybe they were plugged into routers,
maybe they weren't.

274
00:15:59.510 --> 00:16:01.910
Maybe people could burrow into your
network if they got into them.

275
00:16:01.910 --> 00:16:04.690
If you don't have visibility into it,
it's a risk.

276
00:16:04.690 --> 00:16:05.430
>> Absolutely.

277
00:16:05.430 --> 00:16:07.850
They're sitting there unmonitored, unused.

278
00:16:07.850 --> 00:16:09.220
Huge risk.

279
00:16:09.220 --> 00:16:10.770
>> Yeah.
Plain and simple.

280
00:16:10.770 --> 00:16:11.850
Plain and simple.

281
00:16:11.850 --> 00:16:17.670
So, last couple things I wanna touch on
are, I think we have a few minutes left,

282
00:16:17.670 --> 00:16:22.040
is to talk a little bit
about project management.

283
00:16:22.040 --> 00:16:24.670
We talked about that in one
of the previous episodes.

284
00:16:24.670 --> 00:16:29.090
Making sure that you understand your
project management practices, and

285
00:16:29.090 --> 00:16:30.896
how you're applying them to projects.

286
00:16:30.896 --> 00:16:35.150
And then I wanna talk a little bit
about enterprise architecture,

287
00:16:35.150 --> 00:16:36.400
just for a second.

288
00:16:36.400 --> 00:16:39.210
We talked about enterprise risk
management, I mentioned a little bit of

289
00:16:39.210 --> 00:16:45.180
it, but in enterprise architecture, what
we're talking about are concepts like LAN,

290
00:16:45.180 --> 00:16:50.630
WAN, MAN, which doesn't get used
much anymore, local area network,

291
00:16:50.630 --> 00:16:56.450
wide area network, metro area network but
today also, cloud, virtualization.

292
00:16:56.450 --> 00:17:01.090
That enterprise architecture is very
important because what you'll find is

293
00:17:01.090 --> 00:17:07.310
the information systems that you're
auditing can span the globe.

294
00:17:07.310 --> 00:17:12.950
You literally could have an Office 365
enterprise with data residing in Ireland.

295
00:17:12.950 --> 00:17:15.980
It could be residing in Mexico,
do you even know?

296
00:17:15.980 --> 00:17:17.460
Can you find out if you need to?

297
00:17:18.580 --> 00:17:21.510
Again another large national
bank I worked with in the past

298
00:17:21.510 --> 00:17:25.430
actually required Microsoft,
when they moved to Office 365,

299
00:17:25.430 --> 00:17:28.980
to host their data within the boundaries
within the physical boundaries of

300
00:17:28.980 --> 00:17:32.620
the United States because they're
required to by FDIC regs.

301
00:17:32.620 --> 00:17:34.450
Microsoft was able to do that.

302
00:17:34.450 --> 00:17:35.290
But for most companies,

303
00:17:35.290 --> 00:17:38.730
you don't have the clout to do that,
you're not buying 18 thousand licenses.

304
00:17:38.730 --> 00:17:40.430
>> Right.
>> So you don't have the clout, so

305
00:17:40.430 --> 00:17:41.860
your data could be anywhere in the world.

306
00:17:41.860 --> 00:17:47.080
One of the classic bank audit questions
today is do you know where your data is?

307
00:17:47.080 --> 00:17:49.510
And if you can't answer that question

308
00:17:49.510 --> 00:17:52.980
unequivocally you're gonna be on
the hot seat for a couple of days.

309
00:17:52.980 --> 00:17:57.977
Yeah you're gonna really get grilled,
it's extremely important And

310
00:17:57.977 --> 00:18:01.000
I think that's probably it for today.

311
00:18:01.000 --> 00:18:02.150
And I think that's probably it for
the day.

312
00:18:02.150 --> 00:18:03.660
I think that should
wrap up our domain one.

313
00:18:03.660 --> 00:18:07.726
Again as Mike said there's more
information in the CISA study guide fourth

314
00:18:07.726 --> 00:18:08.317
edition.

315
00:18:08.317 --> 00:18:13.252
There's plenty of stuff on
the ISACA website, www.isaca.org.

316
00:18:13.252 --> 00:18:16.130
And I think that's probably a wrap.

317
00:18:16.130 --> 00:18:17.000
>> Very good Mark.

318
00:18:17.000 --> 00:18:19.630
Well heck I think you did a good
job wrapping it up yourself there.

319
00:18:19.630 --> 00:18:25.280
As he said, make sure you guys check
out the CISA study guide a book

320
00:18:25.280 --> 00:18:27.955
written by one of the authors sitting
right here next to me, Mr. Brian O'Hara.

321
00:18:27.955 --> 00:18:30.495
And that is the fourth edition, so
make sure you get that latest one.

322
00:18:30.495 --> 00:18:34.495
So, you get the most current information
to make sure you pass that exam.

323
00:18:34.495 --> 00:18:36.425
We do thank you for
all of that information.

324
00:18:36.425 --> 00:18:37.625
Brian, fantastic stuff.

325
00:18:37.625 --> 00:18:39.785
I hope everybody out
there enjoyed watching.

326
00:18:39.785 --> 00:18:42.715
Signing off for
ITPro.TV I'm Mike Roderick.

327
00:18:42.715 --> 00:18:43.795
>> And I'm Brian O'Hara.

328
00:18:43.795 --> 00:18:46.434
>> And, we'll see you next time.

329
00:18:46.434 --> 00:18:53.849
[MUSIC]

topics.title: The Process of Auditing Information Systems

episodes.title: Governance and Management in IT
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.130 --> 00:00:15.571
>> Hello and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.571 --> 00:00:16.811
I'm your host, Mike Roderick.

4
00:00:16.811 --> 00:00:20.439
And today, we're doing our certified
information systems auditor.

5
00:00:20.439 --> 00:00:25.270
And specifically in this episode,
we're gonna be getting into domain two,

6
00:00:25.270 --> 00:00:29.819
which is gonna deal with governance and
management in the IT framework.

7
00:00:29.819 --> 00:00:33.893
And here with me today
is one of the authors

8
00:00:33.893 --> 00:00:38.674
of the Cibex CISA study guide,
fourth edition.

9
00:00:38.674 --> 00:00:39.794
Mr. Brian O'Hara.

10
00:00:39.794 --> 00:00:41.112
How are you doing, Brian?

11
00:00:41.112 --> 00:00:41.892
>> Good morning, Mike.

12
00:00:41.892 --> 00:00:43.952
Thanks for having me again.

13
00:00:43.952 --> 00:00:47.199
This morning, I'd like to start
talking about domain two.

14
00:00:47.199 --> 00:00:50.319
I wanna dive in to governance and
management of IT.

15
00:00:50.319 --> 00:00:56.348
Domain two is only allocated 16% of
the resources for the CISA exam,

16
00:00:56.348 --> 00:01:01.489
but I believe it's one of
the most underrepresented areas.

17
00:01:01.489 --> 00:01:09.314
Mostly because once your audit
activities have taken place,

18
00:01:09.314 --> 00:01:17.299
the output of those audits is
governance and management of IT.

19
00:01:17.299 --> 00:01:21.621
That's the whole purpose of going
through the audit exercises to provide

20
00:01:21.621 --> 00:01:25.749
information, as input for
the governance and management purposes.

21
00:01:25.749 --> 00:01:29.515
So, I wanted to start off talking just
little bit about those concepts or

22
00:01:29.515 --> 00:01:30.270
constructs.

23
00:01:30.270 --> 00:01:31.665
What is governance?

24
00:01:31.665 --> 00:01:36.046
And how is it structured?

25
00:01:36.046 --> 00:01:37.825
How does it actually
occur inside a company?

26
00:01:37.825 --> 00:01:40.846
Cuz it can take on a whole
lots of different forms.

27
00:01:40.846 --> 00:01:46.802
[COUGH] Basically, governance of IT
really just means putting structures and

28
00:01:46.802 --> 00:01:50.569
mechanisms in place like
steering committees.

29
00:01:50.569 --> 00:01:55.850
We're gonna talk a little bit
more about those in a few minutes

30
00:01:55.850 --> 00:02:00.523
to be able to better manage
the results of audit work and

31
00:02:00.523 --> 00:02:05.211
drive the organization
towards its strategic goals.

32
00:02:05.211 --> 00:02:11.491
We're gonna talk a little bit more
later about the IT strategic plan,

33
00:02:11.491 --> 00:02:16.812
IT architecture and
the differences between strategic and

34
00:02:16.812 --> 00:02:20.019
tactical management objectives.

35
00:02:20.019 --> 00:02:23.725
So again, I wanna go back to talking just
a little bit about what governance is

36
00:02:23.725 --> 00:02:24.649
really all about.

37
00:02:24.649 --> 00:02:29.135
Governance is providing
the oversight necessary for,

38
00:02:29.135 --> 00:02:34.489
especially larger organizations
to manage a lot of moving parts.

39
00:02:34.489 --> 00:02:39.889
One of the terms you hear us talk about
more frequently is a steering committee.

40
00:02:39.889 --> 00:02:42.099
>> What exactly is a steering committee.

41
00:02:42.099 --> 00:02:44.459
It sounds like maybe
they're driving things.

42
00:02:44.459 --> 00:02:48.103
[LAUGH]
>> You made a joke earlier: does it

43
00:02:48.103 --> 00:02:49.899
involve cattle?

44
00:02:49.899 --> 00:02:53.972
No.
A steering committee is really a group of

45
00:02:53.972 --> 00:03:00.109
stakeholders, sometimes at the low
to mid-level of management.

46
00:03:00.109 --> 00:03:01.730
In larger organizations,

47
00:03:01.730 --> 00:03:05.399
it's often composed of higher
level executive management.

48
00:03:05.399 --> 00:03:07.939
It's designed to do exactly that.

49
00:03:07.939 --> 00:03:12.928
Steer IT in the direction that will
help them meet their strategic and

50
00:03:12.928 --> 00:03:16.160
tactical goals, and objectives.

51
00:03:16.160 --> 00:03:20.421
Those goals and
objectives typically will be in line with

52
00:03:20.421 --> 00:03:23.538
the company's overall strategic plan.

53
00:03:23.538 --> 00:03:29.386
Oftentimes, when I see in doing audits
[COUGH] and going into IT organizations.

54
00:03:29.386 --> 00:03:34.181
When I see things run afoul,
it's generally because the IT organization

55
00:03:34.181 --> 00:03:39.051
has gotten sidetracked with doing what
they think is the best IT solution or

56
00:03:39.051 --> 00:03:43.924
the best security solution without
trying to understand what the business

57
00:03:43.924 --> 00:03:47.428
strategy is and
what they're trying to accomplish.

58
00:03:47.428 --> 00:03:52.260
A simpler way of describing it might be.

59
00:03:52.260 --> 00:03:57.338
What does it mean to move
the football down the field?

60
00:03:57.338 --> 00:04:01.463
What are the things that you are doing
that will help accomplish the strategic

61
00:04:01.463 --> 00:04:02.998
goals of the organization?

62
00:04:02.998 --> 00:04:07.288
One of the things, as a side note
about this [COUGH] that a lot of less

63
00:04:07.288 --> 00:04:11.190
experienced auditors don't
understand when they go in and

64
00:04:11.190 --> 00:04:14.934
they ask for, can I see a copy
of your business strategy,

65
00:04:14.934 --> 00:04:20.290
et cetera is trying to understand
executive compensation, for instance.

66
00:04:20.290 --> 00:04:25.088
Executive compensation is oftentimes tied
directly to the company's strategic goals.

67
00:04:25.088 --> 00:04:29.993
So that if those strategic goals are met,
the executives are compensated for

68
00:04:29.993 --> 00:04:31.438
meeting those goals.

69
00:04:31.438 --> 00:04:34.823
So it's really important to understand
that, because that's how you get buy-in

70
00:04:34.823 --> 00:04:37.838
from them when you have an initiative
that you think is really important.

71
00:04:37.838 --> 00:04:42.172
And if it fits with those long-term
strategic goals, you're more likely to get

72
00:04:42.172 --> 00:04:46.138
buy-in by senior management,
because it's going to help them as well.

73
00:04:46.138 --> 00:04:46.978
>> That makes sense.
>> Yeah.

74
00:04:46.978 --> 00:04:50.101
>> [LAUGH]
>> So and then I haven't mentioned yet

75
00:04:50.101 --> 00:04:54.597
talking a little about
the difference between strategic and

76
00:04:54.597 --> 00:04:59.090
tactical, because we're going
to see this come up again and

77
00:04:59.090 --> 00:05:04.578
again when we're talking later on
about organizational structure etc.

78
00:05:04.578 --> 00:05:09.688
Typically, when you're talking strategic
plans, you're talking high-level.

79
00:05:09.688 --> 00:05:13.318
You're talking long range,
three to five years.

80
00:05:13.318 --> 00:05:15.218
Tactical is more short-term.

81
00:05:15.218 --> 00:05:15.878
>> Okay.

82
00:05:15.878 --> 00:05:16.958
>> One year.

83
00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:19.178
One to three years.

84
00:05:19.178 --> 00:05:22.039
And so
when you're talking strategic planning,

85
00:05:22.039 --> 00:05:24.568
you're generally talking about C levels.

86
00:05:24.568 --> 00:05:27.268
They're the ones who set the tone for
your organization.

87
00:05:27.268 --> 00:05:31.288
Typically not always, but typically they
will set the tone for the organization.

88
00:05:31.288 --> 00:05:34.268
They'll setup the strategy for
the company.

89
00:05:34.268 --> 00:05:39.961
The IT strategy and
all the activities around audit and

90
00:05:39.961 --> 00:05:44.178
IT development and acquisition, etc.

91
00:05:44.178 --> 00:05:48.671
Should flow right up into
that larger global company

92
00:05:48.671 --> 00:05:53.378
strategy in order to meet
the company's objectives.

93
00:05:53.378 --> 00:05:57.746
So one of the first things that I do
when I land on autojob is I ask for

94
00:05:57.746 --> 00:06:01.559
a copy of the business's
strategic plan and I also ask for

95
00:06:01.559 --> 00:06:05.708
a copy of the IT strategic plan
to see if A, they even have one.

96
00:06:05.708 --> 00:06:08.628
And me, if they do,
are they in line with each other?

97
00:06:08.628 --> 00:06:14.808
Are they fighting each other, are those
plans completely disconnected, etc.

98
00:06:14.808 --> 00:06:20.001
Let me give you a picture,
let me show you a picture

99
00:06:20.001 --> 00:06:25.948
of the typically the folks
involved at the higher level.

100
00:06:25.948 --> 00:06:27.768
Can you see that okay or
do I need to scroll in?

101
00:06:27.768 --> 00:06:30.426
>> Zoom in just a little, my old eyes.

102
00:06:30.426 --> 00:06:31.166
>> That a little bit better?

103
00:06:31.166 --> 00:06:33.931
>> [LAUGH]
>> You can see there that the staring

104
00:06:33.931 --> 00:06:38.014
committee is at the top level along
with the CEO, the Project sponsor,

105
00:06:38.014 --> 00:06:39.118
the CFO and the CO.

106
00:06:39.118 --> 00:06:43.901
Typically, this is the level where
your strategic planning is occurring,

107
00:06:43.901 --> 00:06:49.350
because it needs to have the folks who
have the vision and the direct ties.

108
00:06:49.350 --> 00:06:51.440
For instance,
if it's a publicly traded company,

109
00:06:51.440 --> 00:06:55.220
to shareholders, et cetera in terms
of what they've been tasked to do.

110
00:06:55.220 --> 00:06:58.828
So, this is the strategic level
we're talking about here.

111
00:06:58.828 --> 00:07:00.968
Let me move on now.

112
00:07:00.968 --> 00:07:04.028
We can close that out.

113
00:07:04.028 --> 00:07:06.888
Give me just one second here.

114
00:07:06.888 --> 00:07:11.389
>> [LAUGH] And that kinda falls in line
with some of the stuff we've talked about

115
00:07:11.389 --> 00:07:15.390
like in project management, for
example, where we see that it's

116
00:07:15.390 --> 00:07:19.908
the higher ups as you said, the C
levels that have that long-term vision.

117
00:07:19.908 --> 00:07:24.398
They know where the company's going where
it wants to be in five years, ten years.

118
00:07:24.398 --> 00:07:27.798
IT down in the trenches,
we're dealing with the day to day stuff.

119
00:07:27.798 --> 00:07:29.996
Our goals are more about
the end of the week,

120
00:07:29.996 --> 00:07:33.748
tomorrow that kind of thing month to
month and really getting the job done.

121
00:07:33.748 --> 00:07:38.718
But if those goals aren't in line with the
overall strategy that the C-level people

122
00:07:38.718 --> 00:07:43.276
wanna see the company in In five years,
then we're never going to get there.

123
00:07:43.276 --> 00:07:45.376
>> Exactly, exactly.

124
00:07:45.376 --> 00:07:51.588
I got one other diagram I wanna bring
up here really quick and show you.

125
00:07:51.588 --> 00:07:52.671
Can you see that okay?

126
00:07:52.671 --> 00:07:54.796
>> Can you zoom in just a hair and
we can scroll up and down maybe.

127
00:07:54.796 --> 00:07:57.570
>> Yeah, there we go.

128
00:07:57.570 --> 00:08:00.856
>> There we go I like that.

129
00:08:00.856 --> 00:08:02.360
Doesn't seem to want to scroll for
some reason.

130
00:08:02.360 --> 00:08:04.241
>> Of course, eh computers,
they never play along nicely.

131
00:08:04.241 --> 00:08:04.867
>> All right.

132
00:08:04.867 --> 00:08:08.314
[LAUGH]
>> So anyway, basically this is just a,

133
00:08:08.314 --> 00:08:09.847
sort of an outline.

134
00:08:09.847 --> 00:08:14.250
This graph, by the way, is in the book
in chapter six I believe it is,

135
00:08:15.950 --> 00:08:19.050
it's called, titled,
The Steering Committee Process.

136
00:08:19.050 --> 00:08:22.338
And it gives you kind of
an idea of the tactical or

137
00:08:22.338 --> 00:08:27.369
daily functional activities that
happen inside a steering committee.

138
00:08:27.369 --> 00:08:30.968
And we talk about things in here
like business continuity planning,

139
00:08:30.968 --> 00:08:33.451
business process re-engineering strategy,

140
00:08:33.451 --> 00:08:37.547
and steering committee member review
analysis, board of directors review,

141
00:08:37.547 --> 00:08:41.658
executive review, stuff like that, so
I'm gonna go ahead and pull out that.

142
00:08:41.658 --> 00:08:42.193
>> All right.

143
00:08:42.193 --> 00:08:42.889
>> Thanks.

144
00:08:42.889 --> 00:08:46.574
So I guess what I'm trying to convey is

145
00:08:46.574 --> 00:08:52.080
that governance is
a company-wide activity.

146
00:08:52.080 --> 00:08:56.190
It typically involves senior level
management all the way down to

147
00:08:56.190 --> 00:08:57.019
field staff.

148
00:08:58.340 --> 00:09:03.810
The more tactical operations typically
occur from the director level down.

149
00:09:03.810 --> 00:09:08.300
And ISACA does have kind of a habit
in their exam prep material and

150
00:09:08.300 --> 00:09:14.750
in the exam of thinking only
of very large organizations.

151
00:09:14.750 --> 00:09:18.938
Keep in mind that ISACA is
an international organization with over

152
00:09:18.938 --> 00:09:21.590
118,000 members worldwide.

153
00:09:21.590 --> 00:09:29.120
So the work that goes into
the domain preparation materials for

154
00:09:29.120 --> 00:09:34.360
the CSA exam is built and

155
00:09:34.360 --> 00:09:37.640
comes off of the work of that
international organization.

156
00:09:37.640 --> 00:09:41.320
So they typically are looking at and
describing very large organizations.

157
00:09:41.320 --> 00:09:44.608
If you go into, excuse me,
if you go into, for instance,

158
00:09:44.608 --> 00:09:51.200
even a medium-size bank
of 10 billion in assets,

159
00:09:51.200 --> 00:09:55.420
that's not a bank that
might run four states.

160
00:09:55.420 --> 00:09:58.890
That's a large community bank.

161
00:09:58.890 --> 00:10:02.040
Typically, their steering committee
does not always include senior

162
00:10:02.040 --> 00:10:02.810
level management.

163
00:10:02.810 --> 00:10:07.550
It may include an information security
manager, because those people,

164
00:10:07.550 --> 00:10:11.900
there's fewer layers between senior
management and the field staff.

165
00:10:11.900 --> 00:10:13.020
>> Yeah, that's what I was gonna say.

166
00:10:13.020 --> 00:10:16.670
Your small organizations,
you've got people wearing many hats, so-

167
00:10:16.670 --> 00:10:17.630
>> That's correct.

168
00:10:17.630 --> 00:10:20.100
>> Those upper level and
lower level, are the same people.

169
00:10:20.100 --> 00:10:21.610
So they know what's going on.

170
00:10:21.610 --> 00:10:25.570
But as we grow, and
as we get the separation between those,

171
00:10:25.570 --> 00:10:28.990
that's when it's extremely important
to make sure we have these plans, so

172
00:10:28.990 --> 00:10:31.930
we can all stay on the same page.

173
00:10:31.930 --> 00:10:34.193
>> Right, exactly.

174
00:10:34.193 --> 00:10:37.590
In fact, in smaller health care
organizations, often times,

175
00:10:37.590 --> 00:10:40.940
the privacy officer and
the security officer are the same person,

176
00:10:40.940 --> 00:10:42.880
they may not even share
a different [INAUDIBLE].

177
00:10:42.880 --> 00:10:45.970
Same thing with medium sized banks,

178
00:10:45.970 --> 00:10:50.940
the IT Director may also be the
information security officer for the bank.

179
00:10:50.940 --> 00:10:54.480
So you're right,
they tend to wear many different hats.

180
00:10:57.150 --> 00:11:01.180
So I can't emphasize enough,
studying up about the differences between

181
00:11:02.530 --> 00:11:07.120
strategic and tactical, and the
differences between a strategic plan and

182
00:11:07.120 --> 00:11:11.800
a tactical plan,
you'll need to know the timeframes,

183
00:11:11.800 --> 00:11:16.590
strategic plans being three to five years,
tactical being one to three.

184
00:11:16.590 --> 00:11:19.960
Those are things that
are going to be on the exam,

185
00:11:19.960 --> 00:11:23.000
you're gonna be expected to know that.

186
00:11:23.000 --> 00:11:23.760
>> What are you gonna do,

187
00:11:23.760 --> 00:11:25.880
knock on the board like
the teacher used to do at school?

188
00:11:25.880 --> 00:11:27.340
This is important, write this down, right?

189
00:11:27.340 --> 00:11:27.940
>> Yeah, exactly.

190
00:11:27.940 --> 00:11:29.546
>> Make sure you-
>> Wink, wink, wink.

191
00:11:29.546 --> 00:11:32.190
That's what I would say, wink, wink.

192
00:11:32.190 --> 00:11:35.010
So the steering community
can actually look

193
00:11:35.010 --> 00:11:39.240
very different depending on
the organization that you are working in.

194
00:11:39.240 --> 00:11:44.390
It can be as simple as three or
four people in mid tier management

195
00:11:44.390 --> 00:11:49.830
who report to the CEO, or it could be
the CEO, CFO, CIO depending on whether or

196
00:11:49.830 --> 00:11:54.030
not you have those level of
folks in your organization.

197
00:11:54.030 --> 00:11:59.981
I wanna talk now, just for a minute, about

198
00:12:04.485 --> 00:12:07.320
Sarbanes-Oxley.

199
00:12:07.320 --> 00:12:08.900
I wanna take a little
bit of a shift here and

200
00:12:08.900 --> 00:12:11.775
talk about how governance
plays into all that.

201
00:12:11.775 --> 00:12:14.010
Sarbanes-Oxley, or SOX,

202
00:12:14.010 --> 00:12:19.830
as it's typically called, came out of
the Enron scandal back in the early 2000s.

203
00:12:19.830 --> 00:12:23.280
Actually, it was in 2000, prior to 9/11.

204
00:12:23.280 --> 00:12:29.990
There was a huge fraud that was
perpetrated by the company.

205
00:12:29.990 --> 00:12:34.020
And as a result to that,
the Sarbanes-Oxley Act was passed,

206
00:12:34.020 --> 00:12:41.090
which now requires all publicly traded
organizations to establish these processes

207
00:12:41.090 --> 00:12:44.530
that I'm talking about, governance,
steering committees, all of that stuff.

208
00:12:44.530 --> 00:12:48.770
Those are all required now by law,
by any company that is publicly traded.

209
00:12:48.770 --> 00:12:53.050
Lots of folks tend to think
that publicly traded companies

210
00:12:53.050 --> 00:12:55.440
are a great big giant corporation.

211
00:12:55.440 --> 00:12:57.450
That's not always the case.

212
00:12:57.450 --> 00:13:01.120
I worked with a bank, two years ago,
that was simply one location,

213
00:13:01.120 --> 00:13:03.960
that didn't even have a branch,
publicly traded company.

214
00:13:05.230 --> 00:13:09.400
We typically call them penny stocks,
etc., but those companies,

215
00:13:09.400 --> 00:13:13.270
once they make the decision that
they wanna be publicly traded, and

216
00:13:13.270 --> 00:13:19.330
they put shares up for sale,
they fall under the Sarbanes-Oxley act,

217
00:13:19.330 --> 00:13:24.000
and are therefore required
to have these structures in

218
00:13:24.000 --> 00:13:28.130
place in order to provide governance and
oversight for their operations,

219
00:13:28.130 --> 00:13:33.530
just to prevent, hopefully, another
incident like Enron from happening again.

220
00:13:33.530 --> 00:13:35.640
That hasn't happened to
date that we know of.

221
00:13:35.640 --> 00:13:39.552
There have been other financial crisis
that we're all very familiar with.

222
00:13:39.552 --> 00:13:43.690
But that key one has not
happened since that time.

223
00:13:43.690 --> 00:13:48.520
So I wanna talk about, that's just one of
the sort of incidents over the last 20 or

224
00:13:48.520 --> 00:13:51.740
30 years that has really
begun to drive this.

225
00:13:51.740 --> 00:13:56.340
In addition to that,
more recently, there have been,

226
00:13:56.340 --> 00:14:00.590
I believe it was the Target
breach that you may or

227
00:14:00.590 --> 00:14:04.990
may not have read about a year or
two ago, where

228
00:14:06.850 --> 00:14:11.250
liability now has been
held to the board level.

229
00:14:11.250 --> 00:14:17.150
To the point that share holders
on the target corporation have,

230
00:14:17.150 --> 00:14:20.480
I don't know that they've been successful,
but several of them have filed

231
00:14:20.480 --> 00:14:25.310
class action share holder suits
against the corporation for not

232
00:14:25.310 --> 00:14:30.840
following due diligence in governance and
oversight to have prevented that attack.

233
00:14:30.840 --> 00:14:36.180
So now, it's no longer a case of,
well, I'm just the CEO.

234
00:14:36.180 --> 00:14:39.140
I'm protected because it's a corporation.

235
00:14:39.140 --> 00:14:41.330
You can see the corp,
but you can't see me.

236
00:14:41.330 --> 00:14:42.500
That's not the case anymore.

237
00:14:42.500 --> 00:14:47.325
They're actually able to go after board
members and officers of a corporation.

238
00:14:47.325 --> 00:14:50.090
And so,
what you're seeing today is much more

239
00:14:50.090 --> 00:14:53.490
emphasis on direct board involvement
in the governance process.

240
00:14:54.990 --> 00:14:58.280
I see it much more in banking than
anywhere else because they're so

241
00:14:58.280 --> 00:15:01.450
closely tied to the financial
system infrastructure

242
00:15:01.450 --> 00:15:03.980
that the government keeps
extremely close tabs on them.

243
00:15:05.270 --> 00:15:07.133
For instance, go ahead [CROSSTALK].

244
00:15:07.133 --> 00:15:09.247
>> Yeah, I was thinking a good
thing in the end though,

245
00:15:09.247 --> 00:15:11.750
having a little more
accountability at that C level.

246
00:15:11.750 --> 00:15:14.927
>> It is, it is actually, and
it's actually begun to drive change,

247
00:15:14.927 --> 00:15:17.962
if I can give you a couple more,
sort of war stories [CROSSTALK].

248
00:15:17.962 --> 00:15:18.682
>> Yeah, absolutely.

249
00:15:18.682 --> 00:15:24.452
>> I had a vice president of a bank
a couple of years ago, I won't say where,

250
00:15:24.452 --> 00:15:30.227
who sort of came unglued at some of my
audit results that had to do with some

251
00:15:30.227 --> 00:15:36.550
very serious security problems that I
felt needed to be addressed in the bank.

252
00:15:36.550 --> 00:15:39.290
One of them had to do with,
it's kind of an off subject, but

253
00:15:39.290 --> 00:15:43.690
it had to do with user access control,
the little sign on Windows 7 and

254
00:15:43.690 --> 00:15:47.230
10 that beeps up when you go to try
to install a piece of software.

255
00:15:47.230 --> 00:15:50.393
He didn't like it so
he told the IT department to turn it off.

256
00:15:50.393 --> 00:15:53.273
And he's the CEO, so you do what the CEO-
>> They turned it off, right?

257
00:15:53.273 --> 00:15:54.758
>> They turned it off on their base image,

258
00:15:54.758 --> 00:15:57.058
which means that every machine
in the bank had it turned off.

259
00:15:57.058 --> 00:15:57.696
>> Wow.

260
00:15:57.696 --> 00:16:00.739
>> Yeah, exactly,
which is a huge security problem.

261
00:16:00.739 --> 00:16:04.730
It's going around your controls.

262
00:16:04.730 --> 00:16:08.480
And he didn't like hearing that and
I said, well you may not like hearing it.

263
00:16:08.480 --> 00:16:09.800
But when the FDIC comes in and

264
00:16:09.800 --> 00:16:12.530
sees it, you're going to get
called on the carpet about it.

265
00:16:12.530 --> 00:16:16.020
And sure enough,
he got called on the carpet about it.

266
00:16:16.020 --> 00:16:17.970
>> Wow.
>> But I was just an external vendor and,

267
00:16:17.970 --> 00:16:21.479
but I mean, he really kind of
came unglued at me about it.

268
00:16:22.700 --> 00:16:27.450
And so today, when you work in that bank,
the UAC's turned off.

269
00:16:27.450 --> 00:16:28.870
>> You still see it, yeah.

270
00:16:28.870 --> 00:16:29.470
Or you see it now.

271
00:16:29.470 --> 00:16:30.200
>> No, it's turned on now.

272
00:16:30.200 --> 00:16:31.460
The UAC's turned on now.

273
00:16:31.460 --> 00:16:32.770
Yeah, they fixed that.

274
00:16:32.770 --> 00:16:38.100
And the reason, again, is because the
federal government, the FDIC and FFIC and

275
00:16:38.100 --> 00:16:42.980
the regulatory agencies in
banking are enforcing that now.

276
00:16:42.980 --> 00:16:44.740
>> Mm.
>> That the board must be aware,

277
00:16:44.740 --> 00:16:47.405
they must be involved in
the Steering Committee process.

278
00:16:47.405 --> 00:16:48.140
>> Uh-huh.

279
00:16:48.140 --> 00:16:52.140
>> They must be involved in completing
their fiduciary responsibilities to

280
00:16:52.140 --> 00:16:53.400
their shareholders.

281
00:16:53.400 --> 00:16:56.200
>> To ensure that those adequate
types of controls are in place.

282
00:16:56.200 --> 00:17:00.140
>> So no more hiding behind I'm the CEO
and I don't see the daily stuff.

283
00:17:00.140 --> 00:17:01.840
>> Well, or, that was ITs problem.

284
00:17:01.840 --> 00:17:06.670
It's not ITs problem anymore, it's a
company problem and it's a board problem.

285
00:17:06.670 --> 00:17:07.830
>> Very good.

286
00:17:07.830 --> 00:17:11.830
>> The good side of that is, you now have
>> stakeholders with

287
00:17:11.830 --> 00:17:16.470
resources at your finger tips to be able
to get project initiatives started and

288
00:17:16.470 --> 00:17:19.490
funded well and get things accomplished.

289
00:17:19.490 --> 00:17:20.170
>> Very good.

290
00:17:21.270 --> 00:17:22.650
>> So, excuse me.

291
00:17:22.650 --> 00:17:25.890
So I just want to talk about Sarbanes
Oxley because it was a pretty big deal

292
00:17:25.890 --> 00:17:30.800
in terms of how it changed the way
that we view governance and

293
00:17:30.800 --> 00:17:31.990
view board involvement.

294
00:17:33.000 --> 00:17:35.730
I can make a comment too about HIPAA.

295
00:17:35.730 --> 00:17:40.710
In the HIPAA regulations today it's very
clear, very clearly stated in their senior

296
00:17:40.710 --> 00:17:45.390
management must be involved in
the risk assessment process, and

297
00:17:45.390 --> 00:17:50.620
in all the governance activities that take
place within the healthcare organization.

298
00:17:50.620 --> 00:17:56.550
Now, that culture still hasn't come
to full fruition in healthcare.

299
00:17:56.550 --> 00:18:00.140
They tend to still be kinda dragging
their feet just a little bit.

300
00:18:00.140 --> 00:18:05.270
Banking on the other hand has been heavily
regulated for well over 50 or 60 years.

301
00:18:05.270 --> 00:18:08.080
So to them it's just okay
what do we gotta do now?

302
00:18:08.080 --> 00:18:09.910
>> Another regulation that
we have to deal with.

303
00:18:09.910 --> 00:18:12.490
>> What do we have to change to
make sure that we meet the rules?

304
00:18:12.490 --> 00:18:14.700
And they're beginning to understand and
see it.

305
00:18:14.700 --> 00:18:18.310
It's actually kind of rewarding to
go in and do some audit work, and

306
00:18:18.310 --> 00:18:21.395
actually have a CEO ask
an intelligent question.

307
00:18:21.395 --> 00:18:24.670
>> [LAUGH]
>> And be engaged in the process.

308
00:18:24.670 --> 00:18:25.880
Because in the past, they wouldn't have.

309
00:18:25.880 --> 00:18:27.580
They would have just come in and
stomped their feet,

310
00:18:27.580 --> 00:18:30.290
and said why are you charging me so
much money?

311
00:18:30.290 --> 00:18:31.366
>> And yadda, yadda, yadda.

312
00:18:31.366 --> 00:18:33.286
And so.

313
00:18:33.286 --> 00:18:37.386
>> [LAUGH] Now for this particular exam
we've talked about a couple of these

314
00:18:37.386 --> 00:18:40.220
different, the HIPAA, the Sarbanes-Oxley.

315
00:18:40.220 --> 00:18:44.075
Do we need to be familiar with the details
of those types of regulations?

316
00:18:44.075 --> 00:18:46.395
And what they entail and what they state?

317
00:18:46.395 --> 00:18:49.435
Or is it more about just being familiar
with the fact that they're there and.

318
00:18:49.435 --> 00:18:51.135
>> Yeah that's a great question, Mike.

319
00:18:51.135 --> 00:18:54.905
No you do not have to know the details
of any of those for the exam.

320
00:18:54.905 --> 00:18:58.687
You won't be questioned on any of
their their specific regulations.

321
00:18:58.687 --> 00:19:00.917
But you do need to be
aware of what they are.

322
00:19:00.917 --> 00:19:05.437
Those are the ones where you may
see a question or two, wink wink,

323
00:19:05.437 --> 00:19:09.567
where they throw a term like that at
you and it's clearly a wrong answer.

324
00:19:09.567 --> 00:19:11.497
You do not have to know
the details of that.

325
00:19:11.497 --> 00:19:15.627
In fact, one of the things we'll talk
on in a future sessions is COBIT,

326
00:19:15.627 --> 00:19:22.760
which is an Isaca Policy framework that
stands for control objectives for it.

327
00:19:22.760 --> 00:19:25.920
Been around for 40 or 50 years now.

328
00:19:25.920 --> 00:19:28.620
You will not have to know
the details of that either.

329
00:19:28.620 --> 00:19:29.240
>> Okay.

330
00:19:29.240 --> 00:19:31.860
>> But you will you will need
to be able to spot the name and

331
00:19:31.860 --> 00:19:33.990
understand what it means.

332
00:19:33.990 --> 00:19:35.530
Beyond that I can't say much more though.

333
00:19:35.530 --> 00:19:36.030
>> Okay very good.

334
00:19:36.030 --> 00:19:37.110
>> Yeah.
Very good.

335
00:19:37.110 --> 00:19:39.060
>> So that pretty much wraps it up for
this episode.

336
00:19:39.060 --> 00:19:40.870
I just wanted to talk about, again,

337
00:19:40.870 --> 00:19:45.990
as I mentioned it's only 16%
of the questions on the exam.

338
00:19:45.990 --> 00:19:50.470
But, to me, it's one of the most
important pieces, because you know all

339
00:19:50.470 --> 00:19:54.560
of your audit work revolves around the
steering committee and those activities.

340
00:19:54.560 --> 00:19:57.250
They're the ones who set
up the audit charter.

341
00:19:57.250 --> 00:19:58.870
We talked about it in a previous episode.

342
00:19:58.870 --> 00:20:00.310
They set the audit schedule.

343
00:20:01.380 --> 00:20:05.960
They're the ones who
will be responsible for

344
00:20:05.960 --> 00:20:08.930
the follow up that we talked about
in one of the previous episodes,

345
00:20:08.930 --> 00:20:11.730
about how important it is to,
when you complete your audit,

346
00:20:11.730 --> 00:20:15.220
to set up follow up with them for
30, 60, and 90 days.

347
00:20:15.220 --> 00:20:18.240
So you can go back and actually see and
track whether or not they're

348
00:20:18.240 --> 00:20:23.200
making progress on addressing the findings
that came out in the audit and etcetera.

349
00:20:23.200 --> 00:20:24.200
So.

350
00:20:24.200 --> 00:20:27.630
>> All right Brian, a lot of great
information there as we dive into domain

351
00:20:27.630 --> 00:20:30.600
two, Governance and Management of IT.

352
00:20:30.600 --> 00:20:34.600
And remember, if you guys want to get any
more in depth information on the topics

353
00:20:34.600 --> 00:20:39.710
we're discussing, go get your copy
of the Sybex CISA Study Guide,

354
00:20:39.710 --> 00:20:44.900
fourth edition of which Brian O'Hara is
one of the authors, so check that out.

355
00:20:44.900 --> 00:20:47.910
All right, hope everybody out
there enjoyed watching this one.

356
00:20:47.910 --> 00:20:51.110
Signing off for ITPro TV,
I'm Mike Roderick.

357
00:20:51.110 --> 00:20:52.150
>> And I'm Brian O'Hara.

358
00:20:52.150 --> 00:20:54.407
And we'll see you next time.

00:17:39.060 --> 00:17:43.024

00:17:43.024 --> 00:17:47.416
We set a user's password

00:17:47.416 --> 00:17:52.542

00:18:03.340 --> 00:18:06.110
So it's a good idea to keep

information, a little more in depth

475
00:26:47.630 --> 00:26:52.150
coverage on these topics, go out and
grab a copy of the Cybex CISA

476
00:26:52.150 --> 00:26:56.490
study guide fourth edition, of which
Bryan O'Hara is one of the authors.

477
00:26:56.490 --> 00:26:58.730
So go get that, take a look at that.

478
00:26:58.730 --> 00:27:01.160
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

479
00:27:01.160 --> 00:27:03.864
Signing off for IT Pro TV,
I'm Mike Roderick.

480
00:27:03.864 --> 00:27:05.350
>> And I'm Brian O'Hara.

481
00:27:05.350 --> 00:27:06.290
>> And we'll see you next time.

482
00:27:06.290 --> 00:27:15.360
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Governance and Management in IT Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.163 --> 00:00:15.071
Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.071 --> 00:00:17.470
I'm your host, Mike Roderick, and today,

4
00:00:17.470 --> 00:00:20.740
we're doing our certified
information systems auditor.

5
00:00:20.740 --> 00:00:23.830
And specifically in this episode,
this is actually a part three, so

6
00:00:23.830 --> 00:00:28.700
we're continuing on our look at
governance and management in IT.

7
00:00:28.700 --> 00:00:32.140
And with me today is one of
the authors of the Sybex,

8
00:00:32.140 --> 00:00:36.230
CISA, study guide,
fourth edition, Mr. Brian O'Hara.

9
00:00:36.230 --> 00:00:37.900
How you doing, Brian?

10
00:00:37.900 --> 00:00:38.660
>> Good, Mike, thanks.

11
00:00:40.550 --> 00:00:43.910
So, for this session today
we're gonna cover three or

12
00:00:43.910 --> 00:00:48.390
four key points that are in the chapter,
in the book on governance and

13
00:00:48.390 --> 00:00:53.590
management of IT as well as covered in
some of the study materials you can get

14
00:00:53.590 --> 00:00:58.020
from the ISACA website at www.isaca.org.

15
00:00:58.020 --> 00:01:02.200
The first couple are, I'd like to start
off with sort of a general conversation

16
00:01:02.200 --> 00:01:05.260
about regulatory requirements so

17
00:01:05.260 --> 00:01:09.800
that the folks watching at home,
or wherever they happen to be,

18
00:01:09.800 --> 00:01:13.580
become a little bit more familiar and
comfortable with the terms.

19
00:01:13.580 --> 00:01:16.170
I'm sure most all of you
have either heard these or

20
00:01:16.170 --> 00:01:20.210
maybe you know already what they're about
and have some in depth understanding.

21
00:01:20.210 --> 00:01:23.860
But it's important that you
be able to identify and

22
00:01:23.860 --> 00:01:29.740
be able to understand the context of
them in the realm of IT audit and,

23
00:01:29.740 --> 00:01:33.580
more importantly, why they are important.

24
00:01:33.580 --> 00:01:36.830
Because any organization
that has any type of

25
00:01:38.620 --> 00:01:42.310
regulatory requirements is gonna probably
fall into one of these four areas.

26
00:01:42.310 --> 00:01:46.160
>> So Brian, these are different from our
organization requirements that we might

27
00:01:46.160 --> 00:01:47.080
have in place already?

28
00:01:47.080 --> 00:01:47.640
>> That's right.

29
00:01:47.640 --> 00:01:49.780
That's right.
The organization requirements generally

30
00:01:49.780 --> 00:01:52.330
are things that senior
management have felt

31
00:01:52.330 --> 00:01:56.540
are necessary in order to help the
business achieve their strategic goals.

32
00:01:56.540 --> 00:01:58.280
These may be some of the same, but

33
00:01:58.280 --> 00:02:01.730
they may also be different depending
on the nature of their business.

34
00:02:01.730 --> 00:02:05.380
One example might be in a health care
setting where the first one I'm going to

35
00:02:05.380 --> 00:02:10.380
talk about, PCI or the Payment Card
Industry Council, requirements

36
00:02:10.380 --> 00:02:15.650
while they are not statutory in nature,
they are contractual in nature.

37
00:02:15.650 --> 00:02:19.870
So we still consider them
regulatory-like requirements.

38
00:02:19.870 --> 00:02:25.340
A health care organization, for
instance, may have organizational needs

39
00:02:25.340 --> 00:02:29.850
to protect information that go above and
beyond PCI.

40
00:02:29.850 --> 00:02:33.840
But they're concerned with PCI as well,
because that's how they

41
00:02:33.840 --> 00:02:38.830
accept co-payments from patients,
that's how

42
00:02:38.830 --> 00:02:43.800
they receive payments over the phone for,
I guess what you'd call co-payments.

43
00:02:43.800 --> 00:02:47.800
The rest of your deductibles for
payment services, that kind of stuff.

44
00:02:47.800 --> 00:02:51.130
So the first term payment card
industry council requirements

45
00:02:51.130 --> 00:02:54.423
are really contractual in
nature they are not statutory.

46
00:02:54.423 --> 00:02:56.030
But again it's important
that we talk about them,

47
00:02:56.030 --> 00:03:01.082
because you can go almost nowhere today
where any type of commerce occurs where

48
00:03:01.082 --> 00:03:05.260
you aren't going to use your credit card
or debit card or something of that nature.

49
00:03:05.260 --> 00:03:09.670
So it's important that you understand
what the standards are and

50
00:03:09.670 --> 00:03:14.350
sort of a fundamental understanding of
the requirements, which are to protect and

51
00:03:14.350 --> 00:03:18.380
we will talk about in the last
few episodes of the series,

52
00:03:18.380 --> 00:03:20.660
we'll talk about protecting
information assets.

53
00:03:20.660 --> 00:03:23.270
But it's really about protecting

54
00:03:23.270 --> 00:03:27.180
cardholders from having their
information compromised in any way.

55
00:03:28.990 --> 00:03:32.120
So the second group that I'd
like to talk about is HIPPA or

56
00:03:32.120 --> 00:03:37.310
the Health Information Privacy Portability
and Accountability Act.

57
00:03:38.700 --> 00:03:41.190
The HIPPA act was
originally passed back in

58
00:03:41.190 --> 00:03:43.650
the mid 90s during
the Clinton Administration.

59
00:03:43.650 --> 00:03:47.215
In its early days was really designed
around allowing people to be able

60
00:03:47.215 --> 00:03:52.030
to move from job to job without
losing insurance coverage.

61
00:03:52.030 --> 00:03:56.220
It's become much more of a behemoth
today with both a security and

62
00:03:56.220 --> 00:04:01.860
privacy rule that govern requirements
around healthcare systems.

63
00:04:01.860 --> 00:04:06.080
How healthcare data is handled,
and managed, and protected.

64
00:04:07.830 --> 00:04:09.649
So it is statutory in nature.

65
00:04:11.320 --> 00:04:16.420
HIPPA is an act, that's what the last
A in the HIPPA stands for is Act.

66
00:04:16.420 --> 00:04:20.560
It is a federal regulation promulgated
down through the Department of Health and

67
00:04:20.560 --> 00:04:21.950
Human Services.

68
00:04:21.950 --> 00:04:25.970
You don't need to know all that for the
ISACA exam, but it's just important that

69
00:04:25.970 --> 00:04:30.710
you have some familiarity with who the
organization is that manages all that and

70
00:04:30.710 --> 00:04:34.190
some of what their regulatory
requirements are about.

71
00:04:34.190 --> 00:04:39.910
One of the interesting things I always
find about HIPAA is that they have,

72
00:04:39.910 --> 00:04:44.640
we talked in one of the previous episodes
a little bit about administrative and

73
00:04:44.640 --> 00:04:49.710
technical and physical types of safeguards
is what it's called in healthcare, or

74
00:04:49.710 --> 00:04:51.430
control mechanisms.

75
00:04:51.430 --> 00:04:56.560
And in addition to that,
those safeguards have attributes

76
00:04:56.560 --> 00:05:03.580
under the HIPAA regulations that say that
they're either required or addressable.

77
00:05:03.580 --> 00:05:04.950
This one is really kind of interesting.

78
00:05:04.950 --> 00:05:05.990
It's a little sidenote.

79
00:05:05.990 --> 00:05:07.880
You don't have to know this for the exam.

80
00:05:07.880 --> 00:05:09.140
But again, it's good to know.

81
00:05:09.140 --> 00:05:10.390
And that is that,

82
00:05:10.390 --> 00:05:14.990
if something is addressable that does
not mean that it's not required.

83
00:05:14.990 --> 00:05:17.720
It just means that if
you decide not to do it

84
00:05:17.720 --> 00:05:22.490
you had better have good reasons
not to and have it documented.

85
00:05:22.490 --> 00:05:26.810
And a perfect example is,
folks again this is not on the test, so

86
00:05:26.810 --> 00:05:30.980
ixnay on the writing this
down if you don't want to.

87
00:05:30.980 --> 00:05:36.280
Encryption of data at rest is not
required under HIPAA regulations,

88
00:05:36.280 --> 00:05:38.840
however it is addressable.

89
00:05:38.840 --> 00:05:39.530
Which means,

90
00:05:39.530 --> 00:05:44.280
if you don't encrypt your data at rest,
you better have a good reason, and

91
00:05:44.280 --> 00:05:47.870
it better be documented or you're going
to get called on the carpet for it later.

92
00:05:47.870 --> 00:05:48.390
>> Interesting.

93
00:05:48.390 --> 00:05:53.080
>> So, yeah, it is, it's an interesting
form that really only seems to apply.

94
00:05:53.080 --> 00:05:57.130
I'm not sure who came up with, or why,
or how they came up with that kind of

95
00:05:57.130 --> 00:06:00.660
language but it's really interesting
in that they call it addressable,

96
00:06:00.660 --> 00:06:05.330
but it really means is,
it's required but if you can

97
00:06:05.330 --> 00:06:09.500
justify not doing it you can get away with
it but you better have really good reason.

98
00:06:09.500 --> 00:06:13.400
Because it's the first thing I'm gonna
look at is how many of these requirements

99
00:06:13.400 --> 00:06:15.100
that are addressable have you not done?

100
00:06:15.100 --> 00:06:15.850
>> Right.

101
00:06:15.850 --> 00:06:16.810
>> And, I wanna see the documentation.

102
00:06:16.810 --> 00:06:20.034
>> Are you spending all of your time
trying to meet these addressable issues or

103
00:06:20.034 --> 00:06:23.359
are you spending all of your time coming
up with excuses to avoid having to deal

104
00:06:23.359 --> 00:06:23.937
with those?

105
00:06:23.937 --> 00:06:24.808
>> For why you're not.

106
00:06:24.808 --> 00:06:25.957
>> Yes.

107
00:06:25.957 --> 00:06:29.848
So I would think you'd want them to, if
you're avoiding every single one of them,

108
00:06:29.848 --> 00:06:31.165
yeah something's wrong.

109
00:06:31.165 --> 00:06:32.580
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, exactly.

110
00:06:32.580 --> 00:06:33.370
Exactly.

111
00:06:33.370 --> 00:06:36.450
So again that's just a little
side note piece of information.

112
00:06:36.450 --> 00:06:39.090
It's not gonna be on the test or
anything like that.

113
00:06:40.690 --> 00:06:44.718
Another group of regulatory
requirements fall under what's

114
00:06:44.718 --> 00:06:47.050
called the Gramm Leach Bliley Act.

115
00:06:47.050 --> 00:06:50.487
GLBA is what we call it in banking for
short, because if you try and

116
00:06:50.487 --> 00:06:52.800
say Gramm Leach Bliley
three times in a row,

117
00:06:52.800 --> 00:06:55.655
you'll probably spit your
tongue out on the street.

118
00:06:55.655 --> 00:06:57.675
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's a mouthful.

119
00:06:57.675 --> 00:07:00.990
But the Gramm Leach Bliley Act is the act,

120
00:07:00.990 --> 00:07:05.500
I don't recall at the moment
the exact year it was passed, but

121
00:07:05.500 --> 00:07:11.170
it actually requires banks to have
an official information security program.

122
00:07:11.170 --> 00:07:11.990
It's called the ISP.

123
00:07:11.990 --> 00:07:14.250
It's absolutely required under the law.

124
00:07:14.250 --> 00:07:17.910
It's not optional,
it's not addressable, it is required.

125
00:07:17.910 --> 00:07:22.990
And there are certain standards and
guidelines listed in that

126
00:07:24.190 --> 00:07:28.630
as well as strong recommendations
about certain types of policies.

127
00:07:28.630 --> 00:07:33.560
The act, much like the HIPAA act,
calls out that the bank

128
00:07:33.560 --> 00:07:38.750
must in fact name a security officer for
the organization.

129
00:07:38.750 --> 00:07:42.971
Doesn't say what their qualifications
need to be, or anything like that, but

130
00:07:42.971 --> 00:07:44.361
there must be a named one.

131
00:07:44.361 --> 00:07:50.891
Now, one of the interesting things in
banking that's a little bit different

132
00:07:50.891 --> 00:07:57.722
than in healthcare is that in banking very
clearly in the GLBA regs it calls out and

133
00:07:57.722 --> 00:08:01.841
states that the organization Must,
not shall,

134
00:08:01.841 --> 00:08:07.469
must provide adequate resources
including financial in order for

135
00:08:07.469 --> 00:08:13.620
the security officer to carry
out the functions of their job.

136
00:08:13.620 --> 00:08:14.410
>> Interesting
>> So

137
00:08:14.410 --> 00:08:18.230
what that means is, if i'm an FDIC
auditor, and I come in to your bank and

138
00:08:18.230 --> 00:08:24.050
I find that your security officer can't
get his or her initiatives accomplished

139
00:08:24.050 --> 00:08:27.610
because they're not being funded by the
board, the board's gonna get written up.

140
00:08:27.610 --> 00:08:28.860
That is gonna be a finding.

141
00:08:28.860 --> 00:08:29.610
>> Interesting.

142
00:08:29.610 --> 00:08:33.450
>> Yeah, so again, it goes back to what
we talked about in one of the previous

143
00:08:33.450 --> 00:08:39.960
episodes, where we're finding that
both regulatory environment and

144
00:08:39.960 --> 00:08:44.260
just culturally, we're beginning
to drive responsibility for

145
00:08:44.260 --> 00:08:47.680
managing these risks,
back up to the board of directors.

146
00:08:47.680 --> 00:08:52.020
It's no longer something that can be
relegated to the IT department, or

147
00:08:52.020 --> 00:08:57.300
even to your internal auditors, it has to
be embraced by senior level management,

148
00:08:57.300 --> 00:09:00.660
or there's gonna be some price to pay for
that.

149
00:09:00.660 --> 00:09:03.750
>> And that's a good thing, I see in
a lot of these organizations sometimes

150
00:09:03.750 --> 00:09:07.710
it is tough to get by, and from those
upper levels to spend money on things that

151
00:09:07.710 --> 00:09:12.280
are going to protect us, but
there's no immediate results from it.

152
00:09:12.280 --> 00:09:15.368
So sometimes it's hard to get them
to spend money on things like that.

153
00:09:15.368 --> 00:09:17.017
>> Right.
>> Where as you try to explain to

154
00:09:17.017 --> 00:09:19.900
them if that you don't spend
the money this is what could happen.

155
00:09:19.900 --> 00:09:21.730
They're like, yeah maybe but.

156
00:09:21.730 --> 00:09:27.520
>> Yeah that's exactly why, that's exactly

157
00:09:27.520 --> 00:09:31.010
why it's written into the regulation,
you do not have a choice with it.

158
00:09:31.010 --> 00:09:33.780
It's very clear in there
that it's required.

159
00:09:33.780 --> 00:09:38.530
The DHHS regs, Department of Health and
Human Services, who administers

160
00:09:38.530 --> 00:09:43.260
the HIPAA regulations, comes pretty
close to doing the same thing, and

161
00:09:43.260 --> 00:09:46.680
we're seeing more and
more organizations do that.

162
00:09:46.680 --> 00:09:49.230
Somehow try to put it in
either contractually,

163
00:09:49.230 --> 00:09:53.730
or somehow in legislation,
but again banking is such

164
00:09:53.730 --> 00:09:58.180
a critical part of our infrastructure
that the powers that be decided

165
00:09:58.180 --> 00:10:02.410
a long time ago that it was not something
that was optional, it's very mandatory.

166
00:10:02.410 --> 00:10:03.170
>> That's good.

167
00:10:03.170 --> 00:10:07.800
>> So, on another side note,

168
00:10:07.800 --> 00:10:12.990
I always look towards banking regulations,
if you go back and read the early work

169
00:10:12.990 --> 00:10:19.100
on Cobit that ISACA did,
and the COSA Organization,

170
00:10:19.100 --> 00:10:23.660
you'll find that most all of these rules
and regulations that were promulgated

171
00:10:23.660 --> 00:10:27.440
over the last 50 or 60 years,
have come from the banking industry.

172
00:10:27.440 --> 00:10:29.764
And the reason is because the risk is so
high there.

173
00:10:29.764 --> 00:10:34.141
We talked in the previous episode this
morning, and I checked while at lunch,

174
00:10:34.141 --> 00:10:37.206
the loss of the bank in
Bangladesh was $15 million.

175
00:10:37.206 --> 00:10:38.786
>> Wow, 15 million.

176
00:10:38.786 --> 00:10:43.322
>> Yeah, due to a technical error, and of
course the Swift organization claim that

177
00:10:43.322 --> 00:10:46.457
had nothing to do with their software,
their systems,

178
00:10:46.457 --> 00:10:50.360
that it was totally the banks fault,
but the money's gone.

179
00:10:50.360 --> 00:10:51.040
>> Wow.

180
00:10:51.040 --> 00:10:52.110
>> We'll come back to
that story another day.

181
00:10:52.110 --> 00:10:57.618
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I guess the point is that in the US,

182
00:10:57.618 --> 00:11:03.635
banking regulations require that the board
of directors be intimately involved, they

183
00:11:03.635 --> 00:11:09.105
must actually sign off on the security
program every year, at least annually.

184
00:11:09.105 --> 00:11:11.962
And I saw a CEO get written up for
this one time,

185
00:11:11.962 --> 00:11:16.502
there actually has to be documentation
in the board of director minutes,

186
00:11:16.502 --> 00:11:21.119
where the security officer delivered
the annual security program updates

187
00:11:21.119 --> 00:11:26.060
to the board of directors and
that they were agreed upon and accepted.

188
00:11:26.060 --> 00:11:28.040
>> Wow.
>> He got written up because even

189
00:11:28.040 --> 00:11:31.450
though they did it they didn't put it
in the minutes, boom, got a finding.

190
00:11:31.450 --> 00:11:32.030
>> I'll be darned.

191
00:11:32.030 --> 00:11:37.290
>> And in banking what that means,
a finding typically in

192
00:11:37.290 --> 00:11:41.720
other environments that might
lead to a fine or such.

193
00:11:41.720 --> 00:11:44.930
Typically in banking it's a little
different than that, they give you

194
00:11:44.930 --> 00:11:50.920
a little time to get things squared away,
but it's a mark on your record.

195
00:11:50.920 --> 00:11:54.560
So if you have for instance, they call
them memorandums requiring attention or

196
00:11:54.560 --> 00:11:58.540
memorandums requiring immediate attention,
things like that,

197
00:11:58.540 --> 00:12:03.610
what that means is it's kind of like
the IRS if you don't pay your taxes.

198
00:12:03.610 --> 00:12:05.630
They're gonna red flag you
the next time they do an audit and

199
00:12:05.630 --> 00:12:08.770
they're going to really take a deep
dive to make sure you're doing

200
00:12:08.770 --> 00:12:11.230
the things that you're doing,
and they're not going to let up

201
00:12:11.230 --> 00:12:14.900
until they've gone through a couple more
audits where there's none of those left.

202
00:12:14.900 --> 00:12:17.600
>> So it increases the scrutiny that
they're going to face when they go through

203
00:12:17.600 --> 00:12:21.660
their next audit, until they start showing
that they're doing their due diligence.

204
00:12:21.660 --> 00:12:22.430
>> Absolutely.

205
00:12:22.430 --> 00:12:23.220
Absolutely.

206
00:12:23.220 --> 00:12:25.489
It's pay now or pay later, plain and
simple in the audit world.

207
00:12:25.489 --> 00:12:30.910
[LAUGH] Yeah, if you don't pay,
you're going to sooner or later.

208
00:12:31.940 --> 00:12:35.350
So then the last one of regulatory
requirements that I wanted to talk

209
00:12:35.350 --> 00:12:37.480
a little bit about was FISMA,

210
00:12:37.480 --> 00:12:40.240
which is the Federal Information
Security Management Act.

211
00:12:40.240 --> 00:12:41.544
I've got something up on the screen if you

212
00:12:41.544 --> 00:12:42.550
could have-
>> Sure.

213
00:12:42.550 --> 00:12:44.250
>> Titus pick that up for us.

214
00:12:44.250 --> 00:12:47.922
It's a definition, it was passed in 2002.

215
00:12:47.922 --> 00:12:52.002
Let me see if I can blow this up
just a little bit without losing

216
00:12:52.002 --> 00:12:53.290
it off the screen.

217
00:12:53.290 --> 00:12:55.320
There, so everybody can read that.

218
00:12:55.320 --> 00:13:00.140
You do need to be familiar with
these regulatory requirements.

219
00:13:00.140 --> 00:13:02.510
You don't need to know them
in any intimate detail.

220
00:13:02.510 --> 00:13:05.865
You just should know that HIPAA's
different than FISMA, and FFIC or

221
00:13:05.865 --> 00:13:08.510
GWE's different from FISMA.

222
00:13:08.510 --> 00:13:13.670
FISMA is the act that was signed
in 2002 that actually governs

223
00:13:13.670 --> 00:13:16.200
all federal information systems.

224
00:13:16.200 --> 00:13:21.940
There are actually a subset of these
regulations today called FedRAMP,

225
00:13:21.940 --> 00:13:26.740
which is a smaller subsection for
cloud service providers only,

226
00:13:26.740 --> 00:13:32.280
to tell them how they must
configure their systems,

227
00:13:32.280 --> 00:13:36.080
define the boundaries of those systems,
IT systems etc,

228
00:13:36.080 --> 00:13:40.460
in order to do business with
the federal government.

229
00:13:40.460 --> 00:13:42.430
Okay, so these are musts.

230
00:13:42.430 --> 00:13:43.776
Yeah you can go ahead and close that.

231
00:13:43.776 --> 00:13:45.495
These are musts, you can't get away with.

232
00:13:45.495 --> 00:13:47.340
>> It's not a shall or should.

233
00:13:47.340 --> 00:13:47.898
>> No.

234
00:13:47.898 --> 00:13:48.617
Not at all.

235
00:13:48.617 --> 00:13:50.560
You must or it doesn't fly.

236
00:13:50.560 --> 00:13:53.490
And quite honestly,
that's one of the reasons why, and

237
00:13:53.490 --> 00:13:58.695
I know people will jump on
the OMB breach of late, and Mr.

238
00:13:58.695 --> 00:14:03.379
Snowdon's releases etc, but
by and far when you look at

239
00:14:04.660 --> 00:14:10.030
the banking system overall,
and the federal government,

240
00:14:10.030 --> 00:14:15.770
the number of breaches and
intrusions actually is pretty small.

241
00:14:15.770 --> 00:14:17.710
They really do a pretty
good job of managing,

242
00:14:17.710 --> 00:14:20.250
we forget that sometimes
because we like the headlines.

243
00:14:20.250 --> 00:14:24.457
>> They're sensational, they make
the news because it's government or

244
00:14:24.457 --> 00:14:29.012
it's lots of money, but if you saw the
number of attacks that were thwarted or

245
00:14:29.012 --> 00:14:31.886
never succeeded that happen per day or
per hour,

246
00:14:31.886 --> 00:14:35.562
you'd realize that they're
really doing a pretty good job.

247
00:14:35.562 --> 00:14:38.627
>> Yeah exactly, and so
you know you're talking about,

248
00:14:38.627 --> 00:14:43.293
with the federal government that's not
even counting the Department of Defense,

249
00:14:43.293 --> 00:14:47.354
all the black networks that they have
that we don't even know about, and

250
00:14:47.354 --> 00:14:51.883
how they protect all those, and of course
if there was a breach we would never know

251
00:14:51.883 --> 00:14:56.295
about, they would never tell us because
of national security excuse me etc.

252
00:14:56.295 --> 00:15:01.430
But, we live in a hyper
connected world today where PCI,

253
00:15:01.430 --> 00:15:04.680
HIPAA, GLBA, and
FISMA all touch each other.

254
00:15:04.680 --> 00:15:07.520
These don't run in
independent silos anymore,

255
00:15:07.520 --> 00:15:10.580
they're all touching
each other all the time.

256
00:15:10.580 --> 00:15:15.070
For instance, you go to a VA hospital,
they have HIPAA responsibilities, but

257
00:15:15.070 --> 00:15:18.865
they're part of the Federal Government,
so they also have FISMA responsibilities.

258
00:15:18.865 --> 00:15:23.456
And guess what, everybody there pays with
a credit card if they're buying medicine

259
00:15:23.456 --> 00:15:26.150
or that kind of stuff even though
they have veteran's benefits,

260
00:15:26.150 --> 00:15:29.090
there are still copays involved sometimes,
and they pay for

261
00:15:29.090 --> 00:15:32.290
all that with credit cards, which
goes back through our banking system.

262
00:15:32.290 --> 00:15:36.320
So they're all super hyper connected,
you simply can't extract them and

263
00:15:36.320 --> 00:15:40.070
pretend like they're in silos anymore.

264
00:15:40.070 --> 00:15:45.004
So, what that really does is bring me
to my next topic for this episode,

265
00:15:45.004 --> 00:15:46.252
which is IT risk.

266
00:15:46.252 --> 00:15:49.324
And talking a little bit about,
in the previous episodes

267
00:15:49.324 --> 00:15:53.804
we talked about risk in general, we talked
about enterprise risk management, but

268
00:15:53.804 --> 00:15:56.364
we haven't actually
talked about IT risk yet.

269
00:15:56.364 --> 00:15:59.882
So I wanna, wink wink,
write this down, it's in the book.

270
00:15:59.882 --> 00:16:01.844
It's in the study materials.

271
00:16:01.844 --> 00:16:04.630
IT risk is business risk.

272
00:16:04.630 --> 00:16:10.040
Business risk associated with
ownership and operation of IT assets.

273
00:16:11.200 --> 00:16:12.150
Now what's an IT asset?

274
00:16:14.160 --> 00:16:18.940
Servers, software,
hardware, human capital,

275
00:16:18.940 --> 00:16:22.980
your operators, the people who take care
of all of that stuff, those are IT assets.

276
00:16:22.980 --> 00:16:24.730
Without them, you're broke.

277
00:16:24.730 --> 00:16:25.410
>> That's right.

278
00:16:25.410 --> 00:16:28.970
>> You know, after you have a power outage
on the weekend and everything shuts down,

279
00:16:28.970 --> 00:16:33.570
everybody is off on the golf course,
that's an asset you can't have.

280
00:16:34.660 --> 00:16:38.950
They even, Isaac even goes down into
identifying things like firm work

281
00:16:40.990 --> 00:16:46.060
and the most important point I
wanna make about IT risk and

282
00:16:46.060 --> 00:16:50.980
the asset aspect is
talking about inventories.

283
00:16:52.000 --> 00:16:54.730
This is one of the most boring topics-
>> [LAUGH]

284
00:16:54.730 --> 00:16:58.500
>> In the entire [LAUGH] study guide or

285
00:16:58.500 --> 00:17:00.330
in the world of IT audit.

286
00:17:00.330 --> 00:17:02.640
But it's extremely important.

287
00:17:02.640 --> 00:17:08.790
Here's why, if you don't have proper and
adequate inventories,

288
00:17:08.790 --> 00:17:14.060
you don't have any visibility into
your complete inventory of risk.

289
00:17:15.520 --> 00:17:20.010
Because it's those assets that you own
that bring risk to the organization,

290
00:17:20.010 --> 00:17:23.630
it's the ownership, operation,
etc., of those assets.

291
00:17:23.630 --> 00:17:27.850
Well if there's 12 of them that you
don't know about that's unknown risk.

292
00:17:27.850 --> 00:17:28.705
You're not managing-
>> Right.

293
00:17:28.705 --> 00:17:30.830
Mm-hm.
>> That's extremely dangerous.

294
00:17:30.830 --> 00:17:34.420
An old, this is an old story
happened 30 years ago.

295
00:17:34.420 --> 00:17:39.530
When I was first starting up in IT down in
Indianapolis a very good friend of mine.

296
00:17:39.530 --> 00:17:42.360
An old New Horizons
instructor of mind actually.

297
00:17:42.360 --> 00:17:44.460
Who taught me everything
I know about Novell and

298
00:17:44.460 --> 00:17:48.170
IP, was doing a group wise migration for

299
00:17:48.170 --> 00:17:53.380
the school system, and one of the first
tasks he did was a complete network scan.

300
00:17:53.380 --> 00:17:54.560
Now we're talking mid 90s.

301
00:17:54.560 --> 00:17:57.420
That's real rocket science back then.

302
00:17:57.420 --> 00:17:58.510
You didn't have tools.

303
00:17:58.510 --> 00:18:01.290
You did everything from raw keyboard.

304
00:18:01.290 --> 00:18:05.752
And we discovered a Novell 2.1

305
00:18:05.752 --> 00:18:10.720
server running in one of the school system
the school didn't even know they had.

306
00:18:10.720 --> 00:18:13.370
>> Really?
>> [LAUGH] It was actually in a closet

307
00:18:13.370 --> 00:18:15.040
with the door shut.

308
00:18:15.040 --> 00:18:17.470
Nobody ever bothered,
no one even knew what was on it.

309
00:18:17.470 --> 00:18:19.290
But it was sitting there
just chugging away, and

310
00:18:19.290 --> 00:18:21.150
when you did a sweep of the network,
it showed up.

311
00:18:21.150 --> 00:18:22.190
>> You saw it, right?

312
00:18:22.190 --> 00:18:26.330
Yeah so knowing what those assets are,
where they are, what they're doing, etc.,

313
00:18:26.330 --> 00:18:27.680
is vitally important.

314
00:18:27.680 --> 00:18:31.440
>> Absolutely, if that's sitting in
a closet, it's not being patched,

315
00:18:31.440 --> 00:18:36.030
it's not being maintained at all,
so who knows what's going on.

316
00:18:36.030 --> 00:18:39.420
It could have been, I don't know if we had
Warez servers back then but it could have

317
00:18:39.420 --> 00:18:43.600
been doing any number of things that you
probably didn't want on that network.

318
00:18:43.600 --> 00:18:45.210
>> Right.
Exactly.

319
00:18:45.210 --> 00:18:49.420
It was probably host to some gaming
stuff cause it was only a two x server

320
00:18:49.420 --> 00:18:51.840
which was basically doss
remember in those days.

321
00:18:51.840 --> 00:18:55.170
Some students in the classroom
probably playing games on it.

322
00:18:55.170 --> 00:18:57.160
Not World of WarCraft or
anything like that.

323
00:18:57.160 --> 00:18:58.110
>> No.
>> But anyway.

324
00:18:58.110 --> 00:19:03.850
And then you know to bring that up
into a more modern day scenario,

325
00:19:03.850 --> 00:19:07.350
this is something that I talk about
all the time and that's shadow IT.

326
00:19:07.350 --> 00:19:10.230
That's not something that's on the test,
it's not even in the book.

327
00:19:10.230 --> 00:19:13.000
But it's something as professionals
we run into all the time.

328
00:19:13.000 --> 00:19:16.180
It's important you know what that's about.

329
00:19:16.180 --> 00:19:20.670
Shadow IT is when I come into a network
like this, and I connect to the wireless,

330
00:19:20.670 --> 00:19:22.139
and they have no idea that I've done that.

331
00:19:23.190 --> 00:19:25.920
Or, maybe they do know that I do it, but

332
00:19:25.920 --> 00:19:30.730
it's not with an authorized device, it's
not with something that's been scanned or

333
00:19:30.730 --> 00:19:33.480
had preinstalled software checked on it,
etc.

334
00:19:33.480 --> 00:19:38.720
Or when one of the, maybe one of your
film editors needs some more space or

335
00:19:38.720 --> 00:19:42.560
needs to move something to another office
and he throws it up on DropBox real quick,

336
00:19:42.560 --> 00:19:44.640
because he's got a free DropBox account.

337
00:19:44.640 --> 00:19:45.770
You don't know anything about that.

338
00:19:45.770 --> 00:19:47.200
You have no visibility into that.

339
00:19:47.200 --> 00:19:49.820
>> Here's your corporate data
leaving your secured environment and

340
00:19:49.820 --> 00:19:51.330
going out to a public cloud server.

341
00:19:51.330 --> 00:19:53.770
>> Exactly,
that corporate data is an asset and

342
00:19:53.770 --> 00:19:55.290
you've lost complete track of that.

343
00:19:55.290 --> 00:19:58.960
So what you've done is lost track
of the risk associated with it.

344
00:19:58.960 --> 00:20:03.500
So that's why it seems like we're such
bullies, being security and audit people,

345
00:20:03.500 --> 00:20:07.720
when we start coming down hard on
folks about data loss prevention or

346
00:20:07.720 --> 00:20:11.650
DLP and
we talk about content filtering for

347
00:20:11.650 --> 00:20:16.660
websites so that users aren't going
wherever they want to go, etc, etc, etc.

348
00:20:16.660 --> 00:20:21.460
It's because with the proliferation
of tablets and phones,

349
00:20:21.460 --> 00:20:26.370
etc, and other devices It's extremely
hard to track all those assets and

350
00:20:26.370 --> 00:20:28.620
be able to manage those
in an effective way.

351
00:20:28.620 --> 00:20:29.550
We won't even get into BYOD.

352
00:20:29.550 --> 00:20:33.450
We'll talk about that in another session.

353
00:20:33.450 --> 00:20:40.470
But, so that's kinda what I wanted to talk
about in terms of knowing your IT assets.

354
00:20:40.470 --> 00:20:43.610
I use the term visibility all the time,
cuz I'm an old network jock.

355
00:20:43.610 --> 00:20:47.100
I started out in Layer 2 and
3 and 4 and 1.

356
00:20:47.100 --> 00:20:49.690
And so i think of visibility,

357
00:20:49.690 --> 00:20:54.790
being able to touch all of
those assets somehow, someway.

358
00:20:54.790 --> 00:20:56.490
And when you lose touch capability or

359
00:20:56.490 --> 00:21:00.320
visibility, your risk just
goes up dramatically.

360
00:21:00.320 --> 00:21:01.600
>> Alright, well Brian, again,

361
00:21:01.600 --> 00:21:07.370
a lot of great information there in the
world of governance and management and IT.

362
00:21:07.370 --> 00:21:10.860
Remember, if you guys want to get a more
in depth look at any of the material that

363
00:21:10.860 --> 00:21:14.580
we're going over, it's all coming
straight out of the book that Brian

364
00:21:14.580 --> 00:21:19.160
is one of the authors of,
the Cybex CISA study guide fourth edition,

365
00:21:19.160 --> 00:21:22.950
make sure you get that latest one,
help you pass that exam.

366
00:21:22.950 --> 00:21:26.997
Alright, well hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching this one, signing off for

367
00:21:26.997 --> 00:21:28.545
IT Pro TV, I'm Mike Roderick.

368
00:21:28.545 --> 00:21:29.598
>> And I'm Brian O'Hara.

369
00:21:29.598 --> 00:21:32.269
>> And we'll see you next time.

370
00:21:32.269 --> 00:21:39.880

1

2
00:00:12.216 --> 00:00:15.090
Hello, welcome to another

3
00:00:15.090 --> 00:00:17.060
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and

4
00:00:17.060 --> 00:00:20.760
today we're doing our certified
information systems auditor.

5
00:00:20.760 --> 00:00:22.180
And specifically in this episode,

6
00:00:22.180 --> 00:00:26.620
we're continuing our conversation
on governance and management of IT.

7
00:00:26.620 --> 00:00:30.760
I want to remind everybody that if you
need a little more in depth coverage,

8
00:00:30.760 --> 00:00:35.490
make sure you go pick up a copy

9
00:00:35.490 --> 00:00:39.970
fourth edition of which, Mr.
Brian O'Hara is one of the authors, and

10

he happens to be sitting
next to me right now.

11
00:00:42.310 --> 00:00:43.530
How's it going, Brian?

12
00:00:43.530 --> 00:00:44.060
>> Hi, Mike, good.

13
00:00:44.060 --> 00:00:45.210
Thanks for having me again.

14
00:00:46.240 --> 00:00:49.650
Today we're gonna talk a little
bit more about Domain two and

15
00:00:49.650 --> 00:00:54.920
the ISACA exam prep series having to do
with governance and management of IT.

16
00:00:56.000 --> 00:01:00.400
In the previous episodes, we've talked a
little bit about regulatory requirements,

17
00:01:01.570 --> 00:01:04.770
things like HIPAA, GLBA, FISMA, etc.

18
00:01:04.770 --> 00:01:10.350
And even talked about some examples of
places where those have been implemented.

19
00:01:10.350 --> 00:01:13.360
I wanna make sure all the students out
there understand that they need to be

20
00:01:13.360 --> 00:01:15.040
familiar with those terms.

21
00:01:15.040 --> 00:01:20.440
You do not have to understand them in
