22
00:01:20.440 --> 00:01:24.530
but it is helpful for you to understand
that they are regulatory requirements and

23
00:01:24.530 --> 00:01:26.520
how they fit into the world of IT audit.

24
00:01:27.970 --> 00:01:34.030
And then lastly we talked a little bit
about we got started talking about IT risk

25
00:01:34.030 --> 00:01:39.480
being the business risk associated with
ownership at operation of IT assets.

26
00:01:39.480 --> 00:01:42.510
In this episode I'd like to pick
that conversation back up and

27
00:01:42.510 --> 00:01:46.060
start off by talking
about risk management.

28
00:01:46.060 --> 00:01:51.240
In the previous episodes we talked
a little bit about enterprise risk

29
00:01:51.240 --> 00:01:59.960
management, we talked about
>> IT risk a little bit.

30
00:01:59.960 --> 00:02:02.790
>> IT risk a little bit, etc.
Yeah, sorry.

31
00:02:02.790 --> 00:02:07.210
And today we want to start talking
a little bit about down in the weeds

32
00:02:07.210 --> 00:02:10.770
specifics about risk management and
how it all fits into the IT audit world.

33
00:02:12.250 --> 00:02:15.415
Risk management definition,
write this down.

34
00:02:15.415 --> 00:02:17.060
>> [LAUGH]
>> Good students out there.

35
00:02:17.060 --> 00:02:17.650
It's in the book.

36
00:02:17.650 --> 00:02:19.570
It's also in the ISOCA study guides.

37
00:02:21.050 --> 00:02:25.370
Risk management is the coordinated
activities, coordinated being key.

38
00:02:25.370 --> 00:02:27.920
It means not one person's doing this,
okay.

39
00:02:27.920 --> 00:02:31.949
Coordinated activities to manage
IT risk to acceptable levels.

40
00:02:33.640 --> 00:02:36.280
Mike's gonna ask me now,
what are acceptable levels, right?

41
00:02:36.280 --> 00:02:36.870
>> Yeah, exactly.

42
00:02:36.870 --> 00:02:37.920
That's what my question is.

43
00:02:37.920 --> 00:02:39.680
How do we know what
an acceptable level is?

44
00:02:39.680 --> 00:02:43.820
Is there a standard for that or does that
vary amongst different organizations?

45
00:02:43.820 --> 00:02:45.500
>> Yeah.
>> Who determines what it is?

46
00:02:45.500 --> 00:02:49.720
>> Yeah, so, that's the loaded
$64 million question of the day.

47
00:02:49.720 --> 00:02:51.390
Is, what is an acceptable level?

48
00:02:52.550 --> 00:02:53.210
For some of this,

49
00:02:53.210 --> 00:02:56.990
you'll have to go back to the previous
episodes where we talked about the IT

50
00:02:56.990 --> 00:03:02.000
strategy, the overall business
strategy of the organization, ect.

51
00:03:02.000 --> 00:03:08.270
Because what acceptable levels
really means is that your activities

52
00:03:08.270 --> 00:03:14.010
around managing IT risk bring them
to a level that's commensurate with,

53
00:03:14.010 --> 00:03:18.900
what we consider or what we call
the organizations risk appetite, or

54
00:03:18.900 --> 00:03:21.250
risk tolerance level.

55
00:03:21.250 --> 00:03:29.260
A good example of this might be,
let's take a bank and an investment house.

56
00:03:29.260 --> 00:03:33.500
There's two good examples,
both in financial services, correct?

57
00:03:33.500 --> 00:03:36.290
So both have a lot of the same kinds of.

58
00:03:36.290 --> 00:03:40.060
Regulations around the banking being GLBA,
depending on the kind of financial

59
00:03:40.060 --> 00:03:44.950
services it could SEC guidelines,
or something like that.

60
00:03:44.950 --> 00:03:49.940
Both in financial services, though,
very different risk profiles.

61
00:03:49.940 --> 00:03:52.570
A bank tends to be very risk averse.

62
00:03:52.570 --> 00:03:55.740
They wanna make sure that they have
collateral's for their home loans,

63
00:03:55.740 --> 00:03:57.280
or mortgages they give out.

64
00:03:57.280 --> 00:03:58.820
If you want to buy a new car and

65
00:03:58.820 --> 00:04:01.830
finance with them, they're going to make
sure that they've got a title to that car,

66
00:04:01.830 --> 00:04:04.800
they've got a lien on it in
case you default on the loan.

67
00:04:04.800 --> 00:04:07.070
They may ask for a second signer, etc.

68
00:04:07.070 --> 00:04:09.640
Very risk averse organization.

69
00:04:09.640 --> 00:04:13.280
So the activities, or excuse me,
the acceptable levels for

70
00:04:13.280 --> 00:04:17.980
a bank will be very different than
they are for an investment house.

71
00:04:17.980 --> 00:04:21.560
An investment house makes
profit by taking risks.

72
00:04:22.900 --> 00:04:26.090
So, now that doesn't mean
they take undue risk.

73
00:04:26.090 --> 00:04:26.850
Don't get me wrong.

74
00:04:26.850 --> 00:04:30.810
They do their homework very well,
they're very well versed in that, but

75
00:04:30.810 --> 00:04:33.950
they make profit by taking risks.

76
00:04:33.950 --> 00:04:35.440
So the riskier they're.

77
00:04:37.170 --> 00:04:39.730
Excuse me.
The riskier their investments become,

78
00:04:39.730 --> 00:04:41.970

00:17:27.160 --> 00:17:32.200
in that field, I used to work with
a number of large cellular providers.

316
00:17:32.200 --> 00:17:36.150
And one of the rules that they generally
work with what we call a maintenance when

317
00:17:36.150 --> 00:17:39.520
they're on the weekends, when they
would make firewall up, change updates,

318
00:17:39.520 --> 00:17:42.320
that kinds of stuff or
they bring new gear online, etc.

319
00:17:42.320 --> 00:17:46.220
So that if it something malfunctions they
could either roll it back or turn it off.

320
00:17:46.220 --> 00:17:50.820
And they would it between the hours
of say 12 midnight Sunday and

321
00:17:50.820 --> 00:17:54.970
6 AM Sunday morning so that they would
minimize any disruption to customers.

322
00:17:54.970 --> 00:17:59.830
But one of the separation of duties they
did was they would not allow the actual

323
00:17:59.830 --> 00:18:04.880
firewall engineers to
write any policy changes.

324
00:18:04.880 --> 00:18:09.060
The policy changes were written by
a completely different group of engineers.

325
00:18:09.060 --> 00:18:12.480
Handed to the security
firewall engineers and

326
00:18:12.480 --> 00:18:17.630
the firewall engineers then proceeded
with implementing those policies so

327
00:18:17.630 --> 00:18:24.070
one person wasn't able to complete any one
piece of the pie without the other person.

328
00:18:24.070 --> 00:18:27.280
>> If that engineer that was doing the
application thought something was funny he

329
00:18:27.280 --> 00:18:28.700
might not have applied it.

330
00:18:28.700 --> 00:18:31.540
So there's no way for
that one person to get something done?

331
00:18:31.540 --> 00:18:33.020
>> Right, right exactly.

332
00:18:33.020 --> 00:18:37.740
So you can see that the concept of
not only auditor independence, but

333
00:18:37.740 --> 00:18:43.600
separation of duties goes back to what we
started this session with which was risk

334
00:18:43.600 --> 00:18:50.250
management and keeping those activities,
excuse me, making sure that those.

335
00:18:50.250 --> 00:18:53.695
Activities continue to keep
risk at acceptable levels.

336
00:18:53.695 --> 00:18:57.210
>> [INAUDIBLE]
>> So, that's it for this session.

337
00:18:57.210 --> 00:18:58.290
>> All right, Brian again,

338
00:18:58.290 --> 00:19:03.140
fantastic stuff, great stories in there
and just a bunch of great information that

339
00:19:03.140 --> 00:19:07.380
we really need to make sure we're familiar
with as we prepare for this exam.

340
00:19:07.380 --> 00:19:07.980
And remember,

341
00:19:07.980 --> 00:19:12.370
if you want more information, you can
always get a copy of the book that Brian

342
00:19:12.370 --> 00:19:17.830
is one of the authors of
The Sybex CISA Study Guide Fourth Edition,

343
00:19:17.830 --> 00:19:20.620
that's the content that we're
covering here in these episodes.

344
00:19:20.620 --> 00:19:23.160
So thank you for that Brian,
we appreciate it.

345
00:19:23.160 --> 00:19:25.160
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

346
00:19:25.160 --> 00:19:27.970
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

347
00:19:27.970 --> 00:19:28.990
>> And I'm Brian O'Hara.

348
00:19:28.990 --> 00:19:31.013
>> And we'll see you next time.

349

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.199 --> 00:00:10.199
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.637 --> 00:00:15.734
Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.734 --> 00:00:17.384
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and

4
00:00:17.384 --> 00:00:21.330
today we're doing our certified
information systems auditor.

5
00:00:21.330 --> 00:00:23.250
And specifically in this episode,

6
00:00:23.250 --> 00:00:28.190
we'll be diving into information systems,
acquisition,

7
00:00:28.190 --> 00:00:31.930
development and implementation, if I
can get all that out, it's a mouthful.

8
00:00:31.930 --> 00:00:33.557
We got a lot to talk about.

9
00:00:33.557 --> 00:00:38.167
So here to help me with all of
that is one of the authors of

10
00:00:38.167 --> 00:00:43.704
the Sybex CISA Study Guide Fourth Edition,
Mr. Brian O'Hara.

11
00:00:43.704 --> 00:00:44.819
How you doing, Brian?

12
00:00:44.819 --> 00:00:45.975
>> Hi Mike, good thanks.

13
00:00:45.975 --> 00:00:47.671
Thanks for having me again.

14
00:00:47.671 --> 00:00:49.977
Well good morning out there in TV land.

15
00:00:49.977 --> 00:00:52.086
>> [LAUGH]
>> In this episode,

16
00:00:52.086 --> 00:00:56.708
I wanna talk a little bit about
information systems, acquisition,

17
00:00:56.708 --> 00:00:59.270
development, and implementation.

18
00:00:59.270 --> 00:01:04.173
And I'll start off by talking a little
bit about why that's even important.

19
00:01:04.173 --> 00:01:08.918
One of the ground rules or
one of the requirements that ISACA has for

20
00:01:08.918 --> 00:01:13.663
CISA candidates, is that you be
able to provide assurances that,

21
00:01:13.663 --> 00:01:18.492
[COUGH] excuse me, that practices for
the acquisition, etc, etc,

22
00:01:18.492 --> 00:01:22.563
and testing implementation
of information systems meet

23
00:01:22.563 --> 00:01:26.238
the organization's strategies and
objectives.

24
00:01:26.238 --> 00:01:28.560
You've heard this through
a number of episodes.

25
00:01:28.560 --> 00:01:31.040
We just finished a couple
of episodes earlier today

26
00:01:31.040 --> 00:01:34.120
where we talked a great deal about
the organizational strategies and

27
00:01:34.120 --> 00:01:37.160
objectives and
how that all ties to risk management.

28
00:01:37.160 --> 00:01:43.270
The idea being that everything we do
in IT systems should in some way,

29
00:01:43.270 --> 00:01:45.820
the term I use is move
the ball down the field.

30
00:01:45.820 --> 00:01:50.200
It should be helping the organization
to meet his goals and

31
00:01:50.200 --> 00:01:53.330
objectives, and
be in line with his strategies.

32
00:01:53.330 --> 00:01:58.294
So if the strategy is to build 37
more websites next year then all

33
00:01:58.294 --> 00:02:02.715
of the IT efforts should be,
if that's its primary goal,

34
00:02:02.715 --> 00:02:05.785
should be aligned with that strategy and

35
00:02:05.785 --> 00:02:09.869
not get sidetracked in to
other kinds of activities.

36
00:02:09.869 --> 00:02:10.940
Did you have a question Mike?

37
00:02:10.940 --> 00:02:11.605
>> No.

38
00:02:11.605 --> 00:02:12.758
>> Thought maybe you had a question.

39
00:02:12.758 --> 00:02:17.803
So let's start off with a little
bit about talking about how this

40
00:02:17.803 --> 00:02:24.350
begins to wrap things around the
organizational strategies and objectives.

41
00:02:24.350 --> 00:02:29.840
So we've talked about risk, risk
management, risk management activities.

42
00:02:29.840 --> 00:02:33.650
We've talked about or starting to
talk about systems development and

43
00:02:33.650 --> 00:02:37.740
acquisition, and you begin to
see how all of this wraps around

44
00:02:37.740 --> 00:02:40.650
the risk strategy of
the organization as well.

45
00:02:40.650 --> 00:02:46.791
That should be also in alignment with
the organizations, strategies and

46
00:02:46.791 --> 00:02:52.347
objectives and we mentioned this
in one of the previous episodes.

47
00:02:52.347 --> 00:02:58.110
We're trying to manage risk to a level
that allows the organization to meet

48
00:02:58.110 --> 00:03:04.517
its objectives and is aligned with its
strategies not necessarily choking it out.

49
00:03:04.517 --> 00:03:09.413
Because we think that they
shouldn't be absorbing risk that

50
00:03:09.413 --> 00:03:14.214
we don't like for
whatever reasons we may have about that.

51
00:03:14.214 --> 00:03:19.481
So the first part of this
is talking a little bit

52
00:03:19.481 --> 00:03:25.570
about IT supplier selection,
and contracts, etc.

53
00:03:25.570 --> 00:03:27.268
I call this vendor management.

54
00:03:27.268 --> 00:03:34.320
We'll talk about how to do
adequate reviews of vendors.

55
00:03:34.320 --> 00:03:38.820
One of the key components to
this conversation in this

56
00:03:38.820 --> 00:03:43.420
episode has to do with the risk
associated with doing or

57
00:03:43.420 --> 00:03:47.910
not doing business with
a particular vendor.

58
00:03:47.910 --> 00:03:52.565
Something I haven't mentioned before
maybe it'd be useful is that when you're

59
00:03:52.565 --> 00:03:56.404
talking about risk,
you're also talking about opportunities.

60
00:03:56.404 --> 00:04:00.450
It's the flip side of the same coin,
with every risk come opportunities.

61
00:04:00.450 --> 00:04:02.900
In the last episode or
in a previous episode,

62
00:04:02.900 --> 00:04:07.460
we talked about banking and
financial investment, houses.

63
00:04:07.460 --> 00:04:12.750
And how banks are typically more
risk averse than investment houses,

64
00:04:12.750 --> 00:04:16.910
because investment houses make
their money taking large risk.

65
00:04:16.910 --> 00:04:22.050
Banks make their money and
control their income by managing risk

66
00:04:22.050 --> 00:04:25.990
at a more effective level,
so they're more risk averse.

67
00:04:28.850 --> 00:04:32.769
So I'm trying to think where I was at
with that sorry, had a senior moment for

68
00:04:32.769 --> 00:04:33.634
a minute there.

69
00:04:33.634 --> 00:04:36.949
>> [LAUGH]
>> So in talking about vendor selection

70
00:04:36.949 --> 00:04:40.878
which is a very important piece
of working in IT systems.

71
00:04:40.878 --> 00:04:45.504
Because so much of what we do is
purchasing from other vendors or

72
00:04:45.504 --> 00:04:50.587
outsourcing services to other vendors etc,
activities like that.

73
00:04:50.587 --> 00:04:55.131
That vendor management, the selection
process, how we review their,

74
00:04:55.131 --> 00:04:58.109
the risks that they bring
to the organization in

75
00:04:58.109 --> 00:05:02.519
comparison to the opportunities tha
they bring to the organization.

76
00:05:02.519 --> 00:05:06.339
>> And it's something that was sometimes,
we forget to think about I think when

77
00:05:06.339 --> 00:05:09.409
we're looking at vendors,
a lot of times it's bottom line.

78
00:05:09.409 --> 00:05:11.610
Who's gonna give me the best bid?

79
00:05:11.610 --> 00:05:13.280
Who's gonna give me the best price?

80
00:05:13.280 --> 00:05:16.790
But that doesn't always equate to the best
choice when it comes to a vendor, right?

81
00:05:16.790 --> 00:05:19.630
>> It also doesn't equate to the best
opportunity for the organization.

82
00:05:21.070 --> 00:05:24.870
So let me talk about another example we've
mentioned in a couple of previous episodes

83
00:05:24.870 --> 00:05:26.990
and that is the target breech.

84
00:05:28.270 --> 00:05:34.680
The breech occurred because
a third party vendor the HVAC or

85
00:05:34.680 --> 00:05:41.720
heating and air conditioning company
that was managing Target's power in

86
00:05:41.720 --> 00:05:46.830
terms of managing their power and heating
and cooling bills to help them save money.

87
00:05:46.830 --> 00:05:50.190
There was risk associated with
doing business with that vendor.

88
00:05:50.190 --> 00:05:51.670
They assumed that that risk or

89
00:05:51.670 --> 00:05:55.040
they made the determination
that that risk was acceptable.

90
00:05:55.040 --> 00:06:00.020
And what they found out later was
that somebody along the line didn't

91
00:06:00.020 --> 00:06:05.210
check out some of the ways those
vendors connect to the organization,

92
00:06:05.210 --> 00:06:08.680
and risk came along with
doing business with them.

93
00:06:09.830 --> 00:06:12.965
The other side of that is,
you've got to have an HVAC vendor, so

94
00:06:12.965 --> 00:06:15.243
you can't not do business with them,
right?

95
00:06:15.243 --> 00:06:16.273
>> Right.

96
00:06:16.273 --> 00:06:18.678
>> So you got to have somebody so
there is both opportunities and

97
00:06:18.678 --> 00:06:19.915
risks that go along with that.

98
00:06:19.915 --> 00:06:24.095
The point of risk management is to
find the balance of those two and

99
00:06:24.095 --> 00:06:28.741
where risks are above and beyond what
you are willing and able to accept.

100
00:06:28.741 --> 00:06:34.620
Then you need to put controls in place to
bring those down to acceptable levels.

101
00:06:34.620 --> 00:06:38.999
For instance had a risk
assessment been completed and

102
00:06:38.999 --> 00:06:43.010
we're beginning to talk about
that doing risk assessment work.

103
00:06:43.010 --> 00:06:46.930
Had a risk assessment and
adequate been completed,

104
00:06:46.930 --> 00:06:51.640
there's a very good chance that
the vulnerability that the organization

105
00:06:51.640 --> 00:06:55.800
suffered from would have been identified
and controls would have been put in place.

106
00:06:55.800 --> 00:07:01.950
Cuz it really boil down to a very
simple solution of the HVAC vendor

107
00:07:01.950 --> 00:07:07.580
was doing a remote desktop session
directly into the LAN network.

108
00:07:07.580 --> 00:07:08.890
There was no segmentation,

109
00:07:08.890 --> 00:07:12.120
they were not coming through
a secure connection, anything.

110
00:07:12.120 --> 00:07:17.167
And so exposed Target's internal network
to all kinds of vulnerabilities.

111
00:07:17.167 --> 00:07:18.127
>> Wow.

112
00:07:18.127 --> 00:07:20.521
>> A good risk assessment
would have identified that.

113
00:07:20.521 --> 00:07:23.850
>> Now you say risk assessment,
what do you mean by risk assessment?

114
00:07:23.850 --> 00:07:26.750
>> Well so that's a great question.

115
00:07:26.750 --> 00:07:34.530
That's a huge part of the CISA
knowledge base, if you will.

116
00:07:36.370 --> 00:07:39.320
And we'll talk a little bit more in
detail about it in another session.

117
00:07:39.320 --> 00:07:43.000
But basically, what we're talking about is
taking a look at the controls that are in

118
00:07:43.000 --> 00:07:47.050
place, trying to identify
vulnerabilities that are in place.

119
00:07:47.050 --> 00:07:49.247
And determining whether or

120
00:07:49.247 --> 00:07:54.987
not the controls that you have in place
bring the risk down to the level.

121
00:07:54.987 --> 00:07:59.684
We talked about that in our previous
section about bringing risks into line

122
00:07:59.684 --> 00:08:01.481
with your organizational.

123
00:08:01.481 --> 00:08:04.613
The organizations of goals or
objectives, so

124
00:08:04.613 --> 00:08:08.549
risk assessments is designed
to ferret out those risks and

125
00:08:08.549 --> 00:08:13.366
find out if they are in fact in line
with the organizations tolerance and

126
00:08:13.366 --> 00:08:17.970
if not what controls can they put
in place to bring them in line.

127
00:08:17.970 --> 00:08:22.900
Because you have to assume some risk
In order to do business with them.

128
00:08:22.900 --> 00:08:25.250
However, you need to be
able to minimize that so

129
00:08:25.250 --> 00:08:28.350
that it meets your own company's
strategies and objectives.

130
00:08:29.370 --> 00:08:30.140
>> Very good.

131
00:08:30.140 --> 00:08:31.040
>> In the previous session,

132
00:08:31.040 --> 00:08:35.230
I also talked about how that's
different from every organization.

133
00:08:35.230 --> 00:08:38.500
For instance, in the health care industry,

134
00:08:38.500 --> 00:08:42.340
with HIPAA regulations there's something
called a business associate agreement.

135
00:08:43.830 --> 00:08:49.130
Any health care facility, for instance,
to not get too far in the weeds with this,

136
00:08:49.130 --> 00:08:54.080
a hospital, or a physician clinic,
is what we'd call a covered entity.

137
00:08:54.080 --> 00:08:59.770
Anyone they do business with, period,
today, didn't used to be this way till

138
00:08:59.770 --> 00:09:04.240
two years ago, when the,
some new rules were promulgated.

139
00:09:04.240 --> 00:09:09.920
Anyone who does business with a healthcare
entity is a business associate.

140
00:09:09.920 --> 00:09:15.700
Business associates, or subcontractors, or
vendors, or whatever term you want to use

141
00:09:15.700 --> 00:09:20.380
fall under the exact same
regulations as a covered entity.

142
00:09:20.380 --> 00:09:22.490
So if a hospital for instance, and

143
00:09:22.490 --> 00:09:26.900
this is one of the challenges we deal with
today If a hospital for instance wants to

144
00:09:26.900 --> 00:09:32.330
do business with a small local vendor who
does a really good job at what they do.

145
00:09:33.510 --> 00:09:37.920
In order to do business with them,
those subcontractors or

146
00:09:37.920 --> 00:09:42.880
vendors have to have to
same kind of controls in

147
00:09:42.880 --> 00:09:45.990
place as the healthcare organization
in order to do business with them.

148
00:09:45.990 --> 00:09:50.740
>> So me as a vendor even though
I'm not a healthcare provider, but

149
00:09:50.740 --> 00:09:55.030
I want to do business with a healthcare
provider, I must then comply with HIPAA?

150
00:09:55.030 --> 00:09:56.220
>> That's correct.

151
00:09:56.220 --> 00:10:03.140
Not only that, but if you can't
the organization can get into some really,

152
00:10:03.140 --> 00:10:08.340
really dangerous territory
with both auditors and

153
00:10:08.340 --> 00:10:14.360
the federal government in terms
of not only introducing risk that

154
00:10:14.360 --> 00:10:19.550
they can't manage but they can get fined
well into the millions of dollars for

155
00:10:19.550 --> 00:10:23.920
not following procedures and
policies under the HIPAA guidelines.

156
00:10:23.920 --> 00:10:28.420
So it can be quite expensive to get caught
doing business with someone who's not

157
00:10:28.420 --> 00:10:30.550
providing those.

158
00:10:30.550 --> 00:10:35.460
The idea really boils down to, and
I've said this before, we live in such

159
00:10:35.460 --> 00:10:41.450
a hyperconnected world that anyone
who touches any one of those systems

160
00:10:41.450 --> 00:10:45.520
has to have adequate controls in place or
something bad is going to go wrong.

161
00:10:46.710 --> 00:10:50.320
In one of the previous episodes we
talked about the bank in Bangladesh

162
00:10:50.320 --> 00:10:52.760
that just had an $18 million breach.

163
00:10:52.760 --> 00:10:56.590
That could have very easily
impacted the entire world wide or

164
00:10:56.590 --> 00:11:01.470
at least the European Wire
transfer model because they touch

165
00:11:01.470 --> 00:11:06.410
the Swift operating system,
which is the backbone for

166
00:11:06.410 --> 00:11:09.980
organizations outside the U.S.
to be able to do wire transfers.

167
00:11:11.190 --> 00:11:15.040
An adequate risk assessment
had not been done, and

168
00:11:15.040 --> 00:11:17.900
as a result a breach, or
not a breach occurred.

169
00:11:17.900 --> 00:11:19.300
You could call it a breach.

170
00:11:19.300 --> 00:11:22.830
Basically an account takeover occurred,
of the bank, not

171
00:11:24.960 --> 00:11:30.740
a member or an account of the bank,
but the bank itself.

172
00:11:30.740 --> 00:11:36.255
Their money was stolen which is that
obviously ergo customer's money.

173
00:11:36.255 --> 00:11:39.470
[LAUGH] It's not really
their money to begin with.

174
00:11:39.470 --> 00:11:42.750
>> And I'm thinking about it from that
small vendor side because they're doing

175
00:11:42.750 --> 00:11:43.250
the same things.

176
00:11:43.250 --> 00:11:47.860
They've gotta do risk assessment and look
at that and it might be to where I look

177
00:11:47.860 --> 00:11:51.410
at this and I think, I really wanna do
business with this healthcare provider but

178
00:11:51.410 --> 00:11:53.620
that means that I'm gonna
have to comply with HIPAA.

179
00:11:53.620 --> 00:11:57.040
And, if I ever get out of compliance,
they could costs be a lot of money and

180
00:11:57.040 --> 00:11:57.790
put me out of business.

181
00:11:57.790 --> 00:12:01.480
So, the risk is, I could make money
by doing business with them or

182
00:12:01.480 --> 00:12:04.840
I could avoid the risk by not doing
business with healthcare associates.

183
00:12:04.840 --> 00:12:07.610
>> Right.
And, in fact, one of the problems is that,

184
00:12:07.610 --> 00:12:14.720
it's It's creating a barrier to entry for
vendors who could actually do a better job

185
00:12:14.720 --> 00:12:19.830
but they can't afford the compliance
requirements to get into the business.

186
00:12:19.830 --> 00:12:22.280
So it's actually harming
a number of businesses and

187
00:12:22.280 --> 00:12:23.770
I think the federal government's.

188
00:12:23.770 --> 00:12:26.230
Trying to find ways to deal with that.

189
00:12:26.230 --> 00:12:31.080
But for today, it just means that
the hospitals, A can't afford to do

190
00:12:31.080 --> 00:12:34.510
business with you because they'll get in
trouble, and you may not be able to afford

191
00:12:34.510 --> 00:12:40.700
to do business with them because you can't
afford to put the controls in place.

00:25:57.800 --> 00:26:03.070
An investment is something typically that
starts to pay you dividends immediately.

421
00:26:03.070 --> 00:26:05.020
When you invest money in the stock market,

422
00:26:05.020 --> 00:26:07.340
you expect to get returns immediately,
don't you?

423
00:26:07.340 --> 00:26:08.420
>> Yes.
>> With hardware,

424
00:26:08.420 --> 00:26:12.342
acquisition and development and
implementation, that rarely occurs.

425
00:26:12.342 --> 00:26:16.220
>> So your ROI doesn't really occur
until you've finished paying for it,

426
00:26:16.220 --> 00:26:17.490
then it's no longer a purchase.

427
00:26:17.490 --> 00:26:19.200
>> Til it's already written
down off your books.

428
00:26:19.200 --> 00:26:20.150
Yeah, exactly.

429
00:26:20.150 --> 00:26:25.740
But nevertheless, I don't want to get into
arguing tomatoes and tomatoes over that.

430
00:26:25.740 --> 00:26:28.380
Make sure you understand
that those two terms,

431
00:26:28.380 --> 00:26:32.200
you're gonna hear them more as
we go through the next sessions.

432
00:26:32.200 --> 00:26:34.660
And I think that's probably a wrap for
this one.

433
00:26:34.660 --> 00:26:38.225
>> All right Bryan, again, fantastic
stuff, you've got me riveted here.

434
00:26:38.225 --> 00:26:40.440
>> [LAUGH]
>> Hope you guys out there are enjoying it

435
00:26:40.440 --> 00:26:41.460
as much as I am.

436
00:26:41.460 --> 00:26:45.440
Remember, if you wanna get a more in depth
look at any of this information as you're

437
00:26:45.440 --> 00:26:50.090
preparing for the exam, go out and pick
up a copy of the book that Brian helped

438
00:26:50.090 --> 00:26:54.930
write, the Sybex CISA Study Guide,
Fourth Edition.

439
00:26:54.930 --> 00:26:57.240
So make sure that's on your desk.

440
00:26:57.240 --> 00:26:59.340
All right, Brian, again, great episode.

441
00:26:59.340 --> 00:27:01.290
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

442
00:27:01.290 --> 00:27:04.270
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

443
00:27:04.270 --> 00:27:05.260
>> And I'm Brian O'Hara.

444
00:27:05.260 --> 00:27:07.580
>> And we'll see you next time.

445
00:27:07.580 --> 00:27:15.290

episodes.title: Acquisition, Development and Implementation Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.007 --> 00:00:15.644
Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.644 --> 00:00:18.546
I'm your host Mike Roderick and
today we're doing our

4
00:00:18.546 --> 00:00:22.966
Certified Information Systems Auditor,
and specifically in this episode we're

5
00:00:22.966 --> 00:00:27.259
actually continuing on our conversation,
dealing with information systems,

6
00:00:27.259 --> 00:00:30.320
acquisition development and
implementation.

7
00:00:30.320 --> 00:00:32.460
And here with me today
is one of the authors

8
00:00:32.460 --> 00:00:37.650
of the Sybex CISA Study Guide
Fourth Edition, Mr. Brian O'Hara.

9
00:00:37.650 --> 00:00:38.610
How you doing Brian?

10
00:00:38.610 --> 00:00:41.360
>> Hi Mike, good, thanks,
thanks again for having me.

11
00:00:41.360 --> 00:00:46.780
So in today's session, I'd like to start
off talking about, we're at the point

12
00:00:46.780 --> 00:00:51.130
in the sessions where we begin talking
about software development life cycle, or

13
00:00:51.130 --> 00:00:54.730
system development life cycle tools and
techniques.

14
00:00:54.730 --> 00:00:59.790
I wanna make sure that viewers
understand that they can go to get

15
00:00:59.790 --> 00:01:04.849
more information, not only at
the CSI study guide in the book,

16
00:01:04.849 --> 00:01:08.495
but also to the ISACA website, Isaca.org.

17
00:01:08.495 --> 00:01:12.150
There's more information on the SDLC tools
and techniques located there as well.

18
00:01:13.570 --> 00:01:15.310
But before we get started with that,

19
00:01:15.310 --> 00:01:19.440
I wanna talk just a little bit about gap
analysis and vulnerability management,

20
00:01:19.440 --> 00:01:24.420
those are two concepts that you'll
need to be familiar with for

21
00:01:24.420 --> 00:01:27.550
your CISA exam coming up here,
hopefully in the next month or so.

22
00:01:29.460 --> 00:01:36.130
Gap analysis is a concept that
has to do with the difference

23
00:01:36.130 --> 00:01:41.759
between where an organization would
like to be and where they actually are.

24
00:01:43.090 --> 00:01:44.124
Maybe I did that backwards.

25
00:01:44.124 --> 00:01:48.050
>> [LAUGH]
>> The idea being,

26
00:01:48.050 --> 00:01:52.710
for instance, an organization
I'm working with right now.

27
00:01:52.710 --> 00:01:55.450
They don't really understand
where they are, but

28
00:01:55.450 --> 00:01:56.860
they know where they'd like to be.

29
00:01:56.860 --> 00:02:01.550
So we're doing a gap analysis to find
out where in there information system

30
00:02:01.550 --> 00:02:05.770
an acquisition, development life cycle,
etc., that they may have gaps.

31
00:02:05.770 --> 00:02:10.650
It's a very large shop that develops a lot
of applications, and they wanna make sure

32
00:02:10.650 --> 00:02:15.410
that they're doing the best that they
can in ensuring that the applications

33
00:02:15.410 --> 00:02:20.060
not only meet their customer needs but are
developed in a timely manner, etc., etc.

34
00:02:20.060 --> 00:02:23.729
So I've been asked to come in and
do a gap analysis.

35
00:02:25.440 --> 00:02:29.600
And explain to them the things that
I uncover during my gap analysis.

36
00:02:29.600 --> 00:02:32.480
My gap analysis could also
be thought of as an audit

37
00:02:32.480 --> 00:02:37.080
in the sense that I'm actually looking
at what they say they wanna be doing or

38
00:02:37.080 --> 00:02:40.860
what they are attempting to do and
what they are actually accomplishing.

39
00:02:40.860 --> 00:02:42.905
So again, we're doing some reconnaissance.

40
00:02:42.905 --> 00:02:46.630
We're asking a lot a very
hard questions to find out

41
00:02:46.630 --> 00:02:51.400
where there might be risk in
the process that they were unaware of.

42
00:02:51.400 --> 00:02:54.240
And the reason for that again,
is not to make it personal or

43
00:02:54.240 --> 00:02:58.650
not to shoot down their products or
their processes or their people.

44
00:02:58.650 --> 00:03:03.520
But to find areas that we can bolster
their risk management practices and

45
00:03:03.520 --> 00:03:08.310
put controls in place to ensure that the
work that they're doing is effective and

46
00:03:08.310 --> 00:03:14.580
meets the organization and the IT
department or organization's strategic and

47
00:03:14.580 --> 00:03:19.040
tactical plans and operations, okay?

48
00:03:20.140 --> 00:03:24.650
One of the ways we do that is by
conducting a vulnerability assessment.

49
00:03:25.990 --> 00:03:28.520
And, helping them with
vulnerability management.

50
00:03:29.870 --> 00:03:34.010
Any time you're dealing with a large
number of information systems,

51
00:03:34.010 --> 00:03:36.780
you're going to run into vulnerabilities.

52
00:03:36.780 --> 00:03:40.640
Exposed by the operating system
by applications running on those

53
00:03:40.640 --> 00:03:42.100
operating systems.

54
00:03:42.100 --> 00:03:46.850
Whether that be even a mainframe
can have vulnerabilities exposed.

55
00:03:46.850 --> 00:03:52.170
But desktops, servers, and even Linux
boxes, and yes, my favorite Apple,

56
00:03:52.170 --> 00:03:57.495
I don't know if you're aware of it but
Apple in 2015 actually had more

57
00:03:57.495 --> 00:04:02.610
vulnerabilities identified and
remediated than Windows 10.

58
00:04:02.610 --> 00:04:03.730
>> Really?

59
00:04:03.730 --> 00:04:06.826
>> Yeah, Windows 8.1, Windows 10
hadn't been released at that point.

60
00:04:06.826 --> 00:04:09.910
>> [LAUGH]
>> They did it quicker and

61
00:04:09.910 --> 00:04:12.750
more efficiently than Microsoft
had done in the previously year,

62
00:04:12.750 --> 00:04:15.038
but the number was larger.

63
00:04:15.038 --> 00:04:20.280
So a big piece of any type
of Software development or

64
00:04:20.280 --> 00:04:25.640
system development life cycle management
involves vulnerability management.

65
00:04:25.640 --> 00:04:29.720
How to identify vulnerabilities,
what to do with them when you find them,

66
00:04:29.720 --> 00:04:33.826
how to risk rank them so

67
00:04:33.826 --> 00:04:39.340
that you're utilizing resources
the most effectively, etc.

68
00:04:39.340 --> 00:04:43.820
A good example might be you're
getting ready to roll out,

69
00:04:43.820 --> 00:04:46.150
this happened to me not too long ago.

70
00:04:46.150 --> 00:04:47.870
Coming getting ready to roll out a new,
not

71
00:04:51.360 --> 00:04:56.430
a customer portal but a,
they're a co-op, and so they have

72
00:04:56.430 --> 00:05:00.540
what they call members which are their
customers but their not retail customers.

73
00:05:00.540 --> 00:05:04.680
They're wholesale customers who buy from
the company, they rolled out an invoice

74
00:05:04.680 --> 00:05:10.540
management system, and in that invoice
management system we discovered

75
00:05:10.540 --> 00:05:16.020
banking information that was not only
not needed, but had been inadvertently

76
00:05:16.020 --> 00:05:20.890
loaded into the database on the back-end
because it came from another source.

77
00:05:20.890 --> 00:05:23.080
And the company hadn't identified that.

78
00:05:23.080 --> 00:05:25.390
So that was a vulnerability
that we discovered.

79
00:05:25.390 --> 00:05:29.020
We were able to remove that
table from the database.

80
00:05:29.020 --> 00:05:30.970
It wasn't being published.

81
00:05:30.970 --> 00:05:34.310
The users, as far as we know,
were never able to access it.

82
00:05:34.310 --> 00:05:36.290
But there was no reason for
it to be in the database, so

83
00:05:36.290 --> 00:05:37.910
we removed the table completely.

84
00:05:37.910 --> 00:05:39.275
>> Hm, very cool.

85
00:05:39.275 --> 00:05:44.403
>> So, and when we talk about
vulnerability management we also talk

86
00:05:44.403 --> 00:05:49.438
about how do you determine how
that happened in the first place,

87
00:05:49.438 --> 00:05:54.800
and then how you prevent it
from happening in the future.

88
00:05:54.800 --> 00:05:59.950
How do you build ongoing monitoring

89
00:05:59.950 --> 00:06:03.220
to ensure that those kinds of
things dont happen over and over?

90
00:06:03.220 --> 00:06:05.190
And in your other applications as well.

91
00:06:06.290 --> 00:06:11.120
So that's part of what vulnerability
management means in the respective of

92
00:06:12.210 --> 00:06:14.080
system acquisition,
development, and management.

93
00:06:16.350 --> 00:06:21.290
Next, we're gonna talk a little bit
about some SDLC tools and techniques.

94
00:06:21.290 --> 00:06:24.937
You'll hear me use the term SDLC
cuz it's a lot easier than saying

95
00:06:24.937 --> 00:06:29.070
system development life cycle
control management etc., etc., etc.

96
00:06:29.070 --> 00:06:30.965
SDLC's a lot shorter.

97
00:06:30.965 --> 00:06:36.451
There are a number of SDLC techniques
that are used in application development,

98
00:06:36.451 --> 00:06:40.090
the first of which I wanna
talk about is called Agile.

99
00:06:41.800 --> 00:06:46.810
You don't have to know details of what
Agile is or what it means for the exam,

100
00:06:46.810 --> 00:06:51.780
but it's important that you understand
that it is a very viable form of software

101
00:06:51.780 --> 00:06:56.560
development model in use
today in a lot of shops.

102
00:06:56.560 --> 00:07:01.760
Agile is built around
the idea that traditional,

103
00:07:01.760 --> 00:07:05.509
what we would have called
waterfall models in the past which

104
00:07:05.509 --> 00:07:10.430
involved step B could not even
start until step A was completed.

105
00:07:10.430 --> 00:07:13.880
Step C could not start until step
B was completed which means,

106
00:07:13.880 --> 00:07:18.250
step C also couldn't be started
unless A and B were both completed.

107
00:07:18.250 --> 00:07:22.630
That tended to drag out IT
software development projects,

108
00:07:23.680 --> 00:07:26.490
we found ourselves in a situation where

109
00:07:26.490 --> 00:07:31.390
companies were continually missing
deadlines, costs were skyrocketing,

110
00:07:31.390 --> 00:07:36.730
it was just not a really great model for
managing software development.

111
00:07:36.730 --> 00:07:39.840
So a number of decades ago,

112
00:07:39.840 --> 00:07:43.130
some folks came up with the idea
of what we would call, Agile.

113
00:07:43.130 --> 00:07:46.630
Which really has to do
with focusing more on

114
00:07:46.630 --> 00:07:50.960
the outcome of the software
development than the process.

115
00:07:50.960 --> 00:07:52.590
So the customer's input and

116
00:07:52.590 --> 00:07:56.490
the user experience becomes far more
important than whether or not certain

117
00:07:56.490 --> 00:07:59.590
critical functions were performed
during the process of development.

118
00:08:00.750 --> 00:08:06.113
That's rolled into another term we
call today, DevOps or development ops,

119
00:08:06.113 --> 00:08:10.908
which is taking that same model,
and rolling it into IT management.

120
00:08:10.908 --> 00:08:14.810
One of the activities that
you conduct here at ITProTV,

121
00:08:14.810 --> 00:08:19.873
I'm not sure if you know it or not,
that it's part of the Agile concept,

122
00:08:19.873 --> 00:08:22.630
is the morning meetings that you have.

123
00:08:22.630 --> 00:08:23.170
>> Our scrum.

124
00:08:23.170 --> 00:08:24.110
>> Yeah, your scrums.

125
00:08:24.110 --> 00:08:26.649
That's exactly, that's an Agile term.

126
00:08:27.710 --> 00:08:30.400
Where everyone comes in the room and
you very quickly go around the room and

127
00:08:30.400 --> 00:08:32.890
talk about what you're gonna do for
the day and then you get to it.

128
00:08:32.890 --> 00:08:34.100
There's not a lot of meetings.

129
00:08:34.100 --> 00:08:35.020
You don't go on and on and

130
00:08:35.020 --> 00:08:38.330
on ad nauseam about the kinds of
things you've been thinking about.

131
00:08:38.330 --> 00:08:39.660
It's what are we doing today?

132
00:08:39.660 --> 00:08:40.510
Let's go to it.

133
00:08:40.510 --> 00:08:41.850
>> Okay.
>> Plain and simple, very quick.

134
00:08:43.860 --> 00:08:46.610
There are some pitfalls with that idea.

135
00:08:46.610 --> 00:08:48.990
It can be taken to extremes.

136
00:08:48.990 --> 00:08:52.790
If certain types of security testing or

137
00:08:52.790 --> 00:08:57.060
security mechanisms aren't built
into the software development

138
00:08:57.060 --> 00:09:01.440
mechanisms properly,
problems can creep into the code.

139
00:09:01.440 --> 00:09:06.440
For instance, part of what's called
continuous development has to do with

140
00:09:06.440 --> 00:09:11.440
testing nightly builds of codes to
ensure that they meet certain criteria.

141
00:09:12.950 --> 00:09:15.790
Side note, this is not on the test,
you won't even see or

142
00:09:15.790 --> 00:09:21.280
hear this term on the test, but there
is something called the OWASP Top 10.

143
00:09:21.280 --> 00:09:24.847
The Open Web Application
Security Project Top 10.

144
00:09:24.847 --> 00:09:30.030
Those include things like SQL injection,
cross-site scripting, etc., etc.

145
00:09:30.030 --> 00:09:34.350
Ensuring that code is not
susceptible to any of those,

146
00:09:34.350 --> 00:09:38.120
because they're called the top ten,
because they're the ten most frequently

147
00:09:38.120 --> 00:09:42.620
seen vulnerabilities on the Internet,
year after year after year, I might add.

148
00:09:42.620 --> 00:09:47.140
That if your code is not susceptible to
any vulnerabilities in the OWASP Top 10,

149
00:09:47.140 --> 00:09:50.949
you're probably doing a pretty good job of
managing your code and doing development.

150
00:09:53.370 --> 00:09:58.120
Another concept in SDLC tools and
techniques we talk about is prototyping.

151
00:09:58.120 --> 00:10:01.473
And that's building prototypes of
applications that you've never

152
00:10:01.473 --> 00:10:02.410
built before.

153
00:10:02.410 --> 00:10:05.950
You have no idea whether they're going
to work but you gotta try something, so

154
00:10:05.950 --> 00:10:06.880
you prototype them.

155
00:10:08.020 --> 00:10:10.830
That's where you'll see
very quick revisions.

156
00:10:10.830 --> 00:10:14.460
The oldest example I can think of,
this is with Windows.

157
00:10:14.460 --> 00:10:18.212
Most people may remember Windows 3 or
Windows 3.1.

158
00:10:18.212 --> 00:10:22.850
But very few people have ever
seen Windows 1 or Windows 2.

159
00:10:22.850 --> 00:10:25.290
There was a Windows 1 and
a Windows 2 version.

160
00:10:25.290 --> 00:10:26.830
Very few people have ever seen it.

161
00:10:26.830 --> 00:10:27.521
>> I have not.

162
00:10:27.521 --> 00:10:31.178
>> And Windows 3 and 3.1 and
3.5 stayed around not very long.

163
00:10:31.178 --> 00:10:34.530
3.5 in particular was very short-lived.

164
00:10:34.530 --> 00:10:37.867
But those were the testbeds before,
I don't think 1 or

165
00:10:37.867 --> 00:10:41.428
2 were ever actually released
to the public for purchase.

166
00:10:41.428 --> 00:10:45.760
I believe 3.0 was the very first
version of Windows ever released,

167
00:10:45.760 --> 00:10:47.040
that I'm aware of.

168
00:10:48.760 --> 00:10:51.100
There's another one called
rapid application development.

169
00:10:51.100 --> 00:10:53.200
That's another model that you used.

170
00:10:53.200 --> 00:10:55.510
It's very similar to Agile and

171
00:10:55.510 --> 00:10:58.915
that is designed for
rapid application development.

172
00:10:58.915 --> 00:11:02.925
It is the idea that we want to
very quickly move through modules,

173
00:11:02.925 --> 00:11:06.495
to get to where we need to go, and
we'll worry about security, and

174
00:11:06.495 --> 00:11:08.955
the process on the back-end of all that.

175
00:11:08.955 --> 00:11:13.995
Again, I think you can see,
that these kind of models tend to

176
00:11:13.995 --> 00:11:19.390
have the propensity to
introduce vulnerabilities

177
00:11:19.390 --> 00:11:24.570
because we're sometimes moving faster
with function than we are with security.

178
00:11:25.590 --> 00:11:29.020
My goal, my hope is some day we'll
be able to marry the two of those.

179
00:11:29.020 --> 00:11:31.700
I don't think they're incongruent, but

180
00:11:31.700 --> 00:11:35.600
a lot of coding people don't
seem to care about that.

181
00:11:35.600 --> 00:11:38.530
Or aren't willing to invest in
learning about how to change that.

182
00:11:38.530 --> 00:11:42.510
Their process and security people
have a tendency historically to kinda

183
00:11:42.510 --> 00:11:45.680
stomp their feet and
not want to work with developers either.

184
00:11:45.680 --> 00:11:52.590
I think there's a way we can find
some happy ground with that.

185
00:11:52.590 --> 00:11:58.780
And in those lines, are what
are called secure coding practices.

186
00:11:58.780 --> 00:12:01.630
More and more you are starting to see,
I don't know if it happens

187
00:12:01.630 --> 00:12:06.790
at New Horizons here, but more and
more around the country I am seeing

188
00:12:06.790 --> 00:12:11.500
courses on secure coding practices
being deployed in colleges and

189
00:12:11.500 --> 00:12:14.650
universities it is just beginning
to creep into the curriculum.

190
00:12:14.650 --> 00:12:16.710
More training facilities like this.

191
00:12:16.710 --> 00:12:21.666
Where you're seeing more and
more secure coding practice classes.

192
00:12:21.666 --> 00:12:26.130
So that we develop applications from
the ground up, thinking that well,

193
00:12:26.130 --> 00:12:31.098
if I'm gonna create a form field, then the
first thing I need to do is to ensure that

194
00:12:31.098 --> 00:12:35.490
I've instructed the application to
only accept certain kinds of data,

195
00:12:35.490 --> 00:12:38.449
certain length strings, etc., etc., etc.

196
00:12:38.449 --> 00:12:39.775
So that those aren't vulnerable.
>> There's validation in there.

197
00:12:39.775 --> 00:12:42.360
>> Yeah, exactly so
that they aren't vulnerable later on.

198
00:12:42.360 --> 00:12:45.750
Rather than just creating them on
the fly and worrying about it later,

199
00:12:45.750 --> 00:12:48.523
because we all know that those
kind of vulnerabilities.

200
00:12:48.523 --> 00:12:49.361
>> Later never comes.

201
00:12:49.361 --> 00:12:51.880
>> Yeah, exactly, exactly.

202
00:12:51.880 --> 00:12:56.420
So we're seeing more and
more secure coding practices being

203
00:12:56.420 --> 00:13:01.330
baked into the the culture
in coding environments, but

204
00:13:01.330 --> 00:13:04.480
it's still not as widespread
as I'd like to see it.

205
00:13:04.480 --> 00:13:05.670
>> Right.

206
00:13:05.670 --> 00:13:10.360
>> And then the last piece I wanna
talk about, sort of ties together with

207
00:13:10.360 --> 00:13:15.370
a couple of these and that has to do
with system version control systems.

208
00:13:16.490 --> 00:13:21.030
So things like Git,
I can't remember what Microsoft changed,

209
00:13:21.030 --> 00:13:24.710
it used to be called
the team something server.

210
00:13:24.710 --> 00:13:25.830
>> GitHub or?

211
00:13:25.830 --> 00:13:29.740
>> GitHub was one but
the Microsoft product were code where

212
00:13:29.740 --> 00:13:33.510
your code repositories, team server
I think is what it was called but

213
00:13:33.510 --> 00:13:36.350
they change it about every year or
every two years something like that.

214
00:13:36.350 --> 00:13:39.980
But basically the idea is
that you check code in and

215
00:13:39.980 --> 00:13:43.220
out as it's developed,
much like you would a document.

216
00:13:43.220 --> 00:13:47.140
Because you may have three different
coders or a dozen different coders working

217
00:13:47.140 --> 00:13:51.930
on the same software but on different
modules and you wanna ensure that you have

218
00:13:51.930 --> 00:13:57.010
correct code versioning so
that you don't break some functionality.

219
00:13:57.010 --> 00:14:01.640
Where this becomes really important is,
I see this I don't

220
00:14:01.640 --> 00:14:05.360
see it directly anymore because most of
this has moved up to cloud providers.

221
00:14:05.360 --> 00:14:09.290
But in days gone by,
when banks still used mainframes for

222
00:14:09.290 --> 00:14:13.580
conducting their transactions in-house,
they would typically buy a mainframe or

223
00:14:13.580 --> 00:14:17.460
they will lease it from IBM or
HP, something like that.

224
00:14:17.460 --> 00:14:22.830
And then IBM or HP will take care of
the software for them anytime there were

225
00:14:22.830 --> 00:14:28.370
software changes which were very,
very rare and coming, they

226
00:14:28.370 --> 00:14:32.620
would come with very specific instructions
on how the code was to be upgraded.

227
00:14:32.620 --> 00:14:37.370
And it was pretty much built
in that you couldn't break it.

228
00:14:37.370 --> 00:14:39.900
It was, you push this tape in and
leave it alone.

229
00:14:39.900 --> 00:14:43.100
The coders had already
designed it to install itself.

230
00:14:43.100 --> 00:14:44.940
You couldn't mess anything up.

231
00:14:44.940 --> 00:14:49.376
And generally the changes were very small.

232
00:14:49.376 --> 00:14:56.237
It was very rare that they would
actually change any of their code.

233
00:14:56.237 --> 00:15:00.696
Sort of the one of the standing
testimonials to mainframes is that their

234
00:15:00.696 --> 00:15:02.650
code is so rock solid.

235
00:15:02.650 --> 00:15:06.769
That we run our banking transactions
all over the country and

236
00:15:06.769 --> 00:15:10.890
across the world on mainframes
today that were still running

237
00:15:10.890 --> 00:15:14.543
code that was written in COBOL 50 or
60 years ago.

238
00:15:14.543 --> 00:15:15.705
>> That is impressive.

239
00:15:15.705 --> 00:15:17.345
>> It's extremely reliable.

240
00:15:17.345 --> 00:15:18.559
It's extremely resilient.

241
00:15:18.559 --> 00:15:22.601
It's almost no one understands the code
anymore, so in terms of hacking it's

242
00:15:22.601 --> 00:15:26.091
nothing like a web page where you
might be able to do a SQL injection or

243
00:15:26.091 --> 00:15:27.495
something like that.

244
00:15:27.495 --> 00:15:29.705
It's really, really robust.

245
00:15:29.705 --> 00:15:36.810
It's extremely fast, can handle millions
and millions of transactions in real time.

246
00:15:36.810 --> 00:15:38.530
And it's also extremely secure.

247
00:15:38.530 --> 00:15:40.850
It's been tested decade after decade.

248
00:15:42.090 --> 00:15:46.330
Those early mainframes were all built
on Department of Defense models, so,

249
00:15:46.330 --> 00:15:49.725
the code and the architecture,
the hardware architecture,

250
00:15:49.725 --> 00:15:54.572
etc., was built from the ground up to be
reliable, resilient and secure, all three.

251
00:15:54.572 --> 00:15:55.568
>> Wow, nice.

252
00:15:55.568 --> 00:16:00.283
>> So, that pretty much wraps it up for
the first session of the software

253
00:16:00.283 --> 00:16:05.920
development life cycle as well as the
acquisition development implementation.

254
00:16:05.920 --> 00:16:08.230
We'll have more of this
in our next episode.

255
00:16:08.230 --> 00:16:09.520
>> All right, right.

256
00:16:09.520 --> 00:16:10.570
Sounds good, Brian.

257
00:16:10.570 --> 00:16:13.520
Again, great stuff there, appreciate that.

258
00:16:13.520 --> 00:16:16.930
Remember, if you guys wanna get more
information look more in depth on any of

259
00:16:16.930 --> 00:16:21.110
these topics, make sure you pick up a copy

260
00:16:21.110 --> 00:16:26.080

261
00:16:26.080 --> 00:16:28.880

hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

262

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Brian continue explaining some key terms and definitions in reference to systems acquisitions, development, and implementation. Here they run through many terms and concepts that deal with Project Management which includes Request for Proposal, Project Portfolio, and Program Evaluation and Review Techniques(PERT). They also cover IT Resources and the IT Portfolio.

24

In terms of, what are the actual
steps involved for an auditor or for

34

[INAUDIBLE] places a great bit of
value and information on project

management throughout the five domains and
through the materials we talk about.

38

Because they part of our role as
auditors is auditing the project

management function of IT departments when

Right now, we're only gonna be

The first being request for
proposal or RFP.

00:03:55.950 --> 00:03:57.500

00:03:57.500 --> 00:04:03.030
and you can find more RFPs than you can
shake a stick at, in 30 seconds or less.

what a request for proposal looks like.

The really difficult part is figuring
out how those are written, and

If you've never written an RFP,
it's quite a bit of work and

that's part of what I
wanna talk about here.

way or is it basically just any kind of,

00:04:20.270 --> 00:04:22.530
as long as it is in some

00:04:24.170 --> 00:04:29.380
>> Well, there are a lot of different
formats out there that you will see and

00:04:29.380 --> 00:04:32.270
you'll run across
>> We're gonna talk specifically about

the steps involved that recommends.

So they should follow this
general guideline but

What it really boils down to
if you look at it from a,

there's two ways to approach it.

00:04:47.170 --> 00:04:53.120
One is from the check box view, which
is did it meet all these requirements

00:04:53.120 --> 00:04:57.480

86
00:04:57.480 --> 00:05:01.960
And as an auditor, I think what you'll
find over time is that there's a balance

00:05:01.960 --> 00:05:06.040

find, and that any organization needs to

88
00:05:06.040 --> 00:05:10.940

00:05:12.250 --> 00:05:16.410

So, the first step
before you even begin to

I don't think I can, yeah,

Phase two requirement's definition, that's

00:05:42.550 --> 00:05:46.850

you start talking to all the people

98
00:05:46.850 --> 00:05:52.380
involved with purchasing a new system or
acquiring a new system of some type.

99
00:05:52.380 --> 00:05:56.410

a virtual desktop environment.

100
00:05:56.410 --> 00:05:59.230
BDIs, or

101

Those sound like great ideas,

propositions in large companies.

103
00:06:05.370 --> 00:06:09.270

definitions in order to be able to get

00:06:09.270 --> 00:06:11.260

00:06:11.260 --> 00:06:12.730
Otherwise, they're going to say,
this is crazy,

00:06:12.730 --> 00:06:14.680
you just want to spend a bunch of money.

00:06:14.680 --> 00:06:17.550
So writing you requirements
in the definitions for

108
00:06:17.550 --> 00:06:20.240

109

The feasibility study, which Isaka

00:06:24.960 --> 00:06:26.820
I'm not sure I can get

Then after requirements
definitions are completed,

done in an environment where you've,

118

again, separated.

120

>> Might be a little
conflict of interest there.

00:07:11.937 --> 00:07:16.807

00:07:16.807 --> 00:07:20.730

>> You also wanna make sure that

by the IT steering committee,

typically consists and that there

137
00:08:04.545 --> 00:08:08.138
graphs in the book that show
the The organizational design of that.

138
00:08:08.138 --> 00:08:11.310
But, the steering committee
typically consists of

139
00:08:11.310 --> 00:08:15.880
senior level managers from all
the different competing departments.

140
00:08:15.880 --> 00:08:21.510
HR, IT, Operations,
the CFO could be involved.

141
00:08:21.510 --> 00:08:22.790
Lots of different people.

142
00:08:22.790 --> 00:08:28.590
We talked yesterday too, about the fact
that those committees can be very

143
00:08:28.590 --> 00:08:33.390

144
00:08:33.390 --> 00:08:34.760
That makes it a little tougher.

The bigger the organization the more
you can sort of spread the love

And lo and behold, they didn't realize it.

394
00:24:36.210 --> 00:24:41.260
Because they weren't addressing
the tables, but there were actually

395
00:24:41.260 --> 00:24:46.260
tables inside the database that contained
bank routing and account information.

396
00:24:46.260 --> 00:24:49.410
And it wasn't until I said, well show
me the database, and they went, yeah,

397
00:24:49.410 --> 00:24:51.220
there's a table with
banking information on it.

398
00:24:51.220 --> 00:24:52.830
Well, why is that there?

399
00:24:52.830 --> 00:24:53.700
Well we don't know.

400
00:24:53.700 --> 00:24:55.300
We just got handed the database.

401
00:24:55.300 --> 00:24:56.210
We don't publish that.

402
00:24:56.210 --> 00:24:58.320
We don't,
we're just looking at these tables.

403
00:24:58.320 --> 00:25:01.220
Well, but did you look at all
the tables to see if there was data

00:25:01.220 --> 00:25:03.180
in there that needs to be destroyed?

00:25:03.180 --> 00:25:04.540
And sure enough, we found a couple, so

00:25:04.540 --> 00:25:08.960
we were able to destroy those
tables inside the database.

407
00:25:08.960 --> 00:25:13.840
So anyway, those are the kinds
of things that you will

408
00:25:13.840 --> 00:25:18.980
run into in system development life
cycle acquisition, implementation.

409
00:25:18.980 --> 00:25:21.090
They don't call it destruction here.

410
00:25:21.090 --> 00:25:23.530
It's acquisition, development,
and implementation.

411
00:25:23.530 --> 00:25:25.760
But really, there should be another
word on the end of that title,

412
00:25:25.760 --> 00:25:30.640
which is destruction or decommissioning or
disposal or something like that.

413
00:25:30.640 --> 00:25:33.920
Because that, in my opinion,
I also have a security background,

00:25:33.920 --> 00:25:36.390
in case you students out
there don't know that.

That's every bit as important

416
00:25:39.500 --> 00:25:44.780
Because how many times a week do we read
in the newspaper where a stolen laptop,

417
00:25:44.780 --> 00:25:49.600
or a lost laptop, or a hard drive shows
up somewhere it shouldn't with tons and

00:25:49.600 --> 00:25:53.210
tons of data on it because
it wasn't encrypted?

>> My favorite is the least multi
device the printer, fax, copier thing.

00:25:58.318 --> 00:26:00.010
You said it's got a hard drive in it.

It's taking images of everything and

00:26:03.910 --> 00:26:08.120
You turn it back in, people are ransacking
these storage facilities to get these-

>> Yeah, one of the classic scams is

this guy shows up at your front door

loan because there's something wrong.

426
00:26:19.200 --> 00:26:20.840
You got a factory recall on it.

427
00:26:20.840 --> 00:26:23.970
He walks out the door with your system,

00:26:23.970 --> 00:26:26.860

00:26:26.860 --> 00:26:28.850

00:26:28.850 --> 00:26:34.420
Yeah, that's actually happened in a couple

00:26:34.420 --> 00:26:37.589
But so the point is, and

00:26:37.589 --> 00:26:42.510
disposable should also talk about.

433
00:26:42.510 --> 00:26:46.300
But we don't this isn't on the exam
just a little tid bit story is-

434
00:26:46.300 --> 00:26:48.350
>> Part of disclaimer random aside.

435
00:26:48.350 --> 00:26:50.330
>> Yeah repurposing.

436
00:26:50.330 --> 00:26:52.150
Yeah, so a lot of people don't do this.

437

I was in an organization
just a few weeks ago.

00:26:54.780 --> 00:26:58.598

00:26:58.598 --> 00:27:00.770
So that, cuz I do a lot of work there,
and when I come in,

00:27:00.770 --> 00:27:02.750
that way I've got a system to work with.

00:27:02.750 --> 00:27:07.130
And they'de simply taken someone else's

00:27:07.130 --> 00:27:08.150
So I logged in.

00:27:08.150 --> 00:27:10.750
The first thing I did being a security and
audit guy was go, well,

00:27:10.750 --> 00:27:13.020
number one,
you just violated all your policies.

00:27:13.020 --> 00:27:13.520
But number two,

00:27:13.520 --> 00:27:16.740
more importantly, there's actually stuff
on here I can pull off the hard drive.

447
00:27:16.740 --> 00:27:18.164
I run a little utility [NOISE].

448
00:27:18.164 --> 00:27:21.080
Pull up all the documents,
spreadsheets, everything there.

449
00:27:21.080 --> 00:27:22.620
I found malware on it.

450
00:27:22.620 --> 00:27:26.040
So the drive wasn't scrubbed
it wasn't repurposed it wasn't

00:27:26.040 --> 00:27:27.895

Because that's part of

00:27:31.700 --> 00:27:33.730
The drive should've been

Completely reimaged with a fresh image.

And only my profile stored on it so.

00:27:40.798 --> 00:27:43.720
>> Well, that just goes to show you

458
00:27:44.550 --> 00:27:47.180
Cuz if we don't,
then you have some sensitive data that,

you let this guy in your office and

00:27:49.559 --> 00:27:51.265
And that's what we wanna avoid, right?

461

And if he's auditing you,

462
00:27:53.463 --> 00:27:55.575
[LAUGH] He's gonna come and

463
00:27:55.575 --> 00:27:59.725
>> And more importantly, we forget

00:27:59.725 --> 00:28:03.825

steps that are necessary to do a good job.

00:28:03.825 --> 00:28:09.105
We forget sometimes that, and Isaac is

00:28:09.105 --> 00:28:13.500
That the whole purpose of what

467
00:28:13.500 --> 00:28:18.040
Not to check boxes and yell at people
because they aren't following policies and

468
00:28:18.040 --> 00:28:18.890
procedures.

469
00:28:18.890 --> 00:28:21.030
It's really to manage risk.

470
00:28:21.030 --> 00:28:23.420
And if they're doing
a good job of that then,

471
00:28:23.420 --> 00:28:25.920
our job is to help them, not punish them.

472
00:28:25.920 --> 00:28:28.530
And show them the error of their ways.

473

>> There you go right,
it's a gentle hand of guidance.

474

It's really a firm hand of vengeance.

Sorry. [LAUGH] >> So

>> Yes, I'm looking at our clock.

David Cannon and

Keel.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Brian describe what is involved with software acquisition. They also describe 2 software development models; the traditional Waterfall model which is slow to implement but highly reliable, and the Agile model which is fast to deploy, but can be more insecure. They also discuss the importance of Input controls as well as Quality Assurance(QA) and Quality Management(QM).

1

2
00:00:12.176 --> 00:00:16.416
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV,

3

I'm your host Daniel Lowry,
and in today's episode,

we're continuing with our CISA series,
that's right.

5

I've got the book right here.

6

The study guide, fourth edition,

7

the Certified Information Systems Auditor
exam.

8

And joining us in the studio today,

a treat, is one of the authors of said

sir, how's it going today?

11

>> Thanks, Daniel.

12

Good.
Thanks for having me again.

13
00:00:41.940 --> 00:00:44.200
In today's episode, we're going to talk,

14

we're going to continue our discussion of
system acquisition, implementation, etc.

15
00:00:49.623 --> 00:00:52.301
And today we're gonna, in this episode,

16
00:00:52.301 --> 00:00:58.510
we're gonna specifically talk about
software acquisition, implementation, etc.

17
00:00:58.510 --> 00:01:02.300
And the reason that this is an important
piece is because software is so

18
00:01:02.300 --> 00:01:05.480
much more complicated
today than hardware is.

19
00:01:05.480 --> 00:01:08.920
With hardware,
it's generally fairly easy to

20
00:01:08.920 --> 00:01:11.940
be very specific about
the requirements that you need.

21

You submit those to a vendor and
you get the hardware that you need with

22
00:01:14.860 --> 00:01:18.810
the proper amount of processing power,
RAM, storage, etc., etc.

23
00:01:20.130 --> 00:01:22.810
Software's much more complicated and

24
00:01:22.810 --> 00:01:30.060
can have much far-reaching problems or
impact if something goes wrong.

25
00:01:30.060 --> 00:01:35.060
Again if a hard drive fails in
a system today we have redundancy.

26
00:01:35.060 --> 00:01:37.880
Hardware's so much more reliable
today than it used to be.

27
00:01:37.880 --> 00:01:43.100
Often times we use virtualization so we
have complete backup copies of the system.

28
00:01:43.100 --> 00:01:46.630
We can have backup and
online in mere seconds.

29
00:01:46.630 --> 00:01:50.330
Software is not so easy again
you can be talking anywhere from

00:01:50.330 --> 00:01:53.570
thousands to literally
millions of lines of code.

31
00:01:53.570 --> 00:01:57.700
Very easy for mistakes to creep in,
and of course, again,

32
00:01:57.700 --> 00:02:04.000
focusing on risk management as
part of the audit industry.

33
00:02:04.000 --> 00:02:09.415
What we're really trying to do in terms of
the software acquisition, implementation,

34
00:02:09.415 --> 00:02:16.600
etc, life cycle is to ensure that the
companies that we're working with or for

35
00:02:16.600 --> 00:02:22.430
are doing their proper due
diligence in evaluating software.

36
00:02:22.430 --> 00:02:26.120
Ensuring that it's developed properly so
that

37
00:02:27.230 --> 00:02:32.080
when it's completed not only does it

00:02:32.080 --> 00:02:36.520

Things like completeness and accuracy

that kind of transactional log system that

42
00:02:49.890 --> 00:02:54.180
two decades now with systems
to ensure that transactions

43
00:02:54.180 --> 00:02:58.860
are 100% accurate and complete

44
00:02:58.860 --> 00:03:00.799
There's a system built
in to check all that.

45
00:03:02.170 --> 00:03:05.300
So, I wanna start off by talking
about a couple of different

46
00:03:05.300 --> 00:03:08.080
models of software development.

47
00:03:08.080 --> 00:03:13.080
These will be on the test, you'll need to
know the fundamentals, not the details,

48
00:03:13.080 --> 00:03:16.730
I'm gonna go into a few more details

less experienced auditors to understand

50
00:03:22.480 --> 00:03:26.420
Typically, we have a tendency to
focus on policies and processes.

51
00:03:26.420 --> 00:03:29.820
And checking whether people
are following their policies, etcetera.

52
00:03:29.820 --> 00:03:34.570
But software is such a huge
part of what we're doing.

53
00:03:34.570 --> 00:03:39.490
It's basically the interface between
hardware and the outside world.

54
00:03:39.490 --> 00:03:42.708
That it's really important that we
understand how software is developed,

55
00:03:42.708 --> 00:03:47.050
tested, implemented, etc.

56
00:03:47.050 --> 00:03:50.170
So the first model we're
gonna talk about is

57
00:03:50.170 --> 00:03:53.740
a more traditional called
the waterfall model.

58
00:03:53.740 --> 00:03:55.020
Wink, wink.

59
00:03:55.020 --> 00:03:57.310
This will probably be on the test.

60
00:03:57.310 --> 00:04:00.800
The waterfall model really talks about

61
00:04:02.080 --> 00:04:06.400

concrete steps and stages,

62
00:04:07.730 --> 00:04:12.950
none of which will allow the next to start

63
00:04:12.950 --> 00:04:18.150
So step A must be completed and
signed off before step B can begin.

64
00:04:18.150 --> 00:04:20.550
Or process B or section B.

65
00:04:20.550 --> 00:04:22.440
Same thing with section C.

66
00:04:22.440 --> 00:04:25.190
Section C cannot start, or begin,

67
00:04:25.190 --> 00:04:29.230
until section B has been completed and
signed off.

68
00:04:29.230 --> 00:04:35.640
I forget what the term is,
but therefore section C

69
00:04:35.640 --> 00:04:40.530
can't begin until both A and
B have been completed and signed off.

70
00:04:40.530 --> 00:04:48.660
So you can see how very quickly this
can be a slow drudgery process.

71
00:04:48.660 --> 00:04:49.950
Developers hate it.

72
00:04:51.410 --> 00:04:57.140
It is extremely reliable,
which is why it was developed early on.

73
00:04:57.140 --> 00:05:02.080
In particular with Mainframe software
back in the 70s, 60s and 70s and 80s.

74
00:05:02.080 --> 00:05:06.390
The model was developed because it was
very important in those days, one little

75
00:05:06.390 --> 00:05:10.970
bit or one little byte out of place
could wreak havoc across a main frame.

76
00:05:12.140 --> 00:05:14.110
In today's world, it's very common for

77
00:05:14.110 --> 00:05:17.850
all kinds of vulnerabilities to creep
into software which is why we're

78
00:05:17.850 --> 00:05:20.980
gonna talk a little bit about some
of the other models and testing etc.

79
00:05:20.980 --> 00:05:24.590
because there's so many hundreds
of thousands of lines of code.

80
00:05:24.590 --> 00:05:27.160
There's so many different languages.

81
00:05:27.160 --> 00:05:30.130
It's just very easy for
errors to creep in.

82
00:05:30.130 --> 00:05:33.590
So it's extremely important for
us to find ways to test for that.

83
00:05:35.070 --> 00:05:38.920
And because of the rapid
deployment cycle we live in today

84
00:05:38.920 --> 00:05:41.339
we don't have the time of
the waterfall model anymore.

85
00:05:42.560 --> 00:05:47.880
There are still some certain
mission critical areas where it's

used like in banking and in mainframe
programming where this occurs.

87
00:05:52.520 --> 00:05:57.358
In the financial services industry,
for instance, most banks today with

88
00:05:57.358 --> 00:06:01.980
the exception of the very, very large,
Chase's and Wells Fargo's.

89
00:06:01.980 --> 00:06:06.179
And those who have their own systems

90
00:06:06.179 --> 00:06:09.710
you know your local regional
lake city bank or whatever here.

91
00:06:09.710 --> 00:06:11.200
I don't know if I can say that or
not here.

92
00:06:11.200 --> 00:06:12.068
>> That's fine.

93
00:06:12.068 --> 00:06:13.540
>> in etc.

94
00:06:13.540 --> 00:06:17.280
They typically use cloud server providers

00:06:17.280 --> 00:06:21.410
the back end that do all the transactions

00:06:21.410 --> 00:06:24.270

97
00:06:24.270 --> 00:06:27.580
It is written and maintained in these

00:06:27.580 --> 00:06:29.670
centers across the world or
across the country.

99
00:06:31.090 --> 00:06:35.046
The code in those was written
40 years ago or longer

00:06:35.046 --> 00:06:37.633
>> were talking cobalt and horse ram.

101
00:06:37.633 --> 00:06:38.850
>> Cobalt actually.

102
00:06:38.850 --> 00:06:40.920
Exclusively Cobalt.

103
00:06:40.920 --> 00:06:45.210
In fact one very large bank that I
worked with last year in Indiana,

00:06:45.210 --> 00:06:50.140
has over 1.5 million lines of code
written in COBAL in the mainframe systems

105
00:06:50.140 --> 00:06:53.588
they use to manage your student loans.

106
00:06:53.588 --> 00:06:56.420
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So

107
00:06:56.420 --> 00:07:01.650
they very rarely change that code and
when they do, they go through exhaustive

108
00:07:01.650 --> 00:07:06.510
regressive testing to make sure that
nothing can go wrong in the transactions.

109
00:07:06.510 --> 00:07:07.650
Because if it did,

110
00:07:07.650 --> 00:07:11.870
it could cost them millions of dollars

111
00:07:11.870 --> 00:07:14.240
So it has to be absolutely rock solid.

112
00:07:14.240 --> 00:07:15.700
It has to be needed.

113
00:07:15.700 --> 00:07:20.110
They don't just patch stuff because
somebody thought it was a good idea.

114
00:07:20.110 --> 00:07:26.270
The other side of that is their code has
been regression tested for 40 to 50 years.

115
00:07:26.270 --> 00:07:29.960
And we know that it's rock solid and

116
00:07:31.030 --> 00:07:36.210
They have safeguards built in so that for

00:07:36.210 --> 00:07:40.730
one of the things we talk about are ACH or

automated batch transfers where I

00:07:46.900 --> 00:07:49.390

the federal reserve bank and

00:07:49.390 --> 00:07:52.060
clears overnight and
the money gets transferred, etc.

121
00:07:52.060 --> 00:07:54.880
There are a number of
steps in that process.

122
00:07:54.880 --> 00:07:58.738
If any one of those steps fails,
the entire transaction backs out and

00:20:54.350 --> 00:20:58.690
how an attacker does this, and how they
garner information about your company's or

355
00:20:58.690 --> 00:21:01.310
the company you're working with systems.

356
00:21:01.310 --> 00:21:05.956
So that you understand as part of
the system development lifecycle.

357
00:21:05.956 --> 00:21:09.111
We talked in the previous
episode about the review stage.

358
00:21:09.111 --> 00:21:12.376
Well that's where we get into, and
we're not required to know how to do this,

359
00:21:12.376 --> 00:21:14.267
unless it's something that interests you.

360
00:21:14.267 --> 00:21:17.298
Doing vulnerability scanning and
doing vulnerability

361
00:21:17.298 --> 00:21:21.690
assessments on your applications to
make sure that they're patched properly.

362
00:21:21.690 --> 00:21:28.875
A large majority of the systems we
work with are Windows based servers.

363
00:21:28.875 --> 00:21:33.134
So the applications run on a Windows
Server all the way from, believe it or

364
00:21:33.134 --> 00:21:36.365
not, there's still people
running Server 2000,

365
00:21:36.365 --> 00:21:39.409
clear up to Server 2016
which is available now.

366
00:21:39.409 --> 00:21:45.600
And not knowing that those servers
may bee grilled with vulnerabilities.

367
00:21:45.600 --> 00:21:48.952
So it's important that you
understand how all this works,

368
00:21:48.952 --> 00:21:52.319
how it fits together in the system
development life cycle.

369
00:21:52.319 --> 00:21:56.849
The last thing I wanna talk about
was QA and QM, quality assurance and

370
00:21:56.849 --> 00:21:58.344
quality management.

371
00:21:58.344 --> 00:22:04.570
Just talking I wanna refer back to both
the agile and water file methods in that.

372
00:22:04.570 --> 00:22:08.945
Those are both quality assurance and
quality management methods for

373
00:22:08.945 --> 00:22:10.460
developing software.

374
00:22:12.260 --> 00:22:15.896
And that you be familiar with those
terms with the QA and the Qa.

375
00:22:15.896 --> 00:22:18.940
Definitions are in the book, there's
more reading about this in the book.

376
00:22:18.940 --> 00:22:24.750
And there is more information on the ISACA
website at www.isaca.org, as well.

377
00:22:24.750 --> 00:22:28.745
So I think we're gonna wrap it up
with that for this morning session.

378
00:22:28.745 --> 00:22:31.264
I think that's enough to chew off for
one more session and

379
00:22:31.264 --> 00:22:33.440
we'll see you back here at the next one.

380
00:22:33.440 --> 00:22:36.520
>> All right Brian, you've definitely
given us a lot to chew on,

381
00:22:36.520 --> 00:22:40.530
but we do appreciate you stopping by and
enlightening our minds to these very facts

382
00:22:40.530 --> 00:22:42.699
and things that we need to know for
the exam.

383
00:22:42.699 --> 00:22:44.210
That's kind of an important thing as well.

384
00:22:44.210 --> 00:22:46.440
That being said, don't forget everyone,

385
00:22:46.440 --> 00:22:50.260
pick up a copy of the new Study Guide
Fourth Edition that our good friend Mr.

386
00:22:50.260 --> 00:22:52.630
Brian O'Hara here is
one of the authors of.

387
00:22:52.630 --> 00:22:56.600
So grab that from Wiley,
I believe is the publishers on that.

388
00:22:56.600 --> 00:23:00.460
And that being said, I'm looking at our
clock, it is totally out of time for us.

389
00:23:00.460 --> 00:23:04.111
Thank you guys for watching, signing
off for ITProTV, I've been your host,

390
00:23:04.111 --> 00:23:04.898
Daniel Lowery.

391
00:23:04.898 --> 00:23:06.180
>> And I'm Brian O'Hara.

392
00:23:06.180 --> 00:23:08.650
>> And we'll see you next time.

393
00:23:08.650 --> 00:23:13.225

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Brian discuss the Human Resource element of systems acquisition, development, and implementation. They give you an overview of the many IT job roles like IT Operations Manager, System Architect, Change Control Manager, App developer, and Help Desk Support, and their importance.

WEBVTT

1

17

Anyway, so today we're going

18
00:00:58.830 --> 00:01:03.100
the information system acquisition
development and implementation domain.

19
00:01:03.100 --> 00:01:07.760
Domain 3 in your CISA
study prep materials.

00:01:07.760 --> 00:01:09.600
And, in this episode I want to talk about,

21

I want to get down to
the weeds a little bit.

22
00:01:11.550 --> 00:01:17.030
I kept a couple sessions rather higher
levels, talking about policies and

23
00:01:17.030 --> 00:01:20.410
steering committees and
how things are supposed to work.

24

This episode I want to
get down in the weeds and
