talk about who is actually
doing all of this stuff.

26
00:01:24.510 --> 00:01:28.050
Who's doing all the testing
of these applications or

27
00:01:28.050 --> 00:01:32.260
these systems and what are the roles and
how do they all fit together?

28
00:01:32.260 --> 00:01:38.182
So, and again, I want to stress that
iSocket is a world wide organization

29
00:01:38.182 --> 00:01:42.970
with over 118,000 members
in 80 some countries.

30
00:01:42.970 --> 00:01:46.870
So, they tend to take a very large
enterprise view of the universe, and

31
00:01:46.870 --> 00:01:50.410
that's what we're going to
be talking about today.

32
00:01:50.410 --> 00:01:53.690
This doesn't mean that every IT
organization you work in, or

33
00:01:53.690 --> 00:01:58.620
even any of the IT organizations you work
in are going to have this many folks

34
00:01:58.620 --> 00:02:04.616
involved in the acquisition implementation
or design phases of information systems.

35
00:02:04.616 --> 00:02:07.070
But, we want to talk about them because
you need to be familiar with them

36
00:02:07.070 --> 00:02:07.680
on the exam.

37
00:02:07.680 --> 00:02:10.960
And, it's important for
you to know as your career grows and

38
00:02:10.960 --> 00:02:14.020
you move into more complex environments.

39
00:02:14.020 --> 00:02:15.440
So, [COUGH] Excuse me.

40
00:02:15.440 --> 00:02:16.830
At the top of the food chain.

41
00:02:16.830 --> 00:02:18.450
And one other sidenote real quick.

42
00:02:18.450 --> 00:02:24.650
We've talked about resources and

43
00:02:24.650 --> 00:02:27.550
what are information systems, and

44
00:02:27.550 --> 00:02:32.695
I mentioned a couple of episodes ago about
human resources being part of the systems.

45
00:02:32.695 --> 00:02:35.170
That`s what we are really
talking about today.

46
00:02:35.170 --> 00:02:40.028
These resource individuals are part of
your information access management,

47
00:02:40.028 --> 00:02:46.610
excuse me acquisition, implementation and
management of information systems.

48
00:02:46.610 --> 00:02:50.660
They are assets that help us
deploy all that stuff and

49
00:02:50.660 --> 00:02:54.830
make sure that we're managing
risk to acceptable levels.

50
00:02:54.830 --> 00:02:58.380
So, we'll start off there are actually
17 roles outlined in the book in

51
00:02:58.380 --> 00:02:59.100
chapter five.

52
00:02:59.100 --> 00:03:01.670
If you take a look I
forget the exact page.

53
00:03:01.670 --> 00:03:04.230
But, it starts with the IT director.

54
00:03:04.230 --> 00:03:05.330
And, you can go through the book and

55
00:03:05.330 --> 00:03:09.610
read these for yourself and see
the definitions, but I want to talk about

56
00:03:09.610 --> 00:03:13.990
each of the roles simply because my years
of experience give me the ability to talk

57
00:03:13.990 --> 00:03:18.600
about how I've seen these roles played
out in different organizations.

58
00:03:18.600 --> 00:03:24.160
So, the IT director is typically
someone who works below the CIO level.

59
00:03:24.160 --> 00:03:26.910
They are involved in
day to day operations.

60
00:03:26.910 --> 00:03:34.310
The CIO is more interested or
busier dealing with things like budgets,

61
00:03:34.310 --> 00:03:38.040
overall project management of
multiple project portfolios.

62
00:03:38.040 --> 00:03:42.240
Where the IT director is generally
in charge of just a small portion of

63
00:03:43.540 --> 00:03:47.040
the IT domain if you will,
having to do with systems.

64
00:03:48.540 --> 00:03:52.970
Below the IT Director, generally there's
an operations manager of some kind.

65
00:03:52.970 --> 00:03:55.450
Or, the IT Director have
some type of staff.

66
00:03:55.450 --> 00:03:57.920
Again, we're talking about
a very large organization.

67
00:03:57.920 --> 00:04:01.040
Maybe thousands of employees
in multiple locations.

68
00:04:01.040 --> 00:04:03.950
And in fact,
there may be multiple operation managers,

69
00:04:03.950 --> 00:04:08.680
depending on how large your organization
is and how big the IT staff is.

70
00:04:08.680 --> 00:04:12.200
I remember years ago working
with a large automobile,

71
00:04:13.340 --> 00:04:18.066
car auction company that had

72
00:04:18.066 --> 00:04:24.220
an IT budget in somewhere in the
neighborhood of $50 to $75 million a year.

73
00:04:24.220 --> 00:04:24.770
And they had.

74
00:04:24.770 --> 00:04:25.851
>> So it's a small shop.

75
00:04:25.851 --> 00:04:26.542
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

76
00:04:26.542 --> 00:04:31.430
[LAUGH] Yeah, they had roughly 250
IT employees with multiple managers,

77
00:04:31.430 --> 00:04:35.910
that multiple managers working under
IT directors in different states,

78
00:04:35.910 --> 00:04:38.060
in different regions,
even some outside the country.

79
00:04:38.060 --> 00:04:40.760
They had operations in Canada and Mexico.

80
00:04:41.950 --> 00:04:47.710
The number of IT operation managers
can vary depending on the size or

81
00:04:47.710 --> 00:04:48.970
the organization.

82
00:04:48.970 --> 00:04:50.230
The point being that the, and

83
00:04:50.230 --> 00:04:54.100
these typically have a direct
reporting structure up and down.

84
00:04:54.100 --> 00:04:59.460
You'll see multiple IT operation
managers reporting to the IT director,

85
00:04:59.460 --> 00:05:01.320
and generally there's only one director.

86
00:05:01.320 --> 00:05:03.600
They may break it up and
call it something different, but

87
00:05:03.600 --> 00:05:05.510
generally you've only got one director,

88
00:05:05.510 --> 00:05:10.080
who then reports up to the CIO because
he may have, the CIO, may in fact have

89
00:05:10.080 --> 00:05:14.030
a project management office director
that reports to him as well, or her.

90
00:05:14.030 --> 00:05:20.430
And, in many organizations, to my dismay,
the CISO will report directly to the CIO.

91
00:05:20.430 --> 00:05:22.690
The Chief Information Security Officer.

92
00:05:22.690 --> 00:05:27.680
But, again, it's important that you
understand that these positions exist,

93
00:05:27.680 --> 00:05:28.900
and their functions.

94
00:05:28.900 --> 00:05:30.850
>> Got to know the pecking order.

95
00:05:30.850 --> 00:05:35.940
>> Not so much the pecking order as
the fact that they provide a very

96
00:05:35.940 --> 00:05:39.425
functional role in the organization
in terms of getting things done.

97
00:05:39.425 --> 00:05:42.048
Because it takes a lot of people-
>> Do they really, Brian?

98
00:05:42.048 --> 00:05:43.440
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] It

99
00:05:43.440 --> 00:05:46.990
takes a lot of people to keep
these large organizations running.

100
00:05:46.990 --> 00:05:49.070
>> And, you tend to see this with
larger organizations, right?

101
00:05:49.070 --> 00:05:50.080
>> Right.
>> And then smaller shops,

102
00:05:50.080 --> 00:05:54.100
obviously there's just not enough
personnel to facilitate or need.

103
00:05:54.100 --> 00:05:57.870
>> And there's not a need, that's right,
there's typically not a need for that.

104
00:05:57.870 --> 00:06:04.210
And, in addition to that in smaller shops,
folks often wear multiple hats.

105
00:06:04.210 --> 00:06:07.785
So, they may be both an operations
manager and an IT director.

106
00:06:07.785 --> 00:06:09.190
>> [LAUGH]
>> It just depends on the-

107
00:06:09.190 --> 00:06:10.300
>> And the janitor.

108
00:06:10.300 --> 00:06:13.020
>> And the janitor,
exactly, etcetera, etcetera.

109
00:06:13.020 --> 00:06:16.440
So, the next role that I'd like
to talk a little bit about,

110
00:06:16.440 --> 00:06:20.710
which is really rather important,
is the system architect and

111
00:06:20.710 --> 00:06:24.558
I get asked quite often why
are they called architects?

112
00:06:24.558 --> 00:06:27.470
Well, an architect in

113
00:06:27.470 --> 00:06:31.580
the realm of buildings is the person
who designs the building.

114
00:06:31.580 --> 00:06:34.220
And, when I say design I
mean they draw the pictures.

115
00:06:34.220 --> 00:06:37.700
They don't actually get down in the weeds
with, what kind of steel you use,

116
00:06:37.700 --> 00:06:38.970
although they might.

117
00:06:38.970 --> 00:06:42.660
They don't get down in the weeds with,
what's the local code for

118
00:06:42.660 --> 00:06:44.760
how much rebar has to be put in concrete,

119
00:06:44.760 --> 00:06:48.140
depending on how deep the basement is,
blah, blah, blah, all the details.

120
00:06:48.140 --> 00:06:52.530
They're the Frank Lloyd Wrights of
the world who design beautiful sculptures

121
00:06:52.530 --> 00:06:57.150
of buildings, and then let the engineers
figure out how to actually build it, okay?

122
00:06:57.150 --> 00:06:58.630
System architects are very similar.

123
00:06:58.630 --> 00:07:02.140
They're the ones who design
the systems that say, well,

124
00:07:02.140 --> 00:07:04.430
we're going to need 16 CPU cores.

125
00:07:04.430 --> 00:07:07.400
We're going to need at
least 64 gig of RAM, and

126
00:07:07.400 --> 00:07:12.350
we need flash drives because this is
a web-based application for e-commerce.

127
00:07:12.350 --> 00:07:15.080
And, the last thing we want
to do is have it running slow

128
00:07:15.080 --> 00:07:17.520
when people want to be doing transactions.

129
00:07:17.520 --> 00:07:22.590
Or, they might say well, these
systems are the ones that we're going

130
00:07:22.590 --> 00:07:27.450
to use during the holiday season
when our traffic is the heaviest.

131
00:07:27.450 --> 00:07:31.840
Or, they may say, let's design
something up in the AWS cloud for

132
00:07:31.840 --> 00:07:35.970
scaling up during the holidays and
we'll only use it during that period.

133
00:07:35.970 --> 00:07:38.140
And then, when we're finished,
well, we'll scale it back down.

134
00:07:38.140 --> 00:07:41.050
We'll shut those services off so that
they're, because they're no longer needed.

135
00:07:41.050 --> 00:07:45.780
>> Yeah Brian, it sounds like
the architects have to a very, overall

136
00:07:45.780 --> 00:07:50.940
an encompassing foundational knowledge
of the IT systems as a whole.

137
00:07:50.940 --> 00:07:53.149
>> Right.
>> So, that they can effectively design

138
00:07:53.149 --> 00:07:55.589
these systems to work
the way we need them to.

139
00:07:55.589 --> 00:07:56.689
>> That's right Daniel,

140
00:07:56.689 --> 00:07:59.549
your architects are sometimes
some of the brightest people.

141
00:07:59.549 --> 00:08:03.583
The problem you have to be
careful with is they oftentimes

142
00:08:03.583 --> 00:08:06.525
>> Have great ideas, but they don't

143
00:08:06.525 --> 00:08:13.128
realize there are stumbling blocks to
implementing those kinds of systems.

144
00:08:13.128 --> 00:08:16.348
So, the system architects
are the ones who develop the needs.

145
00:08:16.348 --> 00:08:19.389
We talked in the previous
episode about that process

146
00:08:19.389 --> 00:08:22.014
of finding out what
the customer needs are for

147
00:08:22.014 --> 00:08:26.178
the application or system,
what it ever is that they're looking for.

148
00:08:26.178 --> 00:08:29.763
The system architect is the one
who takes all that and says, well,

149
00:08:29.763 --> 00:08:32.965
if this customer is saying that
we need this much capacity,

150
00:08:32.965 --> 00:08:35.797
then we're gonna have to
design a system like this.

151
00:08:35.797 --> 00:08:39.980
A system architect is very involved
when you're talking about telling

152
00:08:39.980 --> 00:08:43.128
communications and
designing redundant circuits.

153
00:08:43.128 --> 00:08:44.848
Designing redundant hardware.

154
00:08:44.848 --> 00:08:49.588
So that if a firewall, for instance fails,
you still have some safety in place,

155
00:08:49.588 --> 00:08:53.788
a safety net in place and you're able
to continue to conduct business.

156
00:08:53.788 --> 00:08:54.968
Things like that, so

157
00:08:54.968 --> 00:08:58.978
they architect all kinds of things
are a very important part of the team.

158
00:08:58.978 --> 00:09:02.318
It's often times is smaller organizations.

159
00:09:02.318 --> 00:09:06.474
It's a service that's outsourced,
because it is so critical and

160
00:09:06.474 --> 00:09:09.378
companies often times
don't have the staff.

161
00:09:09.378 --> 00:09:13.648
You'll see system architects
both in IT and in security.

162
00:09:13.648 --> 00:09:18.481
Security architects are also something
that you see in a lot of larger

163
00:09:18.481 --> 00:09:22.982
organizations, because it takes
a lot of years of knowledge and

164
00:09:22.982 --> 00:09:27.338
understanding of the complexity
of the products available.

165
00:09:27.338 --> 00:09:31.289
And the pitfalls of deploying
applications to understand

166
00:09:31.289 --> 00:09:35.808
how to build security systems to
protect those systems, as well.

167
00:09:35.808 --> 00:09:40.931
And then lastly, of course,
with the onslaught of attacks

168
00:09:40.931 --> 00:09:47.498
like the recent banking attack in
Bangladesh that cost the bank over there.

169
00:09:47.498 --> 00:09:49.238
I believe it was $18 million.

170
00:09:49.238 --> 00:09:53.318
I saw at lunch,
I got an update on the attack over there.

171
00:09:53.318 --> 00:09:56.468
So your system architects are really,
really, really very important.

172
00:09:56.468 --> 00:09:59.731
Your IT directors a little bit
more of a higher level manager

173
00:09:59.731 --> 00:10:01.438
than your operation manager.

174
00:10:01.438 --> 00:10:06.260
Your system architect usually
sits off to the side, but

175
00:10:06.260 --> 00:10:09.858
a very, very important part of the team.

176
00:10:09.858 --> 00:10:14.022
Below that or next to that,
I should say next to the line, but

177
00:10:14.022 --> 00:10:17.546
next to that is the information
security manager.

178
00:10:17.546 --> 00:10:20.866
And I wanna take just
a quick minute to mention,

179
00:10:20.866 --> 00:10:24.858
ISACA has a certification called,
which I hold as well.

180
00:10:24.858 --> 00:10:28.558
The CISM or
Certified Information Security Manager.

181
00:10:28.558 --> 00:10:34.448
Those CISMs are designed to fit into
this slot, and work with CIOs, etc.

182
00:10:34.448 --> 00:10:38.711
A security manager is
someone who works with

183
00:10:38.711 --> 00:10:43.558
security analysts,
that's the next rung down.

184
00:10:43.558 --> 00:10:47.116
Much like the system architect and
the operation manager,

185
00:10:47.116 --> 00:10:51.883
the information security analyst is led
by the information security manager to

186
00:10:51.883 --> 00:10:56.723
help them ensure that things occur like

00:23:54.568 --> 00:23:59.368
to a certain level to be able to assist
the end user when they run into problems.

415
00:23:59.368 --> 00:24:00.663
>> Is that what we were
supposed to be doing?

416
00:24:00.663 --> 00:24:01.410
>> Yeah.

417
00:24:01.410 --> 00:24:03.066
[LAUGH]
>> So,

418
00:24:03.066 --> 00:24:06.900
a great example of this most recently,
I really have to brag about this.

419
00:24:06.900 --> 00:24:11.860
I'm doing a project with a rather
large state government, and

420
00:24:11.860 --> 00:24:15.590
I needed some help with my laptop
that they had issued for me.

421
00:24:15.590 --> 00:24:20.310
And I wasn't really expecting a great
experience, but it's happened two or

422
00:24:20.310 --> 00:24:22.830
three times now, so
I know it's system wide.

423
00:24:22.830 --> 00:24:24.580
Absolutely blew my mind away.

424
00:24:24.580 --> 00:24:26.940
They were so awesome to work with.

425
00:24:26.940 --> 00:24:29.560
They had all the tools they
needed at their fingertips.

426
00:24:29.560 --> 00:24:32.920
They were able to get what I
needed run through very quickly.

427
00:24:32.920 --> 00:24:35.250
Because some of the questions
asked they weren't sure of.

428
00:24:35.250 --> 00:24:38.860
Could I install a printer in
my home across their VPN?

429
00:24:38.860 --> 00:24:41.289
Hmm, let me check,
I gotta ask my boss that real quick.

430
00:24:41.289 --> 00:24:44.122
Boom, [SOUND] got it,
got my printers installed, ready to go.

431
00:24:44.122 --> 00:24:46.583
So a really top-notch organization.

432
00:24:46.583 --> 00:24:48.403
I was really very impressed
with their help desk.

433
00:24:48.403 --> 00:24:51.527
>> A good help desk is really
worth its weight in gold.

434
00:24:51.527 --> 00:24:53.852
>> Absolutely.
>> As I got up and I left the help desk,

435
00:24:53.852 --> 00:24:58.222
I started becoming a higher level of
support and a systems administrator,

436
00:24:58.222 --> 00:24:58.881
>> Right.

437
00:24:58.881 --> 00:25:01.681
>> And just dealing with other help
desks and how much they really just

438
00:25:01.681 --> 00:25:05.043
want to pass the buck and make it,
it's your fault, it's your computer.

439
00:25:05.043 --> 00:25:06.213
Can't help you, sorry about that.

440
00:25:06.213 --> 00:25:06.718
>> Yeah, reboot [LAUGH].

441
00:25:06.718 --> 00:25:08.800
>> And I'm like,
let's revisit this there really quickly.

442
00:25:08.800 --> 00:25:10.160
>> Yeah, or they wanna do this thing.

443
00:25:10.160 --> 00:25:11.900
>> Yeah, yeah,
they'll do this number right there, yeah.

444
00:25:11.900 --> 00:25:13.136
>> The hardware and the software guys.

445
00:25:13.136 --> 00:25:14.404
Well you must have installed something
on your machine we don't support.

446
00:25:14.404 --> 00:25:16.145
>> Yeah, yeah.

447
00:25:16.145 --> 00:25:17.129
>> Yeah, one of those.

448
00:25:17.129 --> 00:25:22.062
So anyway, so that's the list of
folks who are involved in this

449
00:25:22.062 --> 00:25:26.760
system acquisition development and
implementation.

450
00:25:26.760 --> 00:25:29.280
It's important that you have some
fundamental understanding of

451
00:25:29.280 --> 00:25:31.584
those different roles and
how they play into all this.

452
00:25:31.584 --> 00:25:35.990
And I think you're beginning to see
that there's this gigantic wheel and

453
00:25:35.990 --> 00:25:39.120
there's all these little gears, and
that's what we've been trying to

454
00:25:39.120 --> 00:25:42.490
talk about in each of these sessions,
is try to break it down into livable,

455
00:25:42.490 --> 00:25:47.250
useable chunks of gears that make
that big system run efficiently,

456
00:25:47.250 --> 00:25:52.450
at a level of risk that
the organization can tolerate,

457
00:25:52.450 --> 00:25:55.190
and reaches its strategic goals and
objectives.

458
00:25:55.190 --> 00:25:56.250
>> That's excellent stuff.

459
00:25:56.250 --> 00:25:58.510
And it's definitely things
that we need to be aware of.

460
00:25:58.510 --> 00:26:02.160
We have to have these
fundamental concepts and

461
00:26:02.160 --> 00:26:05.950
ideas underneath our belts, in our tool
kits, because if we don't then, A,

462
00:26:05.950 --> 00:26:08.670
we're gonna have a hard time
on this exam most likely.

463
00:26:08.670 --> 00:26:11.879
And B, it's just helpful for
us in our actual day to day environments.

464
00:26:11.879 --> 00:26:15.451
As an auditor, when you're going
out there, if you don't understand

465
00:26:15.451 --> 00:26:18.605
the different roles that are being
played in the IT structure,

466
00:26:18.605 --> 00:26:22.594
then you're gonna have a hard time
pinpointing who's responsible for what and

467
00:26:22.594 --> 00:26:25.959
then you're not gonna be able to
make sense of the spaghetti mess,

468
00:26:25.959 --> 00:26:26.888
>> That's right.

469
00:26:26.888 --> 00:26:29.351
>> That can be an IT house or
shop [LAUGH].

470
00:26:29.351 --> 00:26:30.628
>> Yep, absolutely.

471
00:26:30.628 --> 00:26:32.354
>> Well Brian, we do thank you for
unraveling that mess for

472
00:26:32.354 --> 00:26:32.997
us,
>> You're welcome.

473
00:26:32.997 --> 00:26:36.698
>> And giving some more insight into that
for ourselves, so we can use that and

474
00:26:36.698 --> 00:26:37.785
pass the exam.

475
00:26:37.785 --> 00:26:40.680
Don't forget guys, pick up the CISA book.

476
00:26:40.680 --> 00:26:42.210
One of the authors sitting right here,

477
00:26:42.210 --> 00:26:44.630
giving you the lowdown on
what is inside of here.

478
00:26:44.630 --> 00:26:48.520
Obviously great material that you're gonna
need, great study guide help for you guys.

479
00:26:48.520 --> 00:26:51.670
That being said, looks like we've
run out of time for this episode.

480
00:26:51.670 --> 00:26:52.850
We thank you for watching.

481
00:26:52.850 --> 00:26:55.039
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

482
00:26:55.039 --> 00:26:56.664
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

483
00:26:56.664 --> 00:26:57.825
>> And I'm Brian O'Hara.

484
00:26:57.825 --> 00:27:00.194
>> And we'll see you next time.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Brian explore the importance of change management. They begin by explaining what change management is as well as explaining change management boards or committees and how they operate. They also talk about how change requests create a proper documentation for an audit trail.
episodes.title: Acquisition, Development and Implementation Part 6
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.976 --> 00:00:15.921
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:15.921 --> 00:00:17.880
I'm your host Daniel Lowry and

4
00:00:17.880 --> 00:00:22.220
in today's episode we're continuing
on with our CISA series.

5
00:00:22.220 --> 00:00:27.050
And joining me back in the studio is one
of the authors of this fine CISA study

6
00:00:27.050 --> 00:00:30.950
guide that we were using throughout the
show, is our good friend Mr. Brian O'Hara.

7
00:00:30.950 --> 00:00:32.750
Brian, welcome back to the show.

8
00:00:32.750 --> 00:00:33.529
How's it going today sir?

9
00:00:33.529 --> 00:00:34.240
>> Hi Daniel.

10
00:00:34.240 --> 00:00:35.630
>> Going well, thank you.

11
00:00:35.630 --> 00:00:38.190
Appreciate you having me back on.

12
00:00:38.190 --> 00:00:43.050
In this episode today I would like
to talk about something near and

13
00:00:43.050 --> 00:00:45.880
dear to my heart which
is change management.

14
00:00:45.880 --> 00:00:47.590
>> Cue the scary music right?

15
00:00:47.590 --> 00:00:48.500
>> Yeah, do, do, do, do.

16
00:00:48.500 --> 00:00:51.020
The what is that the dun.

17
00:00:51.020 --> 00:00:52.310
>> Dun dun dun.

18
00:00:52.310 --> 00:00:58.240
>> Yeah, in the previous episode,
I talked about the different roles or

19
00:00:58.240 --> 00:01:02.790
the titles of the role of the different
people that are involved in

20
00:01:02.790 --> 00:01:07.880
the system acquisition, development and
implementation processes.

21
00:01:07.880 --> 00:01:11.670
And in this episode,
I'd like to talk a little bit about, or

22
00:01:11.670 --> 00:01:16.980
extensively about change management,
in terms of once the systems have

23
00:01:16.980 --> 00:01:22.770
been implemented, some of this applies
during a process, but more so after

24
00:01:22.770 --> 00:01:28.670
the systems have been implemented, about
how important change management can be.

25
00:01:28.670 --> 00:01:32.470
And I may tap you in a minute to talk
about the story we were discussing

26
00:01:32.470 --> 00:01:34.870
offline a few minutes ago
in terms of your first,

27
00:01:34.870 --> 00:01:37.000
more of your first experiences
with change management.

28
00:01:38.950 --> 00:01:44.320
So what I'd like to talk a little bit
about is change managements boards or

29
00:01:44.320 --> 00:01:45.840
committees.

30
00:01:45.840 --> 00:01:48.510
Depending on the organization,
you may hear them called change

31
00:01:48.510 --> 00:01:51.790
management boards or change boards,
or change committees.

32
00:01:51.790 --> 00:01:56.200
Doesn't matter what you call it,
the purpose of that

33
00:01:56.200 --> 00:02:00.940
particular group is to do two or
three things.

34
00:02:00.940 --> 00:02:04.110
One of which is configuration control.

35
00:02:04.110 --> 00:02:07.880
And, excuse me, the reason why I say
configuration control is because

36
00:02:07.880 --> 00:02:10.350
when you bring a new system online,

37
00:02:10.350 --> 00:02:15.290
and it's configured properly,
you don't wanna make changes to that

38
00:02:15.290 --> 00:02:20.180
system without going through a process
to vet the changes, or you could

39
00:02:20.180 --> 00:02:24.290
introduce more risk into the organization
without anyone ever knowing it.

40
00:02:24.290 --> 00:02:25.330
That's not a good thing.

41
00:02:25.330 --> 00:02:28.010
That's something that you
want to avoid at all costs.

42
00:02:28.010 --> 00:02:31.000
So, configuration control

43
00:02:31.000 --> 00:02:35.130
is vital in maintaining the risk
profile of the organization.

44
00:02:35.130 --> 00:02:40.329
Even something as simple as
changing a parameter on passwords,

45
00:02:40.329 --> 00:02:44.265
something that may seem fairly simple.

46
00:02:44.265 --> 00:02:47.425
I noticed an, we'll switch gears and
talk about it,

47
00:02:47.425 --> 00:02:52.165
an application error that occurred
about a year ago I believe it was.

48
00:02:52.165 --> 00:02:54.220
Maybe a year and a half ago, or two.

49
00:02:54.220 --> 00:02:56.730
It had to with iPhone IOS.

50
00:02:56.730 --> 00:02:59.970
It had to do with, if you recall, there
was a vulnerability that was only there

51
00:02:59.970 --> 00:03:04.270
for about four or five days but somebody
discovered that in the code of the IOS

52
00:03:04.270 --> 00:03:09.190
there was a missing carriage
return next to a semicolon.

53
00:03:09.190 --> 00:03:12.960
One simple little change that happened
in the IOS that happened in the IOS

54
00:03:12.960 --> 00:03:15.990
that didn't get caught in
the change management process.

55
00:03:15.990 --> 00:03:19.410
I believe it was version 8.7 or
something like that, but

56
00:03:19.410 --> 00:03:22.489
it would cause your phone to
reboot if you did a certain thing.

57
00:03:22.489 --> 00:03:27.660
If you texted or it was some
character sequence that you could

58
00:03:27.660 --> 00:03:30.930
text to the phone and
it would cause the phone to reboot.

59
00:03:30.930 --> 00:03:33.810
Apple fixed it very quickly,
but it's kind of funny because

60
00:03:33.810 --> 00:03:37.940
it was simply a carriage return I believe
or something like or something like that.

61
00:03:37.940 --> 00:03:40.230
A space missing in
a piece of the base code.

62
00:03:40.230 --> 00:03:44.259
>> Reminds me of back in the days when
we used [INAUDIBLE] telephone systems.

63
00:03:44.259 --> 00:03:46.248
>> Right.
>> It was the tones that were interpreted

64
00:03:46.248 --> 00:03:47.108
by the phone itself.

65
00:03:47.108 --> 00:03:49.473
And people would get that
Captain Crunch whistle and

66
00:03:49.473 --> 00:03:51.260
it whistled at 2600 [INAUDIBLE].

67
00:03:51.260 --> 00:03:54.250
>> Right.
>> You'd walk by a phone bank and

68
00:03:54.250 --> 00:03:55.593
blow that whistle and they'd all hang up.

69
00:03:55.593 --> 00:03:56.724
[LAUGH]
>> Yep, exactly.

70
00:03:56.724 --> 00:03:58.290
Exactly.
Things like that.

71
00:03:58.290 --> 00:04:03.980
So, configuration control is just one
of the functions of change management.

72
00:04:03.980 --> 00:04:06.660
I wanna talk a little bit about
the composition of the change management

73
00:04:06.660 --> 00:04:10.020
board, because I've seen change
management committees or

74
00:04:10.020 --> 00:04:14.890
CABs as they're oftentimes called,

75
00:04:14.890 --> 00:04:19.610
in that, I've seen them done very broadly,

76
00:04:19.610 --> 00:04:23.080
I've seen them done very narrowly,
and I've seen them not done at all,

77
00:04:23.080 --> 00:04:28.180
and I've seen them done to the point
where they drive people crazy cuz it's so

78
00:04:28.180 --> 00:04:32.860
hard to get any kind of a change made
that people oftentimes will just simply

79
00:04:32.860 --> 00:04:37.580
either go around the change control,
not follow a policies and procedures and

80
00:04:37.580 --> 00:04:42.445
because there have not been adequate
controls to keep that from occurring,

81
00:04:42.445 --> 00:04:45.370
that'-s actually an audit finding

82
00:04:45.370 --> 00:04:49.690
that someone could go around
the controls without getting caught.

83
00:04:51.270 --> 00:04:53.830
And also to the point where they're so

84
00:04:53.830 --> 00:04:55.970
sloppy that really nobody
knows what's going on.

85
00:04:55.970 --> 00:04:57.970
People just approve them,
check, check, check.

86
00:04:57.970 --> 00:04:59.830
That can often happen in an organization.

87
00:04:59.830 --> 00:05:05.070
There's one I'm working with now where,
excuse me, they're doing somewhere in

88
00:05:05.070 --> 00:05:10.490
the range of, I've seen on a busy day,
they might do 30 change requests.

89
00:05:10.490 --> 00:05:14.010
That's a lot, on a daily basis,
even for a big organization.

90
00:05:14.010 --> 00:05:15.520
You're nodding your head yes.

91
00:05:15.520 --> 00:05:19.080
And when I talked to them, they're like,
well, that's just normal for us.

92
00:05:19.080 --> 00:05:21.930
I'm like, well, but it's not normal for
the rest of the world.

93
00:05:21.930 --> 00:05:26.100
And what I discovered is that
they're running their application

94
00:05:27.170 --> 00:05:29.990
change management through
the same board that they're doing

95
00:05:29.990 --> 00:05:32.760
all of the entire company's
change management through.

96
00:05:32.760 --> 00:05:35.210
Then because they're an application
development company,

97
00:05:35.210 --> 00:05:40.270
that obviously involves a lot of changes,
so in their particular instance,

98
00:05:40.270 --> 00:05:46.770
I strongly suggested that they break
the change boards into multiple boards so

99
00:05:46.770 --> 00:05:53.280
that what would happen would be they
might get 30 or 40 sometimes in a day

100
00:05:53.280 --> 00:05:59.630
mainframe code changes to change
a field from yes to no or from 0 to 1.

101
00:05:59.630 --> 00:06:02.090
I mean these tiny little minutia things,

102
00:06:02.090 --> 00:06:05.450
but to a database programmer and
to a mainframe programmer

103
00:06:05.450 --> 00:06:08.190
you don't do anything without
going through a changed process.

104
00:06:08.190 --> 00:06:13.090
Because it could have repercussions
in the financial side of things.

105
00:06:13.090 --> 00:06:16.050
So they're getting just flooded with
all these mainframe changes, and

106
00:06:16.050 --> 00:06:19.640
so what happens is when
a security issue pops up,

107
00:06:19.640 --> 00:06:24.530
or a sort of a normal operational
issue pops up, you kind of get numb.

108
00:06:24.530 --> 00:06:28.075
It's like having Department of
Homeland Security alerts on red forever.

109
00:06:28.075 --> 00:06:29.570
>> [LAUGH]
>> You know, pretty soon,

110
00:06:29.570 --> 00:06:31.670
you just go, yeah right, whatever.

111
00:06:31.670 --> 00:06:33.470
You don't pay any attention to it.

112
00:06:33.470 --> 00:06:37.180
And that's how accidents happen and
things slip through the process.

113
00:06:37.180 --> 00:06:40.710
>> Yeah, it's like turning the alerts up
on your exchange server, or something.

114
00:06:40.710 --> 00:06:41.660
>> Right.
>> To the maximum.

115
00:06:41.660 --> 00:06:44.240
You're getting alerts about everything,
and suddenly you're, okay,

116
00:06:44.240 --> 00:06:47.850
I'm just gonna run Outlook rules this,
send all this to the trash.

117
00:06:47.850 --> 00:06:48.647
>> Right.
>> [LAUGH]

118
00:06:48.647 --> 00:06:49.148
>> Right, exactly.

119
00:06:49.148 --> 00:06:49.994
>> And the server's on fire. And.

120
00:06:49.994 --> 00:06:51.340
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, [LAUGH] exactly.

121
00:06:51.340 --> 00:06:54.360
So finding a good balance in
your change of management

122
00:06:54.360 --> 00:06:57.860
activities is extremely important
because change management

123
00:06:58.890 --> 00:07:02.490
is almost always where I see
problems creep into the mix.

124
00:07:03.960 --> 00:07:09.260
Vendor management and change
management are the two biggest areas

125
00:07:09.260 --> 00:07:13.090
outside of things you can't control like
phishing attacks and stuff like that in

126
00:07:13.090 --> 00:07:16.570
terms of introducing vulnerabilities and
risk into the organization.

127
00:07:16.570 --> 00:07:19.310
Vendor management through
poor vendor selection,

128
00:07:19.310 --> 00:07:22.360
through poor vendor monitoring
etc those kinds of things.

129
00:07:23.660 --> 00:07:28.500
And in change management primarily
through not properly vetting and

130
00:07:28.500 --> 00:07:30.480
managing those changes.

131
00:07:30.480 --> 00:07:34.030
So let's talk a little bit more
about who's involved in that.

132
00:07:34.030 --> 00:07:38.960
One of the things that I have stressed
in every organization I work with,

133
00:07:38.960 --> 00:07:40.300
again because as most of you know,

134
00:07:40.300 --> 00:07:44.010
if you've been watching I have a strong
security background as well as audit.

135
00:07:44.010 --> 00:07:48.350
And that is that security have a voice
at any of those boards because any and

136
00:07:48.350 --> 00:07:51.640
all of those changes could
have an impact on security for

137
00:07:51.640 --> 00:07:54.442
the organization which
translates into risk.

138
00:07:54.442 --> 00:07:57.746
And that's what we're all about,
as auditors and audit functions,

139
00:07:57.746 --> 00:07:58.647
is managing risk.

140
00:07:58.647 --> 00:08:01.918
You'll hear that over and over and
over, not only from me, But

141
00:08:01.918 --> 00:08:05.622
throughout the CISA study materials,
you'll see it on your exam, and

142
00:08:05.622 --> 00:08:08.670
you're gonna run into it when
you get into the business.

143
00:08:08.670 --> 00:08:13.920
We're no longer a check box function
just to see that we're doing things for

144
00:08:13.920 --> 00:08:15.080
the sake of doing them.

145
00:08:15.080 --> 00:08:19.020
It's really about reducing and
managing risk to manageable levels for

146
00:08:19.020 --> 00:08:19.709
the organization.

147
00:08:20.820 --> 00:08:25.610
So you've got a security officer,
you may have a network change board

148
00:08:25.610 --> 00:08:30.260
where any changes to the route
switch environment are involved.

149
00:08:30.260 --> 00:08:32.880
You probably ought to keep it
to just those people involved.

150
00:08:32.880 --> 00:08:35.870
The IT manager, or excuse me,
the route switch manager for

151
00:08:35.870 --> 00:08:40.830
that area, people who understand
what their technicians are doing but

152
00:08:40.830 --> 00:08:44.840
you don't necessarily want a technician
in the room arguing their case.

153
00:08:46.810 --> 00:08:49.660
Well, excuse me, deciding their case.

154
00:08:49.660 --> 00:08:53.190
That's another part of the change
management process we will talk about,

155
00:08:53.190 --> 00:08:54.810
which is number one,

156
00:08:54.810 --> 00:08:59.852
proper documentation, whether you
are using SharePoint or spreadsheets.

157
00:08:59.852 --> 00:09:02.940
Or, there are change management
applications that you can buy.

158
00:09:02.940 --> 00:09:06.390
A lot of companies will use their
helpdesk ticketing software

159
00:09:06.390 --> 00:09:10.970
to manage change management, so
that they have an ongoing audit trail.

160
00:09:10.970 --> 00:09:12.060
Wink, wink.

161
00:09:12.060 --> 00:09:13.130
Test question.

162
00:09:13.130 --> 00:09:17.120
So, that they have an ongoing audit
trail of all of their changes.

163
00:09:17.120 --> 00:09:20.530
So, if something were to occur a week or
two weeks or

164
00:09:20.530 --> 00:09:25.430
three weeks down the road, they could
possibly have forensic information

165
00:09:25.430 --> 00:09:29.020
about when the change occured and
what exactly occurred.

166
00:09:29.020 --> 00:09:31.585
And why it was asked, who asked for it.

167
00:09:31.585 --> 00:09:35.715
Maybe it's an insider job and you've got
somebody who sliped something through in

168
00:09:35.715 --> 00:09:39.196
the change management board that
would elevate their permissions and

169
00:09:39.196 --> 00:09:42.730
allow them to do something that
might benefit them financially.

170
00:09:42.730 --> 00:09:43.320
Something like that.

171
00:09:43.320 --> 00:09:47.330
Allow them to get into accounts that
they should not have access to.

172
00:09:49.000 --> 00:09:53.880
So in an application change management
board, the network guys are gonna,

173
00:09:53.880 --> 00:09:55.491
they're gonna do this.

174
00:09:55.491 --> 00:09:57.154
[SOUND].

175
00:09:57.154 --> 00:10:01.074
So, do you really want them in your
application change management?

176
00:10:01.074 --> 00:10:04.435
Again, security person,
having a security analyst or

177
00:10:04.435 --> 00:10:08.750
a security person at those
meetings is very useful as well.

178
00:10:08.750 --> 00:10:14.270
The frequency, in my opinion,
once a day's too much, but again,

179
00:10:14.270 --> 00:10:19.040
the one organization I mentioned I was
working with, they feel it's necessary.

180
00:10:19.040 --> 00:10:21.160
They don't wanna break it up,
they like it.

181
00:10:21.160 --> 00:10:23.370
They come in every morning,
it's the very first thing they do and

182
00:10:23.370 --> 00:10:26.810
then they go finish their day, and they've
been doing it that way for a long time.

183
00:10:26.810 --> 00:10:30.670
And it seems to work for them, but
generally, if you're doing daily changes,

184
00:10:30.670 --> 00:10:32.350
something's wrong.

185
00:10:32.350 --> 00:10:33.915
Here's my take on that,

186
00:10:33.915 --> 00:10:38.468
this is not on the exam this is just
good practical knowledge and that is,

187
00:10:43.361 --> 00:10:46.678
Typically when you're doing
changes on a daily basis,

188
00:10:46.678 --> 00:10:50.842
people tend to wait to the last minute
to ask for them, to submit them,

189
00:10:50.842 --> 00:10:55.460
which means you have very little time
to review them adequately and vet them.

190
00:10:55.460 --> 00:10:58.120
That's a dangerous mix.

191
00:10:58.120 --> 00:11:01.840
That's asking for
errors to creep into the process.

192
00:11:01.840 --> 00:11:03.200
But it happens quite often.

193
00:11:03.200 --> 00:11:05.012
Someone will come up to
you at the last minute,

194
00:11:05.012 --> 00:11:07.140
I just gotta have this done tomorrow or
tonight.

195
00:11:07.140 --> 00:11:09.970
I gotta get this approved,
let me get in front of the cab today.

196
00:11:09.970 --> 00:11:13.800
Well if you have changes like that,
you should have an emergency change

197
00:11:13.800 --> 00:11:16.990
process in place to be able to
handle those kinds of things.

198
00:11:16.990 --> 00:11:20.700
Those should not be going through the
general channels of your change management

199
00:11:20.700 --> 00:11:22.820
activities for obvious reasons.

200
00:11:22.820 --> 00:11:25.580
You want to know that it's an emergency or

201
00:11:25.580 --> 00:11:27.650
you've got somebody who's
crying wolf all the time.

202
00:11:27.650 --> 00:11:30.310
And that's most of the time,
that's what it turns out to be.

203
00:11:30.310 --> 00:11:32.676
You got an employee, or a staff group,

204
00:11:32.676 --> 00:11:35.750
who's just simply used
to getting their way.

205
00:11:35.750 --> 00:11:39.780
They don't plan their work out so
that they turn in requests in

206
00:11:39.780 --> 00:11:43.860
an adequate timeframe so that everyone
has a chance to review and vet them.

207
00:11:45.590 --> 00:11:51.140
So typically, in most organizations
I've worked with cabs meet once a week,

208
00:11:51.140 --> 00:11:52.760
and, all the stuff piles up.

209
00:11:52.760 --> 00:11:56.212
There's still some late-nighters
who come in at the last minute and

210
00:11:56.212 --> 00:11:58.484
they don't tell you
until the night before.

211
00:11:58.484 --> 00:12:03.525
But the point is, you should always take
the time necessary to vet those requests,

212
00:12:03.525 --> 00:12:07.640
and if you don't have enough
time in the meeting, table it.

213
00:12:07.640 --> 00:12:10.260
And tell them flat out,
you didn't get it to us in time or

214
00:12:10.260 --> 00:12:12.960
you didn't provide us enough information
to make a good decision about it.

215
00:12:12.960 --> 00:12:16.110
>> Now Bryan, other than just vetting
the change requests that are coming across

216
00:12:16.110 --> 00:12:19.210
the board, what else happens
inside of these meetings?

217
00:12:19.210 --> 00:12:23.340
What are some of the typical change
requests, committee or board?

218
00:12:23.340 --> 00:12:25.980
>> Yeah, so here's an example of
one that happened in a healthcare

219
00:12:25.980 --> 00:12:28.500
organization I worked
with a couple years ago.

220
00:12:28.500 --> 00:12:33.550
>> I was the only security person
sitting in on the meeting at that time.

221
00:12:33.550 --> 00:12:36.070
They did not have that
role in the organization.

222
00:12:36.070 --> 00:12:38.970
And I was asked to come in and
audit and make recommendations,

223
00:12:38.970 --> 00:12:41.370
do an assessment of the process.

224
00:12:41.370 --> 00:12:46.630
And during the conversation
one of the networking

225
00:12:46.630 --> 00:12:51.670
team brought up that they had
added a new vendor to the VPN,

226
00:12:51.670 --> 00:12:56.850
who had then had gained
access to their systems

227
00:12:56.850 --> 00:13:00.530
because they needed to
share some information.

228
00:13:00.530 --> 00:13:02.260
I cannot give you anymore
details than that.

229
00:13:03.730 --> 00:13:07.759
And I said, number one,
who vetted the vendor?

230
00:13:09.070 --> 00:13:10.734
No one could answer that question.

231
00:13:10.734 --> 00:13:14.572
Number two, I said, did they sign
a business associate agreement,

232
00:13:14.572 --> 00:13:19.150
which is a requirement under the EMPA
regulations, and no one could answer that.

233
00:13:20.180 --> 00:13:25.508
And then I said, do they have access to
PII, Personally Identifiable Information,

234
00:13:25.508 --> 00:13:28.772
or healthcare information,
anything sensitive?

235
00:13:28.772 --> 00:13:30.450
No one could answer that.

236
00:13:31.450 --> 00:13:33.720
So of course I sent to the boss and

237
00:13:33.720 --> 00:13:38.000
I said, I think you kind of ran through
a change you ought to take a hard look at.

238
00:13:38.000 --> 00:13:40.220
So it really wasn't properly vetted.

239
00:13:40.220 --> 00:13:42.450
Those are the kinds of
conversations that happen.

240
00:13:42.450 --> 00:13:47.330
But in addition to that,
we'll see things like, we'll

241
00:13:47.330 --> 00:13:52.850
see a network manager
submit an application

242
00:13:52.850 --> 00:13:57.820
for a firewall change that someone in
the committee does not quite understand.

243
00:13:57.820 --> 00:14:01.250
So we may get them on the phone, or ask
them to come down to the meeting room, and

244
00:14:01.250 --> 00:14:04.050
say, can you give us some more
details about what this really means,

245
00:14:04.050 --> 00:14:06.990
because we do not quite
understand your description.

246
00:14:06.990 --> 00:14:11.710
So they might come in, or they might even
be required to appear before the board

247
00:14:11.710 --> 00:14:15.985
to make their case that it's
an important change and explain it.

248
00:14:15.985 --> 00:14:19.250
Oftentimes, folks are too busy to stop
what they're doing and come in and

249
00:14:19.250 --> 00:14:23.000
do that so they typically
write that up in the request.

250
00:14:23.000 --> 00:14:25.870
But sometimes they don't do a very good
job of explaining it, so they have to come

251
00:14:25.870 --> 00:14:29.910
down and actually make their case in
front of the change management board.

252
00:14:29.910 --> 00:14:33.130
Then the change management board will
discuss it, they'll decide well,

253
00:14:33.130 --> 00:14:36.130
does it meet our criteria?

254
00:14:36.130 --> 00:14:38.701
What is the impact going to be?

255
00:14:38.701 --> 00:14:42.603
One of the most important things is,
the questions to ask,

256
00:14:42.603 --> 00:14:45.920
have you tested this change before?

257
00:14:45.920 --> 00:14:48.520
Not every organization
has a test environment.

258
00:14:48.520 --> 00:14:52.250
Those are expensive and
time consuming and require staff.

259
00:14:52.250 --> 00:14:56.500
So not everybody has the ability to
test every single change that they wanna

260
00:14:56.500 --> 00:14:57.754
push out to make sure that it works.

261
00:14:59.235 --> 00:15:02.555
But it's still a good question for
you to ask, have you tested this?

262
00:15:02.555 --> 00:15:05.527
Have you done any kind of mock-up or

263
00:15:05.527 --> 00:15:10.835
simulation to gauge any kind of idea
of what the impact might be of this?

264
00:15:10.835 --> 00:15:11.705
Or is there no impact?

265
00:15:11.705 --> 00:15:15.155
Is this something new that won't
change anything that we currently do?

266
00:15:16.850 --> 00:15:22.364
So those are some of the questions
that are asked in those situations.

267
00:15:22.364 --> 00:15:26.411
And then most importantly, the single
most important thing you need to

268
00:15:26.411 --> 00:15:30.391
know about when you're in those
committees is asking for adequate and

269
00:15:30.391 --> 00:15:35.690
proper documentation on how to back out
the process if something goes awry.

270
00:15:35.690 --> 00:15:39.619
I can't tell you how many times
everyone has vetted the change,

271
00:15:39.619 --> 00:15:44.131
it looks like it's absolutely golden,
they test it in the environment,

272
00:15:44.131 --> 00:15:47.364
they push it out, and
it burns and crashes big time.

273
00:15:47.364 --> 00:15:49.543
And the CEO's on the phone, he's yelling.

274
00:15:49.543 --> 00:15:51.601
Maybe you're on the front
page of the newspaper.

275
00:15:51.601 --> 00:15:52.494
>> That's a fun time.

276
00:15:52.494 --> 00:15:53.910
>> Who knows what, right?

277
00:15:53.910 --> 00:15:56.853
And you have to be able to
back those changes out.

278
00:15:56.853 --> 00:16:03.517
So, it's not good enough to just say,
what's your roll back?

279
00:16:03.517 --> 00:16:06.043
Or once you roll back, procedures,

280
00:16:06.043 --> 00:16:09.650
what have you got in place
to roll back the change?

281
00:16:09.650 --> 00:16:11.070
Have you tested that?

282
00:16:11.070 --> 00:16:13.820
Have you tested the,
cuz the rollback might not work.

283
00:16:13.820 --> 00:16:17.640
What if the break that you introduced
is so bad that you can't roll it back?

284
00:16:17.640 --> 00:16:18.750
Now what are you gonna do?

285
00:16:18.750 --> 00:16:20.050
Do you have a backup of the system?

286
00:16:20.050 --> 00:16:21.210
Is it a virtual machine?

287
00:16:21.210 --> 00:16:23.566
Can you make a snap shot of it?

288
00:16:23.566 --> 00:16:28.520
Just in case, so that worst case scenario,
maybe we lose five minutes worth of data.

289
00:16:28.520 --> 00:16:31.521
If this is an e-commerce
site,that can cost you a lot

290
00:16:31.521 --> 00:16:34.532
of money if your doing things
from all over the world.

291
00:16:34.532 --> 00:16:40.342
What happens if someone here from ITProTV
makes a change to the video encoding and

292
00:16:40.342 --> 00:16:44.110
all of the sudden, boom,
our video feed goes dead?

293
00:16:44.110 --> 00:16:45.840
What does that do to the business?

294
00:16:45.840 --> 00:16:47.150
How can you roll that back?

295
00:16:47.150 --> 00:16:49.197
>> I'm pretty sure that Don just

296
00:16:49.197 --> 00:16:52.910
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] And starts holding hostages.

297
00:16:52.910 --> 00:16:54.540
>> Yeah, exactly.

298
00:16:54.540 --> 00:16:59.050
So you can see how really critically
important change management

299
00:16:59.050 --> 00:17:03.720
becomes in the overall
operation of managing systems.

300
00:17:03.720 --> 00:17:07.530
Now like I said, we talked a little
bit about using change management

301
00:17:07.530 --> 00:17:11.350
during the app development lifecycle, but

302
00:17:11.350 --> 00:17:16.880
again, things like Agile have
a tendency to kind of bypass that.

303
00:17:16.880 --> 00:17:19.670
Cuz they're more interested in
getting the application delivered,

304
00:17:19.670 --> 00:17:22.630
does it meet the end user's needs, ect.

305
00:17:22.630 --> 00:17:26.890
They're not so concerned about
meeting the change processes, etc.

306
00:17:26.890 --> 00:17:31.200
So, they may very well, and very easily,
they may go through a number of changes

00:17:31.200 --> 00:17:34.270
without ever coming to the change
board in the development cycle.

308
00:17:34.270 --> 00:17:38.480
They do their changes at their, what they
call, their morning stand-up meetings,

309
00:17:38.480 --> 00:17:41.740
things like that, they'll share that
kind of information with each other.

00:17:41.740 --> 00:17:43.090
>> Yeah, like we were talking about,

311
00:17:43.090 --> 00:17:48.560
you mentioned that we were

00:17:48.560 --> 00:17:53.570
my first foray into having to deal

00:17:53.570 --> 00:17:56.865
when I worked for an insurance company,

00:17:56.865 --> 00:18:00.880

00:18:00.880 --> 00:18:03.040

00:18:03.040 --> 00:18:05.960

00:18:05.960 --> 00:18:08.230

00:18:08.230 --> 00:18:12.420

00:18:15.810 --> 00:18:17.571

00:18:21.280 --> 00:18:26.140

00:18:33.020 --> 00:18:36.690

00:18:36.690 --> 00:18:39.460
And what was the end
result of these things.

00:18:39.460 --> 00:18:40.440
It's a lot of a process.

00:18:40.440 --> 00:18:42.000
And I just didn't realize these things.

00:18:42.000 --> 00:18:43.630
And after that, I was change management.

00:18:43.630 --> 00:18:47.270
So once I realized what went into it and

00:18:47.270 --> 00:18:50.230

00:18:50.230 --> 00:18:51.370

00:19:02.585 --> 00:19:06.068

00:19:06.068 --> 00:19:09.043

00:19:10.922 --> 00:19:13.242

00:19:13.242 --> 00:19:17.020

00:19:18.670 --> 00:19:21.235
So, it helps you and

00:19:21.235 --> 00:19:23.100

00:19:23.100 --> 00:19:23.727

00:19:23.727 --> 00:19:26.210

00:19:26.210 --> 00:19:29.570

00:19:34.640 --> 00:19:37.140

00:19:37.140 --> 00:19:40.602
And again, that's the whole

356
00:19:40.602 --> 00:19:45.100

to be able to backtrack when something

00:19:45.100 --> 00:19:49.340
does go wrong because Murphy's Law

358
00:19:49.340 --> 00:19:51.520
If it can go wrong, it will.

00:19:51.520 --> 00:19:52.450
We guarantee it.

360
00:19:52.450 --> 00:19:57.750
Whether it's in, it could be that you've

361
00:19:57.750 --> 00:20:03.380
you just spent 50 or $60,000 on these
brand new monster blade servers for

00:20:03.380 --> 00:20:05.030

[LAUGH]

00:20:12.010 --> 00:20:14.510

368
00:20:14.510 --> 00:20:17.587

369
00:20:17.587 --> 00:20:23.770
So it just goes to show you that Murphy's
Law, if anything can go wrong, it will.

370
00:20:23.770 --> 00:20:28.470
So, change management is right up there,

00:20:28.470 --> 00:20:29.900
It is extremely important.

00:20:29.900 --> 00:20:32.090

00:20:32.090 --> 00:20:37.080

374
00:20:37.080 --> 00:20:40.800
But I wanna make sure you have a good
understanding of how important change

375
00:20:40.800 --> 00:20:44.070
management is in the real world in
terms of what you're going to be doing

376
00:20:44.070 --> 00:20:46.410
as an auditor on an ongoing basis.

377
00:20:46.410 --> 00:20:48.820
You've got to understand the process.

378
00:20:48.820 --> 00:20:52.260
Google it, go to Google and

379
00:20:52.260 --> 00:20:54.340
Read up on it as much as you can.

00:20:54.340 --> 00:20:57.450
Because regardless of how much is on

381
00:20:57.450 --> 00:20:59.880
of it in the real world and
you're going to see

382
00:20:59.880 --> 00:21:03.970
a lot of the problems that you run into
go right back to change management.

383
00:21:05.540 --> 00:21:09.650
One last note I think I would probably put
out there in terms of words of advice is

384
00:21:09.650 --> 00:21:15.930
that, typically, I'm real hardcore
about looking at root cause analysis.

385
00:21:15.930 --> 00:21:20.364
People have a tendency to always go with
what seems to be the simplest answer when

386
00:21:20.364 --> 00:21:21.568
there's a problem.

387
00:21:21.568 --> 00:21:25.070
Like we were joking earlier,
the Internet's down.

388
00:21:25.070 --> 00:21:27.140
No, the Internet's not down.

389
00:21:27.140 --> 00:21:29.732
You may not be able to get to it,
but the Internet itself is still up.

390
00:21:29.732 --> 00:21:32.354
I'm quite sure of that,
unless there's been a very,

391
00:21:32.354 --> 00:21:35.328
very large EMP disaster somewhere
that we don't know about.

392
00:21:35.328 --> 00:21:36.071
>> Very large.

393
00:21:36.071 --> 00:21:37.440
>> Yeah, exactly.

394
00:21:37.440 --> 00:21:41.850
So when you do real root cause analysis,
probably 80% of the time,

395
00:21:41.850 --> 00:21:45.100
maybe 90% of the time, change management.

396
00:21:45.100 --> 00:21:46.550
It goes right back to there.

397
00:21:46.550 --> 00:21:50.990
I will go, if there's a system that
goes haywire or something I find in

398
00:21:50.990 --> 00:21:54.080
an audit that's showing me some
something funny, I'm gonna go right

399
00:21:54.080 --> 00:21:58.440
back to the change management logs and try
to find out when that system was changed,

400
00:21:58.440 --> 00:22:02.840
because I know that, typically,
people don't design things to go haywire.

401
00:22:02.840 --> 00:22:07.160
That happens when someone changes
something without telling somebody else.

402
00:22:07.160 --> 00:22:11.430
So, and then, the last thing I'd say is
what happens when you don't follow good

403
00:22:11.430 --> 00:22:13.850
change management is you lose.

404
00:22:13.850 --> 00:22:16.980
And the students have heard me
say this throughout the series.

405
00:22:16.980 --> 00:22:19.960
You lose visibility into your risk.

406
00:22:19.960 --> 00:22:23.490
Because now you've introduced things
that you don't know are there.

407
00:22:23.490 --> 00:22:24.910
>> Right, you've obfuscated it.

408
00:22:24.910 --> 00:22:25.450
>> Exactly.

409
00:22:25.450 --> 00:22:28.730
And any time you don't have visibility,
you have risk.

410
00:22:28.730 --> 00:22:31.840
And risk is something we want
to definitely at least mitigate.

411
00:22:31.840 --> 00:22:33.482
We can't avoid it, it's always there.

412
00:22:33.482 --> 00:22:34.005
>> We wanna manage it.

413
00:22:34.005 --> 00:22:34.843
>> Right, we wanna manage it.

414
00:22:34.843 --> 00:22:36.310
There we go, I like that better.

415
00:22:36.310 --> 00:22:38.280
I'd like to mitigate it
if I possibly could,

416
00:22:38.280 --> 00:22:40.160
but that's probably not going to happen.

417
00:22:40.160 --> 00:22:43.710
Manage it down to something that
we are able to tolerate, right?

418
00:22:43.710 --> 00:22:44.230
>> Right.
Right.

419
00:22:44.230 --> 00:22:45.080
>> That's what we want to do.

420
00:22:45.080 --> 00:22:46.300
>> Get it within our risk profile.

421
00:22:46.300 --> 00:22:48.710
>> That's right, within our risk profile.

422
00:22:48.710 --> 00:22:52.190
That being said, well, we talked a lot
about change management today, and

423
00:22:52.190 --> 00:22:54.743
hopefully, you guys are seeing
the importance of it,

424
00:22:54.743 --> 00:22:57.950
that you're seeing that it's not just
something that's, it's just the red tape

425
00:22:57.950 --> 00:23:00.880
that you have to go through to make
sure that things are getting done.

426
00:23:00.880 --> 00:23:03.600
And yes, can it be a bit of a pain?

427
00:23:03.600 --> 00:23:04.110
It can.

428
00:23:04.110 --> 00:23:07.805
You gotta fill things out, you gotta
make sure that they've been submitted

429
00:23:07.805 --> 00:23:10.287
correctly, and
that they've been approved, and

430
00:23:10.287 --> 00:23:13.310
then all the other beurocratic type of-
>> [LAUGH]

431
00:23:13.310 --> 00:23:15.888
>> Things that we think of when it come to

432
00:23:15.888 --> 00:23:19.796
change management, but
it really does help us out, and

433
00:23:19.796 --> 00:23:24.891
it keeps you as the person that's
working within a system accountable.

434
00:23:24.891 --> 00:23:28.260
You can say,
I did exactly what I said I was gonna do.

435
00:23:28.260 --> 00:23:30.010
Here's all the things, it's right there.

436
00:23:30.010 --> 00:23:31.898
Anybody is gonna see it,
and it will help you.

437
00:23:31.898 --> 00:23:34.420
Trust me,
I'm speaking from experience on this.

438
00:23:34.420 --> 00:23:37.880
When these guys come around, going,
what is it that you did here?

439
00:23:37.880 --> 00:23:39.100
Let me take a look at that.

440
00:23:39.100 --> 00:23:42.180
You can say, okay,
everything I did was in the realm of-

441
00:23:42.180 --> 00:23:42.920
>> Prove it.

442
00:23:42.920 --> 00:23:44.160
>> Yeah, and I can prove it.

443
00:23:44.160 --> 00:23:45.860
Cuz there it is in my
change management log.

444
00:23:45.860 --> 00:23:46.380
>> Right.

445
00:23:46.380 --> 00:23:47.140
>> That's what I like.

446
00:23:47.140 --> 00:23:49.650
So hopefully,
you guys see the importance of it as well.

447
00:23:49.650 --> 00:23:52.415
That being said,
we've run out of time for this episode.

448
00:23:52.415 --> 00:23:55.900
Bryan, thanks so much for explaining how
important change management is to us and

449
00:23:55.900 --> 00:23:59.190
what we can expect when dealing
with it in our own environments.

450
00:23:59.190 --> 00:24:02.887
Guys, don't forget to pick up
a copy of this CISA Study Guide.

451
00:24:02.887 --> 00:24:05.755
It is the Fourth Edition,
remember, Fourth Edition.

452
00:24:05.755 --> 00:24:06.990
Bryan here is one of the authors.

453
00:24:06.990 --> 00:24:10.180
It is definitely going to help you,
guide you through.

454
00:24:10.180 --> 00:24:11.970
Study Guide is the best
word we could put on it.

455
00:24:11.970 --> 00:24:12.880
I don't wanna say book.

456
00:24:12.880 --> 00:24:15.800
It really is a study guide
to help you pass that exam.

457
00:24:15.800 --> 00:24:18.570
Give you all the great knowledge you
need to get through that sucker.

458
00:24:18.570 --> 00:24:20.730
Cuz, as we understand, it's quite a bear.

459
00:24:20.730 --> 00:24:23.730
So, that being said, we've come to
the end of another great episode.

460
00:24:23.730 --> 00:24:26.080
Thank's Bryan again,
we thank you guys for watching.

461
00:24:26.080 --> 00:24:28.020
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

462
00:24:28.020 --> 00:24:29.980
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

463
00:24:29.980 --> 00:24:30.980
>> And I'm Bryan O'Hara.

464
00:24:30.980 --> 00:24:32.094
>> And we'll see you next time.

465
00:24:33.637 --> 00:24:41.180
[SOUND]

topics.title: Information Systems Acquisition, Development and Implementation

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Brian: Talk about ITIL framework and how it help IT deliver IT services to end users be they sys admin, CIO, or other workers. using frameworks and change management information as metrics to manage risk.
episodes.title: IS Ops, Maintenance and Service Mgmt.
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.539 --> 00:00:16.560
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another exciting episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.560 --> 00:00:18.580
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

4
00:00:18.580 --> 00:00:22.660
In today's episode,
we're continuing on with our CISA series.

5
00:00:22.660 --> 00:00:23.190
That's right,

6
00:00:23.190 --> 00:00:26.540
joining me in the studio today I've
got his lovely study guide right here.

7
00:00:26.540 --> 00:00:29.340
If you haven't grabbed one yet,
you definitely need a copy

8
00:00:29.340 --> 00:00:33.860
of our Certified Information Systems
Auditor Study Guide, fourth edition.

9
00:00:33.860 --> 00:00:38.940
One of the authors, it sounds similar,
I'll go with it though,

10
00:00:38.940 --> 00:00:42.300
one of the authors right here with us,
our good friend, Mr. Brian O'Hara.

11
00:00:42.300 --> 00:00:43.900
Brian, welcome back to the show sir.

12
00:00:43.900 --> 00:00:44.850
How is it going today?

13
00:00:44.850 --> 00:00:45.650
>> Good, thanks Daniel.

14
00:00:45.650 --> 00:00:47.630
Thanks for having me back again.

15
00:00:47.630 --> 00:00:51.160
In today's episode I would like
to start by doing a little

16
00:00:51.160 --> 00:00:56.320
brief review of some of the things we've
talked about in the past few episodes.

17
00:00:56.320 --> 00:01:01.590
We've talked a lot about frameworks,
governance regulation.

18
00:01:01.590 --> 00:01:05.920
We've talked about the CMM model for
maturity.

19
00:01:05.920 --> 00:01:10.060
We've talked a little about the system
development life cycle and/or software

20
00:01:10.060 --> 00:01:12.810
development life cycle framework, and

21
00:01:12.810 --> 00:01:16.590
we've just barely touched
a little bit on ISO standards.

22
00:01:16.590 --> 00:01:20.950
And today what I'd like to talk a little
bit about as we move into domain four,

23
00:01:20.950 --> 00:01:25.281
which is information systems, operations,
maintenance, and service management.

24
00:01:25.281 --> 00:01:27.230
I wanna talk a little bit or

25
00:01:27.230 --> 00:01:31.580
introduce the concept of the IT
infrastructure library or ITIL.

26
00:01:33.010 --> 00:01:37.309
ITIL is an ISO ICE standard basically for,

27
00:01:37.309 --> 00:01:43.270
[COUGH] excuse me, for helping service
organizations understand the IT

28
00:01:43.270 --> 00:01:49.810
environment in a way that they're able to
deliver support for those IT operations.

29
00:01:49.810 --> 00:01:52.550
I've got a diagram here I'd like
to pull up for you real quickly.

30
00:01:52.550 --> 00:01:54.960
Let me get that up on the screen there.

31
00:01:54.960 --> 00:01:56.330
I believe everyone can see that.

32
00:01:57.920 --> 00:02:00.990
Where you can see that you've
heard these terms before.

33
00:02:00.990 --> 00:02:06.380
COSO, the,
I'm forgetting the name of it now.

34
00:02:06.380 --> 00:02:07.710
>> It's flying out of your head.

35
00:02:07.710 --> 00:02:10.505
>> Of sponsoring organizations as COSO.

36
00:02:10.505 --> 00:02:13.619
COBIT being the Control Objectives for
IT which is

37
00:02:16.650 --> 00:02:20.600
ISACA specific framework, and ISO 9000.

38
00:02:20.600 --> 00:02:24.700
ISO, and COSO, and COBIT all three again,
as I mentioned before,

39
00:02:24.700 --> 00:02:28.872
being internationally developed

40
00:02:28.872 --> 00:02:34.510
systems and concepts.

41
00:02:34.510 --> 00:02:39.190
ISACA, I mentioned there's a bunch of
times, ISACA is a worldwide organization.

42
00:02:39.190 --> 00:02:43.530
We have over 118,000 members
worldwide in over 85 countries.

43
00:02:43.530 --> 00:02:48.370
So again, all of this comes from the work
of many, many people across the globe.

44
00:02:48.370 --> 00:02:53.650
This is not a US based or
even slightly US-centric

45
00:02:53.650 --> 00:02:57.030
organization or set of frameworks.

46
00:02:57.030 --> 00:03:01.020
So we get really the best of both worlds,
we get all of the stuff that we've

47
00:03:01.020 --> 00:03:05.270
developed in the US over the last 30,
or 40, or 50 years, combined with all

48
00:03:05.270 --> 00:03:10.960
the genius and brain work, and brain power
from Europe and the rest of the world.

49
00:03:10.960 --> 00:03:12.020
Primarily from Europe, but

50
00:03:12.020 --> 00:03:15.830
there's a number of other organizations
involved in this as well.

51
00:03:15.830 --> 00:03:21.630
So you can see that from this
great ISACA document [LAUGH],

52
00:03:21.630 --> 00:03:25.850
it's in our book, we put it in the book
but you'll see things like this referenced

53
00:03:25.850 --> 00:03:31.850
in ISACA documentation, it's very complex
a little bit on the convoluted side but

54
00:03:31.850 --> 00:03:35.080
if you just take a look at it for
a few minutes I won't burn your eyes out

55
00:03:35.080 --> 00:03:38.220
with it and leave it up during
the whole session today.

56
00:03:38.220 --> 00:03:41.370
But you'll see how things
sort of interconnect.

57
00:03:41.370 --> 00:03:44.750
There's, you'll see,
NIST 800, you see the ISO 20,

58
00:03:44.750 --> 00:03:46.740
let's see if I can highlight these, yeah.

59
00:03:46.740 --> 00:03:50.049
So there's ISO 27002.

60
00:03:50.049 --> 00:03:53.800
Here's the ITIL libraries over here,
here's NIST 800.

61
00:03:53.800 --> 00:03:59.090
And you see how those all drive down
into user support for instance,

62
00:03:59.090 --> 00:04:04.490
clear down to the service desk,
down to problem management for users, etc.

63
00:04:04.490 --> 00:04:10.020
And down here you have the ITIL, which
targets lower level delivery to the user.

64
00:04:11.440 --> 00:04:16.050
What's important for you to understand for
the exam and for the real world is to

65
00:04:17.250 --> 00:04:21.850
have an understanding and appreciation for

66
00:04:21.850 --> 00:04:26.260
the frame with the ITIL framework
in terms of how it helps us or

67
00:04:26.260 --> 00:04:31.260
how it helps IT organizations
delivers services to end users.

68
00:04:31.260 --> 00:04:36.170
Those end users being not just the guy
at the end of the keyboard, but

69
00:04:36.170 --> 00:04:44.290
the system administrator, the CIO, whoever
may need service delivery information.

70
00:04:44.290 --> 00:04:46.500
Or, end user support, etc.

71
00:04:47.700 --> 00:04:51.340
It's a very important function
inside the organization.

72
00:04:51.340 --> 00:04:54.990
And it's good to have
a framework to work from.

73
00:04:54.990 --> 00:05:00.630
I've seen service organizations, and I'll
call them service organizations meaning,

74
00:05:00.630 --> 00:05:05.590
typically what you're referring to is the
help desk organization inside a company.

75
00:05:05.590 --> 00:05:09.850
I've heard a number of them,
or seen a number of them fail,

76
00:05:09.850 --> 00:05:14.490
miserably, because there is no framework
associated with what they're doing.

77
00:05:14.490 --> 00:05:18.560
They're just kind of flailing around in
the water, trying to accomplish something,

78
00:05:18.560 --> 00:05:23.160
keeping help desk tickets to a minimum,
answering questions as fast as they can.

79
00:05:23.160 --> 00:05:25.790
But there's really no
structured framework.

80
00:05:25.790 --> 00:05:29.794
As an auditor, that's one of the things
that you're expected to be able to

81
00:05:29.794 --> 00:05:33.390
evaluate and understand, is to be
able to go in to an organization and

82
00:05:33.390 --> 00:05:39.950
look at that framework, if any exists,
and evaluate the effectiveness of it.

83
00:05:39.950 --> 00:05:42.930
Is the organization using
a structured framework?

84
00:05:42.930 --> 00:05:45.150
Maybe they are, and they don't know it.

85
00:05:45.150 --> 00:05:50.120
Often times if you have a great
service manager, they're struggling

86
00:05:50.120 --> 00:05:54.410
trying to put something in place but
they don't know about other frameworks.

87
00:05:54.410 --> 00:05:56.570
Especially depending on
the size of the organization.

88
00:05:56.570 --> 00:05:58.020
If it's a bigger company,

89
00:05:58.020 --> 00:06:02.880
chances are they've hired someone who has
ITIL certifications or background and

90
00:06:02.880 --> 00:06:06.290
experience, and they understand
the frameworks and how to implement them.

91
00:06:08.160 --> 00:06:13.420
So a number of things come into play,
again, that go way above and

92
00:06:13.420 --> 00:06:18.520
beyond just regular routine
help desk kind of operations.

93
00:06:18.520 --> 00:06:22.490
In particular, in the previous episode
we talked about change management.

94
00:06:22.490 --> 00:06:26.370
Well, in many organizations,
the service organization

95
00:06:26.370 --> 00:06:31.060
is tasked with managing
those change request.

96
00:06:31.060 --> 00:06:33.920
They have what we would call
a ticketing system, for instance.

97
00:06:35.090 --> 00:06:40.290
There's dozens of companies out there
that do that, but they actually will use

98
00:06:40.290 --> 00:06:45.090
the ticketing system for plain old help
desk tickets like, I might submit a ticket

99
00:06:45.090 --> 00:06:50.150
and say, I really don't understand why
my email does this when I'm on the VPN.

100
00:06:50.150 --> 00:06:51.420
Can you help me?

101
00:06:51.420 --> 00:06:54.206
Am I missing something or
does there need to be a setting set up?

102
00:06:54.206 --> 00:06:59.560
Or, maybe it's, I forgot to change my
application or my password excuse me,

103
00:06:59.560 --> 00:07:05.075
to one of the internal applications and
I need to reset it because the application

104
00:07:05.075 --> 00:07:10.460
doesn't give the user the opportunity
to do a self-service password reset.

105
00:07:10.460 --> 00:07:17.420
Those are kind of the typical historical
things we think of help desk with.

106
00:07:17.420 --> 00:07:20.790
But we don't typically associate
them with change management.

107
00:07:20.790 --> 00:07:25.310
However, those ticketing systems have
the same kind of capabilities of tracking.

108
00:07:25.310 --> 00:07:27.000
They provide an audit trail.

109
00:07:27.000 --> 00:07:31.330
You can create standardized forms for
people to fill out.

110
00:07:31.330 --> 00:07:34.470
And then it's just simply a matter
of routing at that point.

111
00:07:34.470 --> 00:07:38.390
When the helpdesk ticket comes in it goes
to the change management board rather than

112
00:07:38.390 --> 00:07:40.050
to a service desk person.

113
00:07:40.050 --> 00:07:42.830
That also gives you the ability
then to collect metrics

114
00:07:44.490 --> 00:07:48.520
on things like how many service
requests your getting a month.

115
00:07:48.520 --> 00:07:52.568
How many of those are change management
requests versus desktop support tickets?

116
00:07:52.568 --> 00:07:58.210
Versus system administration,
could be depending on what

117
00:07:58.210 --> 00:08:02.260
your organization calls them, operations,
change requests, things like that.

118
00:08:02.260 --> 00:08:06.857
Me, I'm always one of the ones who submit
a request please give me admin access to

119
00:08:06.857 --> 00:08:10.050
my local machine, so
I can do whatever I want to it on it.

120
00:08:10.050 --> 00:08:12.403
And give me full access to the network
when I come into the VPN so

121
00:08:12.403 --> 00:08:14.745
I don't have to bother you
with things like that.

122
00:08:14.745 --> 00:08:17.485
And of course they revoke that, right?

123
00:08:17.485 --> 00:08:19.605
>> Well you figured it was worth a shot.

124
00:08:19.605 --> 00:08:21.295
>> Yeah that's right, it's worth a shot.

125
00:08:21.295 --> 00:08:26.209
See if they'll, see if I can social
engineer my way through the Cloud.

126
00:08:26.209 --> 00:08:31.032
Anyway, so it's really important
to understand some of those

127
00:08:31.032 --> 00:08:34.640
functions that the service desk provides.

128
00:08:34.640 --> 00:08:38.790
For instance, server support,
service delivery,

129
00:08:38.790 --> 00:08:42.590
I'm sorry, and then also functional
planning and management.

130
00:08:42.590 --> 00:08:48.830
Because the service organization
can become a great resource for

131
00:08:48.830 --> 00:08:51.280
knowing when you're
reaching capacity limits.

132
00:08:51.280 --> 00:08:56.383
For instance, a company I do consulting
with just recently, for the first time

133
00:08:56.383 --> 00:09:01.638
ever, I found out because I got an alert
message from the exchange server that they

134
00:09:01.638 --> 00:09:06.841
have a policy in place, where you're
only allowed to store 100 meg of email.

135
00:09:06.841 --> 00:09:08.566
100 meg!
>> That's not much.

136
00:09:08.566 --> 00:09:12.600
>> [LAUGH] That's not much at all for
a guy like me.

137
00:09:12.600 --> 00:09:14.400
And it said, you must delete mail or

138
00:09:14.400 --> 00:09:16.840
you're gonna stop being able to send and
receive.

139
00:09:19.040 --> 00:09:22.370
That set off some alarms for me.

140
00:09:22.370 --> 00:09:25.180
And here's where I wanna do
a little sidebar for a second,

141
00:09:25.180 --> 00:09:27.230
talk about root cause analysis.

142
00:09:27.230 --> 00:09:32.090
There had been another issue
come up within that company

143
00:09:32.090 --> 00:09:36.750
recently where there was some
concern of data loss prevention

144
00:09:36.750 --> 00:09:40.829
because people were backing up their
email on portable, removable drives.

145
00:09:42.410 --> 00:09:45.920
And when I said, well,
why would anyone ever do that?

146
00:09:45.920 --> 00:09:48.845
And they couldn't come up with an answer,
well, now I know why.

147
00:09:48.845 --> 00:09:52.450
>> [LAUGH]
>> They had created a storage limit policy

00:09:52.450 --> 00:09:57.370

00:09:58.420 --> 00:10:03.600

let them store more emails.

00:10:03.600 --> 00:10:05.930
They'll stop removing them
in removable drives and

151
00:10:05.930 --> 00:10:10.830
walking off the, walking off the physical
grounds with back up PSD files.

152
00:10:10.830 --> 00:10:12.500
We haven't executed yet, that yet, but

00:10:12.500 --> 00:10:16.290
that was my, that was my recommendation
was you created your own problem.

154
00:10:16.290 --> 00:10:20.170
That would have never come up had
a service desk issue never been tracked,

155
00:10:20.170 --> 00:10:22.640
it said why is this going on?

156
00:10:22.640 --> 00:10:24.310
>> Yeah I've been to
this same exact thing.

157
00:10:24.310 --> 00:10:26.480
I've worked in a corporate environment.

158
00:10:26.480 --> 00:10:30.403
People, they get that email and you're
going okay, our Exchange server is getting

159
00:10:30.403 --> 00:10:33.881
a little full, we need to take a look
at that, where can we trim the fat, and

160
00:10:33.881 --> 00:10:37.030
we were just letting people keep
their entirety of their mailbox for

161
00:10:37.030 --> 00:10:39.047
as long as they've been with the company.

162
00:10:39.047 --> 00:10:43.330
Some people have 50, 60, 90 gigs of email.

163
00:10:43.330 --> 00:10:44.740
So we say, well, we gotta trim that back,

164
00:10:44.740 --> 00:10:46.820
of course,
there's a back push against that.

165
00:10:46.820 --> 00:10:51.340
Well, I can't lose those advertised spams.

166
00:10:51.340 --> 00:10:55.220
Listen, the deleted items box, that is
not a folder for you to store things,

167
00:10:55.220 --> 00:10:57.860
that's for you to delete things and
they didn't realize that.

168
00:10:57.860 --> 00:10:58.470
So that was helpful.

169
00:10:58.470 --> 00:11:00.860
But you got to find that happy medium, and

170
00:11:00.860 --> 00:11:04.230
using these things is like you said,
like a metric is gonna help out with that.

171
00:11:04.230 --> 00:11:04.950
>> Exactly.

172
00:11:04.950 --> 00:11:10.260
Okay, so
we were talking about how the mailbox

173
00:11:10.260 --> 00:11:14.600
issue through root cause analysis
really led us to find another problem,

174
00:11:14.600 --> 00:11:16.960
which was DLP, Data Loss Prevention.

175
00:11:16.960 --> 00:11:21.930
We had PSD files going out the door on
unauthorized back up drives because

176
00:11:21.930 --> 00:11:26.740
users weren't given enough space to
adequately store what they could have.

177
00:11:26.740 --> 00:11:29.810
And, in addition to that,
no one had ever explored the idea.

178
00:11:29.810 --> 00:11:32.850
You were talking about how
employees had stored 50 and

179
00:11:32.850 --> 00:11:36.376
60 gigs worth of email archives.

180
00:11:36.376 --> 00:11:40.360
Archives compress e-mails dramatically.

181
00:11:40.360 --> 00:11:42.400
Exchange or admins know how to do that.

182
00:11:42.400 --> 00:11:46.700
You can set up automatic timing so
that every 30 to 60 to 90 days,

183
00:11:46.700 --> 00:11:48.280
your e-mails get archived.

184
00:11:48.280 --> 00:11:53.080
And you still have access to it because
it creates pointers in your mailbox to

185
00:11:53.080 --> 00:11:57.070
those files and
they're simply not stored until you.

186
00:11:57.070 --> 00:11:59.280
They're actually not stored
on your local machine.

187
00:11:59.280 --> 00:12:01.540
They're stored somewhere
off-site on lower,

188
00:12:01.540 --> 00:12:07.760
cheaper grade storage rather than
super expensive flash drives, etc.

189
00:12:07.760 --> 00:12:11.600
And make them available
to you forever basically

190
00:12:11.600 --> 00:12:16.030
depending on what your data retention
policy is of the organization, etc.

191
00:12:16.030 --> 00:12:20.620
But at any rate, the point I was trying to
make was how the metrics and the reporting

192
00:12:20.620 --> 00:12:25.630
from your service organization can
be extremely helpful in not only

193
00:12:25.630 --> 00:12:30.610
