root cause analysis of those problems and

194
00:12:30.610 --> 00:12:34.590
come up with solutions like we did
at the company I was talking about

195
00:12:34.590 --> 00:12:39.420
where now we have both,
we've satisfied both needs.

196
00:12:39.420 --> 00:12:44.160
Storage is minimized through doing
archiving, which compresses the data so

197
00:12:44.160 --> 00:12:45.780
it doesn't take up as much space.

198
00:12:45.780 --> 00:12:50.447
We've offloaded it to cheaper,
slower spinning drive

199
00:12:50.447 --> 00:12:54.925
storage versus more expensive SAN or
flash storage.

200
00:12:54.925 --> 00:13:00.580
As you may know, there is tiered
architecture in storage today from really,

201
00:13:00.580 --> 00:13:05.713
really, cheap big monster,
massive multi terabyte spinning drives

202
00:13:05.713 --> 00:13:10.759
that cost pennies compared to what
it used to, to SAN storage which is

203
00:13:10.759 --> 00:13:15.718
very fairly fast and robust,
etc to super monster flash drives that

204
00:13:15.718 --> 00:13:20.970
we use in our virtual machines,
etc for that instant access stuff.

205
00:13:20.970 --> 00:13:26.130
So anyway, the point being, that
the service organization can be extremely

206
00:13:26.130 --> 00:13:31.050
valuable to you in an organization in
terms of tracking down problems and

207
00:13:31.050 --> 00:13:32.590
finding out where they surface.

208
00:13:32.590 --> 00:13:39.090
So as an auditor when we go in we try to
look at those metrics to see whether or

209
00:13:39.090 --> 00:13:44.160
not the applications that we
talked about in the last domain,

210
00:13:44.160 --> 00:13:47.000
in the last episodes about the systems and

211
00:13:47.000 --> 00:13:50.940
software etc that we've acquired,
that we've helped the company acquired.

212
00:13:50.940 --> 00:13:56.110
Are they actually delivering
the service that they claim to be or

213
00:13:56.110 --> 00:13:59.660
are we having other kinds of
problems creep into the picture?

214
00:14:00.820 --> 00:14:01.810
The audience for

215
00:14:01.810 --> 00:14:04.760
some of this, interestingly enough,
is senior management.

216
00:14:06.410 --> 00:14:08.930
IT directors, managers and CIO's.

217
00:14:08.930 --> 00:14:11.340
They're the ones that really
like seeing this information.

218
00:14:12.800 --> 00:14:17.490
Your average help desk manager,
that's not really their responsibility or

219
00:14:17.490 --> 00:14:19.950
I should say their service
organization manager.

220
00:14:19.950 --> 00:14:23.980
Their responsibility is simply to feed
the information up the food chain, if you

221
00:14:23.980 --> 00:14:29.280
will, to the powers that be so that they
can begin doing their investigations, etc.

222
00:14:29.280 --> 00:14:33.280
So I might come around to a service
organization manager and say can you show

223
00:14:33.280 --> 00:14:40.530
me your reports on the number of viruses
you've been hit with in the last year?

224
00:14:40.530 --> 00:14:45.420
I might say, you tell me that, or I heard
from one of the employees that there

225
00:14:45.420 --> 00:14:50.210
was a ransomware infection recently that
cost you guys hundreds of hours of time.

226
00:14:51.270 --> 00:14:54.850
Can you show me the log trail
on the incident handling that

227
00:14:54.850 --> 00:14:57.830
occurred as a result of those incidents?

228
00:14:57.830 --> 00:14:58.820
Because typically,

229
00:14:58.820 --> 00:15:03.900
all that's recorded in the service
delivery organization's ticketing system.

230
00:15:03.900 --> 00:15:05.910
So it's a great audit trail.

231
00:15:05.910 --> 00:15:07.880
There's a wealth of knowledge in there.

232
00:15:07.880 --> 00:15:12.040
It can be a bit of
a challenge to do data mining

233
00:15:12.040 --> 00:15:14.600
to find the information
that you're looking for.

234
00:15:14.600 --> 00:15:19.370
But typically if you're doing change
management and you're tracking

235
00:15:19.370 --> 00:15:24.640
incidents of any type and doing all
that inside the service organization.

236
00:15:24.640 --> 00:15:26.630
It's a wealth of knowledge.

237
00:15:26.630 --> 00:15:30.557
It's important for
us as auditor to understand whether or

238
00:15:30.557 --> 00:15:33.460
not there is a service organization.

239
00:15:33.460 --> 00:15:35.440
Is it operating effectively?

240
00:15:35.440 --> 00:15:37.790
Is it being funded properly?

Or is it simply, as I see, unfortunately,

242
00:15:42.170 --> 00:15:46.580
in banks and health care organizations,
just a password

243
00:15:46.580 --> 00:15:51.520
reset function that's being staffed
by people rather than an application.

244
00:15:51.520 --> 00:15:55.250
And sadly, that's what I see a number
of times when I go into organizations.

245
00:15:55.250 --> 00:15:57.050
They just don't see the value in putting,

246
00:15:57.050 --> 00:16:01.390
cuz it comes down to that common
denominator of help desk.

247
00:16:01.390 --> 00:16:04.070
They don't see it as
a service organization.

Now, I have worked with a couple

00:16:08.690 --> 00:16:12.370

251

252
00:16:16.840 --> 00:16:22.190
It helps them track problems and
spot problems before they become really,

253
00:16:22.190 --> 00:16:23.620
really serious.

254

00:16:28.420 --> 00:16:33.220

service management.

it's gonna help us divine

It can be a bear but it ca also be
very beneficial for us as well.

267

Using this as a metric like I said
before is gonna help in that endeavor.

268

Well Brian, we thank you for

feet wet here in domain four.

these concepts to us so

One of our good authors,

He's giving you the inside track so

278

That being said, we're gonna go ahead and

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Brian discuss conducting reviews of IT systems. They start by going through the different types of storage like local storage (Physical Spinning Drives & SSD), attached storage (SAN & NAS), and removable storage(flash). They also discuss network devices (routers & switches). Finally they cover network redundancy and management devices like SEIMs, Firewalls, and DMZs.

you should know about in IT in general.

51

three components of IT hardware system.

52
00:02:57.350 --> 00:02:58.406

53
00:02:58.406 --> 00:03:03.030

then we have storage.

54
00:03:03.030 --> 00:03:05.768

55
00:03:05.768 --> 00:03:11.596
Storage is the most important,
because that's how data is retrieved and

56
00:03:11.596 --> 00:03:16.679
written to for transactional
reasons that we're in business.

57
00:03:16.679 --> 00:03:22.230
So I wanna start off and give you a brief
description of what we call RAID.

58
00:03:23.820 --> 00:03:29.160
RAID stands for, it actually been argued
in the literature for a number of years.

59
00:03:29.160 --> 00:03:33.376
It used to be redundant array
of inexpensive disks, but

60
00:03:33.376 --> 00:03:36.345
discs did not use to be so inexpensive.

61
00:03:36.345 --> 00:03:40.254
It was called inexpensive, because it
was less expensive to take three or

62
00:03:40.254 --> 00:03:43.988
four disks and combine them together
than it was to buy a big giant one.

63
00:03:43.988 --> 00:03:46.229
And when I'm saying combine them,

64
00:03:46.229 --> 00:03:50.497
I'm talking back in the days when
we bought 10 gig or 5 gig disks.

65
00:03:50.497 --> 00:03:52.963
It was much cheaper to
buy four 5 gig disks,

66
00:03:52.963 --> 00:03:57.041
figure out how to get them to work
together.than it was to buy a 20 gig.

67
00:03:57.041 --> 00:04:02.054
Because back in the day, 20 gig drives
could cost a thousand of dollars,

68
00:04:02.054 --> 00:04:05.050
a piece or more and they were very large.

69
00:04:05.050 --> 00:04:09.179
I remember taking a one of the first
ID drives I ever soldered an early

70
00:04:09.179 --> 00:04:09.983
IBM system.

71
00:04:09.983 --> 00:04:13.793
The drive was literally this big and
only held 10 meg.

72
00:04:13.793 --> 00:04:14.356
>> It's like a cinder block.

73
00:04:14.356 --> 00:04:16.633
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah it was gigantic.

74
00:04:16.633 --> 00:04:24.204
So the concept of RAID was designed
to allow us to combine disks,

75
00:04:24.204 --> 00:04:31.357
to either increase the amount
of storage capability we had,

76
00:04:31.357 --> 00:04:37.947
to increase the reliability
of storage we have on hand or

77
00:04:37.947 --> 00:04:43.020
the speed at which we access that storage.

78
00:04:44.030 --> 00:04:49.777
RAID 0, which is also called striping
is the fastest of those three.

79
00:04:49.777 --> 00:04:54.737
RAID 0 allows you to combine and there
are graphs in the book you could look

80
00:04:54.737 --> 00:04:59.539
up if you want to study more of this
in details in terms of how it's done.

81
00:04:59.539 --> 00:05:02.457
I's called striping without parity.

82
00:05:02.457 --> 00:05:05.415
It allows you to combine disks and

83
00:05:05.415 --> 00:05:11.444
what it does is it writes one portion
of each data file to each drive.

84
00:05:11.444 --> 00:05:13.915
So instead of doing one write operation,

85
00:05:13.915 --> 00:05:17.101
it does three write operations
across three drives.

86
00:05:17.101 --> 00:05:20.936
At the same time, it only writes a third
of the amount of data on each drive, so

87
00:05:20.936 --> 00:05:22.006
it can write faster.

88
00:05:22.006 --> 00:05:24.269
So, it does that in
a stripe across the drive.

89
00:05:24.269 --> 00:05:26.482
It goes really monster fast,

90
00:05:26.482 --> 00:05:31.181
you used to see this a lot in
early days with graphic designers.

91
00:05:31.181 --> 00:05:36.283

00:06:01.871 --> 00:06:07.360

00:06:07.360 --> 00:06:11.650

99
00:06:11.650 --> 00:06:16.920

00:06:16.920 --> 00:06:22.924

it will run twice as fast

101
00:06:22.924 --> 00:06:28.218

because there's two copies of the data.

102
00:06:28.218 --> 00:06:31.431

busy when you request the data,

103
00:06:31.431 --> 00:06:33.956

pull the file.

104
00:06:33.956 --> 00:06:38.174

105
00:06:38.174 --> 00:06:42.059

the write operations are slower,

106
00:06:42.059 --> 00:06:47.218
because it has to write two copies of
the data stream, one to each drive.

107
00:06:47.218 --> 00:06:50.813

108
00:06:50.813 --> 00:06:55.647

you still have a copy that's functional.

00:06:55.647 --> 00:07:00.386

00:07:02.974 --> 00:07:06.557

00:09:18.130 --> 00:09:20.800

00:09:20.800 --> 00:09:22.517

three because you can, for

00:31:06.790 --> 00:31:10.820
instance, if your routers are still up,
you could lose a firewall.

541
00:31:10.820 --> 00:31:14.350
You could lose an IPS, IDS and
still maintain business.

542
00:31:14.350 --> 00:31:16.910
They're not absolutely critical,
they haven't stopped everything.

543
00:31:16.910 --> 00:31:21.699
The other thing is you wanna make sure
that those devices are configured so

544
00:31:21.699 --> 00:31:25.418
that, let's take your
intrusion prevention systems.

545
00:31:25.418 --> 00:31:28.245
That's what I'm talking about
when I say IPS and IDS,

546
00:31:28.245 --> 00:31:32.870
intrusion detection system and intrusion
protection system, a little bit different.

547
00:31:34.800 --> 00:31:39.460
Those typically are designed to
do what we call failing open.

548
00:31:39.460 --> 00:31:42.384
So that if an interface were
to die on one of those, or

549
00:31:42.384 --> 00:31:46.504
the machine were to burn out or a power
supply fail or something like that,

550
00:31:46.504 --> 00:31:48.708
that the traffic would not be stopped.

551
00:31:48.708 --> 00:31:50.728
It doesn't become a single
point of failure.

552
00:31:50.728 --> 00:31:55.428
I remember working back in early 2005,
With an intrusion protection

553
00:31:55.428 --> 00:32:00.202
system company where we actually had
to put taps in around the interfaces so

554
00:32:00.202 --> 00:32:04.450
that if anything happened,
the traffic wouldn't stop.

555
00:32:04.450 --> 00:32:07.330
Because you don't want
business transactions to stop

556
00:32:07.330 --> 00:32:10.790
just because your IDS failed.

557
00:32:10.790 --> 00:32:13.650
The last couple things I wanna talk about,
cuz we are running over, here,

558
00:32:13.650 --> 00:32:15.999
is I wanna mention SIMS.

559
00:32:17.870 --> 00:32:21.055
You'll see these spelled two
different ways: S-E-I-M and

560
00:32:21.055 --> 00:32:24.000
S-I-M, Security Event
Information Management Systems.

561
00:32:25.480 --> 00:32:30.570
Those typically tend to set off to the
side of all of your throughput traffic,

562
00:32:30.570 --> 00:32:34.090
and they simply watch for
events and track them, etc.

563
00:32:34.090 --> 00:32:36.870
But it's important that you
understand what those are.

564
00:32:36.870 --> 00:32:40.060
And then a couple of terms you
need to know for sure, for

565
00:32:40.060 --> 00:32:46.270
the exam on firewalls are what a DMZ or
a Demilitarized Zone is.

566
00:32:46.270 --> 00:32:52.630
A DMZ is a specific zone in
the firewall that will allow traffic to

567
00:32:52.630 --> 00:32:57.940
come into a device, typically a web
server of some kind but then controls

568
00:32:57.940 --> 00:33:03.990
access from that device into the inside
land, so that it only specific ports etc.

569
00:33:03.990 --> 00:33:09.330
And when we dive into the OSI model,
probably in later episodes,

570
00:33:09.330 --> 00:33:12.890
I'll talk specifically about ports and
what that all means, so

571
00:33:13.890 --> 00:33:18.950
In reviewing your enterprise architecture,
it's important to remember these points.

572
00:33:18.950 --> 00:33:22.490
Are there single points of failure and
if so

573
00:33:22.490 --> 00:33:27.450
can the organization afford
the downtime if the failure occurs and

574
00:33:27.450 --> 00:33:35.080
if not at what point does it become cost
prohibitive to do something about that.

575
00:33:35.080 --> 00:33:39.640
Second, are resources being
deployed in the correct places?

576
00:33:39.640 --> 00:33:42.420
Are you buying firewalls
that you don't need?

577
00:33:42.420 --> 00:33:46.440
Are they more expensive and have more
capabilities than your staff or evne,

578
00:33:46.440 --> 00:33:50.480
I see this all the time companies will
buy the latest and greatest firewall, but

579
00:33:50.480 --> 00:33:51.830
nobody knows how to use them.

580
00:33:51.830 --> 00:33:53.250
They don't have the time
to get the training.

581
00:33:53.250 --> 00:33:55.250
And they think that because
it's the latest and

582
00:33:55.250 --> 00:33:57.310
greatest that it's going
to do them more good.

583
00:33:57.310 --> 00:34:00.070
And really what winds up happening
is they're too complicated,

584
00:34:00.070 --> 00:34:02.090
they don't know how to configure them and

585
00:34:02.090 --> 00:34:05.910
eventually they get in trouble because
the boxes aren't configured properly.

586
00:34:05.910 --> 00:34:08.530
>> Well they think it's just a magic box,
right?

587
00:34:08.530 --> 00:34:10.280
It works, you plug it in and it goes.

588
00:34:10.280 --> 00:34:16.840
>> And then does the enterprise
architecture itself.

589
00:34:16.840 --> 00:34:19.150
Support the organizational's objective.

590
00:34:19.150 --> 00:34:24.884
So there's all this money that we're
spending and all these design we're doing.

591
00:34:24.884 --> 00:34:30.096
Are they designed or excuse me are they
designed to support the organization's

592
00:34:30.096 --> 00:34:35.480
objectives or the CIO's objective or the
geek guys on the front line objectives?

593
00:34:35.480 --> 00:34:38.280
Did you buy the new firewalls
cuz they just sounded cool and

594
00:34:38.280 --> 00:34:40.590
the sales guy got you
to drink the kool-aid?

595
00:34:40.590 --> 00:34:43.890
Or do they really support
the objectives of the organization.

596
00:34:43.890 --> 00:34:46.790
Because at the end of the day
that's really what it's all about.

597
00:34:46.790 --> 00:34:50.120
And you'll find yourself
in a much better position

598
00:34:50.120 --> 00:34:54.960
if you're allocating resources
based on need rather than want.

599
00:34:54.960 --> 00:34:57.180
>> Alright, well Brian,
that's a lot for us to chew on.

600
00:34:57.180 --> 00:35:00.900
If you're not familiar
with IT technologies,

601
00:35:00.900 --> 00:35:02.330
this has been a great primer for you.

602
00:35:02.330 --> 00:35:04.290
If you are,
then this has been a great review for you,

603
00:35:04.290 --> 00:35:06.600
because these are the kind of
things that we have to understand.

604
00:35:06.600 --> 00:35:10.630
We have to be able to work with, like
Bryan says, speak intelligently about,

605
00:35:10.630 --> 00:35:15.240
as an auditor, you need to be able
to walk up to an IT specialist and

606
00:35:15.240 --> 00:35:18.010
talk about what it is that he does,
and the equipment that he uses.

607
00:35:18.010 --> 00:35:23.310
And how he's using them to create
a good risk management structure,

608
00:35:23.310 --> 00:35:27.690
so if he's the router switch guy,
are you building in that redundancy?

609
00:35:27.690 --> 00:35:31.440
Do you have multiple points of failure
when it comes to our internet connectivity

610
00:35:31.440 --> 00:35:34.180
because if it goes down we're going
to lose all sorts of business.

611
00:35:34.180 --> 00:35:35.140
So that's what it's all about,

612
00:35:35.140 --> 00:35:36.980
that's what we're trying to
help you guys out with today.

613
00:35:36.980 --> 00:35:39.240
Hopefully you've got
a little bit out of this.

614
00:35:39.240 --> 00:35:43.050
Byron, we thank you so much for lending
your expertise on that topic again.

615
00:35:43.050 --> 00:35:43.800
>> You're welcome.
>> Guys,

616
00:35:43.800 --> 00:35:46.344
don't forget, grab a
>> copy of the study guide, fourth

617
00:35:46.344 --> 00:35:50.070
edition, one of the authors sitting right
here giving you the low down on that.

618
00:35:50.070 --> 00:35:52.770
So grab one, go to Amazon or
where better books are sold and

619
00:35:52.770 --> 00:35:54.120
you can get a copy of that.

620
00:35:54.120 --> 00:35:56.290
That being said,
we are outta time for this episode.

621
00:35:56.290 --> 00:35:57.770
So we're gonna go ahead and wrap it up.

622
00:35:57.770 --> 00:36:00.500
For IT ProTV I've been
your host Daniel Laurie.

623
00:36:00.500 --> 00:36:01.290
>> And I'm Brian O'Hara.

624
00:36:01.290 --> 00:36:03.910
>> And we'll see you next time.

625
00:36:03.910 --> 00:36:07.253
[MUSIC]

626
00:36:07.253 --> 00:36:11.168

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Brian talk about evaluating IT operations for the purpose of discovering their effectiveness. Then they explain the process of End of Sale(EoS); what to do when a vendor stops selling a product you use, and End of Life(EoL); what to do when a vendor stops supporting a product you use. Of course they explain how this all is dealt with through change management.
episodes.title: IS Ops, Maintenance and Service Mgmt. Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.487 --> 00:00:16.080
All right greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:16.080 --> 00:00:20.070
I'm your host Daniel Lowry and in today's
episode we are continuing on with our

4
00:00:20.070 --> 00:00:25.390
series on CISA that's right,
the Certified Information Systems Auditor.

5
00:00:25.390 --> 00:00:28.660
And right here I've got the study guide,
fourth edition.

6
00:00:28.660 --> 00:00:32.200
And guess what, one of the very authors
of this lovely study guide is sitting

7
00:00:32.200 --> 00:00:32.830
here right next to me.

8
00:00:32.830 --> 00:00:35.650
He's been helping us guide
our way through this

9
00:00:35.650 --> 00:00:38.730
myriad of information that we need
to know so we can pass this exam.

10
00:00:38.730 --> 00:00:40.590
It's our good friend Mr. Brian O'Hare.

11
00:00:40.590 --> 00:00:41.550
Brian, welcome back to the show.

12
00:00:41.550 --> 00:00:42.700
How's it going today?

13
00:00:42.700 --> 00:00:43.340
>> Thanks Daniel.

14
00:00:44.360 --> 00:00:48.300
This morning and talk a little bit about,
a little bit more about evaluating

15
00:00:48.300 --> 00:00:50.760
it operations to see if
they're still effective.

16
00:00:52.180 --> 00:00:55.500
Part of your job is
an IT Auditor is to be able to

17
00:00:57.160 --> 00:01:02.230
work around it systems and
be able to identify things that may or

18
00:01:02.230 --> 00:01:05.070
may not be brought to your attention,
purposely.

19
00:01:05.070 --> 00:01:08.520
[LAUGH] So
that you can find out whether or

20
00:01:08.520 --> 00:01:12.520
not the organization is managing
their risk effectively.

21
00:01:12.520 --> 00:01:15.220
In the previous episode we
talked a little bit about,

22
00:01:15.220 --> 00:01:19.540
well we talked a lot about routers and
switches and network devices, ect.

23
00:01:19.540 --> 00:01:23.590
In this episode, I'd like to talk
more specifically about applications,

24
00:01:23.590 --> 00:01:27.920
and operating systems, and databases.

25
00:01:27.920 --> 00:01:32.840
In particular, what we're gonna
talk about is the application or

26
00:01:32.840 --> 00:01:34.650
operating system lifecycle.

27
00:01:34.650 --> 00:01:40.200
A little different than the SDLC we
talked about in previous episodes.

28
00:01:40.200 --> 00:01:44.590
so there's three specific terms that I'd
like you all to become familiar with,

29
00:01:44.590 --> 00:01:48.600
some of which will be on your exam,
so you need to kind of know those,

30
00:01:48.600 --> 00:01:53.430
they're in the book as well,
the first being end of sale.

31
00:01:53.430 --> 00:02:00.760
Anytime a vendor, whether it be Microsoft
or Apple or Oracle, something like that,

32
00:02:00.760 --> 00:02:06.590
who sells an operating system there
is a date called end of sale.

33
00:02:06.590 --> 00:02:10.390
It's part of their
application system lifecycle.

34
00:02:10.390 --> 00:02:16.260
That's the date at which the vendor no
longer offers the product for sale.

35
00:02:16.260 --> 00:02:19.250
And the reason that they do that is,

36
00:02:19.250 --> 00:02:22.660
that will feed into the next two terms
we're gonna talk about in a minute.

37
00:02:22.660 --> 00:02:26.778
In terms of how do they end
the life cycle of a product.

38
00:02:26.778 --> 00:02:31.280
So, in the previous episodes we've talked
about data management where there is

39
00:02:31.280 --> 00:02:36.080
a date where the data is created, it has
a lifetime, it has to be managed and

40
00:02:36.080 --> 00:02:41.960
then it has an end of life based on
your data retention policies etc.

41
00:02:41.960 --> 00:02:46.260
And at some point needs to be taken
off line and either archived for

42
00:02:46.260 --> 00:02:49.050
long term storage or
destroy them in some way or another.

43
00:02:49.050 --> 00:02:51.820
Applications and operating systems
are very much the same way.

44
00:02:51.820 --> 00:02:55.120
They have a defined life cycle
where they are first offered for

45
00:02:55.120 --> 00:02:58.580
sale, there are patches, upgrades, etc.

46
00:02:58.580 --> 00:03:04.531
Then the first milestone in that
lifestyle [LAUGH] lifestyle

47
00:03:04.531 --> 00:03:06.090
>> [LAUGH]

48
00:03:06.090 --> 00:03:07.930
>> Where the product's no longer available

49
00:03:07.930 --> 00:03:08.770
to purchase.

50
00:03:08.770 --> 00:03:10.870
For instance,
if you were to go online today.

51
00:03:12.130 --> 00:03:14.330
I ran into this just recently.

52
00:03:14.330 --> 00:03:17.180
If you, cuz I was doing some
snooping around on the web to

53
00:03:17.180 --> 00:03:18.480
see what was out there.

54
00:03:18.480 --> 00:03:24.140
If you try to purchase a licensed
copy of Office 2010, for instance,

55
00:03:24.140 --> 00:03:27.250
there's a very good chance you're liable
to get hold something that's loaded with

56
00:03:27.250 --> 00:03:32.790
malware because there's a number
of malicious sites out there.

57
00:03:33.950 --> 00:03:40.080
We call these drive-by or fishing sites
where Malicious users have loaded

58
00:03:40.080 --> 00:03:45.750
what looked to be legitimate
Microsoft Office 2010 licenses that

59
00:03:45.750 --> 00:03:50.470
turned out to be riddled with malware when
you buy them and download them not only do

60
00:03:50.470 --> 00:03:53.520
you not get Office 2010, you wind up
with a bunch of malware on your machine.

61
00:03:55.130 --> 00:03:56.580
And you have to pay for it.

62
00:03:56.580 --> 00:03:58.070
>> That is right.

63
00:03:58.070 --> 00:04:04.810
If you go to the Microsoft website, or you
just Google Microsoft Windows Lifecycle,

64
00:04:04.810 --> 00:04:09.300
you will actually find a page that
will tell you the end of sale dates,

65
00:04:09.300 --> 00:04:13.890
the end of life dates, and the third
one which we call end of support dates.

66
00:04:13.890 --> 00:04:17.060
But most importantly,
we're gonna look for end of sale.

67
00:04:17.060 --> 00:04:21.440
Because that signals that
if you needed a backup

68
00:04:21.440 --> 00:04:26.410
copy of that software for some reason, you
would no longer be able to purchase it.

69
00:04:26.410 --> 00:04:30.410
So if you ever shop that's
running Office 2010, and

70
00:04:30.410 --> 00:04:35.210
you're now past the end of sale
life cycle in that product.

71
00:04:35.210 --> 00:04:38.600
That means if you have a new user or
if you have a machine destroyed or

72
00:04:38.600 --> 00:04:43.930
something, and you have any trouble
coming up with license keys to

73
00:04:43.930 --> 00:04:48.060
reinstall that application, you may not
be able to purchase those any longer.

74
00:04:48.060 --> 00:04:50.890
So that's important, in terms of

75
00:04:50.890 --> 00:04:55.150
making sure that your organization is
protected from those kinds of losses.

76
00:04:55.150 --> 00:04:57.670
You don't want to have to employ
new software that you haven't had

77
00:04:57.670 --> 00:04:59.090
an opportunity to test, etc.

78
00:04:59.090 --> 00:05:02.620
So you need to know what those dates are.

79
00:05:02.620 --> 00:05:04.410
The second one we want to
talk about is end of life.

80
00:05:04.410 --> 00:05:06.470
This one starts to
become really important,

81
00:05:06.470 --> 00:05:10.090
because what end of life
typically means is that.

82
00:05:11.390 --> 00:05:16.040
The vendor will no longer
provide any type of security

83
00:05:16.040 --> 00:05:21.170
patches short of, excuse me I
should not say security patches.

84
00:05:21.170 --> 00:05:24.340
They won't provide
anymore service packs or

85
00:05:24.340 --> 00:05:28.290
routine patches other than
critical security updates.

86
00:05:28.290 --> 00:05:30.100
That has kind of become the security norm,

87
00:05:30.100 --> 00:05:32.270
although you need to
check with the vendor.

88
00:05:32.270 --> 00:05:37.830
and the same is true of this for
operating systems that run Cisco switches,

89
00:05:37.830 --> 00:05:41.380
Cisco routers,
Juniper gear that kind of stuff.

90
00:05:41.380 --> 00:05:44.480
They all have these same things,
end of sale, end of life, end of support.

91
00:05:45.560 --> 00:05:49.030
End of life is important
because it is signaling you,

92
00:05:49.030 --> 00:05:51.830
also that end of support is coming soon.

93
00:05:51.830 --> 00:05:54.970
You sh ould look at your
documents to find this out.

94
00:05:54.970 --> 00:05:59.560
We've been working with a large
corporation the last two years

95
00:05:59.560 --> 00:06:01.120
trying to get them

96
00:06:02.680 --> 00:06:06.970
to get rid of their no longer supported
operating systems and applications.

97
00:06:08.570 --> 00:06:13.610
This is 2016 and
they're still running Server 2000.

98
00:06:13.610 --> 00:06:17.370
Which has been end-of-sale,
end-of-life, and end-of-support.

99
00:06:17.370 --> 00:06:19.220
We'll talk about
end-of-support in a minute.

100
00:06:19.220 --> 00:06:23.450
As well as Server 2003 which
has now been end-of-supported.

101
00:06:23.450 --> 00:06:28.175
And they're also running no longer
supported versions of Office.

102
00:06:28.175 --> 00:06:32.325
End-of-support, and
I'm gonna come back to that,

103
00:06:32.325 --> 00:06:36.510
end-of-support means that there
will no longer be any patches.

104
00:06:36.510 --> 00:06:37.830
Any security fixes.

105
00:06:37.830 --> 00:06:40.970
Any support whatsoever of the product.

106
00:06:40.970 --> 00:06:45.190
So, if you own it, and you have
a problem with it, you're on your own.

107
00:06:45.190 --> 00:06:48.770
You not only will not be able
to purchase replacement media,

108
00:06:48.770 --> 00:06:53.120
you won't be able to buy license keys.

109
00:06:53.120 --> 00:06:54.760
You're completely stuck out in the weeds.

110
00:06:54.760 --> 00:06:56.830
You're not going to get any
help from the vendor at all.

111
00:06:58.250 --> 00:07:03.500
In addition to that running
end of support software

112
00:07:03.500 --> 00:07:07.820
whether it be on a router or
a switch or a server or

113
00:07:07.820 --> 00:07:12.640
workstation is extremely
dangerous because hackers

114
00:07:12.640 --> 00:07:17.520
know that there are no longer
patches being provided for those and

115
00:07:17.520 --> 00:07:22.990
they will continue to find
vulnerabilities in the baking industry.

116
00:07:22.990 --> 00:07:26.630
You've heard me throughout these sessions
talk about my years of experience working

117
00:07:26.630 --> 00:07:28.855
in baking.

118
00:07:28.855 --> 00:07:33.970
Most of the ATM machines
in the US ran a form

119
00:07:33.970 --> 00:07:40.640
of embedded Windows XP for years and years
it was very cheap to buy that version.

120
00:07:40.640 --> 00:07:45.390
XP as we all know had been around for
years and years.

121
00:07:45.390 --> 00:07:51.090
And it 2012 or 13 I believe it was,
auditors from the FDIC

122
00:07:51.090 --> 00:07:54.710
started making it pretty well known that
was one of the first things they were

123
00:07:54.710 --> 00:07:58.660
gonna check when they showed up was to
make sure that you'd upgraded your ATMs.

124
00:07:58.660 --> 00:08:00.540
Because they did,
the last thing they wanted is,

125
00:08:00.540 --> 00:08:03.910
to have a country full of
ATMs vulnerable to attack.

126
00:08:03.910 --> 00:08:06.880
Because, they couldn't
be patched any longer.

127
00:08:06.880 --> 00:08:10.150
So, that's one of the first things I
do when I go into a financial services

128
00:08:10.150 --> 00:08:11.110
organization today.

129
00:08:11.110 --> 00:08:15.160
Is I start sniffing out operating
systems to see whether or

130
00:08:15.160 --> 00:08:18.500
not there are any end of support
systems in place [INAUDIBLE].

131
00:08:18.500 --> 00:08:19.180
It's a huge,

132
00:08:19.180 --> 00:08:22.460
huge vulnerability, because there's
almost nothing you can do about it.

133
00:08:22.460 --> 00:08:26.800
You can't put some what we might call
compensating control of the place.

134
00:08:26.800 --> 00:08:30.020
There's a definition of that in the book
if you want to check out what compensating

135
00:08:30.020 --> 00:08:31.400

vulnerabilities that continue to be found
in the systems, and that's why we do that.

31
00:01:58.110 --> 00:02:01.460
Now I'll talk about sort of two or
three different realms.

32
00:02:01.460 --> 00:02:05.585
We'll talk about servers and
server-based applications.

33
00:02:05.585 --> 00:02:09.394
We'll talk about workstations and
workstation-based applications.

34
00:02:09.394 --> 00:02:14.380
Then we'll talk about networking gear,
routers, switches, that kind of thing.

35
00:02:14.380 --> 00:02:17.000
We're still talking about patching and
upgrading all those,

36
00:02:17.000 --> 00:02:19.930
but there are some nuances
between the two and

37
00:02:19.930 --> 00:02:22.499
three different environments
that you need to be aware of.

38
00:02:23.980 --> 00:02:29.940
First of all is, going back to what
I've repeated in numerous sessions,

39
00:02:29.940 --> 00:02:35.000
iSocket is a worldwide organization
with over 118,000 members worldwide.

40
00:02:35.000 --> 00:02:39.500
They tend to think and talk in very large
terms, very large enterprise terms.

41
00:02:39.500 --> 00:02:42.570
So, when I say things like,

42
00:02:42.570 --> 00:02:47.860
you need to have a test environment for
testing hardware and software upgrades,

43
00:02:47.860 --> 00:02:51.360
a lot of companies don't have
that capability, they just don't.

44
00:02:51.360 --> 00:02:54.440
It's very expensive, but
when you're in a large enterprise,

45
00:02:54.440 --> 00:03:00.350
it's very expensive to not test
because if you are doing an upgrade or

46
00:03:00.350 --> 00:03:04.020
an update or something along those
lines and you break something critical,

47
00:03:04.020 --> 00:03:08.280
it could cost your company a lot
of money and a lot of downtime.

48
00:03:08.280 --> 00:03:11.331
So when you have the ability,

49
00:03:11.331 --> 00:03:16.214
I can't stress this enough,
test, test, and

50
00:03:16.214 --> 00:03:21.720
retest before you deploy patches,
upgrades, etc.

51
00:03:21.720 --> 00:03:25.666
You can't typically begin
to anticipate every single

52
00:03:25.666 --> 00:03:30.070
interaction that software
might have with other systems.

53
00:03:30.070 --> 00:03:33.300
And so, you can't always
predict how they might react.

54
00:03:33.300 --> 00:03:36.560
In the previous episode,
I talked about on particular routers and

55
00:03:36.560 --> 00:03:41.470
switches about using what has been
in the past called Golden Code or

56
00:03:41.470 --> 00:03:45.430
code that the vendor says is
the latest and greatest, most stable.

57
00:03:45.430 --> 00:03:49.740
It's very important that you know
how to find out what those are or

58
00:03:49.740 --> 00:03:52.550
at least know where to go
to ask those questions.

59
00:03:52.550 --> 00:03:57.830
If you go into a shop and
you find a routing environment where

60
00:03:57.830 --> 00:04:01.730
the staff are four, five,

61
00:04:01.730 --> 00:04:06.440
maybe six versions behind what
the vendor considers to be the latest,

62
00:04:06.440 --> 00:04:09.240
most stable version of
the code on the routers and

63
00:04:09.240 --> 00:04:12.850
switches, I'm gonna start asking
questions why they haven't upgraded.

64
00:04:12.850 --> 00:04:15.790
And if they don't have a really good
answer, which is because they haven't got

65
00:04:15.790 --> 00:04:20.990
around to it, then I'm gonna probably
take a harder look at their management

66
00:04:20.990 --> 00:04:25.010
structure to see why those things aren't
being brought to management's attention.

67
00:04:25.010 --> 00:04:28.960
Why they're not staying up with it,
what is their upgrade policy,

68
00:04:28.960 --> 00:04:32.060
what is their maintenance policy,
etc., for taking care of those things.

69
00:04:32.060 --> 00:04:35.333
And is it adequately
protecting the environment

70
00:04:35.333 --> 00:04:39.813
based on the strategic business
objectives of the organization.

71
00:04:39.813 --> 00:04:45.775
I wanna talk a little bit about some
practical hands-on procedures for

72
00:04:45.775 --> 00:04:47.570
doing that testing.

73
00:04:49.760 --> 00:04:53.651
Typically, find yourself a spare room
in the building somewhere where you've

74
00:04:53.651 --> 00:04:56.220
got adequate power,
network connectivity, etc.

75
00:04:57.740 --> 00:05:00.831
And make sure you have,
if you're doing a hardware upgrade,

76
00:05:00.831 --> 00:05:03.000
that you have identical hardware.

77
00:05:03.000 --> 00:05:07.470
Let's say, for instance, that you're
doing a BIOS upgrade on a server.

78
00:05:07.470 --> 00:05:13.080
That actually rarely happens, but there
are some instances where the firmware

79
00:05:13.080 --> 00:05:17.280
on a server is causing a problem, in
particular, when you're running something

80
00:05:17.280 --> 00:05:21.759
as critical as, say, VMware on top of
that ESXI or something like that, or ESX.

81
00:05:23.670 --> 00:05:27.010
The manufacturer may recommend
a BIOS firmware upgrade.

82
00:05:27.010 --> 00:05:31.600
That's a huge deal on a server because
if a firmware upgrade goes sour,

83
00:05:31.600 --> 00:05:33.330
you could lose the entire server.

84
00:05:33.330 --> 00:05:36.040
You may have to send it back to
the factory to be completely reset.

85
00:05:36.040 --> 00:05:38.280
So you wanna be extremely careful, and

86
00:05:38.280 --> 00:05:44.100
the BIOS is the very core,
the foundation of how that system runs.

87
00:05:44.100 --> 00:05:47.959
And if something messes up with it, it can
really have severe repercussions across

88
00:05:47.959 --> 00:05:50.122
all the applications
running on that system.

89
00:05:50.122 --> 00:05:52.051
>> And ironically,
if you call for support, say,

90
00:05:52.051 --> 00:05:53.800
something's happening with your server.

91
00:05:53.800 --> 00:05:55.970
You think, I need to call HP,
I need to call Dell,

92
00:05:55.970 --> 00:05:57.770
whoever your server vendor may be.

93
00:05:57.770 --> 00:06:01.140
And you say, I'm trying to have this
little issue here, can you help me?

94
00:06:01.140 --> 00:06:04.779
And they say, we'll have you
upgraded to firmware version 8.9?

95
00:06:04.779 --> 00:06:06.820
And you're like, well,
no, we're still on 8.7.

96
00:06:06.820 --> 00:06:10.750
Call us after you've upgraded to version
8.9, otherwise, we don't support you.

97
00:06:10.750 --> 00:06:13.280
And so it's like a catch-22.

98
00:06:13.280 --> 00:06:18.140
Now do I upgrade my firmware and take
the chances of really hosing a system and

99
00:06:18.140 --> 00:06:18.855
lose the support?

100
00:06:18.855 --> 00:06:20.605
And it's a really hard thing to work with.

101
00:06:20.605 --> 00:06:25.807
>> Right, it is, and again,
that's part of our jobs as auditors,

102
00:06:25.807 --> 00:06:30.633
is to go in and find out how
effectively the IT organization is

103
00:06:30.633 --> 00:06:33.868
managing these kinds of difficulties.

104
00:06:33.868 --> 00:06:38.267
So, again, going back to having some
kind of a test environment, for

105
00:06:38.267 --> 00:06:43.115
instance, if you got, I'll just make
something up, a Dell 36x server and

106
00:06:43.115 --> 00:06:46.471
you're being told you need
to upgrade the firmware,

107
00:06:46.471 --> 00:06:51.321
then you should have another 36x server
identical to it in configuration to

108
00:06:51.321 --> 00:06:56.430
test the firmware upgrade on first to make
sure that it's not gonna blow things.

109
00:06:56.430 --> 00:06:59.724
And, in particular, not just the firmware,
but all the applications and

110
00:06:59.724 --> 00:07:02.613
the server software that runs
on that particular machine, etc.

111
00:07:02.613 --> 00:07:06.232
Because, again, the firmware's
the very foundation of the system and

112
00:07:06.232 --> 00:07:09.310
it can affect everything going
clear up the stack later on.

113
00:07:09.310 --> 00:07:13.500
So you wanna make sure that you do
thorough testing on those kinds of things.

114
00:07:13.500 --> 00:07:19.420
Check it out with vendors, and then
also be able to do back out procedures.

115
00:07:19.420 --> 00:07:22.649
What happens if the upgrade goes okay, but

116
00:07:22.649 --> 00:07:26.782
it does cause more problems
with your software, etc?

117
00:07:26.782 --> 00:07:33.318
You wanna be able to rev that firmware
back down so that you still have a machine

118
00:07:33.318 --> 00:07:38.662
that's in equivalent shape of
the one that's in production.

119
00:07:38.662 --> 00:07:42.682
So my next point is just that,
is you need a test environment because you

120
00:07:42.682 --> 00:07:46.841
should never, ever, ever test things
out in a production environment.

121
00:07:46.841 --> 00:07:52.007
That is a recipe for
guaranteed job loss and disaster, okay?

122
00:07:52.007 --> 00:07:55.246
When things can go wrong,
they will absolutely.

123
00:07:55.246 --> 00:07:58.051
You don't do updates on a Friday
afternoon, do you, Daniel?

124
00:07:58.051 --> 00:07:58.965
>> No, you do not.

125
00:07:58.965 --> 00:07:59.771
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

126
00:07:59.771 --> 00:08:00.995
>> Unless you like to work weekends.

127
00:08:00.995 --> 00:08:02.085
[LAUGH]
>> Even then,

128
00:08:02.085 --> 00:08:03.798
you want to make sure you get
hold of support if you need them.

129
00:08:03.798 --> 00:08:04.600
>> That's right.

130
00:08:04.600 --> 00:08:06.870
>> They might not be
available on weekends.

131
00:08:06.870 --> 00:08:10.990
You need to make sure, for instance,
that you have support contracts in place.

132
00:08:10.990 --> 00:08:15.140
That's another problem is you go to do
a firmware upgrade on a very important key

133
00:08:15.140 --> 00:08:18.040
server, then you find out there's
a problem and you pick up the phone and

134
00:08:18.040 --> 00:08:23.520
you realize, uh-oh, purchasing forgot
to cut that check to the company for

135
00:08:23.520 --> 00:08:30.161
your support, or your Cisco Smartnet
contract is gone out of contract and

136
00:08:30.161 --> 00:08:36.330
you now no longer have support,
you can't get updated software, etc, etc.

137
00:08:36.330 --> 00:08:40.610
So, all of these things go into
managing the IT environment, and

138
00:08:40.610 --> 00:08:45.030
when you go in as an auditor, you have to
be looking at all aspects of this stuff.

139
00:08:46.770 --> 00:08:52.180
And it all starts to come up when you're
looking at how they handle upgrades,

140
00:08:52.180 --> 00:08:55.430
how they do maintenance,
how they keep these systems running and

141
00:08:55.430 --> 00:09:00.740
in tip top shape so that they perform
to the best of their ability,

142
00:09:00.740 --> 00:09:06.300
based on the money that you've spend and
the resources you've allocated to that.

143
00:09:06.300 --> 00:09:10.100
So the next thing, let's just assume
you've got somewhat of a test

144
00:09:10.100 --> 00:09:13.840
environment even if it's just a room
with a couple of servers in it,

145
00:09:13.840 --> 00:09:18.120
you wanna check with your application
vendors before you do upgrades as well.

146
00:09:18.120 --> 00:09:22.110
Let's move from the server hardware arena

147
00:09:22.110 --> 00:09:27.250
to the operating system stuff now,
and let's talk about Microsoft.

148
00:09:27.250 --> 00:09:30.730
Because Microsoft, while it's not
the only operating system in the world,

149
00:09:30.730 --> 00:09:34.980
we know that the vast majority of
what you deal with is going to be

150
00:09:34.980 --> 00:09:36.610
the Microsoft environment.

151
00:09:36.610 --> 00:09:41.117
Typically, what you're going to run
into is Lynx, Unix and/or mainframes, or

152
00:09:41.117 --> 00:09:46.470
AS/400s, and Windows, the vast majority
is gonna be Windows stuff, though.

153
00:09:46.470 --> 00:09:49.350
You wanna check with Microsoft.

154
00:09:49.350 --> 00:09:54.930
Find out what kind of
interaction those upgrades and

155
00:09:54.930 --> 00:09:56.980
patches might have on other systems.

156
00:09:56.980 --> 00:10:01.310
It's very typical for
an enterprise environment to have

157
00:10:01.310 --> 00:10:06.510
not only active directory servers,
but exchange servers and SQL servers.

158
00:10:06.510 --> 00:10:10.080
They all could be running on different
platforms with different patch levels.

159
00:10:10.080 --> 00:10:14.710
Based on the needs, certain patches might
break things in SQL that doesn't break

160
00:10:14.710 --> 00:10:18.840
in Exchange, etc, you need to work
very closely with your vendors, again,

161
00:10:18.840 --> 00:10:21.940
making sure that you have
support contracts in place so

162
00:10:21.940 --> 00:10:24.810
that when you do get in a pinch,
as an auditor,

163
00:10:24.810 --> 00:10:28.250
you're not going to be doing the patching
and you you wont have to deal with this,

164
00:10:28.250 --> 00:10:31.400
but you wanna make sure that the
organization has all that stuff in place,

165
00:10:31.400 --> 00:10:36.210
and that the processes for
maintaining that are operating smoothly.

166
00:10:36.210 --> 00:10:39.550
I remember working in a health care
organization a couple years ago and

167
00:10:39.550 --> 00:10:42.840
I had just come on site
to begin my audit work.

168
00:10:42.840 --> 00:10:46.960
I was gathering documentation and
getting names of people, etc.,

169
00:10:46.960 --> 00:10:49.230
and all of a sudden,

170
00:10:49.230 --> 00:10:54.010
the entire hospital, almost 16,000
employees lost Internet connectivity.

171
00:10:54.010 --> 00:10:57.450
Boonk, just offline, the whole network.

172
00:10:57.450 --> 00:10:59.380
That's kind of a major outage.

173
00:10:59.380 --> 00:11:04.600
Come to find out later that what happened
was the purchasing department had failed

174
00:11:04.600 --> 00:11:11.050
to cut a check to the firewall vendor,
who had a web filtering blade installed

175
00:11:11.050 --> 00:11:16.525
in the checkpoint firewall, and when that
license expired, all web traffic stopped.

176
00:11:16.525 --> 00:11:17.710
>> [LAUGH] That will do it.

177
00:11:17.710 --> 00:11:18.940
>> Yeah, yeah.

178
00:11:18.940 --> 00:11:21.570
The CEO was not a happy camper that day.

179
00:11:21.570 --> 00:11:23.280
>> No, heads rolled, I'm sure.

180
00:11:23.280 --> 00:11:25.840
>> Yeah, and so
the fingers start pointing, etc.

181
00:11:25.840 --> 00:11:27.550
But, that was one of my audit findings,

182
00:11:27.550 --> 00:11:30.800
was that purchasing was not
staying on top of it, and

183
00:11:30.800 --> 00:11:35.770
it was partly the IT department's problem,
because they'd submitted the request late.

184
00:11:37.010 --> 00:11:41.680
Imagine that, because they were
understaffed, they were dealing with lots

185
00:11:41.680 --> 00:11:47.320
of other issues, and so, you get into the
blame game or you do root cause analysis.

186
00:11:47.320 --> 00:11:52.070
You've heard me talk about that before,
and go back to guess what?

187
00:11:52.070 --> 00:11:54.750
I mentioned in the last episode,
change management.

188
00:11:54.750 --> 00:11:57.200
This all goes back to change management,

189
00:11:57.200 --> 00:11:59.720
where change management
wasn't handled effectively.

190
00:11:59.720 --> 00:12:02.410
Those documents should have
been turned in ahead of time.

191
00:12:02.410 --> 00:12:05.700
A manager should have probably
been in the middle of all that.

192
00:12:05.700 --> 00:12:10.680
And it all boiled down to the root
cause really was IT didn't

193
00:12:10.680 --> 00:12:14.380
have the resources to do what they
needed to do, they need more staffing.

194
00:12:14.380 --> 00:12:16.980
Now, the upper levels
don't wanna hear that,

195
00:12:16.980 --> 00:12:20.330
they wanna hear that somebody, somebody-
>> Messed up.

196
00:12:20.330 --> 00:12:21.480
>> Forgot to do something, yeah.

197
00:12:21.480 --> 00:12:24.130
And the reality was they're just too busy,
and they didn't get it done.

198
00:12:24.130 --> 00:12:26.750
And the reason they're too busy,
they don't have enough staff.

199
00:12:26.750 --> 00:12:31.630
So, recalls analysis is a great tool to
get familiar with in terms of looking

200
00:12:31.630 --> 00:12:35.990
beyond what seems to be the additional
answer to the problem which was,

201
00:12:35.990 --> 00:12:39.610
well, Billy Bob forgot to
submit that in a timely manner.

202
00:12:39.610 --> 00:12:41.070
Well, that's because Billy Bob was really,
really,

203
00:12:41.070 --> 00:12:44.350
really busy, doing things that
his boss was telling him to do.

204
00:12:44.350 --> 00:12:47.610
He can only be so many places at a time.

205
00:12:47.610 --> 00:12:51.530
>> Is discovering these types of root
causes, is that really one of the end

206
00:12:51.530 --> 00:12:56.440
games of being an auditor, is trying
to discover places where you're really

207
00:12:56.440 --> 00:12:59.740
set up for failure in this point and
yeah it happened on this one but,

208
00:12:59.740 --> 00:13:03.100
as we go in and audit, we're looking for
those things so that they don't happen?

209
00:13:04.840 --> 00:13:06.420
>> I think that's a sign
of a good auditor.

210
00:13:06.420 --> 00:13:07.400
>> Okay.
[LAUGH]

211
00:13:07.400 --> 00:13:08.820
>> There's a differentiator

212
00:13:08.820 --> 00:13:09.450
there, I really do.

213
00:13:10.560 --> 00:13:11.920
An auditor might go in and say, well,

214
00:13:11.920 --> 00:13:17.540
the finding was that the IT department
didn't submit their paperwork on time.

215
00:13:17.540 --> 00:13:19.240
That is true.
There is nothing wrong with that,

216
00:13:19.240 --> 00:13:20.330
that is a finding.

217
00:13:20.330 --> 00:13:22.360
But is it a root cause of the problem?

218
00:13:22.360 --> 00:13:23.970
Probably not.

219
00:13:23.970 --> 00:13:29.290
You mentioned earlier that you used to
do WSUS management in the network and

220
00:13:29.290 --> 00:13:34.820
I haven't asked you this question yet,
but are you aware that WSUS has a flaw?

221
00:13:34.820 --> 00:13:36.995
>> I know it has a lot of flaws,
cuz it was a horrible system.

222
00:13:36.995 --> 00:13:38.200
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah it has a lot flaws.

223
00:13:38.200 --> 00:13:40.720
So here's a great war story about that.

224
00:13:40.720 --> 00:13:43.420
I learned this a long time
at about going in and

225
00:13:43.420 --> 00:13:49.530
I would watch other auditors say this.

226
00:13:49.530 --> 00:13:53.250
They say, well, show me your WSUS log so
that you can prove that

227
00:13:53.250 --> 00:13:57.230
you've applied all the pertinent patches
to your systems, per your policy.

228
00:13:57.230 --> 00:14:00.770
Ok cool, and they'll show you in
the logs and screen shots and all that.

229
00:14:00.770 --> 00:14:04.170
Then I would go and run the Microsoft
Baseline Security analyzer against

230
00:14:04.170 --> 00:14:07.360
the system and I'd find that
there was six patches missing.

231
00:14:07.360 --> 00:14:12.280
I'd go, why it is that WSUS says that
the box is fully patched then my

232
00:14:12.280 --> 00:14:17.270
Microsoft baseline security analyzer says
you're missing six, what's the problem?

233
00:14:17.270 --> 00:14:18.072
>> Where's the disconnect?

234
00:14:18.072 --> 00:14:18.860
>> Yeah, exactly.

235
00:14:18.860 --> 00:14:23.500
Well the disconnect is that WSUS is,
it makes mistakes.

236
00:14:23.500 --> 00:14:24.460
>> It's not infallible.

237
00:14:24.460 --> 00:14:28.980
>> That's right, it's not infallible and
[LAUGH] it says darn Billy Bob left

238
00:14:28.980 --> 00:14:32.617
that in the car, thank you for
that Guido, sorry.

239
00:14:32.617 --> 00:14:37.130
[LAUGH]
Yeah,

240
00:14:37.130 --> 00:14:40.160
that's another example of not
doing good root cause analysis.

241
00:14:40.160 --> 00:14:44.060
You might think that the WSUS server
is doing what it says it's doing

242
00:14:44.060 --> 00:14:46.520
because it said that it's doing it,
but you know what, I don't trust it.

243
00:14:46.520 --> 00:14:47.740
>> Trust but verify, right?

244
00:14:47.740 --> 00:14:49.460
>> Exactly, exactly.

245
00:14:49.460 --> 00:14:49.960
>> That's our motto.
[LAUGH]

246
00:14:49.960 --> 00:14:52.370
>> That should be your mantra, trust but

247
00:14:52.370 --> 00:14:53.610
verify.

248
00:14:53.610 --> 00:14:57.791
I always teach less experienced auditors,

249
00:14:57.791 --> 00:15:03.910
my favorite term is prove it,
and I will challenge your proof.

250
00:15:03.910 --> 00:15:04.666
>> Are you from Missouri?

251
00:15:04.666 --> 00:15:05.849
Yeah.
>> Show me.

252
00:15:05.849 --> 00:15:08.290
[LAUGHS]
>> That's what I do with the MBSA,

253
00:15:08.290 --> 00:15:11.490

232
00:14:54.840 --> 00:15:01.070
So that query process, there may
be 1,000 tables involved in this.

233
00:15:01.070 --> 00:15:07.570
And the query process goes through
a yes no sort of a boolean

234
00:15:07.570 --> 00:15:12.940
logic in trying to find what you're asking
for and it goes until it hits a yes.

235
00:15:12.940 --> 00:15:16.400
It goes no, no, no, no, no,
yes and it finds the data.

236
00:15:16.400 --> 00:15:22.360
The way it goes through that chain of noes
can be impacted by moving tables around,

237
00:15:22.360 --> 00:15:25.550
rearranging the connections, etc.

238
00:15:25.550 --> 00:15:28.693
So if you've got slow
database performance,

239
00:15:28.693 --> 00:15:33.698
it's not always because your hardware's
wearing out or not producing.

240
00:15:33.698 --> 00:15:38.318
It's not always because your Internet
connected speed is not fast enough.

241
00:15:38.318 --> 00:15:43.774
It oftentimes is because your
database tables are not optimized for

242
00:15:43.774 --> 00:15:46.280
optimal search performance.

243
00:15:46.280 --> 00:15:50.120
>> And they can do things like, if I'm
not mistaken, in SQL they do indexing.

244
00:15:50.120 --> 00:15:50.620
>> Correct.

245
00:15:50.620 --> 00:15:54.590
>> And
this helps speed up the querying process.

246
00:15:54.590 --> 00:15:56.138
>> We even do that in Windows.

247
00:15:56.138 --> 00:15:56.872
In Windows or

248
00:15:56.872 --> 00:16:01.287
on the Mac platform there's a process on
the Mac where I can tell it to reindex.

249
00:16:01.287 --> 00:16:04.748
What's called Spotlight, which is
the search engine in Microsoft Outlook.

250
00:16:04.748 --> 00:16:08.144
You can actually tell it to go back
there and it'll re-index all of your

251
00:16:08.144 --> 00:16:11.780
e-mail stuff so that you can do
searches and it'll find things faster.

252
00:16:11.780 --> 00:16:12.740
>> Incredibly faster.

253
00:16:12.740 --> 00:16:15.227
I've done the re indexing myself,
and it's like, [SOUND] [SOUND].

254
00:16:15.227 --> 00:16:16.650
Things speed up really quickly.

255
00:16:16.650 --> 00:16:17.150
>> Yes.

256
00:16:17.150 --> 00:16:18.370
Yes, it does.

257
00:16:18.370 --> 00:16:24.390
So, that has to do with database design
and some of the features of databases.

258
00:16:24.390 --> 00:16:26.590
Now, I want to talk a little bit,
while we still have some time left,

259
00:16:26.590 --> 00:16:29.510
about different database roles.

260
00:16:29.510 --> 00:16:33.490
And, I don't mean the kind that you
go get at the grocery store but

261
00:16:33.490 --> 00:16:38.570
the roles of database,
people who touch databases, okay?

262
00:16:38.570 --> 00:16:40.070
The first one is the data owner.

263
00:16:41.080 --> 00:16:43.560
These are terms that you'll need to know,
wink, wink, wink.

264
00:16:43.560 --> 00:16:47.889
There's very specific
definitions in the book.

265
00:16:48.990 --> 00:16:55.000
The data owner is, for instance, if the
Daniel were my exchange administrator and

266
00:16:55.000 --> 00:16:59.990
I had an exchange account with
email in there, that data's mine.

267
00:16:59.990 --> 00:17:01.750
I own that data, okay?

268
00:17:01.750 --> 00:17:06.170
And, I'm the one who should be
able to say, to some degree,

269
00:17:06.170 --> 00:17:08.510
when I want to archive it or
back it up or move it.

270
00:17:08.510 --> 00:17:10.320
I can move it from folder to folder.

271
00:17:10.320 --> 00:17:12.760
I can change the table layout
because I'm the data owner.

272
00:17:13.940 --> 00:17:20.590
The data custodian is the person who is
in charge of ensuring that the data is

273
00:17:20.590 --> 00:17:26.310
not only available for use, but available
for recovery should something happen.

274
00:17:26.310 --> 00:17:31.180
So, a data custodian not just is in
charge of backups and backup media,

275
00:17:31.180 --> 00:17:35.740
etcetera, but ensuring that the database
remains in good enough shape that

276
00:17:35.740 --> 00:17:41.180
I can continue to access the information
when I want, how I want, etcetera.

277
00:17:41.180 --> 00:17:43.230
Then there's the database administrator.

278
00:17:43.230 --> 00:17:46.380
The database administrator, for
instance, might be an exchange.

279
00:17:46.380 --> 00:17:50.440
Again, we'll go back because exchange and
email really is simply a database.

280
00:17:50.440 --> 00:17:52.790
Not much different than active directory.

281
00:17:52.790 --> 00:17:58.160
An exchange administrator, for instance,
or a database and SQL administrator might

282
00:17:58.160 --> 00:18:03.330
be involved with re-optimizing the tables
that like we just talked about,

283
00:18:03.330 --> 00:18:05.520
that would be a database
administrator's function.

284
00:18:06.670 --> 00:18:12.160
Any new tables that might be created,
the database administrator would create.

285
00:18:12.160 --> 00:18:17.360
If we decided to delete tables or
change tables inside a database,

286
00:18:17.360 --> 00:18:20.480
the database administrator
would typically be doing that.

287
00:18:20.480 --> 00:18:23.360
And, this goes back to
the concept I introduced in

288
00:18:23.360 --> 00:18:27.630
a number of sessions earlier
about separation of duties.

289
00:18:27.630 --> 00:18:30.770
You don't want the data owner
doing the data administration, and

290
00:18:30.770 --> 00:18:34.390
you don't want the data administrator
doing the data custodian work.

291
00:18:34.390 --> 00:18:36.980
You want those functions separated so

292
00:18:36.980 --> 00:18:41.900
that there's, you don't have
someone who's the data owner

293
00:18:41.900 --> 00:18:45.850
doing something with data administrative
capabilities, that might not be kosher.

294
00:18:45.850 --> 00:18:48.800
They might be doing things
that they shouldn't be doing.

295
00:18:48.800 --> 00:18:51.240
So, those should be in large
organizations broken out.

296
00:18:51.240 --> 00:18:56.050
Now, in the real world just like I've
talked about many times in this series

297
00:18:56.050 --> 00:18:57.950
ISOC is an international organization.

298
00:18:57.950 --> 00:19:02.710
They have a tendency to talk about
things at a very high level with big,

299
00:19:02.710 --> 00:19:04.910
large, or enterprises.

300
00:19:04.910 --> 00:19:08.410
In most medium to small size companies,

301
00:19:08.410 --> 00:19:10.920
the same person wears
all three of these hats.

302
00:19:10.920 --> 00:19:13.640
Okay, and
you can't really separate the duties.

303
00:19:13.640 --> 00:19:17.980
You just have to be able to provide
better oversight and do the best you can.

304
00:19:17.980 --> 00:19:21.932
You can't really punish anyone for
doing the best that they can.

305
00:19:21.932 --> 00:19:23.515
>> Well, you can, its just not fair.

306
00:19:23.515 --> 00:19:24.487
[LAUGH]
>> And then,

307
00:19:24.487 --> 00:19:29.136
one more thing I wanted to talk about was
how this all ties back to, again change

308
00:19:29.136 --> 00:19:33.797
management, I know you're getting tired
of hearing it, but it really does.

309
00:19:33.797 --> 00:19:39.223
It all ties back to team change management
where the data custodian is called

310
00:19:39.223 --> 00:19:44.930
upon to do a data restore, because
something's happened to a database table.

311
00:19:44.930 --> 00:19:48.120
It's become corrupt, or
maybe the entire database is corrupted.

312
00:19:48.120 --> 00:19:52.290
All that stuff needs to go through
a change management process.

313
00:19:52.290 --> 00:19:56.890
It's very important that you
stick to those processes.

314
00:19:56.890 --> 00:19:58.830
Then the last thing in wrapping up for

315
00:19:58.830 --> 00:20:02.240
this session we'll talk about
is the data life cycle.

316
00:20:02.240 --> 00:20:05.390
Now, this is a little different
than the STLC we've talked about,

317
00:20:05.390 --> 00:20:10.160
which was Systems Developement Life Cycle
or Software Developement Life Cycle.

318
00:20:10.160 --> 00:20:12.290
Now, we're talking about
the data life cycle.

319
00:20:12.290 --> 00:20:17.300
And, what we're talking about is,
my wife is a physician and

320
00:20:17.300 --> 00:20:21.760
she calls it cradle to grave,
which is actually a great analogy to this.

321
00:20:21.760 --> 00:20:24.910
She's a family physician so
she delivers babies,

322
00:20:24.910 --> 00:20:29.550
she takes care of terminally ill patients
sometimes, and everything in between.

323
00:20:29.550 --> 00:20:33.190
So, what we're talking about
in terms of data life cycle is

324
00:20:33.190 --> 00:20:37.170
everything from the creation of
the actual data, the database, and

325
00:20:37.170 --> 00:20:39.900
the actual input into the database.

326
00:20:39.900 --> 00:20:44.910
To management of the database, the day
to day operations of administration,

327
00:20:44.910 --> 00:20:49.670
making backups, the care and
feeding of that database, if you will,

328
00:20:49.670 --> 00:20:52.450
over whatever its lifespan is.

329
00:20:52.450 --> 00:20:53.260
And then,

330
00:20:53.260 --> 00:20:58.160
that goes into, how do we handle the aging
of those records or that information?

331
00:20:58.160 --> 00:21:02.850
Do we move it off to slower,
less costly storage?

332
00:21:02.850 --> 00:21:06.910
What's the plan for it at it's,
what we would call, end of life.

333
00:21:06.910 --> 00:21:11.330
Okay, which takes us
from aging to retention.

334
00:21:11.330 --> 00:21:16.230
What's your company's retention or
what's their retention policy for data?

335
00:21:16.230 --> 00:21:21.000
And this is the one that really,
the last two are really I think more

336
00:21:21.000 --> 00:21:24.630
important than most people like to talk
about and that is what is your retention?

337
00:21:24.630 --> 00:21:26.500
How long are you keeping data?

338
00:21:26.500 --> 00:21:27.690
And then, most critically,

339
00:21:27.690 --> 00:21:31.040
what happens when it reaches
the end of that life cycle?

340
00:21:31.040 --> 00:21:32.620
How do you destroy the data?

341
00:21:32.620 --> 00:21:36.410
What's your destruction policy,
processes, and procedure?

342
00:21:36.410 --> 00:21:37.800
Here's a great example.

343
00:21:37.800 --> 00:21:40.270
I will go into an organization and

344
00:21:40.270 --> 00:21:44.790
one of the first things I
will do is a data discovery.

345
00:21:44.790 --> 00:21:48.960
I'll actually run some utilities, scan
the network, looking for spreadsheets,

346
00:21:48.960 --> 00:21:51.640
word documents with credit
card numbers in them,

347
00:21:51.640 --> 00:21:55.280
social security numbers, etcetera that
people have accumulated over the years.

348
00:21:55.280 --> 00:21:56.400
They've forgotten about it.

349
00:21:56.400 --> 00:21:57.630
They put it in their email.

350
00:21:57.630 --> 00:22:01.180
They sent it to their brothers
who works in another department.

351
00:22:01.180 --> 00:22:04.220
The next thing you know, you've got
personally identifiable information

352
00:22:04.220 --> 00:22:07.369
all over the network, causing all
kinds of risk to the organization.

353
00:22:08.850 --> 00:22:13.770
So, we want to identify and
locate that information and destroy it.

354
00:22:13.770 --> 00:22:17.480
Make sure that it's properly and
adequately destroyed based on retention

355
00:22:17.480 --> 00:22:23.240
policies, and
based on sound security practices.

356
00:22:23.240 --> 00:22:27.450
That's harder than it may seem, and
the reason most people leave it alone or

357
00:22:27.450 --> 00:22:29.210
most companies leave it alone,
forget about it is.

358
00:22:29.210 --> 00:22:31.660
Well, it's just easier to leave it.

359
00:22:31.660 --> 00:22:33.130
We might need it some day.

360
00:22:33.130 --> 00:22:35.930
I can't tell you how many times I
hear that from companies that say,

361
00:22:35.930 --> 00:22:39.530
well we still have that database and
we just turn the machine off but

362
00:22:39.530 --> 00:22:41.260
we're afraid we might need it sometime.

363
00:22:41.260 --> 00:22:43.520
Well how long you've been holding it?

364
00:22:43.520 --> 00:22:45.610
Since '96 or '97.

365
00:22:45.610 --> 00:22:49.391
[LAUGH] Yeah,
well you are probably not going to use it.

366
00:22:49.391 --> 00:22:53.759
It's kind of like those jeans or
that t shirt that you really,

367
00:22:53.759 --> 00:22:57.290
really love that is just
shredded beyond belief.

368
00:22:57.290 --> 00:22:59.220
Or, when you put it on,
people look at you and go,

369
00:22:59.220 --> 00:23:03.060
"That stinks."
>> I say old databases are like taxes,

370
00:23:03.060 --> 00:23:04.760
after seven years, ditch them.

371
00:23:04.760 --> 00:23:05.280
>> That's right.

372
00:23:05.280 --> 00:23:06.450
That's right, ditch them.

373
00:23:06.450 --> 00:23:11.940
So, again, we've got creation, management,
aging, retention and destruction.

374
00:23:11.940 --> 00:23:14.670
In terms of the stages
of that data life cycle.

375
00:23:14.670 --> 00:23:18.600
And, it's extremely important that
the data be destroyed when it's

376
00:23:18.600 --> 00:23:19.730
no longer needed.

377
00:23:19.730 --> 00:23:24.840
And, done so properly though data
scrubbing, whether that be put

378
00:23:24.840 --> 00:23:29.630
on to hard drives, that mans you have
to find all the backups, everything.

379
00:23:29.630 --> 00:23:32.978
And, that sometimes is a tougher
job than you might think.

380
00:23:32.978 --> 00:23:36.896
Doing proper inventory of your media
helps with that, your backups, etcetera,

381
00:23:36.896 --> 00:23:38.060
etcetera.

382
00:23:38.060 --> 00:23:41.930
>> You know it's funny, you were talking
about really the human factor that comes

383
00:23:41.930 --> 00:23:45.720
in where we say it's just easier to do
this, or it's just easier to do that.

384
00:23:45.720 --> 00:23:48.130
It's not easier to go
through a security audit and

385
00:23:48.130 --> 00:23:51.750
get hammered because you're doing things
that are putting your company at risk.

386
00:23:51.750 --> 00:23:55.510
I remember having a user, and she had
access to a database that she was backing

387
00:23:55.510 --> 00:23:58.520
up to a flash drive and
taking home with her every night.

388
00:23:58.520 --> 00:23:59.750
And, you know how I found this out?

389
00:23:59.750 --> 00:24:01.320
Because her computer,

390
00:24:01.320 --> 00:24:04.740
her workstation at her desk kept
getting infected with malware.

391
00:24:04.740 --> 00:24:08.520
And, I'm running antivirus scans
on this thing on a daily basis.

392
00:24:08.520 --> 00:24:11.680
How are you continuing, what websites
are you going to, I'm looking at logs, and

393
00:24:11.680 --> 00:24:12.950
what she's doing.

394
00:24:12.950 --> 00:24:15.480
What I didn't know was
that little thumb drive,

395
00:24:15.480 --> 00:24:18.640
that she was taking home,
that she plugged into her home computer,

396
00:24:18.640 --> 00:24:20.620
was getting infected and
then bringing it home.

397
00:24:20.620 --> 00:24:22.520
I said, you can't do that.

398
00:24:22.520 --> 00:24:25.550
She goes, well I have this database on
there I need to be able to work with it.

399
00:24:25.550 --> 00:24:29.230
I go, we can set you up with a VPN
connection, everything's encrypted and

400
00:24:29.230 --> 00:24:30.090
secure.

401
00:24:30.090 --> 00:24:32.760
You don't have to worry about
bringing this thing back and forth.

402
00:24:32.760 --> 00:24:34.940
What if you get hit by
a bus on the way to work?

403
00:24:34.940 --> 00:24:36.340
>> Right.
>> And this is database is now gone.

404
00:24:36.340 --> 00:24:37.860
All the changes that you've made.

405
00:24:37.860 --> 00:24:41.390
All these sensitive information is
on the street, literally right?

406
00:24:41.390 --> 00:24:43.690
Because you were taking
a flash drive back and forth.

407
00:24:43.690 --> 00:24:49.040
She argued with me about that, and I said,
you cannot do, this is why we do back ups.

408
00:24:49.040 --> 00:24:51.280
We don't have to worry about that,
everything's encrypted.

409
00:24:51.280 --> 00:24:55.180
It's more safe to do it this
way than it is your easy way.

410
00:24:55.180 --> 00:24:58.980
I know it is harder for us to do it this
way, but Is the more secure way to do it.

411
00:24:58.980 --> 00:25:02.160
And, we've got to look at those types of
things and people just don't realize it.

412
00:25:02.160 --> 00:25:03.190
>> Right.

413
00:25:03.190 --> 00:25:07.210
>> Well, Brian you have definitely given
us a lot to chew on when it comes to

414
00:25:07.210 --> 00:25:11.600
thinking about how we need to manage
our databases and prepare for auditing.

415
00:25:11.600 --> 00:25:13.270
What we need to think about.

416
00:25:13.270 --> 00:25:18.580
How should we engage, working with
a database inside of our environment?

417
00:25:18.580 --> 00:25:20.510
How do we keep those things secure?

418
00:25:20.510 --> 00:25:22.950
And, how do we keep the data out
of the hands of the bad guys?

419
00:25:22.950 --> 00:25:23.970
That's always a good one.

420
00:25:23.970 --> 00:25:26.990
That's one thing we want to work on very,
very highly.

421
00:25:26.990 --> 00:25:28.780
That being said,
we thank you for dropping by.

422
00:25:28.780 --> 00:25:30.960
We thank our good folks out there for
watching.

423
00:25:30.960 --> 00:25:34.390
And remember, yet again, I like to plug
the book, at least twice because this is

424
00:25:34.390 --> 00:25:37.230
a good book and you're going to need
it if you're trying to pass this exam.

425
00:25:37.230 --> 00:25:42.050
It is a bit of a bear, so make sure you
grab one of these copies right here.

426
00:25:42.050 --> 00:25:44.360
CISA and grab it on Amazon or
something like that.

427
00:25:44.360 --> 00:25:48.460
This is the fourth edition it just
hit the shelves, so check that out.

428
00:25:48.460 --> 00:25:50.530
That being said, we thank you guys for
watching yet again.

429
00:25:50.530 --> 00:25:52.300
We're going to go ahead and sign off.

430
00:25:52.300 --> 00:25:56.370
For ITPro TV I've been
your host Daniel Lowrie.

431
00:25:56.370 --> 00:25:59.710
>> And I'm Brian O'Hara.

432
00:25:59.710 --> 00:26:03.180
>> And we'll see you next time.

433
00:26:03.180 --> 00:26:05.700

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Brian talk about incident management which is basically how to properly handle an incident. They explain how you can use your change management process as incident prevention. They look at how incidents should be reported. Also, they discuss Disaster Recovery and Business Continuity Drills and "What if?" scenarios.

1

to another great episode of ITProTV.

>> Hi Daniel, it's going well, thank you.

11

In this episode, today, this is
the concluding episode for domain four:

12
00:00:44.560 --> 00:00:50.060
IT operations, management,
et cetera for the CISA exam.

13
00:00:50.060 --> 00:00:53.390
In this episode we are going to talk
a little bit about the auditor's

14
00:00:53.390 --> 00:00:58.470
responsibility for evaluating problem and
incident management.

15
00:00:58.470 --> 00:01:02.110
To see if those problems are being
handled in an appropriate manner.

16
00:01:03.840 --> 00:01:08.600
In any size organization incidents are
going to occur, and when I say 'incident,'

17
00:01:08.600 --> 00:01:13.400
I don't necessarily mean catastrophic
incidents or criminal incidents.

18
00:01:13.400 --> 00:01:15.160
I just mean, things happen.

19
00:01:15.160 --> 00:01:17.910
I think there's another term
that people sometimes use.

20
00:01:17.910 --> 00:01:20.127
>> I call it 'Life.'
>> That's a little different than that,

21
00:01:20.127 --> 00:01:21.150
but that happens.

22
00:01:21.150 --> 00:01:22.770
But things happen in an organization.

00:09:32.400 --> 00:09:37.440

00:13:06.918 --> 00:13:12.680

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Brian begin their discussion of protecting IS assets. They begin with looking at the concept of the CIA triad (Confidentiality, Integrity, and Availability). They also go over privacy laws and regulations in the US and other countries. Finally, they talk about physical security measures which include things like wet/dry pipe fire suppression, HVAC, Fences, and locks with alerting systems for all.
