will wear out or

303
00:19:07.900 --> 00:19:10.675
damage power supplies over
long periods of time.

304
00:19:10.675 --> 00:19:15.270
Let's talk about physical
controls around the building, for

305
00:19:15.270 --> 00:19:17.870
instance fences, bollards.

306
00:19:17.870 --> 00:19:19.160
I don't know if you know bollards are.

307
00:19:19.160 --> 00:19:22.040
Bollards are those great big,
gigantic round things that stick up outta

308
00:19:22.040 --> 00:19:24.650
the concrete that protect
federal buildings.

309
00:19:24.650 --> 00:19:27.810
That can take the weight of
a semi truck hitting them and

310
00:19:27.810 --> 00:19:29.370
they won't move, believe me.

311
00:19:29.370 --> 00:19:31.850
You do not wanna tie into one of those.

312
00:19:31.850 --> 00:19:35.560
In Washington DC they actually have
mechanical bollards that will come up out

313
00:19:35.560 --> 00:19:39.180
of the ground in event of an emergency
that completely surround the White House

314
00:19:39.180 --> 00:19:40.880
and places like that, so then-
>> Yeah,

315
00:19:40.880 --> 00:19:42.700
I think the Pentagon has them as well,
if I'm not mistaken.

316
00:19:42.700 --> 00:19:45.690
>> They're everywhere today, yeah.

317
00:19:45.690 --> 00:19:47.660
So, those kind of things.

318
00:19:47.660 --> 00:19:52.040
But in most locations, like hospitals,
banks, etc., I look for

319
00:19:52.040 --> 00:19:57.050
things like adequate lighting,
are window's

320
00:19:57.050 --> 00:20:01.800
in a position where, used to do this all
the time when I would do bank audits,

321
00:20:01.800 --> 00:20:03.540
when I'd do a physical sweep.

322
00:20:03.540 --> 00:20:07.970
Walk up and pull my, my phone out and
take a picture through the window

323
00:20:07.970 --> 00:20:10.740
of documents sitting on
a vice president's desk.

324
00:20:10.740 --> 00:20:14.120
And then go in the next day and show
them at the exit interview and say look,

325
00:20:14.120 --> 00:20:16.250
you really need to do
something about this.

326
00:20:16.250 --> 00:20:20.850
Either don't leave your documents out or
put blinds on the windows and close them.

327
00:20:20.850 --> 00:20:23.300
Because a bad guy could do exactly that.

328
00:20:23.300 --> 00:20:25.420
Come in and take a picture of signatures.

329
00:20:25.420 --> 00:20:29.930
I found everything from home mortgages
to loans to cash laying out on tables,

330
00:20:29.930 --> 00:20:31.810
all kinds of things like that.

331
00:20:31.810 --> 00:20:38.810
So you want to take a look at the physical
environment, how are locks handled?

332
00:20:38.810 --> 00:20:41.680
There's a section in the book
that talks about locks.

333
00:20:41.680 --> 00:20:44.960
And you can do some search on Google,

334
00:20:44.960 --> 00:20:49.740
if you want, about the different kinds
of locks, dead bolts verses pin locks.

335
00:20:49.740 --> 00:20:55.530
Versus electronic locks,
weather locks are key cards,

336
00:20:55.530 --> 00:21:00.700
or they use biometric authentication,
a thumb print or

337
00:21:00.700 --> 00:21:06.360
the last place I worked a few
years ago had a retina scanner.

338
00:21:06.360 --> 00:21:11.650
Now this is another a great example of
something that I looked at as a auditor.

339
00:21:11.650 --> 00:21:16.300
I always scratched my head about was they
spent a lot of money for a retina scanner.

340
00:21:16.300 --> 00:21:20.380
It's a fairly expensive system prone
to errors, unless you buy really,

341
00:21:20.380 --> 00:21:21.820
really good ones.

342
00:21:21.820 --> 00:21:24.752
And they had them installed
in both locations.

343
00:21:24.752 --> 00:21:30.050
And yet I would have to walk up and
shine my little eye into

344
00:21:30.050 --> 00:21:34.360
the retina scanner and it would go clink,
turn green and the door would unlatch.

345
00:21:34.360 --> 00:21:35.890
And then I'd have to reach over and
grab it.

346
00:21:35.890 --> 00:21:40.760
Well, number one, there was nobody there
to ensure that people didn't tailgate.

347
00:21:40.760 --> 00:21:44.460
Tailgate is when I walk in at the same
time somebody else does without

348
00:21:44.460 --> 00:21:46.170
me authenticating.

349
00:21:46.170 --> 00:21:49.310
And number two they had
no visitors log [LAUGH].

350
00:21:49.310 --> 00:21:51.815
So I look for visitors logs,
especially in banks.

351
00:21:51.815 --> 00:21:55.260
It's really critical in banks you need
to know who's in those buildings.

352
00:21:55.260 --> 00:21:59.720
I did an audit for a very large health
care organization a number of years ago

353
00:21:59.720 --> 00:22:04.470
who had just built a new data center
in their new executive offices and

354
00:22:04.470 --> 00:22:06.850
they didn't require anyone to
sign in when they showed up.

355
00:22:06.850 --> 00:22:09.340
And I said well what if there
was a fire or a tornado,

356
00:22:09.340 --> 00:22:12.520
how would EMS services know
who might be in the building.

357
00:22:12.520 --> 00:22:14.590
They don't.
You have a list of employees but

358
00:22:14.590 --> 00:22:16.610
you don't know who else is there visiting.

359
00:22:16.610 --> 00:22:20.960
So today they now have not only
a guard watching that, but

360
00:22:20.960 --> 00:22:23.010
everyone who comes in
the building has to sign in.

361
00:22:23.010 --> 00:22:26.090
>> Yeah, the building I worked
at we had armed guards and

362
00:22:26.090 --> 00:22:27.980
they did have a check in station.

363
00:22:27.980 --> 00:22:29.920
All visitors had to show up in the front.

364
00:22:29.920 --> 00:22:33.680
You couldn't get into any of the other
accesses we had, key cards for

365
00:22:33.680 --> 00:22:34.970
locks on the other accesses.

366
00:22:34.970 --> 00:22:38.950
Had to go into the front, sign in,
when their time was, your time out.

367
00:22:38.950 --> 00:22:40.320
So we all, like you said,

368
00:22:40.320 --> 00:22:43.360
if you don't know they're there,
how can I say that they did anything?

369
00:22:43.360 --> 00:22:45.250
You have no record of it whatsoever.

370
00:22:45.250 --> 00:22:46.710
>> Right, exactly.

371
00:22:46.710 --> 00:22:49.760
So that's some of the stuff, in terms of

372
00:22:52.070 --> 00:22:55.910
Making sure that you're familiar
with physical access controls.

373
00:22:55.910 --> 00:22:58.550
Then the last thing is we wrap
up the session here today.

374
00:22:58.550 --> 00:23:02.510
And I wanna talk a little bit about,
logical access controls.

375
00:23:02.510 --> 00:23:06.550
So the biometrics, you'll have to know
a little bit about biometric controls and

376
00:23:06.550 --> 00:23:07.310
how all that works.

377
00:23:07.310 --> 00:23:13.160
That's generally used for authenticating
against, like we've said a door lock.

378
00:23:13.160 --> 00:23:15.690
It could be against a laptop as well but

379
00:23:15.690 --> 00:23:18.600
you don't see that typically
in most environments.

380
00:23:18.600 --> 00:23:23.110
Now I want to talk about logical
access controls which are things like

381
00:23:23.110 --> 00:23:25.850
active directory user names and passwords.

382
00:23:25.850 --> 00:23:29.800
Logical meaning virtual where
there's really nothing real there.

383
00:23:29.800 --> 00:23:36.250
But, those are the controls
used to authenticate and

384
00:23:36.250 --> 00:23:40.600
allow access to information for
which you're authorized to view.

385
00:23:40.600 --> 00:23:42.780
To protect, again, that confidentiality.

386
00:23:44.040 --> 00:23:50.636
Logical access, controls,
can involve everything from usernames and

387
00:23:50.636 --> 00:23:55.287
passwords Actually sometimes
we use biometrics,

388
00:23:55.287 --> 00:24:01.033
facial recognition,
keyboard dynamics, things like that.

389
00:24:01.033 --> 00:24:03.611
We're moving up the stack, if you will,

390
00:24:03.611 --> 00:24:06.495
from physical controls
to logical controls.

391
00:24:06.495 --> 00:24:11.693
We're talking about Software
implementations, things like that,

392
00:24:11.693 --> 00:24:17.417
that will allow us to put controls in
place to protect access to those assets so

393
00:24:17.417 --> 00:24:20.868
that only the authorized
people can see them.

394
00:24:20.868 --> 00:24:26.394
So that the data can't be messed with,
for lack of a better term,

395
00:24:26.394 --> 00:24:31.216
so that we can maintain
the integrity of the data set, and

396
00:24:31.216 --> 00:24:34.850
so that data is accessible
when we need it.

397
00:24:34.850 --> 00:24:36.850
I think that's about as
far as I wanna go today.

398
00:24:36.850 --> 00:24:40.410
Tomorrow, or in the next episode,
I'm sorry, what we're gonna talk about

399
00:24:40.410 --> 00:24:46.670
are some more network and
internet security protocols

400
00:24:46.670 --> 00:24:50.430
that go hand in hand with the logical
access controls we're talking about.

401
00:24:50.430 --> 00:24:54.080
So logical access controllers
are like usernames and passwords etc.

402
00:24:54.080 --> 00:24:58.790
Next we're going to start as we explore
the open system interconnection model.

403
00:24:58.790 --> 00:25:04.000
We're going to talk some more
about security protocols that

404
00:25:04.000 --> 00:25:10.100

405
00:25:10.100 --> 00:25:13.180
and or cables, copper and fiber, right?

406
00:25:13.180 --> 00:25:14.800
>> That will definitely be a lot of fun.

407
00:25:14.800 --> 00:25:18.270
And if you haven't realized so far,
just starting at the physical layer,

408
00:25:18.270 --> 00:25:21.270
we're gonna talk, like you said,
more about the OSI model.

409
00:25:21.270 --> 00:25:24.420
Just things you can touch,
things you can do to put up a fence.

410
00:25:24.420 --> 00:25:27.710
If you're not thinking of
things like an air conditioner.

411
00:25:27.710 --> 00:25:32.650
Well, if the air conditioner is
pumping AC into my server room, and

00:25:32.650 --> 00:25:35.530
I run over there and I jam a stick in it,

413
00:25:35.530 --> 00:25:37.210
well what's going to

414
00:25:37.210 --> 00:25:39.850
I've effectively given
a denial of service attack by

415
00:25:39.850 --> 00:25:41.220

416
00:25:41.220 --> 00:25:44.180
These are the ways that we've
got to think, and as auditors,

00:25:44.180 --> 00:25:48.330
this is how we're We're helping
the companies that we're auditing, right?

418
00:25:48.330 --> 00:25:49.990
We're thinking about these things for
them.

419
00:25:49.990 --> 00:25:52.900
Maybe they haven't had the level of
training that we're going through right

00:25:56.010 --> 00:25:57.040
How will an attacker come in?

00:26:05.030 --> 00:26:06.210

ou say, I was just taking pictures

00:26:08.628 --> 00:26:11.332
I thought it was a pretty bush,

maybe we'll plant them.

00:26:13.528 --> 00:26:16.700
Things of that nature you just social
engineer your way right out of it and

00:26:16.700 --> 00:26:18.900
they go okay, sorry, well have a good one.

431
00:26:18.900 --> 00:26:20.100
Well there you are, and

00:26:20.100 --> 00:26:22.790

00:26:22.790 --> 00:26:25.940
So it's these things that we

00:26:25.940 --> 00:26:31.010

00:26:31.010 --> 00:26:34.220

00:26:34.220 --> 00:26:35.496
Brian says he has gone in and said,

00:26:38.048 --> 00:26:39.768
Well, it's the only
place we had to put it.

00:26:39.768 --> 00:26:42.810
Well, that's great, but
you have to take account for that.

00:26:42.810 --> 00:26:45.640
You have to be ready in

00:26:45.640 --> 00:26:48.920

00:26:48.920 --> 00:26:51.610

you're going to lose that equipment.

443
00:26:51.610 --> 00:26:53.170
So be prepared for that as well.

444
00:26:53.170 --> 00:26:56.800

00:26:56.800 --> 00:27:00.620

00:27:12.370 --> 00:27:15.060

00:27:15.060 --> 00:27:17.470
And it looks like we've wrapped

00:27:17.470 --> 00:27:18.610

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Brian continue their discussion of protecting IS assets. Here they turn their focus towards logical access controls and biometric devices (hand/fingerprint, facial recognition, iris/retina) and voice recognition. They discuss the Type-1 and Type-2 errors associated with those devices. Finally, they describe external attacks from Malware (viruses, worms, trojans) to DOS/DDOS, Phishing, Ransomware, Drive-By, and Advanced Persistent Threat(APT).

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Brian take a look at testing software and hardware for security weaknesses. They begin by discussing enumeration and host discovery. Then they move on to Vulnerability Assessment(VA) and Penetration Testing as well as the differences between them. Finally they explore the 3 types of Pen tests which include Black-box, Grey-box, and White-box. Also covered are Credentialed vs. Non-Credentialed scans.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Brian take time to introduce you to the Open Systems Interconnect(OSI) 7-layer networking model. The OSI model has been a long used system for standardizing how computer networks should operate which leads to greater interoperability between systems. Here they break down each of the 7 layers and their functions as well as explaining the encapsulation/decapsulation process.

what's really amazing when you think

00:15:35.980 --> 00:15:40.950

257
00:15:40.950 --> 00:15:45.919

about it every day, all day long we're

258
00:15:45.919 --> 00:15:50.694

at files, we're sending e-mail.

259
00:15:50.694 --> 00:15:55.068
And every single one of those
bits of information is being

00:15:55.068 --> 00:15:57.537

261
00:15:57.537 --> 00:16:01.890
So not only do you get the thing
that I mentioned about power and

262
00:16:01.890 --> 00:16:07.130
being able to take a toaster to China and
cook toast in it and it works.

263
00:16:07.130 --> 00:16:09.070
But the same thing is true with this.

264
00:16:09.070 --> 00:16:12.880
I can send a picture to Daniel
on my local network, but

265
00:16:12.880 --> 00:16:15.450
I can also send it to someone in China.

266
00:16:15.450 --> 00:16:19.890
Or South America, and it gets there
almost at the speed of light.

267
00:16:19.890 --> 00:16:23.210
It gets there completely in one piece.

268
00:16:23.210 --> 00:16:27.157
There are verification validation
mechanisms built into this to

269
00:16:27.157 --> 00:16:32.033
ensure that if pieces of data are lost
in transmission they're retransmitted,

270
00:16:32.033 --> 00:16:35.563
etc., we don't need to get
into all the details of that.

271
00:16:35.563 --> 00:16:40.420
But just suffice it there are mechanisms
just like there are mechanisms in

272
00:16:40.420 --> 00:16:45.587
your home where if the voltage begins to
dip a little bit, your meter can pick up

273
00:16:45.587 --> 00:16:51.040
the surge and make sure that you have
enough power to run your washing machine.

274
00:16:51.040 --> 00:16:55.230
Plus the machines are built to
withstand some tolerance of that,

275
00:16:55.230 --> 00:16:59.350
same thing with our network stuff and
it will recover, but I really do.

276
00:16:59.350 --> 00:17:03.380
I think it' absolutely mind boggling,
mind boggling,

277
00:17:03.380 --> 00:17:08.310
that I can sit at a keyboard like this and
talk to my granddaughter

278
00:17:08.310 --> 00:17:12.780
who is now 20,
30 some hours by car away from me.

279
00:17:12.780 --> 00:17:15.540
And we can actually have
a live conversation,

280
00:17:15.540 --> 00:17:19.060
she can see a picture of me,
I can see a picture of her.

281
00:17:19.060 --> 00:17:23.010
And she's growing up in a world today
where kids just assume that that works.

282
00:17:23.010 --> 00:17:24.080
Of course, it does.

283
00:17:24.080 --> 00:17:27.490
They have no concept of
how it actually occurs.

284
00:17:27.490 --> 00:17:33.300
So the purpose of this
presentation is to get

285
00:17:33.300 --> 00:17:38.320
you think at the bit level for the first
time, when you're going in and looking

286
00:17:38.320 --> 00:17:42.420
at a network and you're doing those
network scans, this is what you're doing.

287
00:17:42.420 --> 00:17:46.119
Your sending data down that stack.

288
00:17:46.119 --> 00:17:51.460
Remember I mentioned you can go one
to many, many to one, or one to one.

289
00:17:51.460 --> 00:17:52.900
Any combination of those.

290
00:17:52.900 --> 00:17:55.369
When you're doing network scanning,
you're doing one to many.

291
00:17:56.400 --> 00:18:01.330
When you're doing vulnerability
assessments you're looking often times at

292
00:18:01.330 --> 00:18:03.800
are there problems with this?

293
00:18:03.800 --> 00:18:08.010
One of the things I can do with
an in map scan for instance, is

294
00:18:09.680 --> 00:18:15.170
different operating systems handle
this stack a little bit differently.

295
00:18:15.170 --> 00:18:18.470
There are nuances in that, just like,

296
00:18:18.470 --> 00:18:22.560
power may fluctuate in your home,
but your microwave still works.

297
00:18:22.560 --> 00:18:26.690
Well, different operating systems handle
this flow a little bit differently.

298
00:18:26.690 --> 00:18:31.630
And I can actually identify whether that
is a Linux system, or a Windows system, or

299
00:18:31.630 --> 00:18:36.520
a Mac system, simply by the way
the system responds to probes

300
00:18:36.520 --> 00:18:40.490
around these protocols,
because I now know how they work.

301
00:18:41.770 --> 00:18:47.180
So it's really a fascinating topic
I would encourage all of you to

302
00:18:47.180 --> 00:18:49.220

get very familiar with it.

303
00:18:49.220 --> 00:18:52.712
You will have to know those seven layers.

304
00:18:52.712 --> 00:18:54.670
I guarantee you this is
going to be on the exam.

305
00:18:54.670 --> 00:18:56.030
There's no wink wink about it.

306
00:18:56.030 --> 00:18:56.910
It will be there.

307
00:18:56.910 --> 00:18:57.810
Count on it.

308
00:18:57.810 --> 00:18:59.770
You must know all seven layers,

309
00:18:59.770 --> 00:19:03.830
what you're gonna see are questions where
they mix them up and try to confuse you,

310
00:19:03.830 --> 00:19:08.280
they may say pick the best,
be very careful with this, this is

311
00:19:08.280 --> 00:19:12.230
one of those ones that will trip you up,
because you really need their acronyms,

312
00:19:12.230 --> 00:19:15.060
I saw some of the folks on Twitter
>> The mnemonics?

313
00:19:15.060 --> 00:19:17.480
>> Yeah, the mnemonics,
if one of those works for

00:19:17.480 --> 00:19:20.819
you that's great, I prefer you just
simply know what they all mean.

315
00:19:22.020 --> 00:19:23.310
But if you need to memorize them,

316
00:19:23.310 --> 00:19:26.760
try using a mnemonics of
some kind to memorize them.

317
00:19:26.760 --> 00:19:31.270
But be very familiar with them as you
go out into the audit world because

318
00:19:32.860 --> 00:19:37.920
just like you can have applications
that are not patched properly or

319
00:19:37.920 --> 00:19:40.160
operating systems that
are not patched properly.

320
00:19:40.160 --> 00:19:43.656
You can have problems with
your telecommunications,

321
00:19:43.656 --> 00:19:46.470
where things break down inside this model.

322
00:19:46.470 --> 00:19:50.579
A good example is if your routing
protocols are not configured properly,

323
00:19:50.579 --> 00:19:54.490
you can start having delays in
transmissions because things have to go

324
00:19:54.490 --> 00:19:58.864
a much longer way to their destination
than they would normally if your routing

325
00:19:58.864 --> 00:20:01.010
protocols are configured properly.

326
00:20:02.450 --> 00:20:06.270
That can cause denial
of service situations.

327
00:20:06.270 --> 00:20:09.410
That can cause all kinds
of other problems.

328
00:20:09.410 --> 00:20:13.630
You need to find out whether or
not your encryptions are working properly.

329
00:20:13.630 --> 00:20:17.040
When I do a vulnerability
assessment in web servers, today,

330
00:20:17.040 --> 00:20:20.594
I don't even think HTTP,
I think HTTP should just be outlawed.

331
00:20:20.594 --> 00:20:22.160
>> [LAUGH] Just get rid of it.

332
00:20:22.160 --> 00:20:22.870
>> Simple as that.

333
00:20:22.870 --> 00:20:23.800
Just stop using it.

334
00:20:23.800 --> 00:20:25.389
Everything should be HTTPS,

335
00:20:26.850 --> 00:20:31.470
which is secure HTTP if you didn't
know that already over port 443.

336
00:20:31.470 --> 00:20:35.840
Now, in one of the next episodes I'll
talk a little bit more about the ports

337
00:20:35.840 --> 00:20:40.560
which have to do with, I'm not sure if
I can, let me see if I can do this.

338
00:20:40.560 --> 00:20:41.698
No that's an arrow, sorry.

339
00:20:41.698 --> 00:20:43.600
>> [LAUGH]
>> Wrong tool.

340
00:20:43.600 --> 00:20:47.580
We'll talk more detail about
layer three and layer four.

341
00:20:49.050 --> 00:20:52.150
There's not a whole lot you need to
worry about in layer two anymore.

342
00:20:53.490 --> 00:20:57.860
Most of the types of layer
two attacks have been

343
00:20:57.860 --> 00:20:59.740
fairly well mitigated over the years.

344
00:20:59.740 --> 00:21:04.090
There's a couple things you can still do,
but it doesn't generally net you anything.

345
00:21:04.090 --> 00:21:09.140
Layer three and
four still as you get up in the OSI stack.

346
00:21:09.140 --> 00:21:15.069
The attacks become more sophisticated,
but they can also do a lot more damage,

347
00:21:15.069 --> 00:21:21.178
because if I can reroute ports, or change
routing decisions made in layer three,

348
00:21:21.178 --> 00:21:26.604
I can create denial service attacks,
I can do man in the middle attacks.

349
00:21:26.604 --> 00:21:32.017
I can do all kinds of ugly stuff as we go
up the stack in the application layer,

350
00:21:32.017 --> 00:21:37.120
if I can manipulate that with an attack,
I even have more control.

351
00:21:37.120 --> 00:21:40.922
So I'll talk a little bit
about how ports work and

352
00:21:40.922 --> 00:21:45.980
some of the ways that we can
mitigate tax against those.

353
00:21:45.980 --> 00:21:49.560
But again, going back to the model, I
wanna make sure everybody has a very clear

354
00:21:49.560 --> 00:21:53.630
understanding of how this data and
this time I will draw an arrow.

355
00:21:53.630 --> 00:21:59.230
How this data goes down the stack,

356
00:21:59.230 --> 00:22:02.420
goes across the medium and

357
00:22:02.420 --> 00:22:05.630
goes back up the stack at the other end,
and vice versa.

358
00:22:05.630 --> 00:22:06.985
Let me get a little sea
sick there from this.

359
00:22:06.985 --> 00:22:09.870
>> [LAUGH] And one,
too many martinis over there.

00:22:09.870 --> 00:22:13.610
>> And vice versa I could put a second
arrow at the bottom at the end of each of

361
00:22:13.610 --> 00:22:17.680
those but you get the point is,
that it's a two-way communication street,

362
00:22:17.680 --> 00:22:23.200
there's a constant stream of bits and
bytes back-and-forth in that,

363
00:22:23.200 --> 00:22:26.700
and I think that's probably where I
wanna stop today in this episode.

364
00:22:26.700 --> 00:22:30.560
I know we have a few minutes left but

00:22:34.170 --> 00:22:38.761
>> Sounds like a good place to stop, and

forray of encapsulation and decapsulation,

learn what each one of those layers are,

00:22:51.993 --> 00:22:55.851
And that will help you immensely when

00:22:55.851 --> 00:23:00.183
it really will help you a lot in general

Everybody is working

We'll help you troubleshoot your

So it can be very helpful

And joining us back in the studio

9

thank you for having me back again.

10
00:00:38.370 --> 00:00:43.550
In our previous episode, I introduced
the concept of the 7 layers of the OSI,

11
00:00:43.550 --> 00:00:47.120
or Open Systems Interconnection Model, and

12
00:00:47.120 --> 00:00:50.940
how data flows from one
node to another in terms of

how the encapsulation/de-capsulation
process works.

14
00:00:55.050 --> 00:00:59.600
It's important for the CISA Auditor
to have a good understanding of those

15
00:00:59.600 --> 00:01:05.800
processes and the layers, so that when
troubleshooting begins to occur, that they

16
00:01:05.800 --> 00:01:10.990

and where things might be going wrong.

17
00:01:12.230 --> 00:01:16.470
So, in this episode we're going to

00:01:16.470 --> 00:01:20.390
I told you in the previous episodes I
was gonna take a deep dive today into

19
00:01:20.390 --> 00:01:23.770
both the OSI model and encryption.

20
00:01:23.770 --> 00:01:27.160
And so this is, while this is
episode five, I believe it is,

21
00:01:27.160 --> 00:01:31.580
we're at our second episode
regarding the OSI model.

22
00:01:31.580 --> 00:01:34.870
So if I can just go to my
computer screen for a minute.

23
00:01:34.870 --> 00:01:37.620
I brought back up the seven
layer OSI model that we

24
00:01:37.620 --> 00:01:39.610
talked about in the previous section.

25
00:01:39.610 --> 00:01:42.055
So we got the same picture up,
hopefully it will pull up.

26
00:01:42.055 --> 00:01:46.395
You've watched these in consecutive order,
at least these couple of episodes.

27
00:01:46.395 --> 00:01:48.555
And today, in this episode,

28
00:01:48.555 --> 00:01:51.465
what I wanna talk a little bit
about are what we call ports.

29
00:01:52.995 --> 00:01:57.905
In this encapsulation de-capsulation
process, there's a place in here

30
00:01:57.905 --> 00:02:02.195
that takes place right in
this area right in here.

31
00:02:02.195 --> 00:02:04.016
You can see my mouse moving around it.

32
00:02:04.016 --> 00:02:08.363
Where, the destination,
the origination and

33
00:02:08.363 --> 00:02:13.037
destination addresses,
are added into the mix and

34
00:02:13.037 --> 00:02:17.831
it begins to tell the systems
where to send the data.

35
00:02:17.831 --> 00:02:22.598
Doesn't tell it what it's supposed to do
with it, it just says here's where you've

36
00:02:22.598 --> 00:02:25.905
got to go with it and
it takes this little part right in here,

37
00:02:25.905 --> 00:02:29.570
the data packet we talked about,
and it does its thing with that.

38
00:02:29.570 --> 00:02:35.799
What we are going to talk about in this
session is about what we call common ports

39
00:02:37.180 --> 00:02:43.520
and those occur at this layer right
here called the transport layer.

40
00:02:44.670 --> 00:02:48.450
So, let's pretend for a minute.

41
00:02:48.450 --> 00:02:52.330
I haven't talked about IP addresses,
but I will in a little bit.

42
00:02:52.330 --> 00:02:58.000
The IP address of the origination
machine is, let's just call it, dot ten.

43
00:02:58.000 --> 00:02:58.620
And it says,

44
00:02:58.620 --> 00:03:03.700
I want to send this to a machine with
the address that ends in dot 12.

45
00:03:03.700 --> 00:03:08.660
Well, it's one thing to send it to that
machine at the dot 12 address, but

46
00:03:08.660 --> 00:03:11.040
it has to also know, on the other end,

47
00:03:11.040 --> 00:03:15.670
what specific port to
deliver the information to.

48
00:03:15.670 --> 00:03:19.840
And the reason we do that is because
there may be multiple services or

49
00:03:19.840 --> 00:03:22.910
applications running on that end machine.

50
00:03:22.910 --> 00:03:27.590
And each service and each application,
the way the operating system

51
00:03:27.590 --> 00:03:32.440
keeps them separate from each other is
it assigns those to what we call ports.

52
00:03:32.440 --> 00:03:37.630
You can think of ports as just
simply specific locations in Ram.

53
00:03:39.000 --> 00:03:43.770
Something like that in terms of,
let's say you

54
00:03:43.770 --> 00:03:48.950
have an address of dot 11, and
that address, if it were a house,

55
00:03:48.950 --> 00:03:52.845
was a multi-tenant building, and
it had three apartments in it.

56
00:03:52.845 --> 00:03:55.505
You'd have to know whether you
got the right address, but

57
00:03:55.505 --> 00:03:59.500
you'd need to know whether to send it to
apartment A, apartment B, or apartment C.

58
00:03:59.500 --> 00:04:02.229
In this place we talk about common ports.

59
00:04:03.650 --> 00:04:06.520
So not only is it important for
you to understand the OSI model,

60
00:04:06.520 --> 00:04:09.600
it's important that you understand these
common ports because these are what

61
00:04:09.600 --> 00:04:12.840
most of the applications, and
they're called common ports for

62
00:04:12.840 --> 00:04:17.190
that very reason, because the common
applications that we use on a day to day

63
00:04:17.190 --> 00:04:22.900
basis in most IT shops will
run on most of these ports.

64
00:04:22.900 --> 00:04:25.380
So I'm gonna talk a little
bit about each of these.

65
00:04:25.380 --> 00:04:30.770
Port 20 and 21 are typically
associated with a service called FTP.

66
00:04:31.870 --> 00:04:34.300
Or file transfer protocol.

67
00:04:34.300 --> 00:04:35.880
FTP uses two ports.

68
00:04:35.880 --> 00:04:39.500
It's one of the more unusual applications.

69
00:04:39.500 --> 00:04:42.240
But it's also one of
the oldest applications.

70
00:04:42.240 --> 00:04:46.330
FTP was built and
developed way back in the very early 80's,

71
00:04:46.330 --> 00:04:48.600
late 70's even, I think.

72
00:04:48.600 --> 00:04:52.360
So it uses one of those two ports for
communication for

73
00:04:52.360 --> 00:04:56.170
you to send commands back and
forth between the two machines and

74
00:04:56.170 --> 00:05:00.010
it uses port 21 to actually
do the data transfer.

75
00:05:00.010 --> 00:05:04.390
Okay, and so that way I can actually
be sending communications while

76
00:05:04.390 --> 00:05:08.080
I'm sending or receiving data, and that's
what it was designed to do in the day,

77
00:05:08.080 --> 00:05:11.950
because back then,
bandwidth was extremely precious.

78
00:05:11.950 --> 00:05:16.060
We were moving files across cables
that would only let us do, perhaps,

79
00:05:16.060 --> 00:05:20.468
two megabit a second, versus today,
where we're going multi-gigabit.

80
00:05:20.468 --> 00:05:24.310
So it was important to be able to not
have to wait until your transmission

81
00:05:24.310 --> 00:05:27.360
is completed before you
can send another command.

82
00:05:27.360 --> 00:05:30.120
Think of it as, in the old days
when we were on token ring,

83
00:05:30.120 --> 00:05:32.850
it was kind of like talking
to the Martian rover.

84
00:05:32.850 --> 00:05:36.790
Where you had to send a signal, you had to
wait for four days for it to get there.

85
00:05:36.790 --> 00:05:41.140
And then it would execute and then you had

00:19:50.774 --> 00:19:53.800

00:19:53.800 --> 00:19:58.750
Now, the results may take you
